threats: Sites from which this species is known are facing a decline in the quality and extent of forest habitat due to a wide range of anthropogenic activities including conversion of forest lands into plantations, increased use of herbicides and pesticides, introduction of invasive alien species, forest fires, increase in tourism related activities, expansion of agriculture and human settlements, and small to large-scale logging for subsistence purposes and to clear areas for road-laying. Many of these activities are ongoing even in reserves. In Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary selective logging and reed collection in the lower reaches of the sanctuary have been observed. In Perambikulam Wildlife Sanctuary rampant grazing, forest fires set by locals for clearing land for grazing, fuelwood collection, and the spread of invasive species have all been reported. Overgrazing by cattle and firewood collection are also ongoing in Kalakkad-Mundanthurai and Periyar Tiger Reserves. Tourism, railroad traffic and the dumping of toxic waste all threaten habitats in Bhagwan Mahaveer Wildlife Sanctuary. In Sri Lanka, slash and burn for chena cultivation is a threat to this species.
population: Although no quantitative information is available on the population, this lizard seems to be common in parts of its range. There is no evidence of widespread declines, however no research has been conducted to investigate population trends of this skink.
range: This skink is endemic to India and Sri Lanka. In India it is restricted to peninsular India, where it has been reported from eight sites in southern Western Ghats of Karnataka, Kerala and Tamil Nadu (Smith 1935). It also occurs in some locations in the Eastern Ghats of Orissa and Andhra Pradesh. Records from Bhagwan Mahaveer Wildlife Sanctuary (Goa), Parambikulam Wildlife Sanctuary in Palakkad District and Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary in Kollam District (Kerala) need confirmation. In Sri Lanka, it has been reported from the northern portion of the country. It occurs at elevations ranging from sea level to 1,500 m asl.
useTrade: The species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures. Eutropis beddomii is known from many sites that are in the existing protected area network including Bhagwan Mahaveer Wildlife Sanctuary (Goa), Kalakkad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve, Tirunelveli District (Tamil Nadu), Melghat Tiger Reserve, Amaravati District (Maharashtra), Parambikulam Wildlife Sanctuary, Palakkad District (Kerala), Periyar Tiger Reserve, Idukki and Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary, Kollam District (Kerala), and Koundinya Wildlife Sanctuary, Chittoor District (Andhra Pradesh). In Sri Lanka, it has been recorded in Wilpattu National Park. Some loss or degradation of forest habitat is however ongoing in most or all of these reserves. This species could be more widespread than thought, and surveys are needed to verify this.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that this species has a tiny area of occupancy and is subject to ongoing declines in the extent and quality of its habitat, although the population on monitored islands appears to be broadly stable. Surviving subpopulations appear to be remnants following a widespread historical decline, and while this has been attributed to the action of multiple invasive species these do nor appear to be currently impacting monitored subpopulations, and the largest subpopulations are on islands subject to ongoing conservation management. The population as a whole is not presently thought to be severely fragmented, as most remnant subpopulations are apparently viable, but a number of subpopulations appear either to have become recently extinct or survive at densities too low to detect. The global population is not thought to exceed 10,000 individuals. As such the species is close to qualifying for a threatened listing applying criteria B1, B2 and C2ai.
habitat:
This small diurnal skink mostly inhabits coastal rocky regions, often associated with boulder piles and structured bedrock, with fissures, cavities and tussocks of the native grass Zoysia tenuifolia. Animals are mostly active at the hottest times of day when there is little or no cloud cover and quickly take refuge within crevices or under rocks or other debris when disturbed. Their grey to brown dorsal colour sometimes tinged with green or blue (Cole 2009) makes them well-camouflaged against their rocky habitat. They feed mostly upon small invertebrates, particularly small moths, cockroaches, flies and crickets (Bullock 1986, N. Cole pers. obs.). They are often found along the shore within the splash zone and close to rock pools, and have been observed to predate small crustaceans and fish (Cole 2009). In the absence of competitors and predators the skink can be found more inland, usually in rocky and sparsely vegetated habitats, although they will occasionally climb the branches of small native shrubs Pemphis acidula, Suriana maritima and Tournefortia arguta. It has been noted that the Bojer’s Skink, whose microhabitat use overlaps with the Bouton’s Skink (Bullock 1986), is a potential competitor and restricts Bouton’s Skink to the coastal fringes of islets that they both occupy (Vinson and Vinson 1969, Bullock 1986, Jones 1993). The ability of the Bojer’s Skink to exclude Bouton’s Skink from all but coastal rocky habitats has been observed on islets where the Bojer’s Skink has been re-introduced (N. Cole unpublished data), but it does not completely exclude Bouton's Skink.

It has an elongated body and slender legs has a snout to vent length up to 48.1 mm with a total body length up to 103.5 mm (N. Cole unpublished data). It lays two eggs (Vinson and Vinson 1969, Cole 2009) with hatchlings seen from December to May (N. Cole pers. obs.).
threats: Introduced predators, such as rats Rattus norvegicus and R. rattus, mongooses (Herpestes javanicus), cats (Felis catus), musk shrews (Suncus murinus), myna birds (Acridotheres tristis), red-whiskered bulbuls (Pycnonotus jocosus), agamid lizards (Calotes versicolor), common house geckos (Hemidactylus frenatus) and Indian Wolf Snakes (Lycodon aulicus), have either been observed predating upon Bouton’s Skinks or have been implicated in their historical decline (Vinson and Vinson 1969, Jones 1993, Honsterette and Probst 1999, Cole 2005, N. Cole pers. obs.). Some of the subpopulations continue to persist in the presence of these predators and so the actual cause of historical decline is unknown. Littering and marine debris have led to skinks becoming entrapped, and dumping of hot oil and charcoal from barbecues onto coastal rocks have led to Bouton’s Skink mortality (N. Cole pers. obs.), although the extent of these impacts is unknown. Given the restricted range of the skink and presence along coastal fringes, coastal development causing the destruction of rocky habitats and the influx of invasive predators, inappropriate disposal of waste materials, littering and marine debris, sea level rise, storm surges and cyclones represent threats to the species.
population: Monitoring of the Mauritian subpopulations on a few of the islets and periodic visits to the mainland sites indicate that overall they are stable (N. Cole unpublished data). Reintroductions of the Bojer’s Skink from Ilot Vacoas to Ile aux Fouquets and Ile de la Passe has led to predicted declines in the abundance of Bouton’s Skinks, but they persist in the presence of Bojer’s Skinks, as they do on other islets they co-occupy (Cole et al. 2009, 2013, N. Cole unpublished data). The average density of Bouton’s Skinks on Gunner’s Quoin from annual distance sampling surveys along 17 line transects within their restricted range, between 2006 and 2019, is 222.8 (95% confidence intervals: 182.6–271.8) individuals per hectare (N. Cole unpublished data). Gunner’s Quoin maintains the largest population size of approximately 2,674 (2,192–3,262) individuals, followed by Round Island that supports approximately 796 (42–1,550) individuals (Cole et al. 2018, N. Cole unpublished data). All other subpopulations sizes number in the few hundreds or less and the global adult population size is considered to be less than ten thousand.
range:
This species is endemic to Mauritius and Réunion (Horner 2007). In Mauritius, the skink is found in four tiny and isolated coastal subpopulations in the North (Cap Malheureux) and East (Pointe Lafayette, Long Beach and Palmar) on the main island (Vinson and Vinson 1969, Jones 1993, Cole 2009, N. Cole unpublished data). It was recorded sometime around the 1830s among inland rock piles within the Flacq District to the East of Mauritius (Desjardin 1831), but it has never since been rediscovered here (Vinson and Vinson, 1969, Jones 1993, N. Cole pers. obs.). The species was also recorded in the late 1860s at Tamarind Bay in the island's southwest and were described as being abundant around much of the coastline of Mauritius (Pike 1873), which is not the case today. Residents of Mahebourg in the southeast describe seeing small and fast lizards that ran across the ground and rocks on the coastline of Ile aux Aigrettes (0.26 km2) until the 1950s–60s (M. Goder pers. comm. in Cole et al. 2009). This description is consistent with a Cryptoblepharus species, but could have referred to Bojer’s skink Gongylomorphus bojeri (although this species is not known from Isle aux Aigrettes) (Cole et al. 2009).

The skink is also restricted to the coastal areas on five northern islets (Round Island - 2.19 km2, Flat Island - 2.53 km2, Gabriel Island - 0.42 km2, Gunner’s Quoin - 0.70 km2 and Ilot Bernache - 5.28 km2) and three south-eastern islets (Ile aux Fouquets - 0.03 km2, Ilot Vacoas - 0.01 km2 and Ile de la Passe - 0.02 km2) in Mauritius (Vinson and Vinson 1969, Tonge 1990, Jones 1993, Cole 2009, N. Cole pers. obs.). Whilst all the islets and much of the coastline of Mauritius have been searched specifically for Bouton’s Skinks, the Palmar population described by Vinson and Vinson (1969) was not rediscovered until 2018, despite multiple searches of the 0.002 km2 rock from 2002 (N. Cole unpublished data). Similarly, the Long Beach population was not known, until its discovery in 2019 (N. Cole unpublished data; as such it is possible that additional undetected subpopulations survive.

In Réunion a subpopulation was discovered in 1999, restricted to a cliff face in the South of the island close to Petite Ile (Maillard 1863, Honsterette and Probst 1999). Few animals were seen at the time and only one collected (Honsterette and Probst 1999). This represented the only report of this species on Réunion since the 1860s, and the species has not since been detected on Réunion have not since been detected despite intensive surveys in 2009 (Sanchez et al. 2010), 2010 (M. Sanchez and J.M. Probst unpublished data) and 2013 (M. Sanchez, J.M. Probst, S. Caceres, and C. Raxworthy unpublished data). Similarly, the population on Ile aux Fous (0.002 km2) in Mauritius, has not been detected since it was discovered in 1987 (Jones 1993), despite three visits to the small rock between 2006 and 2010 (N. Cole unpublished data). As neither the Réunion nor the Ile aux Fous populations can be confirmed to exist, they are not included as extant subpopulations in this assessment and the Réunion subpopulation is currently considered extinct, although the recent discoveries of long-overlooked subpopulations on small Mauritian islands despite repeated surveys, it remains possible the species survives on both Réunion and Ile aux Fous but at densities too low to reliably detect.

The extent of occurrence for the species is 741 km2, and the area of occupancy derived from 2x2 km2 grid cells is 56 km2 (GeoCat). The actual area occupied is considerably smaller, with the combined range of all the subpopulations on the main island and the offshore islets of Mauritius being 0.42 km2 (N. Cole unpublished data). The species' elevational range is from 0 to 43 m.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: Round Island and Gunner’s Quoin are Closed Nature Reserves and Ilot Vacoas is a Closed National Park, such that access if prohibited without permission from the Ministry of Agro-Industry and Food Security. Monitoring and restoration work is ongoing on these islets and, as such, the Bouton’s skink populations on these islets are protected. Conservation work is also being undertaken on Gabriel Island, Ile aux Fouquets and Ile de la Passe where litter is frequently removed and are periodically checked to detect and remove invasive species. The Mauritian Wildlife Foundation has been running educational workshops and site visits with government departments, tour operators, private boat owners and fishermen that use the southeast and northern islets to work towards reducing associated threats, which will benefit the Bouton’s skink populations.

rationale: Poecilia sulphuraria is endemic to Banos del Azufre and La Gloria springs, two hydrogen-sulfide rich spring systems in the Pichucalco River drainage in Tabasco and Chiapas, Mexico. Banos del Azufre and La Gloria contain 17.7 km2 and 2.2 km2 of suitable habitat, respectively. Estimated population densities and an inferred effective population size suggest that this species is abundant where it occurs. Populations are not severely fragmented. However, several localized stressors at Banos del Azufre have resulted in or are expected to result in a decline in the area, extent, and quality of available habitat. The La Gloria subpopulation is likely stable, given it is not impacted by any known major threats. With an estimated Extent of Occurrence (EOO) and Area of Occupancy (AOO) between 28-50 km2, two locations, and major localized threats that have likely caused declines in suitable habitat quality, P. sulphuraria is listed as Endangered.
habitat:
This species is only found in hydrogen sulfide rich outflows of the Banos del Azufre, and does not occur in adjacent areas that are not characterized by a high concentration of hydrogen sulfide (Greenway et al. 2014, Tobler et al. 2008). At high sulfide concentrations, P. sulphuraria is the only species present; At lower concentrations, it co-occurs with Gambusia eurystoma (Tobler and Plath 2009).

Enlarged lips, head, and gills allow this species to tolerate elevated levels of hydrogen sulfide (Tobler et al. 2008, Culumber et al. 2016). Fecundity is markedly reduced (2.83 ± 0.93) and juveniles are larger when compared to its non-sulphidic congener P. mexicana (Riesch et al. 2010, 2014), which represents a life-history trade-off that may have implications for population resiliency to major environmental perturbations. A maximum length of 5.0 cm is reported (Miller et al. 2005, Bennett and Conway 2010).
threats: Poecilia sulphuraria is threatened by several localized stressors at Banos del Azufre. The nearby hotel complex currently diverts untreated wastewater immediately upstream of the Banos del Azufre subpopulation (Culumber et al. 2016). Many of the springheads have been converted into bathing pools and are used for recreational purposes (Tobler et al. 2008, Tobler and Plath 2009). Use of adjacent land in cattle grazing has significantly altered the riparian buffer zone and spring outflow (Tobler and Plath 2009, Culumber et al. 2016). Agricultural runoff from surrounding sugar cane and palm oil plantations may pose additional threats (Culumber et al. 2016, Brown et al. 2017). There are currently no known major threats to the La Gloria subpopulation (Tobler and Plath 2009).
population:
The population densities of P. sulphuraria within the Banos del Azufre and La Gloria subpopulations are both relatively high (Culumber et al. 2016, Brown et al. 2017). At Banos del Azufre, adult population density averaged 6.8 ± 10.4 individuals/m2 (Culumber et al. 2016). Inferred effective population sizes at Banos del Azufre and La Gloria are approximately 100000 and 25000 individuals, respectively (Brown et al. 2017).

Population trend has been relatively stable historically (Brown et al. 2017). Current population trend is unknown but decline is likely, based on a reduction in the area, extent, and quality of suitable habitat (Tobler and Plath 2009, Culumber et al. 2016, Tobler et al. 2018).

Populations are not considered severely fragmented, given the relatively large effective population sizes, limited evidence of inbreeding, and high genetic diversity (Brown et al. 2017). Annual migration is estimated at 1.41 individuals from La Gloria to Banos del Azufre (Brown et al. 2017).
range:
Poecilia sulphuraria is endemic to Banos del Azufre and La Gloria, two hydrogen-sulfide rich spring systems in the Pichucalco River drainage in Tabasco and Chiapas, Mexico (Tobler and Plath 2009, Gomez-Gonzalez et al. 2015, Velazquez-Velazquez et al. 2016, Brown et al. 2017). This species has not been documented outside of sulphur-rich habitat, despite extensive sampling (Tobler et al. 2008, Greenway et al. 2014). Localized threats are expected to impact the entire subpopulation of P. sulphuraria at Banos del Azufre, whereas the La Gloria subpopulation receives only minor impacts from agricultural practices (Tobler and Plath 2009). Therefore, the number of locations is defined as two.

Banos del Azufre contains approximately 17.7 km2 of suitable habitat, whereas the La Gloria subpopulation is restricted to approximately 2.2 km2 of suitable habitat (Brown et al. 2017, Tobler et al. 2018). Based on these values, Extent of Occurrence (EOO) and Area of Occupancy (AOO) are estimated to be between 28-50 km2.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
Although this species is federally protected in Mexico under the Mexican Official Norm (SEMARNAT 2010), there are currently no species-specific conservation actions directed towards P. sulphuraria. Conservation recommendations include the establishment of proper wastewater treatment, restoration of the natural riparian buffer zone to mitigate the impacts of cattle grazing, and mitigation of recreational pollution resulting from springhead use (Tobler and Plath 2009, Culumber et al. 2016). Maintenance of natural flow regimes with preference towards the habitat selectivity of G. eurystoma (a co-occurring endemic in Bano del Azufres) is suggested as an ideal conservation action that is also likely to benefit P. sulphuraria (Culumber et al. 2016).

The American Fisheries Society’s Endangered Species Committee recognizes P. sulphuraria as threatened with a declining population trend (Jelks et al. 2008). This species does not occur in any protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2018).

rationale: The species is presently known only from a very short stretch (c.2 km long) of a branch  of the upper Nam Phao, a tributary of the Nam Theun in the Mekong drainage in Lao PDR. It inhabits very fast water with waterfalls and large rocks and it feeds in grazing algae and invertebrates at the surface of rocks; sedimentation eliminates its source of food and habitat. It might have a greater range but the area could not yet be surveyed. The only known stretch is along a road  going to the border with Viet Nam, impacted by road maintenance and by wastes from the shops and other border businesses along the road. The other stretches of the Nam Phao are filled with sediments and have no suitable habitat. The river also receives domestic wastes from Laksao and pollution from a gold mine. Because of its very restricted EOO and AOO, and the quantity and  variety of threats this species is assessed as Critically Endangered.  Surveys are needed to confirm the species distribution, and it should be reassessed if further data show that the species has a wider distribution.
habitat: Inhabits a stretch of the stream with waterfalls and large rock bottom. Grazes algae on rocks.
threats: The species is presently known only from a very short stretch of a branch of the upper Nam Phao, about 2 km long. This stretch is along the road leading to the border, which is now crowded by shops and other businesses, and domestic waste enters into the stream. Adjacent streams could not yet be surveyed. Below this point, the stream joins with the Nam Phao which is totally filled with sediments resulting from the construction of a small hydropower reservoir. The recent maintenance of the road going to Vietnam, along the river, also resulted in huge quantities of material being pushed into the river. The river is filled with sediment almost until its confluence with the Nam Theun. In addition the lower Nam Phao receives wastes from Laksao and pollution from a gold mine on one of its tributaries. As the species grazes algae on the rocks, once the rocks are covered by sediment the food disappears.
population: No information available.
range: The species is known only from a short section (c.2 km long) of a small tributary of the upper Nam Phao, a tributary of the Nam Theun, in the Mekong drainage in Lao PDR (Bolikamsai Province), almost on the border with Viet Nam. It might be present elsewhere in adjacent streams, but survey has not yet been possible.
useTrade: Part of subsistence fisheries.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place. Surveys are needed to ascertain the species' exact distribution.

rationale: Atherinella crystallina is known to occur along the Pacific slope, from Rio Fuerte basin southward into Rio de Las Mancuernas, just south of the Rio Grande de Santiago, within the states of Jalisco, Nayarit, Sinaloa and Sonora, found across rivers and estuaries, this species ranges in elevation above 1000 m above sea level. Atherinella crystallina is a federally protected species by the Mexican Official Norm NOM-059, and occurs within multiple protected areas within its range. The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Atherinella crystallina is known to occupy freshwater rocky streams and pools to lowland flood-plains, brackish estuaries, and saltwater lagoons, of depths of one point three metres (Miller, et al. 2005). Adults of this species have a maximum known size of 81 mm (SL) and have been observed breeding in late June, suggesting a long spawning season (Miller, et al., 2005).
threats: Atherinella crystalline is potentially threatened in parts of its range by habitat loss and degradation caused by water pollution, invasive species and over-extraction of water resources.
population: The species is abundant and widespread across its range.
range: Atherinella crystallina is known to occur along the Pacific slope, from Rio Fuerte basin southward into Rio de Las Mancuernas, just south of the Rio Grande de Santiago, within the states of Jalisco, Nayarit, Sinaloa and Sonora (Miller, et al., 2005). Found across rivers and estuaries, this species ranges in elevation above 1000 m above sea level in Rio Verde in Jalisco (Miller, et al., 2005) and is also found within Rio Acaponeta and Rio San Pedro Mezquital in Nayarit (González-Díaz, et  al., 2015)
useTrade: Atherinella crystallina is possibly fished locally.
conservationActions: Atherinella crystallina is a federally protected species protected by Mexican Official Norm NOM-059 (NOM-059, 2010) and also occurs within multiple protected areas along the pacific Mexican coast, for example the La Tovara Ramsar Site (Ramsar Secretariat, La Tovara, Site. No.1776, 2008).

rationale: This widely distributed species is common and abundant where it occurs in estuaries and lagoons. There are no known major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal, amphidromous species inhabits estuaries and lagoons over sand or mud bottoms (Randall and Vergara 1978, Roux 1990,1986). It feeds on fish, shrimps, molluscs, zooplankton, polychaetes and detritus (Diouf 1996). Juveniles commonly found in tidal streams, mangroves and shallow estuarine habitats in southeastern Brazil (Sazima 2002). It forages during the daytime in small groups, hovering close to the bottom and either picks prey off the substrate or digs into it sifting the mouthed sediment through its opercular openings. Its conspicuous black tip on dorsal fin is mimicked by juvenile guianan snooks, Centropomus mexicanus, an example of aggressive mimicry (Sazima 2002). It can be found in mixed groups with C. mexicanus and with E. argenteus (Sazima 2002). It spawns in the sea with gonadal maturation occurring in mangroves (Chaves and Bouchereau 2000). Its maximum size is 18 cm SL (McEachran and Fechhelm 2005).
threats: There are no known major threats. Localized alteration of beach ecosystems may have a negative affect on subpopulations of this species and may be impacted by pollution due to artisanal and commercial fisheries that deposit a variety of plastic marine debris, some of which can be easily ingested by fish (Ramos et al. 2012).
population: This species is highly abundant in many parts of its range. It was the dominant mojarra recorded in a study conducted in a northern Brazilian estuary (Teixeira and Helmer 1997). It was also dominant in seagrass beds of Laguna Madre, the largest coastal lagoon in Mexico (Raz-Guzman and Huidobro 2002). In a study conducted in the Pueblo Viejo Lagoon, northern Veracruz (western Gulf of Mexico), it was one of the top twenty most abundant species recorded (Castillo-Rivera 2013). In a study conducted in the Bocas de Dzilam lagoon (southeastern Mexico) between May 2003-March 2004, this species was not abundant; 0.02 relative abundance (%N) and 0.001 biomass (%W) (Arceo-Carranza and Vega-Cendejas 2009). It is a representative species of the fish assemblage in the Coloradas Basin, Rio Lagartos Lagoon, Yucatan Peninsula (Vega-Cendejas and de Santillana 2004). It has been reported as one if the most common species in the Isla de Sacrificios lagoon, Veracruz, Mexico (Okolodkov et al. 2007) as well as abundant at the mouth of the Soto la Marina river system where it enters the Gulf of Mexico (de Leon et al. 2005). It is a numerically dominant species in the highly saline mangrove system of Sine Saloum in Senegal, accounting for one-third of all fishes recorded (Vidy 2000).
range: This species is distributed across the Atlantic Ocean. In the eastern Atlantic it is known along West Africa from  Mauritania to Angola, including the Cape Verde Islands and Sao Tome and Principe Islands. In the western Atlantic it is known from northeastern Florida south along the USA, the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from northwestern Cuba, the Florida Keys, Apalachicola Bay (Florida) west along the Gulf coast and along Mexico to the northern Yucatan Peninsula, throughout the Caribbean Sea, and along South America to Rio de la Plata, Uruguay (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Its depth range is zero to 25 m (Iwatsuki ECA FAO Guide in prep).
useTrade: Eucinostomus melanopterus is exploited by the small-scale fishery inside the Sine Saloum in Senegal (Vidy 2000). It is marketed fresh, but is not highly esteemed (Randall and Vergara 1978). In Mexico's Laguna Madre, this species is captured at small sizes in the lagoons where they are are marketed only locally and are commonly used as bait (Raz-Guzman and Huidobro 2002). It is collected with beach seines, set nets, handlines and bottom trawls (Schneider 1990). It is of minor commercial importance to the fisheries industry in the Gulf of Mexico.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This widely distributed species is abundant where it occurs in estuaries, mangroves and lagoons. It is commonly utilized by fisheries in some parts of its range and other potential threats include pollution from commercial and artisanal fisheries and habitat degradation due to coastal development, but there is no evidence to suggest that this poses a major threat. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal, euryhaline species occurs in shallow water over soft bottoms in estuaries, mangroves and lagoons, and tolerates freshwater (Thomerson and Greenfield 1975, Cervigón et al. 1992, Rocha and Schiavetti 2007). In an area of mangrove oyster restoration, the occurrence of this species was found to positively correlate with water transparency (de Freitas et al. 2006). Juveniles have been collected during freshwater surveys off Belize (Thomerson and Greenfield 1975). It feeds on polychaetes, copepods, barnacles and insects (Teixeira and Helmer 1997). During sampling in the Almada River, Brazil, this species did not exhibit any seasonal trends in abundance (Rocha and Schiavetti 2007). Its maximum size is 50 cm FL (García-Arteaga et al. 1997). In an effort to improve and develop techniques for experimental-scale mass production of E. brasilianus in Cuba, Alvarez-Lajonchere et al. (1996) recorded the fecundity of spawned female specimens to be 1,395 +/- 249 eggs/g body weight (range = 367-2,167 egg/g).
threats: This species is highly targeted as a food fish. However, as it is also being bred in captivity this is not considered to be a major threat. Also, due to its dependence on freshwater, it is susceptible to alteration of freshwater quality and flow. It may also be susceptible to pollution due to artisanal and commercial fisheries that deposit a variety of plastic marine debris, some of which can be easily ingested by fish. Ingested plastic marine debris can result in intestinal damage and can transfer persistent organic pollutants to the fish (Ramos et al. 2012).
population: This species is very abundant in much of its range. It is one of the most abundant fishes in the coastal lagoons of Cuba (Sanson et al. 1978). It was the third most abundant fish recorded during flood tide in areas of mangrove oyster (Crassostrea rhizophorae) reef restoration in Fortim, Ceará, Brazil (de Freitas et al. 2006). It was found in higher densities in the oligohaline upper estuaries of the Guaraguaçu River (Brazil) (Contente et al. 2011) and it is among the top five fished species in the São Francisco River (Soares et al. 2007). It was also dominant in the middle estuary of Sao Francisco, which is a transitional environment associated with harsh environmental conditions (Neves et al. 2010).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic in the Gulf of Mexico from Tuxpan, Mexico to northwestern Cuba, in the Caribbean from Cuba, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Curacao, along the Central American coast from Mexico to Panama (San Blas), and off Brazil from Amapa to Santa Catarina (Castro-Aguirre 1978, Cervigón et al. 1992, Castro-Aguirre et al. 1999, Floeter et al. 2003, Vaslet et al. 2008, Felder et al. 2009, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. There is a need for research on the effects of freshwater stream modification and system degradation on this species.

rationale: Mimagoniates lateralis ocorre nos riachos e alagadiços de águas ácidas e pretas, nas regiões litorâneas de Mata Atlântica e restinga entre o sul do estado de São Paulo (Itanhaém) e o norte do estado de Santa Catarina (Araquari). É uma espécie abundante, porém pouco frequente, típica de um biótopo específico, dependente da vegetação ripária para manter subpopulações viáveis. A extensão de ocorrência (EOO) da espécie, calculada pelo método do mínimo polígono convexo, é de cerca de 17.000 km2. Seus ambientes preferenciais são bastante sensíveis à degradação ambiental e altamente impactados e fragmentados pela expansão imobiliária litorânea. Desse modo, M. lateralis foi categorizada como Quase Ameaçada (NT).
habitat:
Pouco se sabe sobre a ecologia dessa espécie, mas a orientação superior de sua boca e informações obtidas de outras espécies do gênero, bem como de alguns poucos conteúdos estomacais analisados, sugerem que a alimentação seja principalmente baseada em insetos terrestres. Otto (2006) analisando 468 indivíduos de M. lateralis verificou que os estômagos vazios representaram 1,28%, correspondente a 6 indivíduos. O item com maior representatividade foi Arthropoda (artrópodes não identificados), representando cerca de 50% do total de itens ingeridos, seguido de formas adultas de Diptera e Coleoptera. Essa autora detectou a presença do item Decapoda, que pode indicar um possível forrageamento próximo ao fundo, o que não é usual para outras espécies do gênero Mimagoniates. Ocorre principalmente em córregos e alagadiços florestais das planícies litorâneas, de águas avermelhadas e de fluxo lento. Parâmetros físico-químicos coletados em riachos habitados pela espécie na ilha de São Francisco, no município de São Francisco do Sul (SC), demonstram que ocupa habitat bastante ácidos, com pH oscilando entre 3,9 e 5,8, onde o oxigênio dissolvido varia desde 12 até 100% e a amplitude térmica aquática registrou a mínima em 12,8°C no inverno e máxima de 28,1°C no verão. Nesses ambientes, esta espécie ocorre em sintopia com Scleromystax macropterus, Rachoviscus crassiceps, Spintherobolus ankoseion e, frequentemente, ainda com Rivulus luelingi e Rivulus haraldsioli, espécies - em sua maioria - também ameaçadas. Nesses habitat, M. lateralis é abundante, frequentemente apresentando alta densidade (Duboc e Menezes 2008). Menezes e Weitzman (2009) informam que dados de campo indicam que M. lateralis é totalmente confinada a locais de águas escuras e ácidas. Alguns lotes foram coletados em um córrego de águas escuras nas proximidades de Cananeia (SP), que corre em um trecho perturbado da Mata Atlântica. O córrego apresenta largura média de 1,7 m e 0,4 m de profundidade, e os peixes ocorrem em áreas tanto encobertas pelas sombras, como em áreas abertas, sobre fundo arenoso-rochoso coberto por algas filamentosas e folhas mortas.

Mimagoniates lateralis é a menor espécie do gênero, cujos indivíduos alcançam no máximo cerca de 4 cm de comprimento quando adultos (Duboc e Menezes 2008). Como as demais espécies de Mimagoniates, possui dimorfismo sexual acentuado, os machos possuindo na base da cauda uma estrutura especializada em forma de pequena bomba, sustentada por modificações de raios centrais da nadadeira caudal e recoberta por escamas também modificadas. Este órgão, ausente nas fêmeas, quando acionado por movimentação do pedúnculo caudal, ajuda a espalhar o feromônio produzido pelo tecido glandular que fica concentrado em volta de sua abertura, por ocasião do acasalamento. Os machos também possuem cores mais brilhantes que as fêmeas, predominando a coloração acastanhada característica destes peixes (Duboc e Menezes 2008, Oyakawa et al. 2009). Como acontece com as outras espécies de glandulocaudíneos, a fêmea armazena no interior do oviduto os espermatozóides produzidos pelo macho, utilizando-os para fecundação dos óvulos, o que pode ocorrer mesmo decorrido algum tempo (Oyakawa et al. 2009). Guimarães et al. (1995) verificaram que Mimagoniates lateralis é caracterizada geneticamente por possuir fórmula cromossômica de 2n = 6m+20sm+16st+10a.
threats: Mimagoniates lateralis apresenta distribuição restrita a riachos florestais de águas avermelhadas/ escuras na planície litorânea entre o litoral sul do estado de São Paulo e norte de Santa Catarina. Embora a área de ocorrência desta espécie, em geral, seja ainda relativamente bem preservada, sofre crescente impacto da ocupação urbana. Estes impactos estão associados mais diretamente ao desmatamento da vegetação ripária e à especulação imobiliária. Além da destruição pura e simples dos habitat específicos de ocupação desta espécie, outros impactos são provenientes da poluição oriunda de efluentes de esgoto doméstico e industrial, despejo descontrolado de lixo, aterros e loteamentos, exploração minerária ou mesmo a exploração eventual – e ilegal – da espécie para a aquariofilia (Duboc e Menezes 2008).
population: A espécie é abundante localmente, porém pouco frequente; é exigente em relação ao ambiente, típica de um biótopo específico, dependente da vegetação ripária para manter subpopulações viáveis. L.F.D. Silva (obs. pess.) menciona que espécimes de M. laterais foram coletados em gradiente de ambientes bastante íntegros a degradados, geralmente até 5 km da costa. Mimagoniates lateralis e M. microleps não ocorrem juntas no mesmo ambiente no estado do Paraná; em São Paulo, no entanto, podem ocorrer em sintopia, mas em baixas densidades. Não é uma espécie comum em ambientes impactados, ocorrendo em locais muito específicos, que costumam estar bastante fragmentados pela expansão urbana.
range: A espécie é endêmica do Brasil e ocorre nos riachos e alagadiços de águas ácidas e avermelhadas das regiões litorâneas de Mata Atlântica e restinga entre o sul do estado de São Paulo (Itanhaém) e o norte do estado de Santa Catarina (Araquari) (Duboc e Menezes 2008). No estado de São Paulo é conhecida apenas pela sua ocorrência em pequenos riachos costeiros de água preta, localizados entre as cidades de Santos e Cananeia (Oyakawa et al. 2009). No Paraná, ocorre no alto rio Perequê e afluentes, em riachos costeiros do litoral do estado (Duboc 2007). A espécie foi registrada no Parque Estadual do Acaraí, na ilha de São Francisco, localizada no litoral norte do estado de Santa Catarina (Otto 2006). Sua EOO foi calculada em cerca de 16.700 km2 pelo método do mínimo polígono convexo.
useTrade: Ocorre exploração eventual – e ilegal – da espécie para a aquariofilia (Duboc e Menezes 2008).
conservationActions:
Como estratégia de conservação, Duboc e Menezes (2008) sugerem a proteção mais efetiva das florestas de restinga situadas nas planícies litorâneas entre o sul do estado de São Paulo e o norte de Santa Catarina, cujos riachos abrigam, além de M. lateralis, outras espécies endêmicas de peixes ameaçados de extinção. Abilhoa et al. (2011) mencionam que se trata de uma espécie exclusiva de corpos d’água de baixa altitude, que ocorre em áreas longe de centros urbanos, mas que sofrem forte pressão e, apesar da importância e alto grau de endemismo, não há registros oficiais de indivíduos dessas espécies mantidos em cativeiro com fins de conservação.

Levantamentos de campo mais detalhados são necessários para estabelecer com maior exatidão a presente distribuição de M. lateralis e de outras espécies de peixes simpátricos ameaçados. Essas informações são essenciais para nortear decisões sobre o estabelecimento de unidades de conservação na área (Duboc e Menezes 2008). Abilhoa et al. (2011) reforçam a importância de reunir informações básicas sobre a ecologia, incluindo as preferências de habitat e tolerância ambiental.

Presença em unidades de conservação, São Paulo: APA de Cananeia-Iguape-Peruibe, APA Marinha do Litoral Centro; Paraná/São Paulo: APA de Guaraqueçaba; Paraná: PE do Boguaçu (Duboc e Menezes 2008); Santa Catarina: PE do Acaraí (Beninca 2011, Duboc e Menezes 2008, Otto 2006), APA de Guaratuba, APA da Serra Dona Francisca.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Spintherobolus ankoseion é conhecida de alguns pontos localizados em córregos e arroios nas florestas costeiras entre Guaraqueçaba, no norte do Paraná, e Içara, sul de Santa Catarina. Trata-se de uma espécie rara, típica de um biótopo específico, dependente da vegetação ripária para manter subpopulações viáveis. A extensão de ocorrência (EOO), calculada pelo método do mínimo polígono convexo, foi de 9,400 km2 e ocorre em 8-10 localizações, com base nas principais ameaças à espécie. Os ambientes preferenciais da espécie são bastante sensíveis à degradação ambiental e altamente impactados e fragmentados pela expansão imobiliária litorânea, causando um declínio continuado na qualidade de seu habitat. Desse modo, a espécie foi categorizada como Vulnerável (VU).
habitat: Spintherobolus ankoseion é uma espécie miniatura de lambari, com machos maduros com cerca de 1,8 cm de comprimento padrão. Os maiores indivíduos mal alcançam os 3 cm de comprimento padrão. É uma espécie praticamente desconhecida no que diz respeito à biologia e habitat (Duboc e Malabarba 2008). Os ambientes nos quais é registrada incluem córregos e alagadiços de águas avermelhadas a negras e lênticas das planícies litorâneas (Menezes et al. 2009), em uma área geográfica restrita. A espécie vem sendo encontrada por pesquisadores do Museu de História Natural Capão da Imbuia (MHNCI) em habitat bastante ácidos, onde o pH oscila entre 3,9 e 5,8 e o oxigênio dissolvido varia de 12 a 100%, com a amplitude térmica aquática registrando a mínima em 12,8°C no inverno e 28,1°C no verão. Todos os ambientes em que a espécie vem sendo encontrada estão associados à vegetação ripária e/ou ribeirinha algo preservada, tornando o seu ecossistema preferencial de ocorrência muito suscetível à ação antrópica, já que esses ambientes estão entre os primeiros a sofrer impacto no processo de ocupação humana (Duboc e Malabarba 2008). Vitule (2007) encontrou a espécie em dois trechos do rio Guaraguaçu (PR), sendo um deles bastante conservado, enquanto o outro apresentava conservação precária. Porém, ambos os trechos contavam com abundante vegetação ripária, e o trecho em pior estado de conservação apresentava grandes bancos de gramíneas introduzidas.
threats: A espécie possui elevado endemismo e pequena distribuição geográfica, com habitat preferencial bastante restrito. Em sua região de ocorrência, há áreas bem preservadas, mas que vêm sofrendo impacto crescente de origem antrópico. Tais impactos são associados principalmente ao desmatamento da vegetação ripária, drenagem, aterros e loteamentos provenientes da especulação imobiliária face à crescente ocupação humana do litoral. Há ainda os impactos decorrentes da poluição oriunda de efluentes de esgoto doméstico e industrial, despejo descontrolado de lixo ou mesmo da exploração mineral. Os habitat preferenciais da espécie, constituídos normalmente por pequenos corpos de água parada ou charcos, são depreciados pela população humana em geral, sendo alvos de drenagens, aterros e até mesmo de deposição de lixo (Duboc e Malabarba 2008).
population: Poucos exemplares estão registrados em coleções, todos coletados de forma ocasional e pontual, normalmente como exemplares solitários, sugerindo a condição rara da espécie e com baixa densidade populacional (Duboc e Malabarba 2008).
range: Spintherobolus ankoseion é endêmica do Brasil, conhecida de alguns pontos localizados em córregos e arroios nas florestas costeiras entre Guaraqueçaba, no norte do Paraná, e Içara, sul de Santa Catarina (Duboc e Malabarba 2008). Foi encontrada em trechos do alto rio Guaraguaçu, maior rio do litoral paranaense (Vitule 2007). Em Santa Catarina, na localidade de Santa Cruz, Içara, Spintherobolus ankoseion foi encontrada em um dos últimos fragmentos de floresta paludosa atlântica no sul do estado, com 500 ha, mas que não constitui uma área protegida (Duboc e Malabarba 2008). A extensão de ocorrência (EOO), calculada pelo método do mínimo polígono convexo, foi de 9,400 km2 e ocorre em 8-10 localizações, com base nas principais ameaças à espécie.
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não há nenhum programa de conservação dessa espécie no Brasil. Duboc e Malabarba (2008) sugerem a preservação de ambientes úmidos habitados pela espécie - pequenos córregos e áreas alagadas, que drenam capoeiras e florestas de restinga - como principal estratégia de conservação.

Presença em unidades de conservação Paraná: Área de Proteção Ambiental de Guaratuba (Duboc e Malabarba 2008). Foi também registrada em área limítrofe ao Parque Estadual do Boguaçu; Santa Catarina: Parque Estadual do Acaraí, Área de Proteção Ambiental de Guaraqueçaba.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: The species has been assessed as Data Deficient, due to a lack of information regarding its taxonomic status, distribution, population trends, or direct threats.
habitat: The species is known from a lake (a former branch of the Red River).
threats: The known location, Hô Tây Lake, is within Hanoi city, and is impacted by pollution from a range of sources. The lake is also heavily utilised for recreational activities. The impact of these threats is not known.
population: There is no information available on the species population.
range: The species is known from Hô Tây (West) Lake, in Hanoi, northern Viet Nam (Nguyen and Ngo 2001).
useTrade: No information.
conservationActions: Research is required to confirm the taxonomic placement of the species, as well as its distribution and population trends, and the impact of known threats on the species.

rationale: In the western Atlantic Canthigaster figueiredoi is known from the southern Caribbean to Santa Catarina, Brazil, including the offshore islands of Mãe and Comprida Atol das Rocas and Fernando de Noronha. Records from Trinidad and Venezuela are considered vagrants. Canthigaster figueiredoi appears to be common in parts of its range. Canthigaster figueiredoi inhabits a wide range of reef-associated habitats at depths ranging from 1 to 35 metres. Canthigaster figueiredoi is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. figueiredoi. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. figueiredoi, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of harvest levels.
habitat:
Canthigaster figueiredoi is a reef-associated species which inhabits a variety of habitats, including coral-rich as well as coral-poor areas, and areas with rocky bottoms. It is typically found at depths ranging from 1–35 metres, though it also occurs on deeper reefs up to 54 metres (Feitoza et al. 2005). It is a diurnal species which is often seen in pairs hovering over the reef (Moura and Castro 2002). Canthigaster figuiredoi feeds on vegetation, sponges, crustaceans, and mollusks (Carvalho-Filho 1999).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. figueiredoi available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves  the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
This species has been collected as bycatch in fish traps for ornamental marine species in Brazil (Feitosa et al. 2008), however this is not considered a major threat at present time.

There have been no confirmed population declines in C. figueiredoi. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, we infer that C. figueiredoi may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population:
Canthigaster figueiredoi is described as common (Moura and Castro 2002) and appears to be locally abundant in parts of Brazil.

Canthigaster figueiredoi was found to be very abundant (seen on 10/10 dives) at the Trindade-Martin Vaz oceanic insular complex in Brazil (Pinhiero et al. 2009). On the Guarapari Islands, off the southeastern Brazilian coast, the density of this species per 40 m2 was 0.05 ± 0.04 (0.08% of total) at sheltered sites; 0.19 ± 0.05 (0.27% of total) at moderately exposed sites, and 0.73 ± 0.13 (0.80% of total) at the most exposed sites (Floeter et al. 2007). This species is very common on shallow reefs and reef slopes in at the Laje de Santos Marine State Park, Brazil (Luiz Jr., et al. 2008).

Specimens of C. figueiredoi are uncommon in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012). Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. figueiredoi may be undergoing population declines.
range: Canthigaster figueiredoi is distributed in the western Atlantic along the South American coast from Guyana to Santa Catarina, Brazil including the islands of Cabo Frio and Comprida off Rio de Janeiro (Chaves and Monteiro-Neto 2008), Atol das Rocas and Fernando de Noronha (Moura and Castro 2002), and Trindade Island (Pinheiro et al. 2009, Pereira-Filho et al. 2011). Throughout most of its range south of the Amazon River, it is the only species of Canthigaster in the region (Moura and Castro 2002). Records from the Caribbean off Venezuela and Trinidad are considered vagrants (Rocha 2002, Luiz et al. 2013). Its depth range is 1–54 m.
useTrade: This species is a component of the marine aquarium trade, and is a popular aquarium species in Brazil (Moura and Castro 2002).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. figueiredoi, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: The species is endemic to the headwaters of Río Mezquital (Río del Tunal and Laguna Santiaguillo) in the Federal State of Durango, in the Pacific Slope of Mexico (Miller et al. 2005). A continuing decline in the quality of the species natural habitat has been observed as a result of  water pollution events which have caused mass fish deaths in Río del Tunal. A population size reduction is inferred as a result of these threats. With an EOO of approximately 6387 km2, the species is assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: The species inhabits slow moving backwaters in gradient streams, ponds fed by springs, lakes and dams; generally at depths of 0.7-1.0 m (Miller et al. 2005).
threats: This species is severely threatened by high levels of water pollution which have caused mass fish deaths in Río del Tunal  (De la Maza et al. 2015).
population: More information is needed about the current population size of this Silverside. A population decline is inferred based on several water pollution events causing mass fish deaths in its distribution range (De la Maza et al. 2015).
range: The species is endemic to the headwaters of Río Mezquital (Río del Tunal and Laguna Santiaguillo) in the Federal State of Durango, in the Pacific Slope of Mexico (Miller et al. 2005). Field surveys in 2008 found 10 individuals of this species in the spring system on the 27th November (N. Mercado-Silva pers. comm. 2018). Between 2013-2015 several individuals were captured in Santiaguillo (H. Espinosa-Perez pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions in place that target this species.

rationale: This species is a microendemic of the Laguna de San Juanico an endorheic lake and its tributary, near Cotija, Michoacán, Mexico (Miller et al. 2005). It it is inferred to be threatened by  by water pollution, sedimentation, euthropication, concentration of heavy metals and bacteria, which have caused several mass death fish events. Competition and predation from invasive alien spp. is also a potential threat to this microendemic species. More information is needed however about the species population size and trends to be able to assess it in a category other than Data Deficient.
habitat: The species inhabits quiet waters of lakes, rivers and cannals (Miller et al. 2005).
threats: La Presa de San Juanico is threatened by water pollution, sedimentation, euthropication, concentration of heavy metals and bacteria, which have caused several mass death fish events. Competition and predation from invasive alien spp. is also a potential threat to this microendemic species.
population: More information is needed about the population size and population trend of this species. The taxonomy is not well defined and further research is needed to confirm it's population size.
range: This species is a microendemic of the Laguna de San Juanico an endorheic lake and its tributary, near Cotija, Michoacán, Mexico (Miller et al. 2005).
useTrade: The species is fished as part of a flock of Chirostoma spp.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions in place targeting this species.

rationale:
Allodontichthys zonistius is endemic to the Río Armería and one affluent of the Río Salado (Río Coahuayana drainage) in Jalisco and Colima, Mexico. A continuing habitat quality decline has been observed as a result of water pollution caused by urban, industrial and agricultural discharges and run-off into the rivers. The Armería river is highly polluted with heavy metals, pesticides, herbicides, and organic nutrients, and has undergone hydrological alterations as a result of over-extraction of water resources for agricultural and domestic use. 

With a best case scenario for area of occupancy (1,040 km2), extent of occurence (6,500 km2) and 10 known locations, the Bandfin Splitfin meets the threshold for Vulnerable (AOO: 2,000 km2; EOO: 20,000 km2; locations: 10), so therefore it is assessed Vulnerable.
habitat:
Like all other Allodontichthys-species, the Bandfin Splitfin lives in clear riffles over substrates of gravel, rocks and boulders. It may occur in depths up to 1 m in pools, but generally prefers depths of less than 0.5 m. During the dry season, the currents are slight to moderate, but turbulent during the rest of the year. The only form of submersed vegetation associated with this species is green filamentous algae (Miller 2005).

Harro Hieronimus (1995) observed this species in March 1989 in the Río de la Lumbre near San Antonio on the border between Colima and Jalisco. He described the habitat as a narrow creek up to 1 m wide and 30 cm deep, with the ground made up of gravel, sand, rocks and silt, easily to whirl, and lots of foliage. The riverbed was shaded by large trees; the current slowly running over several steps of boulders and rocks. He found the Bandfin Splitfin hiding under rocks and boulders. Other fish species found at this site were Ilyodon furcidens and Guppys (Poecilia reticulata). The water parametres at 12:45 on March 21 were: temperature 19.5°C, conductivity 560 μS, pH 7.2, total hardness 15°dH and carbonate hardness 10°dH.
threats: The species is mainly threatened by water pollution caused by urban, industrial and agricultural discharges and run-off into the ríos Armería and Coahuayana-basins. A recent study about the water quality of the Río Ayuquila-Tuxcacuesco-Armería system revealed mercury values above the permissible level and lead concentration close to the permissable level (Mancilla-Villa et al. 2017). The whole system is heavily polluted with heavy metals, pesticides, herbicides and organic nutrients. It has also undergone hydrological alterations as a result of over-extraction of water resources for agricultural and domestic use and, as a result of it, the river is often dry at the river mouth, acting as an obstacle for migratory species (Martínez Rivera et al. 2017). Sugar cane production on the plain between Autlán de Navarro and El Grullo threatens the stocks in this area through pesticides and fertilisers. An additional threat for the Río Ayuquila is urban and industrial sewage from the towns of Autlán de Navarro and El Grullo, and for the ríos Colima and Salado from the towns of Colima and Cuauhtemoc.
population:
From the affiliation to two separate river basins (Río Armería respectively Río Coahuayana), two subpopulations of the Bandfin Splitfin, (the Río Armería and the Río Salado subpopulation) can be distinguished.

According to the Río Armería subpopulation, stocks in the Río Ayuquila and some of its affluents recovered after the improvement of water quality from a sugar cane mill discharge near the town of Autlán, but these gains have been offset by population declines further downstream in the Río Armería and in rivers and creeks near Colima belonging to the Río Colima drainage (Lyons 2011). Furthermore, possible habitats in the upper ríos Ayuquila and Tuxcacuesco have become uninhabitable for this species due to dams (e.g. Presa las Piedras, Presa General Ramón Corona). Only one collection site above one dam, at the Arroyo San Pedro, is known. Due to its range and population declines in the lower section of the Río Armería, this subpopulation is regarded Vulnerable.

According to the Río Salado subpopulation, the declines observed in the Río Colima and its affluents can also be observed in this geographically close subpopulation. This subpopulation is much smaller, but includes two locations, so therefore it is regarded Endangered.
range:
The Bandfin Splitfin is endemic to the Mexican federal states of Jalisco and Colima and was originally described from the vicinity of Colima, probably from the Río Colima, Río Armería drainage. In following decades, it was also discovered in several affluents of the Río Armería and in one affluent of the Río Salado, Río Coahuayana drainage. Currently, its geographic range encompasses the Río Ayuquila (the name of the upper section of the Río Armería), the upper Río Armería to about its junction with the Río de la Lumbre (about 15km north-north-west of Colima) including the Río de la Lumbre itself, the Río Tuxcacuesco around its junction with the Río Ayuquila, one affluent in its headwaters (Arroyo San Pedro), and two main affluents of the Río Ayuquila (arroyos Ahuacapán and Manantlán), all from within the upper Río Armería drainage. It also occurs in the headwaters of the Río Colima, the Barranca de la Tía Barragana and Arroyo El Carrizal (Río Comala sources) around the town of Comala, middle Río Armería drainage. Due to a relatively recent stream capture (Lyons and Mercado-Silva 2000, Webb 2002), it has also been found in the Río Coahuayana system near the town of Cuauhtemoc, namely in the Arroyo Cardona, Río Salado drainage, and two of its affluents: the Arroyo Grande and the Río El Cobano.

In 2008, it was estimated that the Bandfin Splitfin had disappeared from about 30% of its historical range (Domínguez-Domínguez et al. 2008).
useTrade: This species is neither traded as food nor as an ornamental species for aquariums.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for Allodontichthys zonistius are known. A recent study (Martínez Rivera et al. 2017) proposes a monthly flow regime to ensure an ecological minimum flow of 4.5 m3s-1 to ameliorate damage to the Río Armería following the Mexican Standard NMX-AA-159-SCFI-2012. However, this hasn't yet been implemented.

rationale: Poecilia teresae is known to occur in Mountain Pine Ridge in Cayo, Belize. It may also be present near Belmopan, Belize and in Calakmul Biosphere Reserve in Mexico, though these collections are of questionable validity. The species is known to be threatened by hydroelectric energy development and may be threatened by urban expansion and agricultural runoff should it occur near Belmopan. Should the species occur only in Mountain Pine Ridge, the species would qualify for listing as Critically Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii). If it also occurs near Belmopan, it would qualify for listing as Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii). The latter interpretation is considered to be more credible in this assessment and the species is thus listed as Endangered. Verification of collections from Mexico may further alter the species' conservation status. Clarification of the species' distribution is urgently needed as it could impact the species' conservation status.
habitat: This species occurs in small streams and pools within tropical pine forest habitat, which are typically characterized by clear, cool, and fast flowing water that cuts through granitic rock, often terminating in high waterfalls that prevent the upstream movement of other species (Greenfield 1990). This species reaches a maximum reported body size of 5 cm standard length (SL) (Lucinda 2003).
threats:
Despite the protected area status of Mountain Pine Ridge Forest Reserve and Chiquibul National Park in southern Belize, aquatic resources are regionally threatened by land-use changes associated with hydropower development, logging, and mining activities (Briggs et al. 2013). Subpopulations near the city of Belmopan are likely impacted by domestic pollution, urban and rural expansion, land clearance associated with agriculture, and cattle grazing (Aké 2005). Military presence and training exercises in the vicinity have resulted in occasional trash accumulations in small pools of water during the dry season, but the impacts and extent of solid waste pollution are unknown (Miller and Miller 1994).

The scope, magnitude, and direct impact of these threats on habitat availability and the population status of P. teresae have not been evaluated in detail. Furthermore, this species persists in a number of small, upland tributary streams subject to isolated threats that may not be affecting immediately adjacent streams. The species is likely to exist in one to three locations depending on the species' distribution. If the species is restricted to Mountain Pine Ridge, one location would exist. If the species also occurs near Belmopan, this would constitute a second location, and the Calakmul subpopulations, if valid, would constitute a third.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. However, this species appears rare where it occurs. In a drainage-wide survey of the Monkey Tail branch of the Macal River, only one individual was collected (Esselman and Allan 2010).
range:
Poecilia teresae occurs in upland tributary streams and isolated pools in the Macal River drainage within the Maya Mountain Range of southern Belize (Lucinda 2003, Bagley et al. 2015, Palacios et al. 2016). It has also been collected in nearby residential areas, including  Mount Pleasant Creek in southern Belmopan (Aké 2005). Additional collection records exist from Calakmul Biosphere Reserve in southern Mexico where individuals were collected at low abundances in isolated pools (Vega-Cendejas et al. 2013), but these collections are questionable and verification of range extension is needed. The type locality of this species is a small stream in Mountain Pine Ridge Forest Reserve (Greenfield 1990, Poeser 2003).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 89-800 km2, and the species can be considered to occur in a single location.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation actions directed towards P. teresae. The range of this species extends into Mountain Pine Ridge Forest Reserve, likely extends into Chiquibul National Park, and may extend northward into Calakmul Biosphere Reserve (Miller and Miller 1994, Vega-Cendejas et al. 2013, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). Additional research regarding distribution, population size, population status, life history and ecology, and the scope and magnitude of existing threats are priorities that will guide future conservation outcomes.

rationale: Species of wide distribution and with small populations. Its habitat has been modified rapidly since 1960, which allows us to infer the reduction in its areas of occupation. Although Astatheros macracanthus is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable, and therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Streams, rivers, lakes, and canals in clear-to-muddy, fresh-to-brackish water; currents slight to strong, usually moderate; substrates mud, silt, detritus, sand, gravel, rock, boulder, logs; vegetation algae, water hyacinth, Typha; depths to 2.0 m (Miller et al., 2005). It appears in backwaters and shallow rapids with vegetation that offers refuge, since they use cavities between the boulders, in the shade of the vegetation, on the undermined banks of the river and in the rapids in the portion protected by the rocks (Soto-Galera, 2006). It occurs in backwaters and shallow rapids with vegetation that offers refuge, since they use cavities between the boulders, in the shade of the vegetation, on the undermined shores of the river and in the portion protected by the rocks in the rapids (Soto-Galera, 2006). Juveniles of 7 to 14 mm LP have been caught from the beginning of March to the middle of April and the beginning of July, that is, both during the dry season and in the rainy season (Miller et al., 2005).
threats:
Arriaga-Cabrera et al (1998) mention among others:
- Modification of the environment: deforestation for agriculture and livestock. Immoderate felling, the high parts (above 800 meters above sea level) better conserved;  overexploitation of tributaries; damming of rivers and lack of fresh water
- Contamination: by garbage, agrochemicals and organic matter.
- Use of resources: forestry, vertebrates, insects and plants at risk. Drug trafficking and social instability. Use of forest and agricultural land.

- Pollution: by agrochemicals, organic matter, petroleum and urban waste and from aquaculture farms.

-Use of resources: introduced species of tilapia, carp and pasture. Overfishing of fish and shrimp, causing a decrease in natural populations.
population: Populations reduced in general in almost all the localities registered in the "Colección Nacional de Peces Dulceacuícolas Mexicanos" are collected when more six specimens, but more frequently one or two (Soto-Galera and Alcántara-Soria, 2016).
range: Astatheros macracanthus is distributed within the Pacific Slope, Río Tehuantepec basin east and southward through Oaxaca and Chiapas to western Guatemala (Miller et al. 2005).
useTrade: More information is needed on whether this species is potentially utilised. It is believed to be bycatch in other fishing targets.
conservationActions: There is no known conservation for this species, although more information on the distribution overlaps with any possible conservation or protected areas is needed.

rationale: Amphilophus istlanus is a relatively widespread species within the Balsas basin of Mexico, occurring from the origins of the Balsas river in Puebla, before continuing westwards between the mountains of the Cordillera Madre Sur de México westward to the rivers depository into the pacific. This species faces multiple threats from urban and industrial pollution, habitat degradation, water extraction and hydro power and damn construction, potential over fishing and aquarium trade extraction and foreign species invasion. More information is required regarding it's population size and trend, harvest and trade, given it is likely to be experiencing local declines. However, this species is widespread, occurs within many protected areas of Mexico and it is not thought that there is a global population decline likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the thresholds of Vulnderable, and therefore Amphilophus istlanus is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Amphilophus istlanus is a specialized entomophagous carnivore (Trujillo-Jiménez, 1998), that inhabits the balsas river, which is composed of fast-flowing to very rapid waters, over rocky, silt and muddy substrates, the latter of which results in reduced water transparency in the lower regions of the river, and only slight transparency within the headwaters of small tributaries during the dry season (Azas, 1996). It is believed that this is a result of local and regional deforestation sediment run-off (Azas, 1996). This species commonly occupies non-vegetated rivers, but when possible, seeks rocks and aquatic vegetation for cover in the form of shrubs on the banks (Azes, 1996). 
The maximum altitude of the occupied rivers for this species is 1,000 meters above sea level, and no less than 20 - 22 ° C (Azas, 1996).  The maximum known size of this species is 28 cm TL. (Male), while the mean leght is 25 cm TL  (González et al., 2018).
Reproduction takes place during dry season, when water is transparent, this allows for the characteristic courtship displays of the species. It is a bentic litophil species, which means that it lays its eggs on a flat rock surface, that is cleaned mainly by the males. The female then deposits close to 500 very small, yellowish eggs on the surface of the rock and the male fertilizes them (Contreras-MacBeath, 1989). The nest is guarded by both parents for about two days when the eggs hatch, when the fry reach the state of free swimming, the male and female will swim along the bottom of the river defending them (Contreras-MacBeath & Díaz-Pardo, 1990).
threats:
Amphilophus istlanus is occasionally found within the aquarium trade, it is fished for recreation purposes and for consumption locally, but to what scale is unknown (Azes, 1996; Trujillo-Jiménez, 1998). Within the Balsas River basin in Mexico, A. nigrofasciata is a well-established, introduced, dominant species that has displaced Amphilophus istlanus (Contreras-MacBeath 1998, Mejia-Mojica et al., 2015) due to a high diet overlap (Medina-Nava et al. 2011).
Amphilophus istlanus also faces threats from pollution, sedimentation and habitat degradation, as within the Balsas river, caused by the regional deforestation from the historic agricultural land use change, together with uncontrolled dumping of wastewater reducing water transparency (Azas, 1996). An example is the Coahuayama River within the basin, that has been decimated by the untreated waters of a paper industry located north of the city of Colima (Azas, 1996).
Also numerous dams and hydropower stations have been constructed along Balsas River, two major projects are the La Villita and El Infiernello, Michoacan, and the Carlos Ramirez Ulloa in Guerrero among others (Salas, 1991; Tortajada, 2005). In addition there is the El Texcal area of Rio Balsas is the outcrop of an underground river and provides drinking water neighboring populations, including Jiutepec and Yautepec (Ramsar Secretariat Site No.1993, 2010).
population: More information is required regarding this species population trend and size. Amphilophus istlanus may well be experiencing local declines due to over fishing, habitat degradation and displacement from exotic species (Azes, 1996; Contreras-MacBeath et al., 1998; Trujillo-Jiménez, 1998; Medina-Nava, et al., 2011; Mejia-Mojica et al., 2015).
range:
Amphilophus istlanus is found across multiple states of Mexico within the Balsas basin, mainly occupying the Rio Balsas (Azes, 1996). The Rio Balsas originates at the confluence of the San Martin and Zahuapan Rivers, as the Atoyac River, in the state of Puebla. It continues westwards between the mountains of the Cordillera Madre Sur de México, also serving as a border between the states of Guerrero and Michoacán, travelling through Morelos, and continuing on to empty into the Pacific coast, in the city of Lázaro Cárdenas (Azas, 1996).
Amphilophus istlanus is known to occur in the Sierra de Manantlán (Lyons 1991), Coahuayana and Armeria rivers (Azas, 1996), Jalisco, and in the Comala River, Colima (Turner, 1989), as well as the headwaters of Rio Amacuzac, a northern affluent running southwards in Morelos state, in Río Tuxpán (Concheiro Pé-rez, et al., 2007). With a length of some 771 kilometers, the Balsas River is one of Mexico's longest rivers, and the mountain range acts a restrictive barrier to this species, so it is scarcely found west of the Balsas.
useTrade: This species is also relatively common within the aquarium trade, but Amphilophus istlanus has traditionally been fished locally for food and for recreational purposes (Azes, 1996; Trujillo-Jiménez, 1998).
conservationActions: There is no species specific protection for Amphilophus istlanus, even though it's distribution does cross into the boundaries of multiple protected areas, such as Sierra de Huautla Biosphere Reserve in the State of Morelos (Mejia-Mojica et al., 2015).

rationale: Amphilophus trimaculatus is of wide distribution within Mexican cichlids. The catches of this mojarra before the decade of the seventies, used to be numerous in each event, frequently more than five individuals, although in some cases, such as in Coyuca, Guerrero and Santiago Jamiltepec, Oaxaca exceeded 150 individuals, however, records in the National Collection of Mexican Freshwater Fishes, ENCB, IPN, point out that of 1980, there are hardly records with more than one individual, and in the specific case of Coyuca and Santiago Jamiltepec the most numerous catches are barely six specimens. Although there may be declines in local populations of this species, there is not thought to be global threat to this species, and so given it's wide distribution this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Streams, rivers, lakes, and canals in clear-to-muddy, fresh-to-brackish water; currents slight to strong, usually moderate; substrates mud, silt, detritus, sand, gravel, rock, boulder, logs; vegetation algae, water hyacinth, Typha; depths to 2.0 m (Miller et al., 2005). Present in the backwaters of rivers and streams, with deep-rooted submerged and emerging vegetation, also on the banks of rivers, taking refuge among rocks, hollows and between pebbles (Soto-Galera, 2006).
threats:
Arriaga-Cabrera et al (1998) mentioned among other threats:
- Modification of the environment: deforestation for agriculture and livestock. Immoderate felling, the high parts (above 800 meters above sea level) better conserved;  over-exploitation of tributaries; damming of rivers and lack of fresh water
- Contamination: by garbage, agrochemicals and organic matter.
- Use of resources: forestry, vertebrates, insects and plants at risk. Drug trafficking and social instability. Use of forest and agricultural land.

- Pollution: by agrochemicals, organic matter, petroleum and urban waste and from aquaculture farms.

- Use of resources: introduced species of tilapia, carp and pasture. Overfishing of fish and shrimp, causing a decrease in natural populations.
population: The catches of this mojarra before the decade of the seventies used to be numerous in each event, frequently more than five individuals, although in some cases as in Coyuca, Guerrero and Santiago Jamiltepec, Oaxaca exceeded 150 individuals. However, the records in the Colección Nacional de Peces Dulceacuícolas Mexicanos, ENCB, IPN, indicate that as of 1980, there are hardly records with more than one individual, and in the specific case of Coyuca and Santiago Jamiltepec the most numerous catches rarely reach the six specimens (Soto-Galera and Alcántara-Alcántara Soria, 2016). The overall population trend and current size are not known for Amphilophus trimaculatus.
range: This species is known to occur from the Pacific slope of Middle America, from Laguna de Coyuca, northwest of Acapulco, Chiapas, Guerrero, Oaxaca, of Mexico and continue eastward into Río Lempa, El Salvador. (Miller, et al., 2005).
useTrade: It is not clear if this species is targeted in fishing, but it may be a by-catch of fish and shrimp fishing in it's range.
conservationActions: There is no known conservation in place for this species, but more information on this species distribution would be beneficial.

rationale: The species occurs in the Pacific Slope of Mexico, from Chiapas eastward into western Guatemala, and from Coatepeque Lake in El Salvador. There is limited evidence to suggest historical declines in the abundance of this species post-1970, based on some reduction in capture success despite similar capture effort. However, validation of major population decline requires further validation on a range-wide scale. While regional and localized threats exist, their impact on the extent of suitable habitat and on the population status of this species have not been evaluated. Given these uncertainties, V. guttulata is assessed as Data Deficient. Validation of potential declines in abundance and research regarding the population status of this species are conservation priorities that warrants immediate attention.
habitat:
This cichlid inhabits small to large streams and lakes in usually clear (occasionally murky) water; in currents slight to strong; and substrates of gravel, rubble, boulder, marl, mud, sand and silt in depths to 2.0 m. Vegetation typically none or sparse, sometimes algae and Chara (Miller et al. 2005).

V. guttulata is a bentopelagic species, restricted to the fresh waters of lotic systems, found in tropical climate sites, with an ambient temperature ranging from 25º to 30º C. The species has been captured in sites with different types of substrate , from mud to sand and rocks; as well as in different portions of the rivers, such as high, medium and low (Breder and Rosen 1966). In the Pacific slope of the Sierra Madre del Sur it is found in sandy pools and pools with rocky outcroppings and boulders, as well as in all those substrates that have cavities between the rocks and / or shelters between the emergent and submerged vegetation. It is captured in well-lit and oxygenated waters, at temperature intervals between 23 and 28 ° C (Soto-Galera 2006).

The capture of individuals of 18 mm, and between 10 to 15 mm of LP, from the end of February to the end of March, indicate reproductive events at least in this part of the year (Miller et al. 2005).
threats: Arriaga-Cabrera et al.
