These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further Research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2009), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Arothron carduus is a rare species that is only known from two fragmented localities of the Sea of Penang, Malaysia and the Ryukyu Islands, Japan. An additional specimen is likely to have originated in the Philippines. It is known to a maximum depth 10 metres, however it may be found in deeper waters. This species is likely to be associated with coral reefs, which are declining globally. There is very little information available on the population status or life history characteristics of this species, it appears to be very rare. Because it is only known from three specimens, from disparate localities, it is assessed as Data Deficient. We recommend continued research on this species' life history characteristics, population status, and distribution.
habitat:
Arothron carduus inhabits the inner reefs of coral reef areas in very shallow water at depths of up to 10 metres (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011, Matsuura and Okuno 1991). Congeners of this species are typically reef-associated omnivores. The toxicity of this species is currently unknown (Nakabo 2002).

Fishes of the genus Arothron are widely distributed throughout the tropical regions of the Indo-western Pacific. Species have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads,  and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in A. carduus. However, because of its association with coral reefs, we infer that A. carduus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. Additionally, A. carduus is sold dried and inflated for use in the curio trade (Matsuura 1991).

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the IUCN Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population:
Arothron carduus is a rare species which was described on the basis of three available specimens in 1991 (Matsuura and Okuno 1991). Specimens of A. carduus are rare in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 2012–03–28).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, A. carduus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Arothron carduus is found in the Sea of Penang, Malaysia in the eastern Indian Ocean and the southern Ryukyus Islands in the northwest Pacific. An additional specimen was purchased dried in Japan and is thought to have originated in the Philippines (Matsuura and Okuno 1991). It is found at depths ranging from 0–10 metres.
useTrade: Arothron carduus can be found in the curio trade, where it is dried and sold as ornaments (Matsuura and Okuno 1991). It is also occasionally found in the marine aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for A. carduus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas (World Database of Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: This species has a vast range from the eastern coast of South Africa to Samoa. There is however very little population information, other than the abundance of museum collections. There are no known major threats, and its wide range overlaps many marine protected areas. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Torquigener hypselogeneion is a demersal species that inhabits shallow coastal sand flats and in estuaries and prefers quiet shorelines to around 20 m. It is typically found in seagrass beds or sandy bottoms shallower than 40 m. It feeds mainly on molluscs, fishes, crustaceans (Smith 1986).

Tetraodontidae
Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough, scaleless skin often covered with small spicules, beak-like dental place divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single short dorsal fin, a single shore anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or injured, and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, or liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: There are no major threats known to this species. This species is called "Namida-fugu" in Japan (Nakabo 2002). Although no population declines have been confirmed, this species may be experiencing population decreases due to its affinity with seagrass beds. One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).
population: Torquigener hypselogeneion is common in museum collections. It is represented by 77 lots (FishNet2 database searched November 2013). This species of fish may be experiencing population declines due to loss of seagrass bed habitat.
range: Torquigener hypselogeneion is found from the Indian Ocean from Kenya, South Africa and along the eastern coast of Africa eastward through the western Pacific to Samoa, and north to Japan (Makabo to Yaeyama Islands) and the coasts of the South China Sea (Masuda et al. 1984, Su and Li 2002), including along most of the coast of Taiwan (K.-T. Shao pers. comm. 2014). It is also found in Australia, off the central Queensland coast (Hoese et al. 2006). It is found at depths of zero to 20 metres (Hardy pers. comm. 2011).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place. This species' range may overlaps marine protected areas.

rationale: Lagocephalus spadiceus is widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific, including the Red Sea, and is an established Lessepsian migrant. It is found in a variety of coastal and offshore habitats at depths ranging from three to 200 metres. It is harvested for human consumption in parts of its range and may be experiencing localized population declines, particularly in the Western Pacific where it is a component of the Fugu/Pufferfish trade. It appears to be taken in mixed catches with the commercially-important L. gloveri, however the relative contribution of L. spadiceus to the catch is unknown. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for L. spadiceus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is likely to benefit from management efforts directed towards other commercially-important pufferfishes such as T. rubripes. Although it is heavily fished in parts of its range and has likely undergone population declines, it is a wide-ranging species. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Lagocephalus spadiceus is a demersal species which is typically an inhabitant of marine waters, but is also a partial resident in estuaries (Talwhar and Jhingran 1991, Vidthayanon and Premacharoen 2002). It is typically found over sandy bottoms in shallow waters less than 50 m (Golani 1998, Tuncer et al. 2008). This species has been found to be non-toxic in Thailand (Brillantes et al. 2003). It feeds on fishes, molluscs and crustaceans. Although established in the Mediterranean, L. spadiceus is not considered invasive and its establishment has not been implicated in negative ecosystem or fishery effects (Akyol et al. 2005). The maximum total length (TL) for this species is 25.0 cm male/unsexed (Bouhlel 1988).

Puffers of the genus Lagocephalus are globally distributed in warm shallow waters, however classification at the species level in Lagocephalus has not yet been studied in depth, causing confusion in the status of several species including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus, and L. wheeleri (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Fugu fishery 
Lagocephalus spadiceus is commercially targeted for the Fugu trade, and has undergone localized population reductions in parts of its range, particularly in Hong Kong where it is no longer present. Japanese fisheries data from 1979–2007 show fluctuating landing trends which appear to indicate shifting targets, with marked declines in recent years. Catch statistics for this species and L. gloveri are lumped together as "sabafugu" in Japan. As fewer highly-desirable and notably over-exploited species are landed (Torafugu T. rubripes and Karasu T. chinensis), landings of other species, including sabafugu (L. gloveri and L. spadiceus) have declined from a peak of roughly 400 tonnes in 1999 to less than 100 tonnes in 2007, a decline of roughly 75%. These declines have been attributed to the effects of highly-effective long-line fishing (Kawata 2012).

The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly-effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012).

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Additional potential threats to L. spadiceus include environmental degradation in parts of its range. Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea, all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
The name L. spadiceus has been widely applied to a number of Lagocephalus species. It is common in the eastern Mediterranean, and is one of the most abundant non-indigenous pufferfishes of the eastern Mediterranean Sea, found along the entire Levantine basin coasts from Port Said to the southern Aegean (Golani 1998, Golani et al. 2002, Tuncer et al. 2008). It is more abundant than L. sceleratus in the Mediterranean (Başusta et al. 2013). It is rare in the Suez Canal (Fouda et al. 1995).

This species may be undergoing localized population reductions in parts of its range due to overfishing. Lagocephalus spadiceus was previously consumed by local fishermen in Hong Kong waters, and is now almost extinct in the area (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011).

As fewer highly-desirable and notably over-exploited species are landed in Japan (Torafugu T. rubripes and Karasu T. chinensis) fisheries began targeting other, less desirable species. Landings of other species, including sabafugu (L. gloveri and L. spadiceus) declined from a peak of roughly 400 tonnes in 1999 to less than 100 tonnes in 2007, a decline of roughly 75%. These declines have been attributed to the effects of highly-effective long-line fishing (Kawata 2012).

Specimens of L. spadiceus are very common in museum collections and is represented by at least 206 lots (FishNet2 retrieved 23 November 2013).
range: Lagocephalus spadiceus is widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific and is known from the Persian Gulf (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014), South Africa eastward to east coast of Australia and north to the South China Sea, Taiwan (Su and Li 2002), and central Japan (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). It is rarely found in the Yellow Sea and Bohai Sea (Su and Li 2002). This species is a Lessepsian migrant which is considered established, although not invasive, in the eastern Mediterranean (Katasanevakis et al. 2009), where it has recorded in the Sea of Marmara (Tuncer et al. 2008). It is found at depths ranging from three to 200 metres, however it is most likely to be found in waters less than 50 metres depth.
useTrade:
Lagocephalus spadiceus is harvested for human consumption in East and Southeast Asia (Brillantes et al. 2003). Catch statistics for this species and L. gloveri are lumped together as "sabafugu" in Japan (Kawata 2012). The name Shira-Sabafugu has also been used to refer to this species in the pufferfish trade.
 
Lagocephalus spadiceus is a commercially important species which is imported into Japan from China. Being less expensive than Takifugu rubripes (torafugu), is often utilized in processed products. In 2006, 90% of pufferfish imported into Japan landed at Shimonoseki Port. Of those pufferfish products 99.7% originated from China, and most were frozen L. spadiceus (Yamaguchi et al. 2013). This species is considered an economic burden to fishermen in the Mediterranean, who must discard them from their nets (Streftaris and Zenetos 2006). In Thailand, L. spadiceus is used as an ingredient in fish balls (Brillantes et al. 2003).
conservationActions:
Fisheries
Lagocephalus spadiceus is a component of the pufferfish fishery in East Asia. While no species-specific regulations are known to be in place for L. spadiceus, management efforts targeting the fishery as a whole are likely to positively impact this species. On a regional scale, the ratification of the United Nations (UN) Convention on the Law of the Sea in 1999 resulted in fisheries agreements reached between Japan, South Korea, and China. These agreements restructured fisheries management by giving coastal countries the ability to regulate foreign fishing vessels. The Fisheries Agency of Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which led to the establishment of an off-fishing season, restriction on minimum body size, improvements to fishing grounds, and other measures. The plan was extended past 2010 to 2012 due to the failure of T. rubripes to recover (Kawata 2012).

Other conservation measures
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for L. spadiceus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Canthigaster papua is widespread in the western Pacific, where is appears to be common. It inhabits a wide range of coral reef-associated habitats at depths ranging from 6 to 180 metres. Canthigaster papua is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. papua, however due to its affinity with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. papua, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Canthigaster papua is a reef-associated species which lives in coastal to outer reef habitats from silty to pristine reefs (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). It occurs in clear, coral-rich areas of lagoon and seaward reefs (Myers 1999). Adults are often seen in pairs along deep drop-offs while juveniles can be found in shallow estuaries (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). Canthigaster papua may be known to occur at depths below 180 m (Adam et al. 1998). The juveniles of two coral-trouts, P. leopardus and P. maculatus, may be mimics of this species (Frisch 2006). This species is an omnivorous benthic forager. Larvae of this species were found to settle on moorings and artificial structures (Leis et al. 2002). This species may have two parapatric colour morphs.

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. papua available. C. papua is sexually dimorphic (Stump in prep. 2014). In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. papua may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

In the South Western Pacific Islands, which include 27,060 km2  of coral reef area, 4% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 17% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

Declines in mean coral cover have been recorded in Mauritius and La Réunion (Wilkinson et al. 2008). In La Réunion, native fish fauna are threatened by eutrophication and pollution, overfishing and poaching, by marine aquaculture, and by shoreline construction (Fricke et al. 2009).

In the southwestern Indian Ocean, which includes 5,270 km2 of coral reef area, 9% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 24% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008).
population:
Canthigaster papua is abundant on inshore coral-reefs of the Indo-Australian Archipelago (Frisch 2006).

Specimens of C. papua are very common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. papua may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Canthigaster papua is distributed from the Andaman Islands throughout the Philippines and Indonesia to Solomon Islands ranging to Palau, Australia (Northern Great Barrier Reef and Northwest Shelf) and New Caledonia (Allen and Erdmann 2012), excluding Christmas Island. The range is extended westward to include: Yap Island, Guam, and Fongafale Island, Tuvalu. The range is extended northward to include the Ryuku Islands, Japan (Stump in prep 2014). It is found at depths ranging from 1–35 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012). The type locality is Bima, Sumbawa Island, Lesser Sunda Islands, Indonesia (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: Canthigaster papua is a component of the marine aquarium trade. It is exported from Sumatra and other parts of Indonesia, and retails for moderate prices (LiveAquaria.com accessed 05 March 2012).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. papua, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifugu reticularis is a near-shore species which is distributed from the Yellow Sea and East China Sea, Bohai Sea and the mouth of the Yangtze River at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 20 metres. It is considered a stray in the waters of Japan. It does not appear to be particularly common—it is uncommon in museum collections and is considered rare in China. There are no known species-specific threats, however, the extent to which T. reticularis is impacted by environmental degradation resulting from large-scale anthropogenic activity within its range is largely unknown. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. reticularis, but it is found in marine protected areas. Fishery management strategies implemented within its range are likely to offer a degree of protection. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu reticulatus is a is a sub-tropical species which is typically found in nearshore, surfzone environments with sandy substrates. The diet consists mainly of polychaetes, but also other food items such as gammaridean amphipods and juvenile fishes are taken (Inoue et al. 2005). The internal organs and blood are thought to be toxic (Nakabo 2002).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000's had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). Although the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. reticularis are unknown, it is likely that populations of this species are impacted by this fishery.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
 Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
Takifugu reticularis is rare in Chinese waters (Liu and Liu pers. comm. 2011). It has been recorded as a stray in Japan, and was the least abundant tetraodontid caught in a nearshore surf-zone environment in Southern Japan (Suda et al. 2004, Inoue et al. 2005). 

Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu reticularis is uncommon in museum collections and is only represented by seven lots (FishNet2 database searched March 2014).
range: In the Northwest Pacific, T. reticularis is known from the Yellow Sea and East China Sea, Bohai Sea and the mouth of the Yangtze River (Nakabo 2002, Su and Li 2002). It has been recorded as a stray in Japan (Suda et al. 2004). It is a shallow-water species which is typically found at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 20 m.
useTrade: This species does not appear to be utilized. This species is called "Amime-fugu" in Japan (Nakabo 2002).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Takifugu reticularis, however, it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. reticularis.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50 m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2009), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Lagocephalus suezensis is widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific where occasionally recorded in parts of its range. This species inhabits offshore reefs to depths of zero to 100 m. It is typically found in shallow sand surrounding reefs. There are no major threats known and this species is not utilized. It is likely found in marine protected areas throughout its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Lagocephalus suezensis is found in a variety of coastal and offshore habitats, including offshore reefs (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). It feeds on fishes, molluscs and crustaceans.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: There are no known major threats to L. suezensis. Due to its association with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss, although no such declines have been recorded. As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and Southeast Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008).
population:
Lagocephalus suezensis is occasionally found in southern Japan (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). It is considered to be common off the southern coast of Turkey (Bileceneoglu et al. 2002).

Specimens of L. suezensis are common in museum collections. It is represented by 70 lots (FishNet2 searched 4 May 2012).

Due to its association with coral reefs, this species may be experiencing population decreases due to loss of habitat.
range: Lagocephalus suezensis is widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific, from the Red Sea eastward to Vanuatu, northward to the coasts of the South China Sea (Su and Li 2002) and southern Japan (Pacific coast of the southern half of Honshu Island, Shikoku Island, Kyushu Island, and the Ryukyu islands; K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014). This species has become established in the Mediterranean, ranging westward to Antalya Bay in the Aegean Sea (Bilecenoglu 2002). It is known from depths ranging from zero to 100 metres.
useTrade: This species is not utilized. It is considered an economic burden to fishermen in the Mediterranean, who must discard them from their nets (Streftaris and Zenetos 2006).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for L. suezensis however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Sphoeroides spengleri is widely distributed in the western Atlantic from Massachusetts (USA) southward to Santa Catarina (Brazil), including the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean, at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 45 metres. It is found in a variety of coastal and island habitats including reefs, seagrass beds and turbid waters with low visibility. Sphoeroides spengleri is considered common, however not abundant, as they are generally solitary fish. This species is considered to be highly toxic, and as such is not targeted by consumption fisheries. However, it is taken as bycatch in shrimp trawl fisheries in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for S. spengleri, however its distribution overlaps several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Sphoeroides spengleri is a coastal, diurnal, generally solitary species which is found in shallow waters over reefs and in seagrass beds to depths of about 45 m. Juvenile S. spengleri feed primarily on amphipods and isopods, and later feed on brachyuran crabs, bivalves, and gastropods. It is also known to feed on the highly toxic zooanthid Palythoa caribaeorum, and may help regulate the abundance of this aggressively competitive species (Francini-Filho and de Moura 2010). Partitioning of food resources enables S. spengleri to coexist with S. testudineus (Targett 1978). Food partitioning also allows S. spengleri to coexist with S. dorsalis—S. spengleri feeds primarily on amphipods at all size classes, while S. dorsalis's diet changes from primarily amphipods as juveniles to primarily pagurid hermit crabs as adults (Gathof 1981).

The toxicity of the skin and viscera of S. spengleri has been confirmed, and it may be one of the most toxic species found in Atlantic waters (Oliveira et al. 2003). Visual census of three islands of Itaipu, Southeast Brazil showed this species to be numerically dominant in habitats characterized by low structural complexity and low visibility (Mendonça-Neto et al. 2008).

Sphoeroides spengleri displays a high tolerance for disruption and is frequently associated with high turbidity and disturbance areas, such as dredging channels (Ribeiro da Silva et al. 2012). There are no species-specific data concerning the length at maturity or spawning season for for Sphoeroides spengleri , but the closely related Sphoeroides testudineus has a maturity length of 13.0 cm and spawns in the late spring to fall, with heaviest spawning periods occurring during the summer (Vega-Cendejas et al. 2012, Targett 1978).

The genus Sphoeroides was found to be paraphyletic and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no major threats known to this species. This species has been recorded in the bycatch of the Florida Shrimp roller-frame trawl fishery, which operates in seagrass beds (Crawford et al. 2011). Although no measurable decrease in population numbers has been observed, S. spengleri may be experiencing population decreases due to loss of reef and seagrass habitat. One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Yhreatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

In the US Caribbean, which include 3,040 km2 of coral reef area, 21% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 31% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

In the Northern Caribbean, which includes 9,800 km2 of coral reef area, 12% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 13% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson and Souter 2008).

In Central America, which includes 9,800 km2 of coral reef area, 12% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 13% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson and Souter 2008).
population:
Sphoeroides spengleri is considered to be common but not abundant through its range. It is found at low densities on reefs. In 1978, this species was considered to be common in the shallow seagrass beds along the south Florida coastline (Targett 1978). This species is considered common in São Paulo coastal waters (Oliveira et al. 2003) and was found to be more abundant in habitats characterized by low structural complexity and high turbidity (Mendonça-Neto et al. 2008). Due to its affinity with seagrasses and reefs, this fish may be experiencing population decreases because of lost habitat.

NOAA unpublished seasonal survey data from 1987–2010 show fluctuating trends in the catch per unit effort for this species.

Sphoeroides spengleri was sighted only once in a ten month study on fish assemblages around corals near the Yucatan Peninsula (Arceo-Carranza et al. 2013).
range:
Sphoeroides spengleri is known in the western Atlantic from Massachusetts south along the U.S. coast, Bermuda, throughout the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea, and along the South American coast to Santa Catarina, Brazil. It is generally found at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 45 metres.

Sphoeroides spengleri resembles the eastern Atlantic S. marmoratus, however, it is likely that S. spengleri is restricted to the western Atlantic (Vacchi et al. 2007). Reina-Hervás recorded this species in the Mediterranean in 2004, however this record likely represents S. marmoratus.
useTrade: Sphoeroides spengleri is not utilized and is only caught unintentionally. It is considered by fishermen in Brazil to be highly toxic (Oliveira et al. 2003). This species may occasionally appear in the Brazilian aquarium trade (Monteiro-Neto et al. 2003).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for S. spengleri. However, its distribution overlaps several marine protected areas and there are confirmed presences of Sphoeroides spengleri in multiple marine protected areas in the Gulf of Mexico (Harter and David 2010). Bycatch-reduction devices implemented in the Florida roller-frame trawl fishery may reduce the bycatch of this species in the penaeid shrimp fisheries operating in seagrass beds (Crawford et al. 2011).

rationale: In China, Takifugu coronoidus is a coastal species which is distributed from Chongming (Shanghai), Shazhou, Haimen and Nantong (Jiangsu), down to southern Guangdong Province. It is found at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 10 metres, and inhabits river mouths and estuaries. There is little population information available, and there are no known species-specific threats, however the extent to which T. coronoidus is impacted by environmental degradation resulting from large-scale anthropogenic activity within its range is largely unknown. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for T. coronoidus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern, pending additional population information. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods, in addition to further research on the life history, habitat and ecology of this species.
habitat:
Takifugu coronoidus is a demersal species which lives in brackish water and feeds on molluscs, crustaceans, and fishes. This species spawns in May (Su and Li 2002).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in T. coronoidus. However, it is likely to be impacted by the following:

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). The species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. coranoidus are unknown, however it is likely to be taken as bycatch.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional Threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea, all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
Molecular analyses of the whole mitochondrial genome of the genus Takifugu revealed that the genetic differences between T. orbimaculatus, T. coronoidus, T. fasciatus, and T. obscurus are not significantly different from the genetic differences between individuals within the species T. coronoidus, reinforcing the need for further taxonomic studies of the genus using molecular and morphological techniques (Yamanoue et al. 2009). Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005).

Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu coronoidus is a rare species throughout its distribution in China. Takifugu coronoidus was not found in a search of available museum collection databases (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2014-06-14).
range: Takifugu coronoidus is found off the coast of China in the lower reaches and mouths of rivers such as the Chongming (Shanghai), Shazhou, Haimen and Nantong (Jiangsu), down to southern Guangdong Province (Wu et al. 1999). It is found at depths ranging from zero to 10 metres. This species is limited to the coasts of lower reaches and estuaries of Yangzi River (Su and Li 2002).
useTrade:
There is no use and trade information available for this species, however many Takifugu species, although not targeted, are incidentally caught. Takifugu spp. are primarily caught by bottom long-line fishing (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011).

Aquaculture
There is currently no evidence that this species is artificially cultured. Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009). The total wild catch of pufferfish species in Japan has been relatively stable, ranging from 7,800 to 11,000 tonnes from 1995 to 2002. The four most common species consumed in Japan are T. rubripes, T. snyderi, T. chinensis, and T. porphyreus. Aquaculture efforts focus on T. rubripes, which ranks fifth among marine aquacultured species (the top aquacultured species in Japan are: Yellowtail (Seriola quinqueradiata), Red Sea Bream (Pagrus major), coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and Japanese flounder (Paralichthys olivaceus). Although highly valuable (the market price of T. rubripes is 1.5 times that of Japanese flounder, three times that of yellowtail or seabream), the value began to decrease rapidly from the late 1990s onwards due to importation of Tiger puffer from China. In Japan, the majority of fingerlings produced in commercial hatcheries are then raised in floating net cages for direct consumption. About 15 million fingerlings are produced by commercial hatcheries for aquaculture, 1.5 times higher than the amount produced for release for stock enhancement by semi-governmental hatcheries in 1999. One of the most serious problems in the net cage aquaculture of tiger puffer is high (over 50%) mortality from outbreaks of parasitic diseases (Ogawa and Inouye 1997).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Takifugu coronoidus, however it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. coranoidus.

Fugu Fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further Research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Canthigaster axiologus was formally described in 2008, and is distributed from Japan to New South Wales, east to the Marshall Islands and Tonga. It has also been recorded from Western Australia, from Exmouth Gulf northwards. Canthigaster axiologus is associated with coral reefs, and inhabits sheltered areas in open sand and rubble bottoms at depths of 1 to 30 meters. Canthigaster axiologus is morphologically similar to C. coronata, a popular aquarium species, and may be experiencing population declines as a result of harvesting for the marine aquarium trade. However, at present time there are no indications of such population declines. There have been no documented population declines in C. axiologus, however due to its affinity with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. axiologus, and its distribution overlaps with several  marine protected areas in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of harvest levels for the aquarium trade.
habitat:
Canthigaster axiologus is a reef-associated species which has been collected from shallow waters near outer reefs (FishNet2 searched 30 March 2012). Canthigaster axiologus is typically found in sheltered areas of seaward reefs, often on open sand and rubble bottom near reefs (Randall et al. 2008, Allen and Erdmann 2012).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. axiologus available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves  the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. axiologa may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

Additionally, this species closely resembles C. coronata, a popular aquarium species, and may be experiencing population declines from harvesting.
population:
Canthigaster axiologus was formally described in 2008. It has been described as being far less abundant than C. coronata (Randall et al. 2008). It is seen occasionally in Taiwan (Shao pers. comm. 2011).

Specimens of C. axiologus are rare in museum collections due to its recent description (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. axiologus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Canthigaster axiologus is distributed from the east Indian region to Tonga and the islands of Micronesia, ranging south to Australia (southern Queensland, New South Wales, and Western Australia) and north to Japan and the coasts of Taiwan (Su and Li 2002, recorded as C. coronata). It is found at depths ranging from 10–80 metres. The type locality is near the Capricorn Group, Queensland, Australia. (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: We infer that due to the popularity of the morphologically similar C. coronata, C. axiologus is also a popular aquarium species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. axiologus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifugu plagiocellatus is known only from one locality in Hainan Island, China. It inhabits seagrass and coral reef habitats at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 10 metres. It was recently described and is only known only from four specimens. There is currently no reason to question the taxonomic validity of this species. AOO was calculated using ArcGIS based on a bathymetric clip of 1-10 m depth range from the ETOPO global relief model. Takifugu plagiocellatus has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 259 km2 and is known from one location. Additionally, degradation of seagrass and coral reef habitat has been reported within this species' known range. Therefore Takifugu plagiocellatus is assessed as Endangered under Criteria B2ab(iii). We strongly recommend further research on its population status, life history characteristics and monitoring of its population and habitat status. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takigugu plagiocellatus is a little known, shallow water coastal species which inhabits coral reefs and seagrass areas at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 10 m (Liu Jing pers. comm. 2011).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in T. plagiocellatus. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, we infer that it may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.This little known species is likely threatened by coral reef and seagrass habitat losses. As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and Southeast Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008). One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

In addition, T. plagiocellatus may be impacted by the following:

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). Although the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. plagiocellatus are unknown, it is likely that populations of this commercially important species are impacted by this fishery.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Because culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea, all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967 Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu plagiocellatus was described in 2002 from four specimens (one holotype and three paratypes), which were collected from Xincun, Hainan Province, China.

Coral habitat degradation has been recorded from Hainan Island, China, the one locality where this species is found (need pers. comm).

Takifugu plagiocellatus is rare in museum collections. No specimens were found in a search of museum collection records. There have been no confirmed population declines in T. plagiocellatus. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, we infer that it may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Takifugu plagiocellatus is only found from Hainan Island, China. It has been recorded at depths ranging from 1–10 metres (Su and Li 2002). The estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of this species is 259 km2.
useTrade:
There is no use and trade information available for this species. Other species of the genus are components of the marine aquarium trade.

Aquaculture
There is no evidence that this species is artificially cultured. Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009). The total wild catch of pufferfish species in Japan has been relatively stable, ranging from 7,800 to 11,000 tonnes from 1995 to 2002. The four most common species consumed in Japan are T. rubripes, T. snyderi, T. chinensis, and T. porphyreus. Aquaculture efforts focus on T. rubripes, which ranks 5fifth among marine aquacultured species (the top aquacultured species in Japan are: Yellowtail (Seriola quinqueradiata), Red Sea Bream (Pagrus major), coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and Japanese flounder (Paralichthys olivaceus). Although highly valuable (the market price of T. rubripes is 1.5 times that of Japanese flounder, three times that of yellowtail or seabream), the value began to decrease rapidly from the late 1990s onwards due to importation of Tiger puffer from China. In Japan, the majority of fingerlings produced in commercial hatcheries are then raised in floating net cages for direct consumption. About 15 million fingerlings are produced by commercial hatcheries for aquaculture, 1.5 times higher than the amount produced for release for stock enhancement by semi-governmental hatcheries in 1999. One of the most serious problems in the net cage aquaculture of tiger puffer is high (>50%) mortality from outbreaks of parasitic diseases (Ogawa and Inouye 1997).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Takifugu plagiocellatus, however it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. plagiocellatus.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Canthigaster margaritata is endemic to the Red Sea. It inhabits a variety of shallow-water, reef-associated habitats at depths ranging from 0 to 24 metres, and can be common and locally abundant in parts of its range. Canthigaster margaritata is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. margaritata, however due to its affinity with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. margaritata, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of harvest levels for the aquarium trade.
habitat:
Canthigaster margaritata is a reef-associated species which is common in tide pools near reefs and in shallow reef areas. It is also known to colonize artificial reefs. This species is a facultative corallivore, ingesting skeletal material and including soft coral in its diet (Cole et al. 2008). The filefish Paraluteres arqat mimics this species in the Red Sea (Randall 2005).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. margaritata available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Although C. margaritata appears to be abundant and widespread, it may be experiencing localized population declines as a result of habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). In the Red Sea, which includes 17640 km2  of coral reef area, 4% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while another 4% are at a critical stage with 50-90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

This species is a component of the international marine aquarium trade. The effect of this trade on the population of C. margaritata.
population:
Canthigaster margaritata appears to be widespread and common in parts of its range. Canthigaster margaritata was found to be moderately abundant on vertical artificial reef structures, such as on the oil jetties of Eilat, off the coast of Israel in the northern Red Sea (Rilov and Benayahu 2000). Surveys conducted on a small, near shore artificial reef over muddy/silty substrate in the Gulf of Elat revealed this species to be relatively rare in abundance (Golani and Diamant 1999).

Specimens of C. margaritata are very common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).
range: Canthigaster margaritata is endemic to the Red Sea (Allen and Randall 1977). It is found at depths ranging from 0–24 metres.
useTrade: Canthigaster margaritata is a component of the marine aquarium trade. It is exported from India as an ornamental species, with a projected annual yield of 46,000 individuals in 2008 off the Lakshaweep Islands, India (Gopakumar 2008). It is also exported from Saudi Arabia and the Red Sea (PERSGA/GEF 2004).
conservationActions: Canthigaster margaritata has been designated an important predator species in the Red Sea, and it is recommended that it not be exported in large numbers (PERSGA/GEF 2004). The distribution of C. margaritata overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Canthigaster bennetti is widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific and appears to be common in parts of its range. Canthigaster bennetti is a reef-associated species which inhabits inner reef flats and sheltered lagoons at depths of 1 to 30 meters. Canthigaster bennetti is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. bennetti, however due to its affinity with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. bennetti, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of harvest levels for the aquarium trade.
habitat:
Canthigaster bennetti is a reef-associated species which inhabits inner reef flats and sheltered lagoons. It is a common inshore species which is often found on algal or silty reefs and among attached Sargassum on shallow rubble flats (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001), as well as near artificial reefs. This species feeds mainly on filamentous green algae and to a lesser extent on fleshy and coralline red algae and benthic invertebrates. Canthigaster bennetti forms monogamous pairs, although alternative mating systems have been observed. Parental care is maternal and males and females maintain separate territories (Whiteman and Côte 2004). Single-species schools of over 10,000 individual C. bennetti have been observed off Sulawesi at depths of 7–30 m, accompanied by mass mortalities (Vail and Sinclair-Taylor 2011).

Canthigaster bennetti forms monogamous pairs, although alternative mating systems have been observed. Parental care is maternal and males and females maintain separate territories (Whiteman and Côte 2004). Species-specific observations of this species during reproduction have not been observed. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster.
