It is found at depths ranging from 0–16 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: Canthigaster amboinensis is a component the marine aquarium trade. Records from Hawaii show that from 1967–2003, 3271 individuals of this species were collected for export at a value of $3,339.65 USD (not adjusted for inflation) (Walsh et al. 2003). Canthigaster amboinensis is also exported from the Solomon Islands (Kinch 2004).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. amboinensis, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifugu variomaculatus is known only from one locality at the mouth of the Pear River, China, where it was collected in shallow water ranging in depth from one to 15 metres. The estimated area of occupancy (AOO) for this species is 5,249 km2. AOO was calculated using ArcGIS based on a bathymetric clip of 1-20 m depth range from the ETOPO global relief model, and included the entire Pearl River Delta.  It is only known from seven specimens, and habitat degradation due to urban development, industrial effluents, and agricultural runoff is occurring in its entire known range. There is little species-specific information concerning the suitable habitat, ecology, population status or life history of this species and it is poorly sampled. Therefore, it is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
Takifugu variomaculatus is an estuarine species which is morphologically similar to T. ocellatus but differs in its habitat selection. Morphological intermediaries between T. variomaculatus and T. ocellatus have been recorded (YuBo and ShunPing 2008).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
The Pearl River is a heavily developed area, housing over nine million people and is heavily polluted due to agricultural and industrial development (Cheung et al. 2003). Additionally, this species is morphologically similar to the commercially-important T. ocellatus, and is likely to be harvested in fisheries targeting this species.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). This species does not appear to be explicitly targeted by fisheries, and the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. variomaculatus are unknown. It may be taken as bycatch.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Because culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aquacultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
Takifugu variomaculatus is known only from seven specimens (Su and Li 2002), the holotype and six paratypes. Molecular analyses of the whole mitochondrial genome of the genus Takifugu revealed that the genetic differences between T. variomaculatus and T. ocellatus, are not significantly different from the genetic differences between individuals within the species T. ocellatus, reinforcing the need for further taxonomic studies of the genus using molecular and morphological techniques (Yamanoue et al. 2009).

Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).
range: Takifugu variomaculatus is known only known from the mouth of the Pearl River, where it was collected at depths ranging from one to 15 metres. This species resembles T. ocellatus and only lives in the estuaries of the Zhujang river canals (Su and Li 2002). The estimated area of occupancy (AOO) for this species is 5,249 km2, calculated using a 1–20 m depth layer.
useTrade:
There is no use and trade information available for this species. The morphologically similar congener T. ocellatus is a commercially important food fish, therefore it is inferred that T. variomaculatus is likely to be taken as incidental catch in pufferfish fisheries throughout its range.

Takifugu ocellatus is a popular food fish in China and fetches a premium price owing to its high quality meat (Chen 2005). This species is also found in the ornamental aquarium trade. Takifugu chinensis, like other fugu species, is primarily caught by bottom long-line fishing, a method which is highly effective at landing Takifugu spp. pufferfishes (K. Matsuura pers comm. 2011).

Aquaculture
Mass culture of T. ocellatus has developed rapidly in China (Yang and Chen 2008) and in South Korea (Liu Jing and K. Matsuura pers comm. 2011), where this species is cultured primarily for local consumption (Yu 2003). Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia.

Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations, which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. variomaculatus, however it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. variomaculatus.

Fugu Fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012). Following the ratification of the UN Convention of the Law of the Sea, Japan implemented the Total Allowable Effort (TAE) system in Ise Bay and Mikawa Bay (Hoshino 2010). Stock enhancement programs exist for this species in Japan using hatchery raised fingerlings (Fushimi 2001). Optimal release locations have been determined (Nakajima et al. 2008), however it has been found that hatchery-reared juveniles were more easily preyed upon than wild juveniles due to differences in swimming depth and TTX concentrations (Shimizu et al. 2008).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50 m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further Research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2009), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Canthigaster capistrata is distributed in the eastern central Atlantic, where it is known from oceanic islands including the Canarian Archipelago in Macaronesia, Cape Verde Island, and Madiera, and has been recorded in the Straight of Gibraltar. It appears to be both common and locally abundant. Canthigaster capistrata inhabits rocky reef habitats and artificial structures at depths ranging from 0 to 20 metres. Canthigaster capistrata may be a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. capistrata. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. capistrata, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Canthigaster capistrata is a bentho-demersal meso-carnivore usually found as solitary individuals. It is associated with rocky reefs consisting of boulders, vertical walls, platform and outcroppings which are often colonized by various algae, and can also be found associated with artificial reefs. Canthigaster capistrata has been known to colonize sea-cage fish farms after the cessation of fish farming (Tuya et al. 2006). This species frequently preys on Diadema aff. antillarum and other echinoderms and is important in regulating the populations of herbivorous urchins in sublittoral rocky reefs (Clemente et al. 2010).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. capistrata available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no major threats known for C. capistrata. Due to its affinity with reef structures, this fish may be experiencing population decline.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population:
Canthigaster capistrata is an abundant echinoderm predator found in the macroalgal beds of the subtropical Canarian Archipelago, as well as in other areas of Macaronesia (Clemente et al. 2010). In the waters off Madeira Island, this species was among the 10 most abundant species sampled over rocky reefs. It was recorded common and abundant in the locations studied along the south coast of Madeira Island (both protected and non-protected) and did not show significant differences in any size categories within locations in all types of bottom studied (Ribeiro 2008).

Specimens of C. capistrata are moderately common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).
range: In the eastern central Atlantic, Canthigaster capistrata is known from oceanic islands including the Canarian Archipelago in Macaronesia (Clemente et al. 2010), Cape Verde Islands (Brito et al. 2007) and Madeira (Ribeiro 2008). This species has been reported in the Straight of Gibraltar (Brito et al. 2007). Canthigaster capistrata may be extending its range northward due to warming ocean temperatures (Wirtz 2005). It is found at depths ranging from 0–20 metres.
useTrade: This species has been identified as a potential aquarium species from Portuguese waters (Calado 2006).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. capistrata, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifugu pardalis is known from Japan, China and from the northwestern Pacific Ocean where it is common in parts of its range and can be locally abundant. It is a coastal species which can be found over rocky, sandy, or muddy substrates and in the vicinity of seagrass beds. Takifugu pardalis is incidentally harvested and marketed as a food fish; however, there does not appear to be a targeted fishery for this species. There are no known species-specific threats to T. pardalis, and its distribution overlaps several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu pardalis is a temperate, coastal, demersal species over rocky (Yamada et al. 1995), sandy, or muddy bottoms as well as in seagrass beds at depths ranging from very shallow to 20 metres. In the Zostera marina beds off central Japan, juveniles of this species feed mainly on gammaridean and caprellidean amphipods, while adults feed mainly on hard-shelled animals such as gastropods, bivalves and crabs (Horinouchi and Sano 2000). Individuals of this species were more likely to be found in the sandy microhabitat near seagrass beds, as opposed to in the beds themselves (Horinouchi 2009). The ovaries and liver are extremely toxic, the skin and intestine are highly toxic, the testes are slightly toxic, and the flesh is generally believed to be innocuous. However, some specimens have been found to be toxic (Nakabo 2002).

This species spawns demersal eggs. In the Yangtze River estuary, this species is known to spawn from May to June, May to July and April to June (Ruijing et al. 2010). 

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Takifugu pardalis may be threatened by coastal habitat degradation and overfishing in parts of its range. 

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). Although the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. xanthopterus are unknown, it is likely that populations of this commercially important species are impacted by this fishery.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea, all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
Takifugu pardalis is most closely related to T. chrysops (Yamanoue et al. 2008). Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu pardalis is common and can be locally abundant in Japan (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011), however it is not common in parts of China (Liu Jing pers. comm. 2011). Takfugu pardalis is moderately common in museum collections, and was represented by 45 lots (FishNet2 database searched December 2013).
range: In the Northwest Pacific, T. pardalis is known from the lower course and mouth area of the Tumen River at the border of Russia and China (Oksyuzyan and Sokolovsky 2003) south to the Bohai and Yellow seas (Su and Li 2002). It is found at depths ranging from one to 20 metres.
useTrade:
Takifugu pardalis is incidentally caught, but is not targeted by consumptive fisheries. It is called "Higan-fugu" in Japan (Nakabo 2002). Takifugu pardalis, like other Fugu species, is primarily caught by bottom long-line fishing, a method which is very efficient in catching this species (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Despite a ban on the sale of toxic pufferfishes in fish markets, T. pardalis may sometimes found in processed fish products in Taiwan (Huang et al. 2014).

Aquaculture
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009). The total wild catch of pufferfish species in Japan has been relatively stable, ranging from 7,800 to 11,000 tonnes from 1995 to 2002. The four most common species consumed in Japan are T. rubripes, T. snyderi, T. chinensis, and T. porphyreus. Aquaculture efforts focus on T. rubripes, which ranks fifth among marine aquacultured species (the top aquacultured species in Japan are: Yellowtail (Seriola quinqueradiata), Red Sea Bream (Pagrus major), coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and Japanese flounder (Paralichthys olivaceus). Although highly valuable (the market price of T. rubripes is 1.5 times that of Japanese flounder, three times that of yellowtail or seabream), the value began to decrease rapidly from the late 1990s onwards due to importation of Tiger puffer from China. In Japan, the majority of fingerlings produced in commercial hatcheries are then raised in floating net cages for direct consumption. About 15 million fingerlings are produced by commercial hatcheries for aquaculture, 1.5 times higher than the amount produced for release for stock enhancement by semi-governmental hatcheries in 1999. One of the most serious problems in the net cage aquaculture of tiger puffer is high (over 50%) mortality from outbreaks of parasitic diseases (Ogawa and Inouye 1997).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Takifugu pardalis, however it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. pardalis.

Fugu Fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further Research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Canthigaster natalensis is known in the western Indian Ocean from Mozambique to South Africa and La Réunion, east to the Changos archipelago. It is found in shallow waters at depths ranging from 0 to 15 metres, and appears to be closely associated with shallow coral reef flats and tidepools. Canthigaster natalensis may be threatened by habitat loss, however this is not thought to reach the thresholds for a threatened category. Canthigaster natalensis is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Canthigaster natalensis is a coral reef associated, demersal species found in shallow water. It has been collected from tidepools and reef flats (FishNet2 search 26 March 2012).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. natalensis available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves  the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988 Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Due to its association with coral reefs, C. natalensis may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

In the southwestern Indian Ocean, which includes 5,270 km2  of coral reef area, 9% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 24% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

Mauritius and La Réunion have experienced declines in mean coral cover which have continued from 2004–2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008). In La Réunion, native fish fauna are threatened by eutrophication and pollution, overfishing and poaching, by marine aquaculture, and by shoreline construction (Fricke et al. 2009).
population:
There is no species-specific population information available for C. natalensis. Specimens of C. natalensis are uncommon in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012). The majority of collected specimens (17 of 21 total located specimens, 80.9% (FishNet2 Database search 26 March 2012)) were collected at shallow depths from La Réunion and Mauritius, which are areas of continuing coral decline (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. natalensis may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Canthigaster natalensis is found in the western Indian Ocean, and is distributed from Mozambique and South Africa to La Réunion and Mauritius, east to the Chagos Archipelago (Fricke 1999, 2009). It is found at depths ranging from 0–15 metres.
useTrade: This species does not appear to be utilized. Many fishes of the genus Canthigaster are found in the marine aquarium trade, however there does not appear to be any interest in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. natalensis, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifufu chrysops is endemic to Japan where it is common in parts of its range (i.e., Sagami Bay). It inhabits sandy and rocky reefs at depths ranging from two to 30 metres. This species is incidentally caught, but is not targeted. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. chrysops, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. There are no known species-specific threats, but the extent to which T. chrysops is impacted by environmental degradation resulting from large-scale anthropogenic activity within its range is largely unknown. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu chrysops inhabits rocky reefs and sandy bottoms at depths ranging from two to 30 metres. It reaches a total length of 30 cm (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). The spawning period for Takifugu chrysops extends from mid to late May in the eastern part of Sagami Bay (Fujita and Shinohara 1986). This species has been reared in laboratory conditions (Fujita and Shinohara 1986). The liver is known to contain concentrations of tetrodotoxin (Matsumoto et al. 2011). The ovaries, liver and skin are highly toxic, the intestine slightly toxic, and the flesh and testes innocuous (Nakabo 2002).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in T. chrysops. However, it is likely to be impacted by the following:

Fugu fishery
 The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). Although the species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. chrysops are unknown, it is likely that populations of this commercially important species are impacted by this fishery.

Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005). In addition, increasing coastal water temperatures near Japan (Nakano et al. 1996) may be displacing this species.
population:
Takifugu chrysops is most closely related to T. pardalis. Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu chrysops is locally common, particularly in Sagami Bay (K. Matsuura pers comm. 2011).

Takifugu chrysops is moderately common in museum collections, represented by 15 lots (FishNet2 database searched December 2013). Tokyo museum collections recorded 19 lots. It appears not to be uncommon (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011).
range: Takifugu chrysops is found on the Pacific coast of southern Japan, from Tokyo Bay to Tosa Bay (Masuda et al. 1984). It is found at depths ranging from two to 30 metres.
useTrade:
Takifugu chrysops is incidentally caught but not explicitly targeted in parts of its range. In Japan, it is called "Akame-fugu". Takifugu chrysops, like other Fugu species, is primarily caught by bottom long-line fishing, a method which is highly effective at landing Takifugu spp. pufferfishes (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011).

Aquaculture
There is currently no evidence that this species is artificially cultured. Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009). The total wild catch of pufferfish species in Japan has been relatively stable, ranging from 7,800 to 11,000 tonnes from 1995 to 2002. The four most common species consumed in Japan are T. rubripes, T. snyderi, T. chinensis, and T. porphreus. Aquaculture efforts focus on T. rubripes, which ranks fifth among marine aquacultured species (the top aquacultured species in Japan are: Yellowtail (Seriola quinqueradiata), Red Sea Bream (Pagrus major), coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and Japanese flounder (Paralichthys olivaceus). Although highly valuable (the market price of T. rubripes is 1.5 times that of Japanese flounder, three times that of yellowtail or seabream), the value began to decrease rapidly from the late 1990s onwards due to importation of Tiger puffer from China. In Japan, the majority of fingerlings produced in commercial hatcheries are then raised in floating net cages for direct consumption. About 15 million fingerlings are produced by commercial hatcheries for aquaculture, 1.5 times higher than the amount produced for release for stock enhancement by semi-governmental hatcheries in 1999. One of the most serious problems in the net cage aquaculture of tiger puffer is high (over 50%) mortality from outbreaks of parasitic diseases (Ogawa and Inouye 1997).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Takifugu chrysops. However, it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. chysops.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Arothron hispidus is widely distributed in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. It is associated with a variety of habitats including coral reefs, rocky reefs, coastal bays and estuaries, at depths ranging from 3 to at least 50 metres. It appears to be common in parts of its range. Arothron hispidus is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for A. hispidus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This species inhabits outer reef slopes, inner reef flats, and lagoons to depths of at least 50 metres. Juveniles are common in weedy areas of estuaries (Smith and Heemstra 1986) and in mangroves (G. Hardy pers. comm. 2011). It is also found in coastal bays and estuaries, usually near rocky reef or on sand-stretches between reefs with low algae-rubble reef to about 20 metres depth, or in shallow areas with sparse seagrass growth (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). It is usually solitary and territorial (Allen and Erdmann 2012). It feeds on a variety of species including algae, detritus, molluscs, tunicates, sponges, corals (Cole et al. 2008), zooanthid anemones, crabs, tube worms and echinoderms (Myers 1991), although it is primarily carnivorous (Pinto and Punchihewa 1996). It is known to prey on the Crown-of-Thorns Starfish, Acanthagaster plankii, and may provide ecosystem services by regulating the population of this destructive starfish (McCallum 1987). The skin, testes, liver, and ovaries are toxic (Nakabo 2002).

Fishes of the genus Arothron are widely distributed throughout the tropical regions of the Indo-western Pacific. Species have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads,  and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in A. hispidus. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs, seagrass beds, mangroves and estuaries we infer that A. hispidus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. Additionally, A. hispidus may be experiencing population declines as a result of harvesting for human consumption as part of the pufferfish trade.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-East Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or near-threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).

Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses in this area, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004).

The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004),  In the lower Yangze River basin it is also likely to be impacted by anthropogenic activities including dam construction and other hydrological alterations, land reclamation, exotic species introductions, eutrophication, rapid sedimentation, deforestation and land erosion (Fu et al. 2003).

Since the 1960s, more than 100,000 ha of Japanese coastal land has been reclaimed for use as new commercial and industrial areas. This has resulted in the denudation of the coastal ecosystem in certain areas.During this period, the ratio of natural seacoast has declined rapidly to 55% for the whole of the Japanese seacoast line, and under 10% in the Tokyo, Osaka and Hiroshima Bay regions (Terawaki et al. 2003)
population: There have been no confirmed population declines in this species. This species appears to be common in parts of its range. It is moderately abundant in Hong Kong waters (Sadovy and Cornish 2000) where it is commonly found in summer months (Yu 2003). Small juveniles are common in mangrove estuaries on the Queensland coast (G. Hardy pers. comm. 2011). Specimens are very common in museum collections (FishNet2, searched 2012–03–28). Due to its affinity with coral reefs and sea grasses, A. hispidus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Arothron hispidus is widespread in the Indo-Pacific, from the Red Sea and East Africa (Smith and Heemstra 1986) to the Pacific coast of southern Japan and the Hawaiian Islands and Tuamotu islands, south to Lord Howe and Rapa islands, east to Baja California and Panama (Bussing 1995, Allen and Robertson 1994, Allen and Erdmann 2012). In China, this species is found in Hong Kong waters, the Pearl River, Penghu Islands, Taiwan Strait, around Taiwan Island, Xisha Islands, and Sanya (Hainan Island) (Su and Li 2002). It is found at depths ranging from 1–50 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade:
This species is a component of the marine aquarium trade (BlueZooaquatics.com, Saltwaterfish.com). It is also used as a cleaning fish in marine culture tanks and cages.

Arothron hispidus was a component of a Japanese study which sought to distinguish between the flesh of different species of pufferfishes marketed for human consumption using genetic markers. It is therefore inferred that this species is consumed in Japan and is commercially traded there (Ishizaki et al. 2006).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for A. hispidus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas (World Database of Protected Areas 2010).

Highly-effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia (Kawata 2012).

The Japanese name for this species is Hoshi-fugu. In Japan, fugu are caught primarily using modified longlines which are attractive to novice fishermen due to their ease of use. 

The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program.

Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

rationale: Canthigaster investigatoris is a rare species known from two syntypes collected off the Andaman Islands in 1910 at depths exceeding 100 m. Based on the limited information available on its population status and life history characteristics, it is therefore listed as Data Deficient. We recommend further research on its population status and general biology.
habitat:
Canthigaster investigatoris is a demersal species. There is little species-specific habitat information available for this species.

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. investigatoris available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in C. investigatoris. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, we infer that C. investigatoris may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population:
Canthigaster investigatoris is a rare, deep-water species (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). This species is known from two syntypes collected in 1910 off the Andaman Islands in the Indian Ocean (Allen and Randall 1977).

Specimens of C. investigatoris are rare in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).
range: Canthigaster investigatoris is known from the Andaman Islands and appears to have a limited local distribution (Allen and Randall 1977). It has been collected at 100-160 m depth (Allen and Randall 1977).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. investigatoris.

rationale: Torquigener flavimaculosus is found in the western Indian Ocean from the northern Red Sea to the Persian Gulf, and south to Kenya to the Seychelles and Madagascar. It is found at depths ranging from three to 57 metres. While there are no population data available, and very little habitats and ecology information, it is not suspected to have any major threats. Also, the wide range of this species overlaps many marine protected areas and the is undergoing expansion and has become a recent emigrant to the Persian Gulf, Mediterranean and Aegean Seas via the Suez Canal. This species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Torquigener flavimaculosus is often found occurring near reefs, and is common in seagrass beds (Khalaf et al. 2012). Torquigener flavimaculosus is a marine, reef-associated species that occurs in tropical waters at depths between three and 57 metres. Maximum total length for this species is 13.0 cm or 130 mm male/unsexed (Randall 1995). Torquigener flavimaculosus is a demersal species which sometimes exhibits burrowing behaviour (Bilecenoğlu 2005). It occurs over soft bottoms and feeds on marine invertebrates (Carpenter et al. 1997, Chinese Academy of Fishery Sciences 2003).

Tetraodontidae
Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough, scaleless skin often covered with small spicules, beak-like dental place divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single short dorsal fin, a single shore anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or injured, and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, or liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no major threats known to this species. However, due to its affinity with seagrass beds and coral reefs, it may be experiencing population declines. As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, south and southeast Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

In the Persian Gulf, T. flavimaculosus is caught as bycatch in trawls and traps (Carpenter et al. 1997).
population: There is no population information available for this species. However, it does seem to be fairly common, but not abundant. Although there have been no confirmed population declines with this species, it may be in decline due to its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds. In the Persian Gulf, this species is fairly common in museum collections and has been recorded with abundance from Israel (Accessed through the Fishnet 2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2014–02–12).
range: Torquigener flavimaculosus is a reef-associated species found at depths of three to 57 metres in the western Indian Ocean, from east Africa to the Seychelles, in the Red Sea and Persian Gulf (Randall 1995). It has also been recorded in Madagascar (Gillibrand et al. 2007). This species is a Lessepsian immigrant to the eastern Mediterranean via the Suez Canal (Golani et al. 2006). It was first recorded in Haifa Bay in Israel in 1987 (Golani 1987), along the Turkish Mediterranean coast (Golani et al. 2006) at Fethiye, Turkey (Bilecenoğlu 2005), and at Yalissos, Trianda Bay, Greece (Corsini-Foka 2006).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species' wide range most likely overlaps several marine protected areas. The current known range for this species is undergoing expansion through the Red Sea and up through to the eastern Mediterranean and Aegean seas. This is one of many species being introduced to the Mediterranean Sea after the construction of the Suez Canal.

rationale: Canthigaster smithae is found in the western Indian Ocean and appears to be uncommon. It inhabits a variety of coral reef-associated habitats at depths ranging from 20 to 37 metres. There have been no documented population declines in C. smithae, however due to its affinity with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. smithae, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Canthigaster smithae inhabits outer reef slopes (Lieske and Myers 1994). It is found on clear inner reefs, often on slopes near bases of steep walls with mixed rubble and boulders in depths of about 30 metres (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. smithae available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves  the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in C. smithae. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs, we infer that C. smithae may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

In the southwestern Indian Ocean, which includes 5,270 km2 of coral reef area, 9% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 24% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Declines in mean coral cover have been recorded in Mauritius and La Réunion (Wilkinson et al. 2008). In La Réunion, native fish fauna are threatened by eutrophication and pollution, overfishing and poaching, by marine aquaculture, and by shoreline construction (Fricke et al. 2009).

In eastern Africa, which include 6,800 km2 of coral reef area, 15% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 22% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008 2008).
population:
There is no species-specific population information available for C. smithae. Specimens of C. smithae are moderately common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. smithae may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Canthigaster smithae is distributed from East Africa and the islands of the western Indian Ocean to the Andaman Sea (Andaman Islands, Myanmar, and Thailand) and Indian Ocean coast of Sumatra, Indonesia (Allen and Erdmann 2012). It is found at depths ranging from 20–40 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012). The type locality is in Fic en Flac, Mauritius (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: This species is occasionally found in the aquarium trade, although it does not appear to be regularly available.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. smithae, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Arothron stellatus is widespread in the Indo-Pacific and appears to be common. Adults are found on clear lagoons and seaward reefs, at depths ranging from 3 to 58 metres, while juveniles are associated with coastal areas and estuaries. Arthron stellatus is a giant among pufferfishes, reaching lengths in excess of one meter. Arthron stellatus is a minor component of the marine aquarium trade, however harvest levels are unknown. Arothron stellatus is also a component of artisanal fisheries, and is incidentally taken as bycatch in several trawl fisheries. There have been no documented population declines in A. stellatus, however due to its affinity with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for A. stellatus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. Therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Arothron stellatus adults are found on clear lagoons and seaward reefs (Lieske and Myers 1994), sometimes swimming high above the substrate or just below the surface. Juveniles of this species occur inshore in sandy and weedy inner reefs, as well as over muddy substrates and in estuaries. Pelagic larvae may disperse over great distances and juveniles can be found in the subtropical zone (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). Arothron stellatus displays differences in colour pattern at various stages of growth, with bands seen on the back in very young sizes breaking up into rows of spots on older specimens (Kuthalingam et al. 1973). Arothron stellatus is a giant among puffers, reaching a total length well in excess of a meter. Arothron stellatus feeds on sea urchins, sponges, crabs, coral (Cole et al. 2008) and algae. It is known to feed on the Crown-of-Thorns Starfish (Acanthagaster planci) (Keesing and Halford 1992). Arothron stellatus possesses toxic muscle, intestine, liver and gonads (Berry and Hassan 1973). The liver and skin are toxic, the ovaries are extremely toxic (Nakabo 2002).

The maximum total length for this species is 120 cm male/unsexed (Lieske and Myers 1994). The common total length (TL) is 54.0 cm male/unsexed (Bouhlel 1988). The largest observed individual in the Persian Gulf was of this species is 55 cm TL in the Gulf.

Fishes of the genus Arothron are widely distributed throughout the tropical regions of the Indo-western Pacific. Species have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Arothron stellatus is incidentally caught in artisanal fisheries (i.e. in Sabah, Malaysia) (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). It is reportedly highly palatable if handled with care. It is called "Moyo-fugu" in Japan (Nakabo 2002). ADue to its palatable taste and demand in the artisan food markets of Japan, this species may be experiencing or may begin to experience population declines.

Arothron stellatus is incidentally taken as bycatch in the Torres Strait Prawn Fishery (Turnbull et al. 2007) and the Australian Northern Prawn Fishery (Stobutzki et al. 2001).

There have been no confirmed population declines in A. stellatus. However, because of its association with coral reefs, mangroves and sea grasses, we infer that A. stellatus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. 

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or near-threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).
population:
Arothron stellatus is common off the coast of India, where it is considered one of the three major species of pufferfishes. Total estimated pufferfish stock size off the Lakshaweep Islands (major reef of India) was 74,974 individuals in 2008. Of this stock a maximum yield was estimated as 50,783 individuals (Gopakumar 2008). Arothron stellatus is occasional to common in the waters of Taiwan (Shao pers. comm. 2011, Hsieh and Hwang 2004) and is rare in Hong Kong waters (Sadovy and Cornish 2000). 

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, A. stellatus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. In the Persian Gulf this species has been described as a common species, low abundance, widespread (Feary pers. comm. 2014). Seven specimens of Arothron stellatus were collected during a 25 minute trawl survey of the artificial reefs off Ras Al-Zoor, Kuwait on April 11, 1981. It represented 15.4 % of the total catch by weight (Downing et al. 1985). This species is very rare on reefs of Kuwait (Carpenter et al. 1997).

Specimens of A. stellatus are very common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 13 April 2012).
range: Arothron stellatus known from the Red Sea and Persian Gulf, Eastern Africa to Micronesia and the Tuamotu Archipelago, south to the Northern half of Australia to southern Japan and the Ryukyu Islands and Ogasawara Islands including the coasts of Taiwan and the South China Sea (Su and Li 2002, Allen and Erdmann 2012). The type locality is Mauritius. It is known from depths of 3–58 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: Arothron stellatus is consumed in the Japan, where it retails under the name "Shoramifugu" (Yu 2003). It is a component of the marine aquarium trade, retailing at prices ranging from $69.99–$149.95 per individual (LiveAquaria.com 2011, ReefHotSpot.com 2011, BlueZooAquatics.com 2011). It is targeted in Kenya for the marine aquarium trade (Okemwa et al. 2009). Arothron stellatus is a component of artisanal fisheries in Fiji (Adams and Dalzell 1994). This species is of no economic value in Qatar (Al-Khayat and Al-Ansi 2007). This species is not sold in the local markets, but it is dried, stretched and utilized by local fisherman (Stanley pers. comm. 2014). Between 2005 to 2011, gargoor bycatch of this species off Abu Dhabi varied from 0.2-0.7 mt per year (S. Hartmann pers. comm. 2014).
conservationActions: There are no known species specific conservation measures in place for A. stellatus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas (Krupp and Muller 1994). In the Persian Gulf this species has been observed benefit from local reef development in areas of coastal zone development where large, stable groins have been placed (D. Feary pers. comm. 2014).

rationale: Arothron reticularis is widespread in the Indo-West Pacific and appears to be fairly common. It is is a shallow-water species which occurs at depths of up to 25 metres on coral reefs, in sandy and macroalgal habitats, as well as in estuaries and muddy bays. Arothron reticularis is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population decline from harvesting at present time. Due to its association with coral reefs, mangroves, and seagrass beds it may be experiencing  localized population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for A. reticularis, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Arothron reticularis occurs among mangrove roots in estuaries, in tidal creeks, and on open sand or mud bottoms of sheltered bays at depths ranging from 1–20 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012). Juveniles of this species are found in mangroves and enter the lower reaches of streams (Kuiter and Debelius 1994, Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). Adults are found at moderate depths, often lying on the mud during the day (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). Arothron reticularis is primarily carnivorous, feeding on corals, molluscs, and other sand-dwelling invertebrates (Schroeder 1980). It also feeds on seagrass and mangroves (Pinto and Punchihewa 1996). The toxicity of this species is unknown (Nakabo 2002). It reaches a maximum size of 43 cm TL (Allen and Erdmann 2012). 

Fishes of the genus Arothron are widely distributed throughout the tropical regions of the Indo-western Pacific. Species have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in A. reticularis. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs, mangroves, and seagrass beds, we infer that A. reticularis may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or near-threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).

This species is a component of the international marine aquarium trade.
population:
Arothron reticularis appears to be common. It is abundant in brackish, muddy environments in Indonesia (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Arothron reticularis is not considered common in Labu Estuary, Papua New Guinea (Quinn and Kojis 1986). It is rare in Taiwan (K.-T. Shao pers. comm. 2011).

Specimens of A. reticularis are very common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 13 April 2012).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, mangroves, and seagrass beds, A. reticularis may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Arothron reticularis is found in the Indo-West Pacific from the east coast of India (Anguchamy et al. 2011), east to the Pacific coast of southern Japan (Nakabo 2002), south to Australia and east to Samoa.
