It has been recently recorded from Micronesia and New Caledonia (Randall et al. 2012), however it is unknown from the Solomon Islands (Allen and Erdmann 2012). The type locality is the Malabar sea, India. It is found at depths ranging from 1–20 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: Arothron reticularis is a component of the marine aquarium trade. It retails at prices of $69.95 per individual (BlueZooAquatics.com 2011). The Japanese name for this species is Womon-fugu.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for A. reticularis, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Arothron diadematus is endemic to the Red Sea. During surveys of marine ornamental fishes, this species was found to be most abundant along the coast of Egypt and is less abundant off the reefs off Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Yemen and Djibouti. Arothron diadematus inhabits coral-rich fringing reefs at depths of 5 to 30 metres, and is an omnivore known to feed on live coral. Arothron diadematus is a component of the marine ornamental trade and is exported primarily from Egypt. Exports of this species have increased from the 1990s to the 2000s, and are expected to continue increasing. There have been no observed population declines and, as of 2004,  A. diadematus has not been designated as needing protection from collectors. Arothron diadematus is also utilized in scientific research. Although there are no species-specific conservation measures in place, A. diadematus likely receives protection from established no-take zones and Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) in the region, as well as regional-level conservation initiatives aimed at protecting coral reefs. Little is known about the life history of this species and there have been no observed population declines as a result of collection for the marine aquarium trade. Further monitoring of population trends is recommended. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Arothron diadematus inhabits coral-rich fringing reefs at depths ranging from 5–30 metres (Lieske and Myers 1994), and is an omnivore that feeds on live coral often consuming whole branches at once. Stomach content analysis of one individual revealed Pocillopora, Acropora, and Millepora skeletal material (Berumen and Rotjan 2010). This species has also been found associated with artificial reef structures, such as oil platforms (Rilov and Benayahu 1998). This species may be found in the vicinity of estuaries for parts of its life cycle.

Fishes of the genus Arothron are widely distributed throughout the tropical regions of the Indo-western Pacific. Species have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads,  and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in A. diadematus. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs, we infer that A. diadematus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

In the Red Sea, which includes 17,640 km2  of coral reef area, 4% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while another 4% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

In Egypt, coastal development to accommodate expanding  tourism, which includes road construction and the discharging of waste from desalination, sewage, and wastewater treatment plants, as well as beach replenishment, increasing fishery, and the production of trash and pollutants, has negatively affected some reefs (Heisse et al. 2005). Additionally, physical damage to corals directly caused by recreational human activities is significant on some reefs (Jameson et al. 1999). As of 2008, the status of coral reefs and coral communities in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden was generally good, with coral cover averaging 30–50%. However pressures from major development for mass tourism and industrialization, over-exploitation and destructive fishing in poorly managed fisheries, Crown-of-Thorns outbreaks, and bleaching events are expected to increase (Kotb et al. 2004).

Arothron diadematus is targeted by collectors for the marine aquarium trade in Egypt, Yemen, and Saudi Arabia, and is of moderate value. Collection pressure is expected to continue to increase. Although there have been no recorded decreases in the abundance of this species, marked decreases in the abundance of other targeted species have been observed on Egyptian reefs from 1997 to 2002 (Kotb et al. 2004).
population:
This species is quite common in the Red Sea (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). In a survey of marine ornamental fishes of the Red Sea, it was found that the percentage average abundance of this species along the Egyptian coast was 67.9%, making it the second most abundant of the 50 ornamental species surveyed. This species showed higher dominance on reefs in Egypt than on those in Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Yemen and Djibouti. The frequency of  appearance on Egyptian reefs was 32.26, versus 11.11 on Jordanian reefs, 27.27 on Saudi reefs, and zero on reefs in Yemen and Djibouti (PERSGA/GEF 2004).

Surveys of corallivorous fish abundances in the Saudi Arabian Red Sea revealed a relatively low density of A. diadematus (0.75 fish per 500 m2) although individuals were observed at 11 of 20 sites (Berumen and Rotjan 2010).

Specimens of A. diadematus are moderately common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 2012–03–28).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, A. diadematus may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Arothron diadematus is found in the western Indian Ocean, where it is endemic to the Red Sea (Su and Tyler 1986). It is found at depths ranging from 5–30 metres.
useTrade:
Arothron diadematus is a component of the marine ornamental fish trade, although it was not designated as one of the top 25 most important fishes traded. A comparison of two Egyptian companies' export records from the years 1990–91 and 2000–01 show an increase in exports of this species from 41 to 159 individuals-per-year. In Egypt in 2004, A. diadematus was valued at $5 USD, a moderate value when compared to other Red Sea ornamentals. This species is also exported from Saudi Arabia and Yemen. Arothron diadematus was not one of the species designated as needing special consideration in regards to its commercial use within the marine ornamental trade (PERSGA/GEF 2004).

Tetrodotoxin (TTX) has been extracted from the skin of this species for use in chemoprevention of cancer studies (Fouda 2005). This species is also utilized in research due to its very small genome (Costantini et al. 2007).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for A. diadematus. This species' distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas in the Red Sea (World Database of Protected Areas 2010). Additionally, regional-level conservation efforts have been implemented with the goal of ameliorating predicted damage to reefs in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden. Many countries of  have enacted national legislation for coral reef conservation and signed multinational agreements with assistance from the Regional Organization for the Conservation of the Environment of the Red Sea and gulf of Aden (PERSGA/GEF 2004) (Kotb et al. 2008).

rationale: Canthigaster ocellicincta is widespread in the western Pacific. It inhabits a wide range of coral reef-associated habitats at depths ranging from 10 to 53 meters. There have been no documented population declines in C. ocellicincta, however due to its affinity with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. ocellicincta, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of habitat status.
habitat:
Canthigaster ocellicincta is a coral reef-associated, secretive species which inhabits invertebrate-rich inshore reefs to outer reef walls, usually in caves and crevices at depths of about 25 m or more. It has also been collected from reef pinnacles over sandy bottoms (Smithstonian Museum of Natural History Division of Fishes Collection accessed 11 May 2011). It is usually found singly or in pairs, but small groups have been observed among plate-corals on soft bottom (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). The toxicity of this species has not yet been confirmed (Nakabo et al. 2002).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. ocellicincta available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves  the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. ocellicincta may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

In the southwestern Indian Ocean, which includes 5,270 km2  of coral reef area, 9% of the reefs have been effectively lost (90% mortality), while 24% are at a critical stage with 50–90% loss of coral cover as of 2008 (Wilkinson et al. 2008).

Declines in mean coral cover have been recorded in Mauritius and La Réunion (Wilkinson et al. 2008). In La Réunion, native fish fauna are threatened by eutrophication and pollution, overfishing and poaching, by marine aquaculture, and by shoreline construction (Fricke et al. 2009).
population:
There is no species-specific population information available for C. ocellicincta. Specimens of C. ocellicincta are moderately common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. ocellicincta may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Canthigaster ocellicincta is known from Malaysia (Sabah), Indonesia (northeastern Kalimantan, Flores, and West Papua), east to Fiji, and from the Great Barrier Reef (Australia) and New Caledonia, north to Palau and Ryukyu Islands (Allen and Erdmann 2012), but not in Taiwan (Nakabo 2002). It is found at depths ranging from 20–53 metres. The type locality is Tanavulu Point near the entrance to Sandfly Passage, Florida Island, Solomon Islands (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species. It is of interest to marine aquarists, however it appears to be rarely encountered in the trade.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. ocellicincta, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Polyspina piosae is a subtropical species distributed from Western Australia to South Australia. It is a nearshore, demersal species which is typically found over sandy bottoms, either singly or in small groups, at depths ranging from one to 37 metres. Although there have been no documented population declines in this species, it may be taken as bycatch in trawl fisheries operating in Australia, and is part of the Australian specialty marine aquarium trade. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for P. piosae; however, its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Polyspina piosae is a subtropical, demersal species which generally inhabits sandy bottoms in coastal waters, including surf zones and areas with sparse seagrass. It is also found on sand near reefs and in protected coastal bays (Gomon 2008, B. Hutchins, W.A. Museum pers. comm. 2006, S.A. Museum record 1982, cited in OZCAM database 2004, R. Foster and S.A. Museum, pers. comm., 2006). Polyspina piosae typically occurs singly or in small groups (Kuiter 1996). It may graze on seagrass (White et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Polyspina piosae may be vulnerable to capture in prawn trawls, in the northern, central and southern Spencer Gulf. Similarly, given the habitat and depth range of this species, it is likely that P. piosae may be (or may have been) part of the pufferfish bycatch in eastern Great Australian Bight and Gulf St. Vincent (Baker 2009). Due to its affinity with seagrass beds and reef structures, this fish may be experiencing population declines due to loss of habitat, although no measurable decreases have been observed.

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and Southeast Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population: Polyspina piosae is not frequently encountered but is sometimes spotted in moderate sized schools (Gomon et al. 2008).  In one survey study in Western Australia, 645 individuals of this species were found, and comprised about 1% of total individuals taken (Hyndes 1999). Specimens of P. piosae are moderately common in museum collections (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2013-09-13). Although no measurable declines have been observed, this species of fish may be experiencing population decreases due to loss of habitat in sea grass beds and reefs.
range: Polyspina piosae is known in the eastern Indian Ocean from the Western and South Australian territories, occurring as far eastward as Kangaroo Island (Hardy, in Gomon et al. 1994). It is found at depths ranging from zero to 37 m.
useTrade: This species is likely a component of the South Australian specialty marine aquarium trade (Baker 2009).
conservationActions:
The distribution of P. piosae overlaps with several marine protected areas.

Polyspina piosae was evaluated as Data Deficient by Baker, 2009 in "Marine Species of Conservation Concern in South Australia", due to its limited distribution, the scarcity of published records, its preference for shallow water, nearshore habitats including coastal reefs which may be vulnerable to anthropogenically-induced habitat modification, it's known depth range (at which prawn and fish trawls are known to operate), the site-specific reproductive habits of pufferfishes in general, the unquantifiable threat of collection for the aquarium trade faced by this species in Southern Australia, and the lack of information about it's biology, population dynamics, or relative abundance (Baker 2009).

rationale: Canthigaster epilampra is widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific and appears to be common. It inhabits a wide range of reef-associated habitats at depths ranging from 6 to 98 metres. Canthigaster epilampra is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. epilampra, however due to its affinity with coral reefs this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. epilampra, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of habitat status and harvest levels for the aquarium trade.
habitat:
Canthigaster epilampra is a reef-associated species which inhabits outer reef slopes and reef caves and ledges at depths ranging from 6–90 metres. It is more common at depths greater than 24 metres (Myers 1991). Canthigaster epilampra has been known to form aggregations over artificial reefs (Moffitt et al. 1989), though it is typically found alone or in pairs. It feeds on molluscs, echinoderms, brachiopods, and filamentous algae (Myers 1991). The intensity of the colour pattern is variable (Allen and Erdmann 2012).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. epilampra available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves  the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: There are no major threats known for this species. However, due to its association with coral reefs, this species may be experiencing population declines. As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and Southeast Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008).
population:
Canthigaster epilampra is a common species in Taiwan (Shao pers. comm. 2011).

Specimens of C. epilampra are common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs, C. epilampra may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: In the Indo-Pacific, Canthigaster epilampra is known from Bali to the Hawaiian and Society Islands and Australia (Great Barrier Reef) to Japan (Ryukyu and Ogasawara islands) and Taiwan. East Indian locations include Malaysia (Sabah), Indonesia (northeastern Kalimantan and Bali eastward), Christmas Island, Philippines, Papua New Guinea, and Solomon Islands (Nakabo 2002, Allen and Erdmann 2012). The type locality is Kihei, Maui, Hawaiian Islands. It is found at depths ranging from 6–90 metres, but is more common below 25 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: Canthigaster epilampra is collected for the aquarium trade. In Hawaii, 1,124 individuals of this species have been captured from 1967–2003 at a combined value of $2,860.50 USD (Walsh et al. 2004). It retails online for $59.99 USD (TadReef.com).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. epilampra, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Lagocephalus cheesemanii is currently undergoing taxonomic revision by K. Matsuura. Revisions have not yet been accepted by the scientific community, and pending publication of this revision there is uncertainty regarding the geographic range of this species. As currently accepted, this species is restricted to eastern Australia and New Zealand. However, if L. gloveri is accepted into the synonymy of L. cheesemanii the geographic range and threats to this species will be substantially increased. Lagocephalus cheesemanii is likely distributed from the Andaman sea east to Indonesia, north to southern Japan, including the Yellow and Bohai seas, and can be found at depths ranging from zero to 100 metres. It may be common in parts of its range. Adults inhabit the continental shelf over sandy or muddy bottoms, and juveniles can be found in estuaries. This species is likely a popular food fish in China, Taiwan and Japan. There is little species-specific population information available. This species is non-toxic and safe for consumption as processed and fresh fish product. It appears to be landed in large quantities in parts of its range, but does not appear to be particularly valuable. Based on population trends seen in other species of commercially important pufferfishes it is inferred that this species may be undergoing population declines in parts of its range. It is also likely to be impacted by coastal habitat degradation, particularly near estuaries and river mouths. Suspected population declines from exploitation and habitat degradation are not currently quantifiable due to lack of reliable data. Additionally, the geographic range of this species is somewhat unclear. Therefore, L. cheesemanii is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
Lagocephalus cheesemanii is a tropical species found at depths ranging from 0-100 m. Adults inhabit the continental shelf where they are found over sandy or muddy bottoms. Juveniles can be found in estuaries (Matsuura and Liu pers comm. 2011). Lagocephalus cheesemanii feeds on molluscs, crustaceans and fishes. It is most similar to L. spadiceus and L. guentheri in appearance (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Pufferfish fishery
Lagocephalus cheesemanni is impacted by pufferfish fisheries in parts of its range. In Japan, Pufferfish landings have declined since the early 1990s. Concern about the fishery centers on the most valuable and preferred species, Takifugu rubripes, which, as of 2010, was considered depleted in Japan. Landings of T. rubripes in Japan had declined to 5% of annual landings in 1987. Landings of "other pufferfish", a category which includes L. cheeesemanii (as L. gloveri) were maximized after the decline in T. rubripes landings. These "other pufferfish" have declined from a peak of roughly 400 tonnes in 1999 to less than 100 tonnes in 2007, a decline of roughly 75%. Declines in landings have been attributed to the effects of highly-effective long-line fishing (Kawata 2012).

Fishery-dependent data from China showed declines in catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) of L. cheesemanii (as L. gloveri) from 2001 to 2003, however this data may represent several species of this genus. In the Zhoushan Islands L. gloveri contributed about 15% of the total salted/dried tetraodontiform fish products found in markets. In northern Taiwan, L. cheesemanii (as L. gloveri) accounted for 80% of the tetraodontiform fish capture volume (uncited/unpublished data).

Habitat degradation
Furthermore, habitat degradation is occurring in many coastal areas within this species' range, particularly near river mouths (J. Liu pers. comm. 2011). In the semi-enclosed regions of the North Bohai and Yellow Seas, large amounts of industrial and municipal effluents containing heavy metals, particularly arsenic, have been implicated in the deterioration of coastal environments (Luo et al. 2010). Heavy metals have also been implicated in the degradation of the heavily populated and industrialized Pearl River delta region in southern China (Cheung et al. 2003). In the Gulf of Thailand, coastal habitat degradation has resulted from pollution, primarily from untreated municipal and industrial waste water, as well as a rapid decrease in mangrove forests, coral reefs, and fisheries resources (Cheevaporn and Menasveta 2003).
population:
Lagacephalus cheesemanii is common and can be locally abundant (K. Matsuura and L. Jing pers. comm. 2011). It is common in Taiwan (Shao pers. comm. 2011) and in the east China Sea (M. Liu and J. Liu pers. comm. 2011). Lagocephalus cheesemanii (often identified as as L. gloveri) is a component of the pufferfish trade in east Asia, where it trades under the name sabafugu. It has also been associated with the name "kuro-sabafugu".

In Japan Pufferfish landings have declined since the early 1990s. Landings of "other pufferfish", a category which includes L. cheesemanii (as L. gloveri), were maximized after the decline T. rubripes landings. These "other pufferfish" have declined from a peak of roughly 400 tonnes in 1999 to less than 100 tonnes in 2007, a decline of roughly 75%. Declines in pufferfish have been attributed to the effects of highly-effective long-line fishing (Kawata 2012). The percent contribution of L. cheesemanii to the category "other pufferfish" is unknown.

Fishery-dependent data from China showed declines in catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) of L. cheesemanii (as L. gloveri) from 2001 to 2003, however these data may represent several species of this genus. The catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) was: 0.88 t/day/boat in 2001, 1.13 t/day/boat in 2002, and 0.72 t/day/boat in 2003 (unpublished data).

Although there is currently no reliable species-specific information concerning the population status of this species and population trends could not be quantified, it is inferred that this species undergoing localized declines in parts of its range where it is harvested commercially.

Specimens of L. gloveri, which may represent L. cheesemanii, are common in museum collections. This species is represented by at least 104 lots in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 30 April 2012).
range: Lagocephalus cheesemanii is originally known known from New Zealand, however it currently undergoing taxonomic revision. Lagocephalus gloveri is likely a synonym of this species (Matsuura 2011, K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014), and is known from the Andaman Sea east to Indonesia, north to southern Japan (Shizuoka Prefecture,West Pacific) and also on the coasts of the South China Sea, East China Sea, Yellow Sea and Bohai Sea (M. Liu and L. Jing pers. comm. 2011, Su and Li 2002, K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Therefore it is likely that the range of L. cheesemanii includes that of L. gloveri, however this is not currently resolved. It has been recorded at depths ranging from one to 100 m.
useTrade: Lagocephalus cheesemanii (as L. gloveri) is widely utilized in the dry fish market through much of east Asia (Chen et al. 2003). This species and L. spadiceus are considered non-toxic, and are approved for use in Taiwan for the dry fish market (Wu et al. 2008). Catch statistics for this species and L. spadiceus are lumped together as "sabafugu" in Japan (Kawata 2012). In Japan, the muscle, skin, and male gonad are consumed (Noguchi and Arakawa 2008).
conservationActions: This species range may overlap marine protected areas.

rationale: Canthigaster coronata is endemic to the Hawaiian Islands, where it is common and locally abundant. Canthigaster coronata is usually found in the vicinity of coral reefs at depths ranging from 5 to 165 metres, on sand or sand and rubble bottom or algal flats. Canthigaster coronata is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. coronata and it appears to be locally abundant. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. coronata, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of its harvest levels and habitat status.
habitat:
Canthigaster coronata is usually found on sand or sand and rubble bottom or algal flats, often in the vicinity of coral reefs. It is also seen on clear coastal reefs, usually along deep slopes or over soft substrates (Randall et al.  2008). Canthigaster coronata is typically found below depths of 23 metres, but is occasionally seen in as little as six metres (Randall 1985). When in shallow waters, it is usually found in lagoons or bays. Canthigaster coronata feeds on a wide variety of benthic organisms, mostly algae, but also gastropods, sponges, bivalves, polychaetes, tunicates, crabs, sea urchins, heart urchins, brittle stars, bryozoans, peanut worms, various small crustaceans and foraminiferans (Randall 1985).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. coronata available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no known species-specific threats to C. coronata. This species is a component of the marine aquarium trade in Hawaii, however there are no present indicators of decline as a result of harvesting for the aquarium trade. Also, due to its association with coral reefs, this species of fish may be experiencing population declines. 

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and Southeast Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008).
population:
Canthigaster coronata was the twentieth most abundant species at the moderately deep terraces and banks of the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands (Parrish and Boland 2004). During surveys of Midway Atoll in the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands, this species is encountered occasionally outside lagoons on open rubble and sand substrates (Randall et al. 1993).

Specimens of C. coronata are common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).

Due to its association with coral reefs, C. coronata may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: This species is endemic to the Hawaiian Island region, including the Midway Islands (Randall et al. 2008); although specimens of Canthigaster conorata were not collected from Johnston Atoll for genetic analysis (Randall et al. 2008), it has been recorded there (e.g., Kosaki et al. 1991). It is found at depths of 6–165 metres.
useTrade:
Canthigaster coronata is a component of the aquarium trade. Between 1967–2003, 30,146 individuals have been collected from Hawaii for export, valuing a total $33,046.50 USD. Canthigaster coronata is among the top 50 most frequently collected species from Hawaii (Walsh 2001).

The Japanese name for this species is Hanakinchaku-fugu.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. coronata, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Canthigaster cyanetron is known only from a few specimens collected from Easter Island (Rapa Nui) at depths ranging from 5 to 40 m. This species has been collected from areas of live coral cover, however it is unknown whether or not it is dependent on this habitat. The AOO for C. cyanetron is estimated at 27 km2. AOO was calculated using ArcGIS based on a bathymetric clip of 1 to 50 m depth range from the ETOPO global relief model. This species is known from few locations (under five). It is likely impacted by coral reef bleaching events, which have been observed at Easter Island due to freshwater runoff and global warming. Therefore, C. cyanetron is assessed as Endangered B2ab(iii).
habitat:
Canthigaster cyanetron is a demersal species which is collected from ledges, under large coral heads and in caves (based on fishbase occurrence records).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. cyanetron available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of color differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: Canthigaster cynetron is likely impacted by habitat loss due to coral reef degradation. Coral reef bleaching events have been observed around the reefs of Easter Island due to freshwater runoff (Glynn 1996) and climate change (Wellington et al. 2001).
population: There is no species-specific population information available for C. cyanetron. Specimens of C. cyanetron are uncommon in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).
range: In the Southeast Pacific Canthigaster cyanetron is known from Easter Island (Rapa Nui) (Randall and Cea-Egaña 1989). It is found at depths ranging from 5–40 metres. The estimated AOO for C. cyanetron is 27km2.
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species and it is unlikely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. cyanetron, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas on Easter Island, which has designated at least three marine protected areas to protect reef biodiversity (Fernandez and Castilla 2005).

rationale: In the eastern central Atlantic, C. supramacula is known from off the Ivory Coast and Ghana, as well as off São Tomé and Príncipe islands in the Gulf of Guinea. It is associated with rocky reefs. There is little species-specific population information available for C. supramacula. It is not commercially utilized, and there are no known species-specific threats. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. solandri, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Canthigaster supramaculata is associated with rocky reefs, and is found at depths of at least two metres (Moura and Castro 2002, Wirtz et al. 2007).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. supramacula available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences. Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in C. supramacula. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, we infer that it may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson 2008).

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population:
Canthigaster supramacula is described as common in Príncipe and from São Tomé (Wirtz et al. 2007). Specimens of C. supramacula are uncommon in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).

There have been no confirmed population declines in C. supramacula.
range: In the eastern central Atlantic, Canthigaster supramacula is known from off the Ivory Coast and Ghana, a coastal range of less than 600 km (Moura and Castro 2002). It is also known from São Tomé and Príncipe islands (Wirtz et al. 2007) and Cape Verde Islands (Wirtz et al. 2013). It may be more widespread along the tropical African coast than is currently known (Wirtz et al. 2007). It is inferred that C. supramacula is found to depths of no more than 50 m.
useTrade: Canthigaster supramacula may occasionally be found in the aquarium trade, however it appears to be rare.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. supramacula. Its distribution likely overlaps marine protected areas in parts of its range.

rationale: Sphoeroides nephelus has a wide range in the tropical western Atlantic, from northeastern Florida to the eastern Gulf of Mexico. It is primarily associated with coastal and estuarine habitats in shallow waters to depths of 20 metres. It appears to be common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no major threats known to this species, its known range overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Sphoeroides nephelus is a coastal, demersal species which is often found to inhabit bays, estuaries, and protected coastal waters (Shipp 1972), including hypersaline lagoons (Peralta-Meixueiro and Vega-Cendejas 2011). It can be found in salinities ranging from five to 45 ppm (Hoese 1960). In Florida, where it appears to be abundant, it is found in habitats characterized by mangroves or emergent wetland vegetation, such as Spartina spp. (Johnson et al. 1999). It is known to form loose aggregations around man-made structures such as bridges and piers etc. (Shipp 2003). The diet consists mainly of invertebrates, principally molluscs and crustaceans (Shipp and Yerger 1969). This species is known to accumulate saxitoxin (Abbott et al. 2009), and has been responsible for poisoning events. Due to morphological variation in colouration and prickles throughout its range, S. nephelus has been frequently misidentified (Shipp and Yerger 1969). Sphoeroides nephelus coexists with S. spengleri and S. testudineus in parts of its range (Palacios-Sánchez and Vega-Cendejas 2010).

Sphoeroides nephelus reaches maturity at 165 mm (Shipp and Yerger 1969) and commonly reaches a total length of 200 mm (Shipp 1978). It feeds primarily on shell fish and crustaceans but also sometimes of finfish (Shipp 2002).

The genus Sphoeroides was found to be paraphyletic, and it is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no major threats known to this species. Although no measurable decrease in population numbers has been observed, S. nephelus may be undergoing population decreases due to loss of habitat. One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

Globally, 16% of mangrove species are at elevated risk of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction (Polidoro et al. 2010). In the Caribbean, approximately 24% of mangrove area has been lost over the past quarter-century (FAO 2007).
population:
Sphoeroides nephelus appears to be the most common and abundant tetraodontid in the shallow coastal lagoons of northeastern Florida (Johnson et al. 1999, Turtora and Schotman 2010). It uncommon in the coastal hypersaline lagoons of the Yucatan Peninsula, and appears to be replaced by S. testudineus in this part of its range (Peralta-Meixueiro and Vega-Cendejas 2011). Mean annual catch per unit effort (CPUE) caught in the Southeast Area Monitoring and Assessment Program (SEAMAP) during the summer trawl surveys from 1987 to 2010 indicate stable trends. Fall trawl surveys only have two records, for 1990 and 2010 (NOAA unpub. data). In contrast, S. nephelus was identified as a species of concern in Louisiana based on declines in mean CPUE after 1991; this species appeared to have once been abundant in Louisiana's estuaries and coastal waters, and its abundance appears to have drastically decreased there (Sandy 2010, based on Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries data). However it is worth noting that S. nephelus is generally more abundant in the eastern half of the Gulf of Mexico (Sandy 2010).

Due to its affinity with mangroves and sea grasses, this fish may be experiencing population decreases due to loss of habitat.

In a recent study conducted by the Gulf of Mexico Reef Fish Industry, only five individuals were taken (all by vertical line and none by longline buoy gear) over the course of a one year study (Scott-Denton and Williams 2013).
range: Sphoeroides nephelus is found in the Western Atlantic, from northeastern Florida (between Jacksonville and Marineland) throughout the majority of the Caribbean Sea and in the eastern Gulf of Mexico, and south to the Yucatan Peninsula (Shipp and Yerger 1969). It is typically found at depths ranging from zero to 11 metres (Lieske and Myers 1994), but can be found to 20 metres (Shipp 2002).
useTrade: This species was historically caught in mixed catches with the previously targeted S. maculatus, a fishery which peaked in the 1970s and has since declined. Sphoroides nephelus is easily and unintentionally caught by recreational fishers, and occasionally consumed despite several reports of saxitoxin poisoning (Deeds et al. 2008).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. This species range overlaps several marine protected areas.

rationale: Canthigaster janthinoptera is widespread in the Indo-Pacific, and appears to be common and locally abundant. Canthigaster janthinoptera is associated with coral reefs, clear lagoons and seagrass beds at depths ranging from 1 to 35 metres. Canthigaster janthinoptera is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. janthinoptera, however due to its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds this species may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. janthinoptera, however its distribution overlaps with several marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of its harvest and trade levels.
habitat:
Canthigaster janthinoptera is a reef-associated species which occurs in clear lagoon and seaward reefs, often near sponges (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001) and in seagrass beds (Gell and Whittington 2002). It prefers sheltered areas in the form of holes in dead and living corals. It is seen either solitary or paired. This species feeds on sponges, polychaetes, filamentous algae and on smaller quantities of tunicates, crustaceans, echinoderms and corals. Off Moorea Island, French Polynesia, this species colonizes reefs when it reaches 30 mm (TL), and recruits at 55 mm (TL) (Lecchini and Galzin 2005). Canthigaster janthinoptera appears to exhibit a pre-settlement habitat different from that of juveniles at Moorea Island. The larvae of this species were encountered over a mid-barrier reef with low living coral cover, and juveniles were found in a variety of reef habitats ranging from those with coral rubble, live coral cover, and 80% dead coral (Lecchini 2005). In Tahiti, this species has been recorded in harbours (Adjeroud et al. 2001).

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. janthinoptera available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves  the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Due to its association with coral reefs and seagrass beds, C. janthinoptera may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or near-threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).
population:
Canthigaster janthinoptera has been described as secretive and generally uncommon (Myers 1999). This species was not among the top 26 most common species caught in seagrass beds in Northern Mozambique (Gell and Whittington 2002). It has been recorded only occasionally in Taiwan (Shao pers. comm. 2011).

Specimens of C. janthinoptera are very common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, C. janthinoptera may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Canthigaster janthinoptera is distributed from the Red Sea and East Africa south to Transkei, South Africa (Smith and Heemstra 1986), east to the Line and Pitcairn Islands and eastern and western Australia and  Xisha Islands, Taiwan (Su and Li 2002), and southern Japan (Hachijo Islands, Ryukyu Islands)( Nakabo 2002). The type locality is Ambon Bay, Ambon, Molucca Islands, Indonesia. It is found at depths ranging from 1–30 metres (Allen and Erdmann 2012). This species is replaced by C. jactator in the Hawaiian Islands and C. punctatissimus in the tropical eastern Pacific (Myers 1999). Canthigaster janthinoptera is an occasional waif in the Galapagos Islands (Grove and Lavenberg 1997), although it may be established there (Ruiz et al. 2011).
useTrade: Canthigaster janthinoptera is a component of the marine aquarium trade. It has formerly been collected for aquarium trade export in the Maldives (Edwards and Shepherd 1992) but has since been banned for export from this region (Saleem and Adam 2004).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. janthinoptera, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifugu stictonotus is distributed in the North West Pacific, where it is common and locally abundant in parts of its range. It inhabits sandy and rocky habitats in ranging from very shallow waters to 30 metres, and is also associated with river mouths. Takifugu stictonotus is not targeted, however it can be incidentally harvested. There are no known additional species-specific threats, however the extent to which T. stictonotus is impacted by environmental degradation resulting from large-scale anthropogenic activity within its range is largely unknown. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. stictonotus. However, it is found in marine protected areas, and fishery management strategies implemented within its range are likely to offer a degree of protection. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu stictonotus is a demersal species which can be found in the lower mouths of rivers (Obsyuzyan and Sokolovsky 2003).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are no confirmed species-specific threats to T. stictonotus. It may be threatened by coastal habitat degradation and overfishing in parts of its range.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. Highly effective fishing gear, including modified long-lines and nets with small mesh sizes, rather than excessive fishing effort, have been implicated in the depletion of Takifugu pufferfish resources in parts of East Asia. In Japan, initial efforts to regulate the fishery in the mid-2000s had not achieved desired results by 2010, and were subsequently re-evaluated (Kawata 2012). This species does not appear to be explicitly targeted by fisheries, and  the  species-specific effects of the Fugu fishery on T. stictonotus are unknown. It may be taken as bycatch.

Genetic effects of cultured fish on natural populations
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aquacultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefor likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
There is little species-specific population information available for T. stictonotus. Takifugu stictonotus is common and locally abundant in Japan, however it is considered rare in Chinese waters. During collections of Takifugu spp. from the Pacific Coast of Tohoku area of Japan for analysis of tetrodotoxin (TXX) content, this species represented three out of 164 specimens collected, and was the least frequently collected Takifugu species (Kodama et al. 1983).

Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Takifugu stictonotus is common in museum collections. It was represented by 17 lots in searches of the FishNet2 database.
range: In the Northwest Pacific Takifugu stictonotus is distributed from southern Hokkaido, Japan to the East China and Yellow seas to Taiwan (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014). It is found at depths ranging from one to 30 metres.
useTrade: Takifugu stictonotus is incidentally caught but does not appear to be targeted. The Japanese name of this species is Gomafugu.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. stictonotus, however it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. stictonotus.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations (UN) Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012). Following the ratification of the UN Convention of the Law of the Sea, Japan implemented the Total Allowable Effort (TAE) system in Ise Bay and Mikawa Bay (Hoshino 2010). Stock enhancement programs exist for this species in Japan using hatchery raised fingerlings (Fushimi 2001). Optimal release locations have been determined (Nakajima et al. 2008), however it has been found that hatchery-reared juveniles were more easily preyed upon than wild juveniles due to differences in swimming depth and TTX concentrations (Shimizu et al. 2008).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Further research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2009), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Canthigaster solandri is widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific where it appears to be common. It is associated with a variety of habitats, including coral reefs, seagrass beds, and artificial reefs. Canthigaster solandri is a component of the marine aquarium trade, however there are no indications of population declines from harvesting at present time. There have been no documented population declines in C. solandri, however due to its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds it may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for C. solandri, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend monitoring of harvest levels for the aquarium trade.
habitat:
Canthigaster solandri inhabits sheltered rocky reefs (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001) as well as intertidal reef flats and lagoon and seaward reefs. This species occurs over open barren areas, as well as among corals and under ledges (Lieske and Myers 1994). Canthigaster solandri is also associated with seagrass beds (Gell and Whittington 2002). It has been known to associate with artificial reefs (Logan Kock 1982). It is often found in pairs and sometimes in small groups. Canthigaster solandri feeds mainly on filamentous red and green algae and coralline red algae but also on corals (Cole et al. 2008), sponges (Pennings et al. 1994), tunicates, molluscs, echinoderms, polychaetes, crustaceans and bryozoans.

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. solandri available. C. solandri is sexually dimorphic (Stump in prep. 2014). In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in C. solandri. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, we infer that C. solandri may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008). Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

One-third of global seagrass species are currently experiencing population declines, and 21% of globally assessed seagrass species are in threatened or Near Threatened categories primarily due to coastal development and pollution (Short et al. 2011).

This species is a component of the marine aquarium trade. The effect of this trade on the population of C. solandri is unknown.
population:
Specimens of C. solandri are very common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012). However, it is rare in Taiwan (Shao pers. comm. 2011).

Due to its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, C. solandri may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: There are a few records of C. solandri in Hawaii, however it does not appear to be established there. This species is distributed from central Philippines (Bohol Region) east to French Polynesia. It is not found in Palau (Allen and Erdmann 2012, Stump in prep. 2014). Several records from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan were based on mis-identifications of C. papua, and this species' presence in Japan remains to to be verified (Stump in prep. 2014)
useTrade: Canthigaster solandri is a component of the marine aquarium trade, where it is regularly available. It has been exported from the Maldives (Edwards and Shepherd 1992). It retails for approximately $25 USD (Liveaquaria.com)
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. solandri, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.

rationale: Takifugu snyderi is distributed in the northwestern Pacific from South Korea, Japan to China. It is typically found at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 20 meters. Juveniles have been recorded from near shore surfzones. Takifugu snyderi appears to be common in parts of its range, and can be locally abundant. Takifugu snyderi may be impacted by over-exploitation and habitat degradation in parts of its range. It is a commercial species which is targeted for the Fugu trade. It is marketed as "shosaifugu" in Japan and is caught primarily by longline. The extent to which T. snyderi is impacted by the Fugu trade is unknown. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. snyderi. However, it is found in marine protected areas, and fishery management strategies, including seasonal closures and size limits, implemented within its range are likely to offer a degree of protection. Takifugu snyderi is therefore assessed as Least Concern. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
Takifugu snyderi is a subtropical, demersal species. In Japan, juveniles have been recorded from nearshore surfzones (Suda et al. 2004).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Fugu fishery
Takigufu snyderi is commercially targeted for the Fugu trade (Kawata 2012). Harvesting levels at the present time do not suggest that population declines approaching threatened thresholds (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines throughout East Asia. In the Yellow Sea all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population:
There is little species-specific population information for T. snyderi. Takifugu snyderi is common and locally abundant in Japan (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). It is common in museum collections (13 lots).

Due to their relatively recent divergence times, Takifugu interspecific crosses produced by artificial and natural fertilization in both natural and laboratory settings were found to be viable (Fujita 1967, Masuda et al. 1991, Miyaki et al. 1995, Kai et al. 2005). Each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008).
range: In the Western Pacific, T. snyderi is distributed from Japan, with northernmost records located off the Tohoku district, to the southern Korean Peninsula (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014). This species is found at depths ranging from one to 30 metres.
useTrade: Takifugu snyderi, also known as "shōsai-fugu" in Japan, is commercially targeted for the consumptive pufferfish trade. In Japan, pufferfish are caught primarily using modified longlines which are attractive to novice fishermen due to their ease of use (Kawata 2012). The Japanese name of this species is Shōsai-fugu.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. snyderi, however, it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. snyderi.

These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50 m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing  areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2009), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Takifugu basilevskianus was described as endemic to the Shandong Peninsula in China. There is some doubt as to the taxonomic validity of this species, however pending revision this species is accepted as valid. This species may have undergone severe population declines, as it was historically fished but is no longer reported in landings. It is closely related to T. rubripes, T. pseudommus and T. chinensis, geographically sympatric species which have experienced varying degrees of population decline. Given the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within the genus and the existing doubt concerning the distribution, population, and habitat/ecology of this species species, conclusions about population trends cannot currently be made. Therefore T. basilveskianus is listed Data Deficient. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods.
habitat:
There is little species-specific habitat and ecology information available for T. basilevskianus. 

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough, scaleless skin often covered with small spicules, beak-like dental place divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single short dorsal fin, a single shore anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or injured, are and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, or liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There are anecdotal accounts of population decline in T. basilevskianus, the magnitude of which cannot currently be quantified. Given that this species' closest genetic relatives (T. rubripes, T. pseudommus, and T. chinensis) are geographically sympatric, are highly-commercialized, and have undergone varying degrees of decline, we infer that the T. basilevskianus is likely to be impacted by the following threats:

Fugu fishery
