Since then, trade appears to have shifted from live specimen trade to processed meat and in particular the trade in ‘calipee’, the dried and processed cartilaginous margin of the carapace. Well over 16,400 live specimens, in 19 shipments, were documented as seized from illegal trade during the period 2000–2015, the fourth most numerously seized CITES-listed turtle species, and the most numerously seized Appendix I turtle species (CITES CoP17 Doc73). Seized shipments of calipee can be huge and are normally not identified to species.

In some places (such as the Indus basin), animals are persecuted by fishermen as perceived nuisance. In addition to targeted exploitation, Choudhury and Bhupathy (1993) noted habitat destruction in the Ganga and Mahanaddi as having adversely affected the species.
population: Historically Nilssonia gangetica was widespread and common throughout most of its range. It was encountered in 17 of 35 surveyed markets before 1983 (Moll 1983), but was only encountered in three of 61 markets surveyed in 1991–1993 (Choudhury and Bhupathy, 1993). Choudhury et al. (2000) considered the species common throughout its range in India, but possibly in decline. Participants at the 2005 Red List Workshop considered that the species remained fairly widespread and common in Northeastern India and in Bangladesh, but had declined severely elsewhere over the previous 12 years and in places was nearly gone. By the time of the 2011 Asian Turtle Red List Workshop in Singapore, better survey and trade data available by then indicated that a drastic reduction in numbers, and size of animals had occurred, with an estimate made that the species’ overall population had likely more than halved. Nilssonia gangetica remains widespread and stable in temple ponds.
range: Nilssonia gangetica occurs throughout the northern plains of the Indian Subcontinent, in the Indus, Ganga, Narmada and Mahanadi basins and most tributaries and intervening drainages of Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Afghanistan (Schneider and Djalal 1970), and the Brahmaputra basin (Das 1995, Iverson 1992, Praschag and Gemel 2002). This species occurs from the lowlands (perhaps 20 m) maybe up to 1,000 m above sea level (in Afghanistan).
useTrade: Nilssonia gangetica is harvested for food markets, domestically and internationally (East Asian).
conservationActions:
Nilssonia gangetica is included in CITES Appendix I, prohibiting all forms of international commercial trade. The species (as Trionyx gangeticus) is protected under Schedule I of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (amended), which includes endangered species that may only be hunted under exceptional circumstances, under licence from both federal and provincial authorities. From 1987 onwards the species has been focus of a project to reduce pollution in the Ganga, where large softshells were protected to fulfil their scavenging function; this involved protecting natural nests, headstarting hatchlings, and enforcing protective legislation for the species. Nilssonia gangetica has been recorded from several protected areas, including Chambal National Park (MP), Keoladeo National Park (Rajasthan), Harike Lake (Punjab), and Dudhwa Tiger Reserve (UP) in India (Das 1995, Hanfee 1999), and Chitwan National Park in Nepal (Das 1995). It may also be present in the protected river valley in Assam's Kaziranga-Orang Riverine Landscape (KORL). Confirmation of occurrence in effectively protected areas in Bangladesh and Pakistan is needed.

Current population status data is needed, and monitoring of key populations is desirable. Improving legal protection from exploitation is needed in all range countries, combined with alternative livelihoods measures to minimise exploitation pressures. Continued monitoring and enforcement of (illegal) trade is critically important.

rationale: Nilssonia hurum is considered to be Endangered as it has been exploited at very substantial trade volumes in recent years, mainly for export to East Asia, and indications from reduced market supply as well as from interviews and field surveys are that populations have declined substantially. Anecdotal data from field and market observations suggest that this decline amounts to 20% or more in India per generation during the recent past and at present. Overall, with an estimated generation time of 20–25 years, a 50% overall reduction over the past three generations is appropriate.
habitat: Nilssonia hurum inhabits rivers, lakes and ponds (Das 1991, 1995).  It feeds omnivorously; reported diet items include snails and other molluscs, prawns, fish, and mosquito larvae; items fed in temple ponds include rice and sweetmeats. It reaches a size of about 60 cm carapace length and 15–20 kg weight, possibly less as many large N. nigricans were misidentified as N. hurum (Praschag and Gemel 2002). The age of maturity is perhaps seven to eight years, with a generation length of 20–25 years. There is no information on longevity.
threats:
Nilssonia hurum is extensively collected for subsistence consumption and local, regional and illegal international commercial trade (Moll 1983, Choudhury and Bhupathy 1993, Das 1995, Das et al. 2010). Exploitation for (illegal) international trade to East Asia increased sharply in the late 1990s, when peak volumes of 60–80 tons per week were reported in East Asian markets (TFTSG and ATTWG 2000). In recent years, trade has shifted from live specimens to trade in calipee (dried, processed cartilage from the carapace margin). A single confiscation from illegal trade, involving an unreported number of live specimens, has been reported during the period 2000–2015 (CITES CoP17 Doc73), though Das et al. (2010) referred to its occurrence in five seized consignments in Uttar Pradesh in 2009 alone. Seized shipments of calipee can be huge and are normally not identified to species.

Trade volumes in Bangladesh peaked in the late 1980s and early 1990s, when annual export volume amounted to about 10,000 metric tonnes (converting to approximately 700,000 adult animals). In addition to targeted exploitation, Choudhury and Bhupathy (1993) and Das et al. (2010) noted riverine habitat destruction in the Ganga as having adversely affected the species. Water pollution and entanglement in monofilament fishing nets are additional threat factors that need recording and monitoring.
population:
While specific population information appears unavailable, Nilssonia hurum is generally recorded as one of the most frequently traded species in the region (Moll 1983, Das 1995). Choudhury and Bhupathy (1993) considered that it could not be termed ‘abundant’, while Choudhury et al. (2000) considered it ‘nowhere common’. While it was encountered in nine of 35 surveyed markets before 1983 (Moll 1983), it was only encountered in one of 61 markets surveyed in 1991–1993 (Choudhury and Bhupathy 1993). By 2011, the species was understood to be decreasing in central India (S. Singh pers. comm. at Singapore Red List Workshop 2011). Nilssonia hurum is most commonly traded in Assam and Tripura, with specimens believed to be sourced from Bangladesh (Participants, Singapore Red List Workshop 2011).

A 2014 survey of seven sites in Charsadda, Pakistan, found 69 individuals and considered the population of N. hurum to be in good condition (Safi and Khan 2014). However, it is rare in Sindh, southern Pakistan (Khan et al. 2015). In Bangladesh the species was considered to still occur in good numbers in the southeast of the country (relatively better than N. gangetica), but under increasing exploitation pressure (P. Praschag pers. comm. at Singapore Red List Workshop 2011). On balance, this species may be considered endangered throughout its range with a reduction of at least 50% in the past three generations and continuing into the future.
range: Nilssonia hurum occurs throughout the Indus, Ganga and Brahmaputra basins of Bangladesh, northern India, southern Nepal and Pakistan (Iverson 1992, Das 1995, Praschag and Gemel 2002, Das et al. 2010). It does not appear to be present in Myanmar as suggested by Das et al. (2010). This is a lowland species found up to about 200 m above sea level.
useTrade: Nilssonia hurum is extensively collected for both domestic and international (East Asian) food markets and can occasionally be found as individuals in the domestic pet trade (I. Das pers. comm. 2018).
conservationActions:
Nilssonia hurum is included in CITES Appendix I, prohibiting all forms of international commercial trade. It is protected (as Trionyx hurum) under Schedule I of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (amended), which includes endangered species that may only be hunted under exceptional circumstances, under licence from both federal and provincial authorities. In Pakistan it is protected by inclusion in Appendix III of the Wildlife Protection Ordinance for Sindh, Punjab, Balochistan, and Northwest Frontier Agency, and its export from Pakistan is banned under the Pakistan Export Policy, 2006–2007. In Bangladesh it is included under Schedule III of the Bangladesh Wildlife (Preservation) Act of 1974.

Nilssonia hurum has been reported to occur in D’Ering Wildlife Sanctuary, Mehao Wildlife Sanctuary, Namdapha Tiger Reserve and Pakhui Wildlife Sanctuary (Arunachal Pradesh), Kaziranga Tiger Reserve, Manas Tiger Reserve, Mupa-Lanteng Forest Reserve (Assam), Bherihari Wildlife Sanctuary (Bihar), Hastinapur Wildlife Sanctuary (and Sarnath Turtle Sanctuary (UP), the National Chambal River Sanctuary (MP and Rajasthan) and Keoladeo National Park (Rajasthan), and Dibru-Saikowah, in India, as well as the Sundarbans in Bangladesh (Das 1995, Hanfee 1999, Choudhury et al. 2000, Das et al. 2010). It also occurs in Pablakhali Wildlife Sanctuary in Bangladesh.

The species was part of the headstarting program to increase populations of scavenging turtles in the Ganga in the 1980s and 1990s; pollution control measures for the Ganga will also have benefited this species.

Much more information on the precise distribution, natural history, status and exploitation of A. hurum is needed. Practical conservation measures are needed, including enforcement of existing laws on trade, updating of legal status to possibly include provisions for monitored, regulated sustainable utilization, and engagement with hurtle hunters to develop alternative livelihoods (Das et al. 2010)

rationale: Only four known animals remain (two are in captivity), none of which have reproduced successfully in recent decades, Rafetus swinhoei is one of  the most severely threatened species on Earth. It is listed as Critically Endangered because it has experienced a population reduction of over 99% over the last two generations; its area of occupancy is less than 10 km2, its population is severely fragmented, and in continuing decline; and there number of mature individuals is less than 50.
habitat:
According to Heude (1880), some of the specimens he described were caught in the Huangpu River (the largest river flowing through Shanghai and the last significant tributary of the Yangtze before it empties into the East China Sea), and some in and on the shores of Tai Hu near Suzhou. All these wetlands are interconnected through the Grand Canal, the oldest and longest canal in the world with a history of over 2,500 years. The Yangtze subpopulation therefore appears to have inhabited lowland lakes and rivers in the Yangtze coastal plain. Pritchard (2012), reviewing records of the species in Viet Nam, describes it as cryptic, fairly sedentary, inhabiting sluggish or still waters associated with major rivers, shuffled into the mud and detritus on the bottom, and eating almost anything organic. Wang et al. (2013) reviewed the habitat selection of Rafetus swinhoei in the upper Red River, China, and demonstrated that they were mainly recorded in river sections with sandbars and in particular at confluences of tributaries with the main river where the water was deeper. They seem to occur in deep sections of large rivers, in backwaters and in lakes. The two known live wild individuals in Viet Nam both live in semi-artificial lakes (dammed back with barrier structures). The captive R. swinhoei in China accepts animal matter like fish, various mammalian meats, chicken, crayfish, snails, salad and other plants, and also sadly junk food thrown into his pond by visitors (Kuchling et al. 2010). At least adults of the species are omnivorous. The female in China preferred to nest on open, sunny sand banks and avoided different soil and vegetation cover (Kuchling unpublished), but nothing is known of nest site selection in the wild. Nothing is also known on the biology and habitat selection of hatchlings and juveniles.

The Yangtze female was well over 90 years of age at the time of death and usually laid three, sometimes four, clutches per year of 55 to 65 (infertile) eggs each. This suggests a generation time of at least 100 years.
threats: Rafetus swinhoei remains under extreme pressure from exploitation of adults and eggs for (subsistence) consumption and targeted capture attempts in recent years due to its increased value. In addition, it has been affected by habitat loss through conversion, drainage, fragmentation and pollution of wetlands and riparian habitats, and hydroelectric barrages and sand mining.
population: An adult male of the Yangtze population has been kept for decades at the Suzhou Zoo in China. A female in the same zoo died in April 2018 and had mated many times with the male without producing fertile eggs. A male of the Red River subpopulation inhabited for a long time Hoan Kiem Lake in downtown Hanoi, Viet Nam, but died in January 2016. Another individual of the Red River subpopulation of unknown sex inhabits Dong Mo Lake west of Hanoi (subsequently captured in October 2020 and confirmed to be a female; WCS 2020) and a further individual was recently confirmed by eDNA in Xuan Khanh Lake, not far from Hanoi and Dong Mo Lake (Asian Turtle Program Press Release 11th April 2018). Surveys of the Red River basin in both Yunnan and Viet Nam in recent years have hinted at the possible survival of one or more animals, at least until recent times, but had not documented confirmed additional living animals until the capture of a female in October 2020. While the species has declined substantially over recent historical times, extensive records were known from the Red River subpopulation in both China and Viet Nam from the 1960s until the 1990s (Pritchard 2012). The last records from the lower Yangtze River region date from the 1930s. The decline accelerated greatly with increased agricultural and industrial development since the 1980s, and assuming a generation time of 100 years, has probably declined by over 99% over the past two generations.
range:
Historical records for Rafetus swinhoei exist from throughout the Red River basin of Yunnan and Viet Nam, as well as the coastal plains of northern Viet Nam. The species is also known from the lower Yangtze lowlands of eastern China. Based on late Pleistocene and Holocene fossils from Zhejiang and Taiwan Straits, speculatively it may historically have occurred in the Pearl River system and other drainages between northern Viet Nam and the Yangtze delta.

At the time of assessment, the current distribution in the wild was limited to two animals in reservoirs near Hanoi; the possibility remained of rediscovery in other northern Vietnamese wetlands. In October 2020, a female turtle was captured in a Dong Mo Lake near Hanoi and the genetic results confirmed it to be this species (WCS 2020). There is potentially another turtle in the same lake where she was found.
useTrade: In the 19th and early 20th centuries, Rafetus swinhoei was offered for sale at the market in Suzhou. The late female at Suzhou Zoo was reportedly bought at Suzhou market in the 1930s by a travelling animal show. The main use of R. swinhoei is for meat consumption on the local village level or in restaurants. In 1998 a R. swinhoei was rescued from a restaurant at the Chinese Red River and released (Wang et al. 2013). In 2008 the known individual of Dong Mo Lake in Viet Nam was caught by a fisherman who offered it for sale to a restaurant, but it was bought back and rescued by the Asian Turtle Program. The last record of a R. swinhoei slaughtered by villagers for its meat is from about 2009 at the Chinese part of the Red River (Kuchling et al. 2013). In the 1970s and 1980s there was some trade of R. swinhoei from Viet Nam into China (Pritchard 2012), but overall international trade does not seem to have been a significant factor in the decline of the species. Since its recognition as a high-value species there is a risk that animals are targeted for trade.
conservationActions:
Rafetus swinhoei was listed in CITES Appendix II in 2013 and is a species that is Protected for Beneficial, Economic or Scientific Value under China’s Wild Animals Protection Law. It is fully protected under Vietnamese Decree 160 ND-CP 2013, and a conservation action plan for Viet Nam has been drafted, to be published in summer 2018.

The Asian Turtle Program is working with villagers and stakeholders to protect the two known wild individuals in Viet Nam.

The captive male and late female in China were subjects of an intensive captive breeding program, but all eggs produced were infertile. An examination of the male in 2015 revealed that he had lost the majority of his penis probably during a past fight with another male and is unable to inseminate the female with the remaining stump without seminal grooves. Artificial insemination was attempted several times but did not result in egg development (Kuchling and Shunqing 2015).

Intensive, targeted surveys are needed in the Red River paleo-drainage of northern Viet Nam and adjoining Lao PDR, and possibly in Yunnan and elsewhere.

Establishment of a secure facility in Viet Nam is a necessity, to transfer any discovered animals into to attempt their captive breeding. The discovery of a female in October 2020 and the potential that others may still survive provides hope for the future survival of this species.

rationale: Pangshura tentoria is a widespread and common species which occurs in a number of major protected areas and not known to be subject to any significant declines of populations or available habitat. Trade is fairly limited relative to the large overall population size, and it remains relatively common over much of its range. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Pangshura tentoria is primarily a riverine turtle, inhabiting small and large rivers; they bask on rocks and tree snags (Das 1991). Pangshura tentora occurs up to 80 m altitude in the terai of Nepal (Schleich and Kästle 2002). Adult females are predominantly herbivorous, males and juveniles are more carnivorous, taking a variety of freshwater invertebrates and possibly small fish (Das 1991). May consume large quantities of water plant pest species (Eichhornia, Pistia, Salvinia, etc.). Females may reach 23 cm carapace length (tentoria) / 27 cm (circumdata) / 20 cm (flaviventer), males remain much smaller (Das 1991). Average clutch size for ssp. tentoria is five eggs, range 3–6, and likely two clutches are produced per female annually (Singh 1985 in Das 1991). Subspecies circumdata produce clutches of on average six eggs (range 3–12) (Rao and Singh 1987), while flaviventer females produce clutches of 6–10 eggs (Moll 1987). Overall, age of maturity of is about 5–6 years; with a generation length estimate of about 20 years; longevity is not well known.
threats: Large specimens of Pangshura tentoria are occasionally exploited for consumption (Das 1991); P. tentoria was encountered in seven of 35 surveyed markets before 1983 (Moll 1983), but was not encountered in 61 markets surveyed in 1991–1993 (Choudhury and Bhupathy 1993). Modest numbers of juveniles are traded in the global pet trade. At least 52 live specimens, in three shipments, were reported as seized from illegal trade during the period 2000–2015 (CITES CoP17 Doc73). While habitat loss impacts such as pollution, reservoir construction, sand mining and agricultural conversion of riparian habitats likely affect individual populations, these have not been argued to represent significant threats for the species overall. Trade and seizures of subspecies circumdata have increased in recent years.
population: Pangshura tentoria is considered a very common species (Das 1991), noted as common in many areas of its range (Choudhury et al. 2000). Overall Pangshura tentoria continues to be considered of Least Concern in India (Participants Lucknow Red List Workshop 2005, Singapore Red List Workshop 2011) and as Near Threatened in Bangladesh (Rashid and Praschag pers. comm. at Singapore Red List Workshop 2011). Participants at the Singapore Red List Workshop (2018) agreed.
range:
Pangshura tentoria inhabits the lowlands of the Ganga, Brahmaputra, Mahanadi and Godavari River basins (Iverson 1992, Das 1995).

Pangshura t. tentoria inhabits the Mahanadi and Godavari River basins of Andhra Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Orissa and is thus endemic to India.

Pangshura t. circumdata inhabits the upper and central parts of the Ganga basin of southern Nepal and northern India (Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh), and has also been reported from the Gambir River of Gujarat.

Pangshura t. flaviventer occurs in the northern tributaries and lower Ganga, from Nepal through Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, and West Bengal in India, to Bangladesh.

The subspecific identity of the form inhabiting the Brahmaputra is unclear (Das 1995: 130).
useTrade: This species is collected for both the domestic and international food markets and pet trade.
conservationActions:
Pangshura tentoria is included in CITES Appendix II, allowing international commercial trade in the species, provided such trade is not detrimental to the species, and subject to national trade legislation. It is apparently not listed in the Schedules of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (amended), though it may have been intended to be covered under Schedule I because tentoria and its subspecies were considered subspecies of Pangshura tecta at the time the law was implemented. Inclusion of Pangshura tentoria in one of the Schedules of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act should perhaps be considered (Appendix II).

Pangshura tentoria circumdata has been recorded from Katerniaghat Wildlife Sanctuary and Dudhwa Tiger Reserve in Uttar Pradesh, India (Hanfee, 1999) and the Chambal River Sanctuary, while P. t. flaviventer occurs in probably all protected areas along the main stem of the Brahmaputra (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2005). The subspecies P. t. tentoria, however, has not been confirmed from any protected areas (Participants Lucknow Red List Workshop 2005).

Taxonomic re-analysis of the subspecies and river basin populations (especially of flaviventer in apparent sympatry with circumdata, and identity of the Brahmaputra population) is highly desirable.

Status surveys throughout its range, with emphasis on protected areas, are desired, as is monitoring of key populations. Detailed natural history studies would be welcome. Safeguarding populations in effectively protected areas continues to be the main conservation objective.

rationale: This species is extremely restricted in range to an area of occupancy of 0.3 km2 (surface area of La Albeca) and is facing many pressures from invasive species, uncontrolled pollution, heavy water abstractions and drought. Chirostoma bartoni is already believed to be extinct since the drying up of La Alberca in 2006, but it is not known if sufficient sampling efforts have been made to confirm this. With the lake no longer stream fed and continuing heavy water abstractions, the chance of this species surviving the drought or another potential drought are minimal. Therefore, this species is assessed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct).
habitat: Chirostoma bartoni is a benthopelagic freshwater species, with a maximum known size for this species is 7.1 cm SL (Hugg 1996).  More information is needed regarding this species' ecological role. La Alberca caldera is an elevated extinct volcanic crater lake, groundwater fed (there are no rivers or streams entering the lakes), with locals and natives indicating other crater-lakes used to be spring fed, but these have dried. This is most likely due to the severe descent of the groundwater table, caused by over-pumping for irrigation and large agricultural land use (Alcocer et al. 2000). The crater lake where C. bartoni lives is characterized by its rocky coastline, with steep slopes that prevent the presence of aquatic macrophytes. The analysis of water quality shows that it is highly transparent, since the turbidity fluctuates between 10 and 18 UFT and has few suspended solids (up to 15 mg/L). The hardness expressed as calcium carbonate varies depending on the time of year, but it goes from 19 to 79 mg/L and the pH is strongly alkaline given that it reaches values of around 9.5 (Díaz-Pardo pers. obs/ 2001). Maximum known S.L. 81 mm (Miller et al. 2005).
threats:
Chirostoma bartoni is threatened by severe water abstraction and resulting drought of the lake, water pollution and the non-native invasive species Oreochromis aureus (Blue Tilapia) and Oreochromis mossambicus (Mozambique Tilapia) are invasive species, both of African origin (Lozano and García 2014). 

Along the shoreline of the lakes, garbage is a common feature, as well as the water being polluted with washing bleaches and detergents discharged into the littoral zone of the lake without any controls. In addition, there is severe descent of the groundwater table because of over-pumping for irrigation. Large greenhouses used to cultivate commercial crops could be seen when driving through the area. Chirostoma bartoni is commonly believed to be extinct in the wild as the Alberca caldera crater lake temporarily dried in August 2006 (E. Díaz-Pardo pers. comm. 2007, Burkhead 2012).
population: Chirostoma bartoni is believed to be extinct in the wild because the La Alberca caldera crater lake temporarily dried in August 2006 (E. Díaz-Pardo pers. comm. 2017, Burkhead 2012). Being mostly groundwater fed, there are no rivers or streams entering the lake, as historically these streams dried as well, leaving no alternate passage (Alcocer et al. 2000). However, it is not known if adequate sampling efforts have been conducted to confirm this possible extinction.
range: Chirostoma bartoni is a species endemic to the Lerma River basin in Mexico, specifically only believed to be found within the La Alberca caldera (Burkhead, 2012; Dzul-Caamal, et al. 2012). The Valle de Santiago crater-lakes are located in the southern portion of the Guanajuato State, not far from the northern boundary of Michoacán State.
useTrade: Chirostoma bartoni is not known to be utilised.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation efforts for this species. Chirostoma bartoni is thought to be extinct, but further research is required to confirm this. La Alberca is included within the boundaries of the La Region Volcanica Siete Luminarias National Park and the CONABIO (the 'Comisión Nacional para el Conocimiento y Uso de la Biodiversidad') Hydrological Area Region 61. The species is also recorded in the NORMA Oficial Mexicana NOM-059-SEMARNAT-2010 where it is listed as in danger of extinction.

rationale: As a species, the global population of Crocodylus porosus is secure because of large populations, extensive habitat and effective management in Australia, Papua New Guinea and, to a lesser degree, Indonesia. There are increasing C. porosus populations in the Solomon Islands, Sarawak and Sabah due to effective protection measures, although management may require incentives derived from sustainable use in order to counter negative public attitudes towards them.
habitat:
Crocodylus porosus is considered the largest of the living crocodilians, with reported lengths of up to 6–7 m (Webb and Manolis 1989, 2009; Whitaker and Whitaker 2008). Crocodylus porosus preys on people when given the opportunity. It is one of the most widely distributed of all crocodilians, ranging from southern India and Sri Lanka, throughout southeast Asia, east through the Philippines to Micronesia, and down through Indonesia, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands to northern Australia.

Within this distribution, C. porosus occupies a wide of wetland habitats from the sea (including thousands of islands) to hundreds of kilometres inland. A great deal of ecological research was carried out in the 1970s and 1980s, particularly in Australia and Papua New Guinea. Contrary to its common name “Saltwater crocodile”, which implies a marine existence, the species commonly inhabits non-tidal freshwater sections of rivers, and inland freshwater lakes, swamps and marshes. Indeed, it thrives in freshwater environments and some of the highest densities of C. porosus have been reported from heavily vegetated freshwater swamps without any tidal inﬂuence (Webb et al. 1977; 1984). Breeding and recruitment take place principally in rivers with signiﬁcant freshwater input, or in freshwater swamps (Jelden 1981, Webb et al. 1983, Cox 1985). In the marine environment it mostly inhabits tidal rivers and creeks, where salinity changes with different seasons and distance upstream, but they regularly move around the coast between rivers and occupy offshore islands.

Long-distance voyages at sea occur (Allen 1974, Manolis 2005) with unknown frequency (e.g. Cox 1985; Jelden 1985; Webb et al. 1984, 1987; Messel and Vorlicek 1989; Webb and Manolis 1989, 2009). Historical and recent data suggest that individuals move between range states (e.g. Malaysia-Singapore, Australia-Timor Leste). However, the species demonstrates high site fidelity, with long distance movements usually associated with translocated adults, or sub-adult and sub-dominant crocodiles dispersing in search of a territory. Individual crocodiles are also known to travel long distances between breeding and non-breeding sites (>100 km) as well as to and from seasonal feeding sites (e.g. sea turtle nesting). The exact nature of these movements is not well known.

In the tidal waterways of northern Australia, the movement of C. porosus between river systems appears to be related to sex and ontogenetic changes in social status. Radio and satellite tracking of large, male C. porosus are now providing insights into the pattern of movement out of rivers onto the coast, between river systems, and within tidal and non-tidal habitats, including homing associated with relocated individuals (Read et al. 2007, Kay 2004, Brien et al. 2008, Fukuda et al. 2019). However, a recent study involving the genetic analyses of C. porosus nests along the Northern Territory coast, combined with satellite tracking data from five translocated adult males, revealed that the Coburg Peninsula appears to be a significant geographical barrier to movement and dispersal of C. porosus from the east and west of the Northern Territory (Fukuda et al. 2019).

While the species is highly territorial, they are known to congregate at times of the year when resources are abundant. There are multiple reports of large numbers of adult crocodiles congregating around dead cattle floating in rivers of the Northern Territory and Western Australia. At Shady Camp lagoon on the Mary River, Northern Territory, large numbers (>100) of sub-adult and adult crocodiles have been reported congregating at a barrage separating tidal from non-tidal waters when mullet are spawning. A similar occurrence happens on islands and beaches of northern Australia each year during sea turtle nesting seasons (e.g. green, flatback, etc.).

In the Northern Territory of Australia, the recovery of wild C. porosus populations following protection (1971) was carefully documented, providing new information on population dynamics. Increasing numbers of large crocodiles over time have been accompanied by decreasing numbers of small crocodiles (Webb and Manolis 1992, Fukuda et al. 2011), which are predated or excluded from rivers and sometimes forced into marginal habitats, including upstream freshwater areas used for recreation by people (Letnic and Connors 2006).

Female C. porosus mature at around 2.2–2.5 m (12+ years of age in the wild). They lay their eggs in a mound of vegetation during the annual wet season (October-May; Webb et al. 1977, 1983). Mean clutch size in Australia is around 50 eggs at 113 g per egg (Webb et al. 1983), whereas in Papua New Guinea it is around 60 eggs at 100 g per egg (Cox et al. 2006). Incubation is typically 80-90 days (depending on temperature). As nesting is a wet season activity, loss of nests due to ﬂooding is typically very high (Webb et al. 1983; Cox 1985). Some wild females actively defend their nests and loss of eggs to non-human predators is exceptionally low. Lizards (varanids) take eggs, but usually when the eggs are dead and rotten, and can be located by smell. The recent invasion of Cane Toads (Rhinella marina) into the Northern Territory has reduced the varanid population which reduces this egg predation risk. The loss of very small numbers of eggs to rodents has been recorded (WMI, unpublished data), and wild pigs have been reported to raid C. porosus nests, but the signiﬁcance of this has not been demonstrated.
threats:
Human-crocodile conflict (HCC) – The largest risk posed to successful C. porosus conservation is the cohabitation of humans with an apex predator. Public awareness and education programs can help alleviate parts of this threat such as “Be CrocWise” (Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia in Australia). However, when C. porosus and humans are forced to cohabit, and even compete for resources (e.g. fishing), the risk of conflict will increase. Innovative solutions to further mitigate these risks are urgently required for continued conservation success.

Land use – Crocodylus porosus attack cattle and other livestock as they drink at the water’s edge. Pastoralists involved in the Northern Territory of Australia’s egg and wild harvests are compensated to some degree for stock losses, and are also provided with incentives to conserve habitats. Elsewhere, retaliation killings occur as crocodiles threaten the livelihoods of local people. Fishermen inadvertently trap and kill crocodiles with fishing equipment (hooks and nets).

Food – Unregulated fishing may be depleting fish stocks in some range states, which could have detrimental effects on C. porosus populations both from resource competition and increasing interactions leading to HCC.

Invasive weeds – Introduced plants for the pastoral industry including Para Grass (Urochloa mutica) in northern Australia have a high heat during decomposition which increases the temperature experienced by the developing embryos within the nest. No research into the effects on embryo survival or resultant sex ratios has been conducted to know if detrimental impacts could result. Water Hyacinth (Eichhornia crassipe) is also a reported as a problem in Sri Lanka (Samarasinghe and Chandrasiri 2013).

Invasive pests – No detrimental impacts on Australian C. porosus from the introduced Cane Toad (Rhinella marina) have been reported so far (Fukuda et al. 2016). Feral pigs and buffalo are known to have impacted negatively on nesting in some areas in northern Australia, but the significance has not been quantified (C. Manolis, pers. comm. 2019). In Papua New Guinea, introduced ﬁsh species (Piaractus brachypomus and Barbonymus gonionotus) to degrade nesting habitats (Cox et al. 2006, G. Solmu, pers. comm. 2018).

Habitat destruction and pollution – Urban encroachment, sand mining, tourism and agriculture threaten habitat modification for C. porosus as well as pollutants (Samarasinghe and Chandrasiri 2013, Amarasinghe et al. 2015) in some range states.

Traditional harvesting – Some traditional harvesting occurs by indigenous peoples throughout the range states but poses little threat to the overall C. porosus populations.
population:
The total wild population of Crocodylus porosus is estimated to be in excess of 400,000 non-hatchlings. As a species, the global population of C. porosus is secure because of large populations, extensive habitat and effective management in Australia, Papua New Guinea and to a lesser degree Indonesia (mainly Papua and West Papua Provinces). There are increasing C. porosus populations in the Solomon Islands and Malaysia (Sarawak and Sabah) due to effective protection measures and future management may require incentives derived from sustainable use to counter growing negative public attitudes due to human-crocodile conflict (HCC). Reintroduction and protection efforts in Bhitarkanika National Park, India, have been successful although increasing HCC is now occurring. In contrast, re-establishment of populations outside of protected areas in India may never be possible due to the large human population and lack of suitable habitat. Likewise, re-establishment of wild populations of C. porosus in Thailand, Viet Nam and Cambodia, where the species has long been presumed extinct, is unlikely, even in protected areas.

The species has the most commercially valuable skin of any crocodilian (Fuchs 2006) and was intensively hunted for skins historically throughout its range, particularly from the mid-1940s to the 1970s. Restoration of depleted populations have been demonstrated to recover reasonably quickly if: (1) habitats are intact; (2) they are given the opportunity through effective protection; and (3) people are prepared to tolerate expanded populations. Examples are the populations in Australia, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia which have also implemented successful sustainable use models to assist in this recovery. However, elsewhere these preconditions have not been met. Habitat loss continues to be a major problem in many areas occupied by C. porosus, and frequently they are killed as pests regardless of whether their skin is used commercially or not. Another significant source of mortality is drowning in fishing nets, especially in river systems where commercial net fishing occurs (eg. northern Australia). Therefore, resourceful incentives will be required to enhance the tolerance of people co-existing with these apex predators with HCC considered the largest risk to their continued abundance.

Information on the current status of C. porosus in each range state is summarized as:

Australia
Surveys by Professor Harry Messel and colleagues established the baseline for crocodile monitoring in northern Australia in the 1970s (e.g. Messel et al. 1978-1987). The population was protected (Western Australia 1970; Northern Territory 1971; Queensland 1974) after intensive unregulated hunting commenced in 1945-46. The recovering Australian population was transferred to CITES Appendix II (for ranching) under Resolution Conf. 3.15 in 1985 (Webb et al. 1984), and was given an unqualiﬁed Appendix-II listing in 1994 (under the old Berne Criteria, as Resolution Conf. 9.24 was only agreed to in 1994, at the same CITES meeting). Australia is considered the most secure long-term stronghold for C. porosus throughout its range due to large tracts of relatively uninhabited land and a successful sustainable use program that lead to the exportation of nearly 35,000 skins in 2015 (Caldwell 2017).

Northern Territory: Spotlight surveys carried out since the early 1970s indicate that in some rivers the population continues to increase, whereas in others the numbers have stabilized (Fukuda et al. 2011) despite high levels of legal egg harvest (ranching program) in almost all river systems (Saalfeld et al. 2016). The size structure is now biased towards larger animals (>2 m), and total crocodile biomass continues to increase, even in rivers where numbers have stabilized (Fukuda et al. 2011). The total population in the Northern Territory is considered to be near pre-exploitation levels with an average of five non-hatchling crocodiles per km (Webb et al. 2000, Fukuda et al. 2011, Saalfeld et al. 2016). A sustainable use program based on ranching of wild eggs forms the basis of management (Leach et al. 2009, Saalfeld et al. 2016), combined with a program of problem crocodile removal (Fukuda et al. 2014) and a limited wild harvest by landowners. Recognising the public impact of living with a large predator, the Northern Territory government runs a public education program called “Be Crocwise” to reduce HCC (becrocwise.nt.gov.au). Eight farms are currently in operation and crocodiles were estimated to add $54.3 million to the Northern Territory economy from direct and indirect contributions of employment, capital expenditure and tourism (Ernst and Young 2017). There is no evidence that introduced cane toads (Rhinella marina) have impacted on C. porosus at all (Fukuda et al. 2016). Buffalo are known to have impacted negatively on nesting in some areas in northern Australia, but the significance has not been quantified (C. Manolis, pers. comm. 2019).

Western Australia: Major C. porosus populations occur in the northwest of the state. Between 1992 and 2012, the population monitoring program was based on an annual aerial survey in the Cambridge Gulf (Ord River, West Arm), with spotlight surveys carried out less regularly in some areas (Mawson 2004). Regular monitoring is currently restricted to an annual spotlight survey of the King River, which has been surveyed fairly consistently since 1989 (1989–1990, 1992–2015, 2017–2019; WMI 2019a). Helicopter surveys indicated a 5.1% per annum (p.a.) population increase in the Ord River (2000–2008) and a 4.1% increase in West Arm (1999–2008) with no signs that the populations were approaching stability (WMI 2008). Recent spotlight surveys of the Ord River in 2019 suggest that the population in the tidal mainstream may be approaching stability, but the population in the upstream non-tidal mainstream continues to increase significantly (WMI 2019b). In 2015, spotlight surveys of the Prince Regent, Hunter and Roe Rivers confirmed healthy breeding populations with a 300% increase in abundance since 1970 (Parke 2015). Cattle grazing is a potential threat to some nesting habitats, and some illegal harvesting of eggs is known to have occurred in 2009–2010.

The increasing C. porosus population has prompted authorities to implement a public safety program, similar to the “Be Crocwise” program in the Northern Territory (Parke 2017). Legal harvesting of juveniles, sub-adults, adults and eggs was undertaken in West Arm between 1989 and 1994 to provide stock for crocodile farms. However, only one farm is currently in operation, in Broome, and it is based solely on captive breeding.

Queensland: There is a high-density human population on the east coast of Queensland and signiﬁcant habitat alteration for agriculture. The abundance of C. porosus varies between river systems, with the highest densities of crocodiles reported from northwest Cape York Peninsula (Read et al. 2004a, b). The most recent surveys (2009–2010) of 48 major waterways (735 km surveyed) along the east coast of Queensland revealed a relative density of 0.49±0.72 non-hatchlings/km (Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service 2010). For those individuals where size could be estimated (N=258), crocodiles ranged from hatchlings to 3.8 m, with 73% less than 2 m (13% were hatchlings). The number of non-hatchlings could be an under-estimate as 33% of crocodiles counted were “eyes only” which does not allow length to be estimated but tend to be larger, more wary crocodiles. On western Cape York Peninsula, surveys based in 10 key river systems in 2008 showed a relative density of 0.85 non-hatchlings/km with successful nesting occurring (Big Gecko, pers. comm. 2009). Identiﬁable threats to nesting success include feral pests (pigs) and invasive weeds.

Over the last ten years authorities have been under increasing public pressure to deal with increasing numbers of saltwater crocodiles in urban areas, which seems to be in response to more larger crocodiles moving around the coast, an increasing human population, and increased publicity and the ability to easily report sightings (Brien et al. 2017). The highest number of attacks, sightings, removals and relocations have occurred along the populated east coast between Townsville and the Daintree River during wet season months (November-February; Brien et al. 2017). There were 35 crocodile attacks in Queensland between 1971 and 2015 (total 0.8 per year; fatal 0.3 per year), mostly involving local people or regular visitors (77.1%), specifically adult males (71.4%; mean age 44 years; Brien et al. 2017). There has been an increase in the rate of crocodile attacks over time, with an average of 1.3 per year since 1996, most of which were non-fatal (84%; Brien et al. 2017).

In response, in 2017, the Queensland Government embarked on a 3-year monitoring program involving systematic spotlight and helicopter surveys in carefully selected, previously surveyed river systems throughout the state. This is the most comprehensive program since 2003, and will be used to determine the size, distribution and abundance and extent of recovery of the C. porosus population over time. Currently, the Queensland Crocodile Management Plan (https://environment.des.qld.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0024/87711/wl-mp-croc-manage-plan.pdf) consists of six clearly defined zones, from Central to Far North Queensland, with management actions determined by the zone-specific risks of interactions between crocodiles and people. Similar to the Northern Territory problem crocodile program (Fukuda et al. 2014), any C. porosus that poses a threat to human safety is removed or relocated. So far, 608 crocodiles have been relocated although this number has fluctuated widely between years (range 1-57; Brien et al. 2017).

The utilization of crocodiles on Queensland farms is mostly limited to captive breeding, with some farms importing large numbers of Northern Territory and Western Australian sourced eggs and/or juvenile crocodiles. However, an important step towards improving the public perception of crocodile use was attained in late 2018 by a change in legislation (Nature Conservation Act 1994) to allow for a limited wild egg harvest program. Currently (2019) there is only one permit in place for this to occur in Pormpuraaw, northwestern Cape York.

Bangladesh
In Bangladesh, C. porosus are restricted to the Sundarbans (Ganges delta). In 1982, four crocodiles and 20 tracks were recorded during daytime (450 km) and nighttime (95 km) surveys. In 2014–2015, daytime surveys in 351 km of river recorded 42 crocodiles (Aziz and Islam 2018). In 2016, 60 crocodiles and 31 tracks were recorded during the day in 1,893 km of river. Protected in 1974, the population was estimated to comprise 150–200 individuals in 1985, 250–300 adult C. porosus in 2000, and by 2012 it was considered to not exceed 100–150 adults (Rashid 2013). The reduction in the population is due to a variety of reasons, including an increasing human population, habitat alteration and illegal killing (eg ﬁshermen believe crocodiles compete with them for ﬁsh; Manik 2009). In February 1999, 14,300 ha (143 km²) or 2.3% of the Bangladesh Sundarbans was declared a wildlife sanctuary where extraction/collection of wildlife resources was banned. The sanctuary includes Kotka-Kochikhadi in East Sundarbans, Notabele in West Sundarbans, and Nikamol in South Sundarbans.

The Karamjal Crocodile Breeding Centre (KCBC) was established in 2000, and in 2016 breeding stock consisted of two females and one male (Anon 2016a). In early 2017, total stock comprised 215 crocodiles (Anon 2017) from this limited founder population. One of the goals of the KCBC is to make animals available for release into the wild. However, by early 2016, only about 19 C. porosus had been released into canals and rivers of the Sundarbans (Anon 2016b, Manik 2009).

Brunei
Little information is available on the status of C. porosus in Brunei. Cox (2006) reported low numbers in most rivers and creeks in Brunei Bay (relative density of 0.33 individuals/km). Habitats are largely undisturbed so the biological potential for recovery exists if incentives for the local human population to accept increased numbers of crocodiles can be provided (Ibrahim and Cox 2006). There have been eight confirmed attacks by C. porosus on humans since 2006 (CrocBite 2017).

Cambodia
Saltwater Crocodiles are considered to be extinct in Cambodia. It is believed that C. porosus were extirpated from Tonle Sap Lake about 30–50 years ago (Platt et al. 2006) although some individuals may still exist in coastal areas (Thuok and Tang 1994, Jelden et al. 2005, Ouk Vibol, pers. comm. 2017). Very few C. porosus are held on the 900+ crocodile farms in Cambodia (Jelden et al. 2005) with the local crocodile farming industry being based on the Siamese Crocodile (C. siamensis). Hybridization with C. siamensis is not a frequent occurrence (Starr et al. 2009).

China
The presence of wild C. porosus in southern China is currently unknown. Farming operations on the mainland and on Hainan Island may still have some C. porosus, imported from range states such as Thailand (Chen 2001, Geng 2001, Li 2001).

India
Saltwater Crocodiles remain in the northeast coastal region of mainland India and the Andaman Islands (Kar 2013, Singh and Kar 2006). A “rear and release” program in Bhitarkanika National Park (BNP), Odisha State, has released more than 2,950 captive-reared juveniles (approximately 1 m long) between 1977 and 2015 and several released females are known to be nesting successfully (Kar 2017). As such, the C. porosus population in BNP has increased significantly since the reintroduction program started from 95 sightings in 1976/77 (relative density= 0.87/km) to 1682 sightings in 2017 (relative density= 13.4/km; Kar 2019). The number of nests has increased from five in the mid-1970s, to 65 in 2009, 70 in 2017, to 101 in 2019 (Kar 2009, 2017, 2019). BNP is considered to comprise around 75% of the total population of wild C. porosus in India (Kar 2019).

The population increase in BNP has led to increased dispersal and HCC (Padro and Padhi 2019). A team of crocodile husbandry and management staff at the Dangmal/Bhitarkanika Research Facility are now engaged to capture problem C. porosus and relocate them back to suitable locations within BNP (Anon 2008a). Previously, groups of captive-bred C. porosus were released by the Forest Department in the southern-most part of BNP, primarily as a deterrent strategy for human activities in the mangrove forest (Kar 2007).

Concerns about the potential impact of the Dhamara seaport and Rengali canal developments on BNP and its C. porosus population were raised previously (see Webb et al. 2010). However, Dhamara seaport has now been in operation since 2010 and does not appear to have had a detrimental effect on the crocodile population or its mangrove habitats. Studies conducted by government and non-government agencies on the impact of the Rengali Dam (upstream Brahmani River) on the flow of fresh water also highlighted negligible impact on mangrove ecosystems, including those in BNP, and at present there appears to be sufficient freshwater flow from both the Brahmani and other rivers (e.g. Baitrani and Kharasrota Rivers).

In the Indian portion of the Sundarbans in West Bengal, daytime surveys in January 2012 reported a relative density of 0.11 non-hatchlings/km (1,163 km), with a bias towards adults (49.3%) although this is typical of daytime surveys and is not considered to reflect the real population size structure (Choudhury et al. 2012). As of March 2012, more than 450 C. porosus had been bred at the Forest Department of West Bengal’s farm in the Sundarbans and released into the wild (Nagchoudhury 2012).

Although C. porosus are known to be widely distributed in areas with suitable breeding habitat (freshwater swamps), there are no recent data on the status of C. porosus in the Andaman Islands (Whitaker and Whitaker 1978, Andrews and Whitaker 1994). Human occupation is considered to be displacing crocodiles (Andrews and Whitaker 1994) and HCC is an increasing problem (Whitaker 2008, 2009; Giles 2015) that threatens tourism, which is the biggest industry in the islands. A review of management options for the Andaman Islands was conducted in July 2018 (G. Webb, pers. comm. 2018).  

Indonesia
An extensive survey program was conducted by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the Indonesian CITES Management Authority (PHKA - Direktorat Jenderal Perlindungan Hutan dan Konservasi Alam) in the 1990s, but it did not provide an estimate of the total population of C. porosus within Indonesia, nor its distribution across the archipelago nation (CITES 1994). The stronghold for C. porosus is West Papua and Papua Provinces, particularly the Mamberano River drainage in the north. Past human exploitation and habitat alteration have reduced the population of C. porosus throughout much of Indonesia, although localities in Sumatra and the extensive rivers and lowlands of Kalimantan clearly support wild populations. With the exception of Papua and West Papua Provinces, captive breeding and ranching (subject to approval and population monitoring) of C. porosus is permitted elsewhere in Indonesia (e.g. Java, Sumatra, Kalimantan, Sulawesi). In July 2007, there were 15 registered farms in Indonesia (Manolis 2007, Manolis and McInnes 2007), but the number is now reduced. The last intensive review of crocodile conservation and management in Indonesia was in the early 1990s (Webb and Jenkins 1991), although some aspects of management were dealt with by a IUCN SSC Crocodile Specialist Group (CSG) mission in 2014 (Brien et al. 2014).

Despite a self-imposed hunting moratorium between 1994 and 1996, it seems that by 1997 many crocodile farms in Papua Province had stockpiles of wild C. porosus skins collected during this time. Based on these stockpiles, the management plan was revised in 1997 to allow ranching (Directorate General of Forest Protection and Nature Conservation 1997) (H. Kurniati, pers. comm. 2009). A system of ranching (juveniles) and wild harvest (sub-adults), similar to that established in neighbouring Papua New Guinea, is now well established in West Papua and Papua Provinces.

Annual export quotas are established by the Indonesian CITES Scientiﬁc Authority (LIPI - Lembaga Ilmu Pengetahuan Indonesia) based on monitoring results, and the CITES Management Authority (PHKA) regulates the quotas. Spotlight surveys, which form the basis for monitoring the wild C. porosus population (Kurniati and Rumbarar 1999), were not undertaken between 1998 and 2008, and a zero export quota for the species was put in place. In 2007, it was reported that about 10,000 hatchlings were taken through ranching (H. Kurniati, pers. comm. 2009). Industry is also interested in an egg harvest, which was undertaken on a trial basis with the New Guinea Crocodile (C. novaeguineae) in the early 1990s under an FAO project (Manolis and McInnes 2007), but costs of collection in the remote swamps of West Papua and Papua Province have been prohibitive (H. Kurniati, pers. comm. 2009). Concerns have been raised that the harvest quotas in Papua Province could be increased and that the system of quota allocation between farms may not be equitable (Manolis and McInnes 2007). Although minimum and maximum size limits for wild C. porosus skins (25 cm and 51 cm belly width respectively) are established, large skins are still purchased illegally by buyers. It is difﬁcult for hunters to distinguish between the two species of crocodiles around the maximum size limit.

It is widely recognized that the crocodile industry in Indonesia (as in Papua New Guinea) is an important, and sometimes the only, source of cash income for many rural communities in remote areas. In 2015, 8133 skins were exported from Indonesia (Caldwell 2017).

Malaysia
The Malaysian population of C. porosus was transferred to CITES Appendix II in 2016, mainly to allow the State of Sarawak to implement a wild harvest and ranching program to create incentives to address increasing levels of HCC (CITES 2016). A zero export quota for wild specimens of C. porosus currently applies to Peninsular Malaysia and Sabah.

Peninsular Malaysia: Saltwater Crocodiles were considered relatively rare but are now sighted more regularly throughout Peninsular Malaysia (e.g. Klang River; Kwan 2017). Sebastian (1993) listed 10 localities where C. porosus had been reported and suggested that the Setui-Chalok-Bari basin on the east coast near Terengganu may contain the most signiﬁcant population, but this is yet to be conﬁrmed by surveys. A preliminary survey of C. porosus in Rembau Estuary in 2009 indicated a relative density of 2.9 non-hatchlings/km with the presence of hatchlings indicating successful nesting the previous season (Nazli and Hashim 2009). In July 2013, a large C. porosus, estimated to be around 6 m long, was found dead on the banks of the Kuala Selangor River at Bukit Belimbing, Kuala Selangor. A sack and plastic bag found in its stomach suggested that pollution may have been implicated in its death (Chen 2015).

Sabah: Surveys of the C. porosus population have been undertaken irregularly over time in Sabah. Stuebing and Mohammed Sah (1992) surveyed the Klias River and found a small but viable population of around 50 individuals (hatchling-adult), while Cox and Gombek (1985) reported uniformly low densities throughout Sabah. Kaur (2006) reported that the relative density of C. porosus in the Segama River had increased from around 0.04 individuals/km in 1981 (Whitaker 1984) to 1.42 individuals/km in 2005. Stuebing (2002) reported a mean density of 1.1 non-hatchlings/km in Sabah rivers—22 times that reported by Whitaker in 1984 (0.05 non-hatchlings/km). A three-year state-wide survey program across 11 of Sabah’s largest rivers, selected on the basis of historical data and incidence of HCC, was completed in late 2019 to assess status and population trends. Preliminary results from six of those rivers indicated a mean relative density of 0.66 non-hatchlings/km; Luke Evans pers. comm. 2017). Notwithstanding that the preliminary mean density reported in 2019 is lower than that reported by Steubing et al. (2002), there is little doubt that the C. porosus population in Sabah has recovered signiﬁcantly over the last 20+ years. This is considered to be the result of a combination of legal protection (since 1982), a decline in the timber industry which decreased habitat/river disturbance, stabilization of oil palm estates and secondary growth along river banks, opening of closed canopy swamp and riverine forest, the El Niño-Southern Oscillation episode of 1997-98 which reduced ﬂooding of nests and led to high recruitment that year, and a dramatic decline in the harvest of wild crocodiles for skins during the late 1990s due to both lower prices and the implementation of CITES (Steubing et al. 2002).

The increase in HCC in recent years (30 attacks in 2015–2019; CrocBite 2020) is of major concern to authorities (Webb 2008). Problem crocodiles have been captured and removed to farms (Look Fook Soon Trading, unpublished data), although some individuals are shot due to their proximity to human habitation. The current state-wide survey program will inform a new management plan to be drafted in 2020.

Sarawak: Saltwater Crocodiles occur in most major rivers in Sarawak and large individuals are sufﬁciently common to be a serious threat to people. Surveys undertaken in the early 1980s found uniformly low densities of crocodiles throughout Sarawak (0.05 non-hatchlings/km; Cox and Gombek 1985) but recent surveys indicate that numbers have increased markedly since that time (CITES 2016). Surveys conducted in 2012–2014 indicated densities of 0.68 non-hatchlings/km (Sarawak Forestry Department) and 0.83 non-hatchlings/km (Sarawak Forestry Corporation), and the population was estimated to be around 12,000–13,500 individuals (CITES 2016). Sarawak is currently implementing the “Management Plan for Estuarine Crocodile (Crocodylus porosus) in Sarawak 2016–2020” which includes removal of problem crocodiles, population surveys and monitoring, wild harvest and ranching, and community-based ecotourism and research.

The size structure of the population, with a high proportion of large individuals, is considered to have contributed to high rates of HCC. Attacks on humans in Sarawak have increased over time (1980–1999: 1.85/yr; 2000–2009: 4.3/yr; 2010–2017: 8.5/yr; CrocBite 2018; Lading 2004) leading authorities to undertaking culling operations in areas where fatal attacks have taken place. In May 1992, a notorious and distinctively marked (white back) C. porosus, Bujang Senang, was killed after 30 years in which it is reported to have eaten 13 people (Ritchie and Jong 1993).

Myanmar
Once widely distributed throughout all coastal areas, C. porosus is now largely restricted to the lower Ayeyarwady (= Irrawaddy) River, and coastal Rakhine and Tanintharyi states. The only viable population is in Meinmahla Kyun Wildlife Sanctuary (MKWS) and adjacent forest reserves of the Ayeyarwady Delta, where nesting and recruitment were documented in 1999 (Thorbjarnarson et al. 2000; 2003; 2006). The sanctuary was resurveyed in January 2017 and the numbers were comparable to the 1999 survey (S. Platt et al. unpublished data). It is speculated that this population may function as a source population for coastal regions in southern Myanmar, including offshore islands in the Myeik Archipelago and one of the only significant populations of C. porosus remaining on mainland southeast Asia. Reports of crocodile attacks (CrocBite 2018) indicate that C. porosus is present in the Myeik Archipelago, albeit at low densities. MKWS could also be the source of crocodiles that recently turned up near Phuket Island, Thailand.

Platt et al. (2015) surveyed Lampi Marine National Park in the Tanintharyi region of Myanmar and found no evidence of an extant crocodile population, although it harboured a population of C. porosus as recently as the 1990s. Local extinction is attributed to direct persecution, egg harvesting (for domestic consumption and sale), and capture of crocodiles to sell to buyers from crocodile farms in Thailand. The park appears to be a potential site in which C. porosus could be reintroduced. It is also possible the island group could be recolonized by crocodiles dispersing from MKWS or elsewhere on the mainland.

A small population of approximately 20 C. porosus is known to occur in Ban Pone Chaung, a mangrove wetland on the mainland near Ywa Thit Village in the southern Tanintharyi region (Platt et al. 2014). A few crocodiles reportedly still occur in the Tanintharyi River, although these probably do not constitute a viable population (Platt et al. 2012). Other small populations of questionable viability are rumoured to be scattered along the coast from Ywa Thit northwards to Myeik but have not been formally confirmed (Platt et al. 2014).

Hatchlings from the MKWS were collected for captive rearing and 68 were released back to the wild when up to 1.2 m long between 1998 and 2001 (Thorbjarnarson et al. 2006). A farming-ranching program was implemented by the government in 1978 and the first farm (Thaketa Crocodile Farm) established in 1979 (Aung Moe 1994). Juvenile C. porosus collected from the wild (4097 between 1978 and 1999) and captive-bred individuals (3,087 hatchlings between 1983 and 1999) were used to stock the farm. Exports were mainly of live animals to Thailand and Singapore but since 1990 there has been limited production. The farm remains in operation but continues to be poorly managed (Platt et al. 2013) due to a range of technical problems (Thorbjarnarson et al. 2006). Efforts to register it as a CITES captive breeding facility in early 2008 were unsuccessful. In 2013, the farm maintained 500-600 crocodiles, ranging in size from hatchlings to large adults. Hatching success is poor and may be related to the nutritionally inadequate diet of marine fish and fish skins (obtained from a nearby fish processing facility) provided to adult breeders.

During the 1970s, the Government of Cambodia presented three C. siamensis to General Nwe Win, the former ruler of Myanmar. The C. siamensis can no longer be accounted for, and it is unknown if these hybridized with the more numerous C. porosus in the farm. Platt et al. (2013) recommended Thaketa Crocodile Farm concentrate solely on public education where it could make a significant contribution to regional crocodile conservation.

Palau
Saltwater Crocodiles were extensively hunted in Palau for their skins between the 1960s and 1980s. The ﬁrst systematic survey of crocodiles undertaken in 1991, by Messel and King (1992b), recorded 42 crocodiles in 112 km of waterways concentrated in two small populations at North Estuary on Belilou and Ngerdok Lake on Babeldaob. Brazaitis et al. (2009) estimated the total population to be 500–750 individuals from a survey in 2003. The Bureau of Marine Resources has run a crocodile program since 2004 and conducted surveys between 2005 and 2008. The most recent surveys revealed relative densities of 0.41 to 1.48 individuals/km in coastal mangrove habitat, and 0.41 to 2.81 individuals/km in creeks with the majority of individuals estimated to be 0.6–3.0 m total length (J. Eberdong pers. comm 2008). The available survey results suggest that the population has not increased signiﬁcantly since the early 1990s but is probably stable. However, interviews with 46 past and present crocodile hunters in 2002/2003 suggested that there were more crocodiles than there had been historically (Matthews 2003, 2005).

There have been two crocodile attacks reported in Palau, the first in 1965 and the most recent in 2012 (CrocBite 2018). The Palau program focuses on ‘problem’ crocodile complaints and public awareness, with 21 problem crocodiles reported between 2005 and 2008, mostly from the north of the country (J. Eberdong, pers. comm. 2009). A few adult C. porosus were maintained in captivity in Koror, which have produced captive-bred hatchlings that have been released back into the wild. The success of reintroduction remains unknown.

Despite concerns about the genetic integrity of C. porosus in Palau due to past importation of different crocodile species (New Guinea Crocodile: C. novaeguineae; Philippines Crocodile: C. mindorensis, and American Alligator: Alligator mississippiensis; Brazaitis et al. 2009), an analysis of 39 blood samples from wild C. porosus conﬁrmed no hybridization (Russello et al. 2007). A CSG review in 2005 highlighted the fact that crocodiles are not currently protected by law, and that the public generally “dislike” them and consider them pests (Anon 2006). At times, crocodiles are killed and eaten as food but are not thought to be detrimental to their numbers.

Papua New Guinea
Crocodylus porosus is widely distributed throughout the lowlands of Papua New Guinea and on the islands of New Britain, New Ireland, Bougainville and Manus. Current management of the wild population involves ranching (eggs, hatchlings, juveniles) and wild harvest (with size limits to protect breeding stock). A monitoring program has included regular nest surveys of representative habitats in the middle Sepik River since 1982 with a review of the program carried out in 1995 and subsequent revision of nesting indices (Manolis 1995). Nesting surveys indicate that the C. porosus population in the Sepik River is healthy and increasing at a rate of 2.4% p.a., with greater than 70 nests detected annually from 2003–2014 across 12 primary sites (Solmu et al. 2014). This increase has been attributed in part to a conservation awareness campaign and conservation incentives generated from an expanded C. porosus egg harvest (Wilken and Langelet 2004, Sine and Kula 2006, Solmu et al. 2014). The increasing involvement of local communities in the egg collection program has helped turn a HCC problem into an economic opportunity that supports the conservation of C. porosus (Solmu et al. 2014). However, increasingly strict skin grading standards in the international market have resulted in reduced purchases of ranched juveniles by farms leading to a reduction in price for wild skins, and thereby threatening the incentives that have been created in some remote areas through the program (E. Langelet, pers. comm. 2018).

Introduced ﬁsh (Pacu: Piaractus brachypomus, Java Barb (Java Carp): Barbonymus gonionotus) continue to degrade nesting habitats (Cox et al. 2006, G. Solmu, pers. comm. 2018) although other factors (e.g. climate change) may be implicated. Consideration is currently being given to size and quality of current remaining habitats, land tenure and land use, presence of other fauna and expansion (data collection) into new areas in which the Sepik Wetlands Management Initiative (formed in 1998) is working.

Given the very large area of inaccessible and undeveloped habitat, and the incentives for local traditional landowners to maintain crocodiles, C. porosus appears secure in Papua New Guinea. Reports from New Britain suggest that increasing numbers of attacks on people and livestock were due to increasing numbers of C. porosus (PNG National Newspaper, 28 August 2009). However, attack data reported by CrocBite (2017) for the country as a whole suggest that the frequency of attacks by C. porosus has remained somewhat stable over the last 15 years (5.6 per year; range 1 to 11).

Philippines
Saltwater Crocodile populations and habitats are reduced throughout the Philippines, and no large populations of C. porosus remain (Ortega et al. 1994). Today they exist as a few single individuals, small groups, and some iconic populations scattered through remaining wetland habitats. Areas with the highest numbers of C. porosus are thought to be on the island of Mindanao (e.g. Ligawasan Marsh), rivers and estuaries around southern Palawan, Sulu Archipelago in southwestern Philippines, northeastern Mindanao and some part of northeastern Luzon. A recent survey (Manalo et al. 2012) found evidence of basking areas that are potential nesting sites in the Agusan River basin, but no large viable population of C. porosus is known to exist. The connectivity of the islands of Palawan and Mindanao with the northeast coast of Borneo suggests a shared crocodile population.

The Balabac Group of Islands in southern Palawan had higher numbers of C. porosus compared to other areas in the Philippines. Recent population data derived from spotlight surveys at 17 locations reflects that the population in the southern portion of Palawan, at a density of 1.05 individuals/km, is higher than previously thought and the historical declines appear to be reversible. The populations of C. porosus in Sulu Archipelago, Zamboanga Peninsula and Siargao Island are still viable (R. Manalo, pers. comm. 2018), and locally protected. Surveys conducted in 2019 recorded the presence of C. porosus along the coast of southern Mindanao and in the coastal municipalities of Surigaodel sur Province, with high numbers in Tawi-tawi (1.78 individuals/km) in Sulu Archipelago. Although both C. porosus and C. mindorensis co-exist in Ligawasan Marsh, interviews with local residents in 2007 suggest that C. mindorensis is more commonly sighted than C. porosus (Pomares et al. 2009). To date, no surveys have been undertaken to quantify the abundance of either species in the area. The northern Sierra Madre National Park in Isabela also appears home to a small population of C. porosus (R. Manalo, pers. comm. 2018), which is threatened by killing as pests, by-catch in ﬁshing nets, and agricultural encroachment (Manalo 2004).

In the late 1980s and early 1990s, the majority of the remaining wild adult C. porosus population on Palawan (141 individuals) and Mindanao (115 individuals) were caught or acquired from private collectors and relocated to the Crocodile Farming Institute, where they formed the nucleus of a captive breeding population. The progeny of these animals were later relocated to private establishments, some of which have begun commercial farming based on captive breeding (Mercado 2007). Captive-bred stock are thus available for reintroduction efforts in the future (Crocodylus Porosus Philippines Inc., pers. comm. 2018).

Of 26 crocodile attacks in the Philippines in 2000–2015, 20 occurred in southern Palawan (Corvera et al. 2017) despite no evidence of an increasing crocodile population. Crocodiles that threaten the safety of people and livestock are usually killed, but in most cases crocodiles are afforded a level of protection by indigenous communities that still practice their cultural beliefs toward crocodiles and their habitats. In addition, continuous information and education campaigns throughout the species’ distribution are being conducted to strengthen human-crocodile coexistence (R. Manolo pers. comm. 2019).

In February 2007, a forum convened to address conservation, management and sustainable use of crocodiles in the Philippines (Anon 2007). This led to an exchange of information and experience between organizations in Luzon (Mabuwaya Foundation) and Mindanao (University of Southern Mindanao) (USM Crocodile Research Team 2007; Mabuwaya Foundation Inc. 2007), and closer collaboration with the crocodile farming industry (Crocodylus Porosus Philippines Inc.). In 2015, the Philippine Government reconstituted the Philippine Crocodile National Recovery Team (PCNRT), to be known as the National Committee for the Conservation of Crocodiles (NCCC). The NCCC developed the “Conservation and Management Plan for the Crocodile in the Philippines” that serves as a guiding framework for both species of crocodiles in the country. The key goals and strategies include the establishment of sanctuaries, enhancement of social understanding and acceptance, implementation of protocols in managing human-crocodile conflict, and effective monitoring and management of wild and captive populations (see Manalo and Mercado 2019). A second forum on crocodiles in the Philippines (theme: Strengthening Partnerships in Conservation Research and Sustainable Management of Crocodiles) was convened in March 2019 (Manalo and Mercado 2019).

Seychelles
Crocodiles were noted when the first Europeans visited the Seychelles in 1609. Re-examination of skeletal material suggests that the species that occurred there at the time of European discovery was C. porosus, and not C. niloticus as previously assumed (Gerlach and Canning 1993). Europeans had extirpated the population by the early 1800s.

Singapore
Considered to have been extinct in Singapore, Saltwater Crocodiles have been present and breeding in Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve (SBWR), on the northwest coast of Singapore, since around 2004 (H.C. Beng, pers. comm. 2017). The reserve is around 130 ha in size and was listed as an ASEAN Heritage Park in 2003. Given the high rate of local and international visitation to SBWR, the potential for HCC is of concern to authorities so barriers have been constructed along some walkways that are close to where crocodiles regularly bask to mitigate the HCC risk (H.C. Beng, pers. comm. 2017). CrocBite reports 26 attacks between 1842–1957 with the two most recent attacks in 1974 and 1989. Individual C. porosus have been reported in other parts of Singapore. The population was previously estimated to comprise around 15 adults but this number can vary from year to year, and in 2017 only 5–6 adult C. porosus were regularly sighted (H.C. Beng, pers. comm. 2017). The source of the C. porosus population in Singapore is considered to be Peninsular Malaysia, which is around 1 km from Singapore. One crocodile tagged with a location device by Singaporean authorities regularly travelled every few days between the two countries.

Solomon Islands
The only vessel-based survey of crocodiles in the Solomon Islands was undertaken in 1989 by Messel and King (1990) who identiﬁed survey sites based on knowledge from local people and crocodile hunters. Suitable habitat is restricted by the terrain and further reduced by human occupation and agriculture. Most sightings were from three localities - Lauvi Lagoon (Guadacanal), Lake Tatae (Russell Islands) and Ghahirahobo (Santa Isabel). With the cessation of hunting for skins in 1989, the C. porosus population has increased, resulting in increased HCC and fatalities in different parts of the country. The situation has been exacerbated by the banning of firearms following civil unrest and the arrival of the Australian-led Regional Assistance Mission (RAMSI) in 2003, such that local people were unable to deal with problem crocodiles themselves.

In 2018 (April–August), WorldFish in partnership with the Solomon Islands Government, conducted a nationwide survey of community knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs toward crocodiles (Van der Ploeg et al. 2019). The purpose was to obtain reliable information on the population status of saltwater crocodiles and the extent of HCC in the country. This would in turn be used to develop a management plan as identified in the Solomon Islands National Biodiversity Strategic Action Plan 2016–2020. A total of 822 people (472 men and 350 women) were interviewed in 234 villages in seven provinces across the Solomon Islands. The knowledge of local people on the number of crocodiles in particular areas proved to be a robust way of estimating abundance. A total of 225 crocodile attacks on people were reported since 1998, 83 of which were fatal (37%) including 31 children. Over the past 10 years, on average, five people per year have been killed by saltwater crocodiles. Since the cessation of commercial hunting in 1993, the saltwater crocodile population has recovered rapidly. It is estimated that there are now between 1,400 and 2,300 non-hatchling Saltwater Crocodiles in the country, with breeding reported on every major island (Van der Ploeg et al. 2019).

With more and larger saltwater crocodiles present, the number of attacks on people has and will continue to increase. Throughout the archipelago, communities are taking preventive measures to minimize the risks of crocodile attacks, with people emphasizing the need to supervise children, avoid fishing alone, and be alert at night and during floods. Flashlights are considered an effective tool to prevent a crocodile attack, and in many villages, crocodiles are killed by local hunters with traps and spears as a precautionary measure or in retaliation of an attack. Cultural restrictions on killing and eating crocodiles remain pervasive throughout the country. Crocodiles are widely regarded as taboo (sacred) animals that need to be treated with respect, with attacks often attributed to the wrath of ancestors or to sorcery (Van der Ploeg et al. 2019).

Sri Lanka
The status of C. porosus in Sri Lanka varies between locations, although how current abundance in different areas compares to historical abundance is unknown. The C. porosus population in Sri Lanka was estimated to be around 375 non-hatchlings in 1978, with the majority (70%) conﬁned to the southwest coast of the island (Whitaker and Whitaker 1979). More recently, Amarasinghe et al. (2015) conservatively estimated the C. porosus population to be around 2000 non-hatchlings, although field surveys are yet to support these numbers.
