Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). As culture fish are genetically distinct from natural populations, the release of aqua-cultured fish can result in a range of genetic outcomes, from no detectable effect to complete introgression or displacement of wild populations (Hindar et al. 1991). Fishes of the genus Takifugu are relatively recently diverged, and each combination of Takifugu species is expected to produce fertile hybrid crosses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). It is therefore likely that the effect of intentional and unintentional release of cultured Takifugu on the genetic integrity of wild populations is significant.

Regional threats: environmental degradation and over-fishing
Major threats to biodiversity of the China seas include over-exploitation of fishery resources and environmental deterioration. The China Seas have faced severe environmental degradation due to a range of anthropogenic activities within a relatively recent and short time frame (Daoji and Daler 2004). The degradation of estuarine environments due to pollution and coastal production is of particular concern, as these areas are characterized by high productivity and represent spawning and nursery areas for many species (Liu 2013). Large areas of the China Seas (Liu 2013) and the Gulf of Thailand (Blaber 2000) are considered to be heavily overfished. Additionally, heavy bottom-trawling in the 1980s and the widespread use of modified driftnets for multi-species fisheries in the Bohai Sea, combined with other anthropogenic stresses, have been implicated in the steady decrease in fish landings in this area (Xianshi 2004). In the Yellow Sea, previously dominant large demersal species became the targets of heavy fishing pressure during the 1950s and 1960s and greatly declined in abundance. By the 1980s, many large pelagic species were also showing great declines in abundance, and since that time the dominant species in the Yellow Sea have been small, planktivorous pelagic species, such as anchovies and sardines (Jin and Tang 1996). In the Yellow Sea, all ecological indexes such as the species number, species richness, species diversity and the evenness were lower in the year 2000 than in the year 1985 (Lin et al. 2005).
population: There is little species-specific population information available for wild populations of T. obscurus.
range: In the Western Pacific, Takifugu obscurus is known from the Yellow Sea, East China Sea and South China Sea south to the Korean Peninsula. It is found in rivers in China (Nakabo 2002). It is found to depths of at least 20 m, and may be found deeper.
useTrade:
Takifugu obscurus is a popular food fish in China and fetches a premium price owing to its high quality meat (Yang and Chen 2008). This is a species of interest for intensive aquaculture in China (Zhou and Jia-Xin 2003).

Aquaculture
Fishes of the genus Takifugu have become the focus of increasing aquaculture efforts throughout East Asia. Aquacultured Takifugu are used to meet increasing demand for pufferfish products and to enhance natural populations which have been depleted throughout the region (Kawata et al. 2012). Takifugu pufferfishes, principally represented by the tiger puffer, T. rubripes, are raised in floating net pens in Japan, Korea, and China (Belle and Nash 2009). The total wild catch of pufferfish species in Japan has been relatively stable, ranging from 7,800 to 11,000 tonnes from 1995 to 2002. The four most common species consumed in Japan areT. rubripes, T. snyderi, T. chinensis, and T. porphyreus. Aquaculture efforts focus on T. rubripes, which ranks fifth among marine aquacultured species (the top aquacultured species in Japan are: Yellowtail (Seriola quinqueradiata), Red Sea Bream (Pagrus major), coho Salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) and Japanese flounder (Paralichthys olivaceus). Although highly valuable (the market price of T. rubripes is 1.5 times that of Japanese flounder, three times that of yellowtail or seabream), the value began to decrease rapidly from the late 1990s onwards due to importation of Tiger puffer from China. In Japan, the majority of fingerlings produced in commercial hatcheries are then raised in floating net cages for direct consumption. About 15 million fingerlings are produced by commercial hatcheries for aquaculture, 1.5 times higher than the amount produced for release for stock enhancement by semi-governmental hatcheries in 1999. One of the most serious problems in the net cage aquaculture of tiger puffer is high (over 50%) mortality from outbreaks of parasitic diseases (Ogawa and Inouye 1997).

Tiger puffer (T. rubripes) was introduced to China from Japan (Lin and Huang 2007). To meet increasing demand for pufferfish, China began large-scale artificial breeding of pufferfish in the 1990s. An annual output of about 4,000 tonnes of T. rubripes, which was introduced from Japan to China (Lin and Huang 2007) is exported to Japan and South Korea. Additionally, an annual output of about 6,000 tonnes of T. obscurus was also produced for export in China. Pufferfishes are still landed in China, mostly in Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong and other places. Nationwide, the total output of pufferfish is now around 20,000 t per year (Ma et al. 2011)
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for T. obscurus, however, it is possible that management efforts aimed at sustaining T. rubripes fisheries have benefited T. obscurus. Additionally, T. obscurus has been bred in captivity to meet increasing demand and to enhance existing stocks.

Fugu fishery
The Fugu fishery is acknowledged to have undergone significant declines. Japan, South Korea and China previously operated their fisheries under a policy which prevented the regulation of foreign fishing vessels and treated the open sea in East Asia as common property. Since 1999, with the ratification of the United Nations (UN) Convention on the Law of the Sea and new fishery agreements between these nations, this policy has shifted to enable coastal countries to regulate foreign fishing vessels. As a result of this policy shift, Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which set dates for an off-fishing season, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock-enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, and mandated the release of small fishes. As of 2010, stocks had not fully improved, prompting a re-assessment of the program. Several recommendations have been made in order to ensure its continued existence, particularly in light of socio-economic constraints which limit the possibility of developing alternative fisheries. Recommendations include gear restrictions and mandating that fishers catch older and heavier fish by postponing the beginning of the fishing season (Kamara 2012).

In order to sustain fisheries of the East China Sea, the government of China has implemented a number of management and conservation measures. These include establishing a prohibited-fishing zone along the 50-m depth contour, the establishment of seventeen national nature reserves and five special marine protected areas, the creation of fishery protected areas which are annually closed to trawling, and a summer closed-fishing areas, which prohibit trawling and have been extended to the South China Sea, Yellow Sea, and Bohai Sea (Cheng et al. 2007).

Takifugu obscurus can be found in both freshwater and marine protected areas. According to the protection regulations for wetlands in the Poyang Lake of Jiangxi Province (2004) and the implementation of Chinese Fishery Lawin Jiangxi Province (1987), fishing is is banned from March 20th to June 20th every year in Poyang Lake. This corresponds with the spawning migration of this species in China, although whether or not this species spawns in the lake is unknown. Fishing has also been banned for two months from June 1st to July 31st each year since 1987 along the Xiajiang reach, Xingan reach, Jishui reach and Jian reach of the Ganjiang River, where this species has been recorded. However, this does not correspond to the freshwater spawning migration of this species (Huang et al. 2010).

Further research
The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008), and we support this recommendation.

rationale: Microphis jagorii is a brackish and freshwater pipefish that inhabits the Philippines and Ryukyu Islands, southern Japan. Little is known about the species' distribution, habitats, ecology, or threats.  Philippine river systems are threatened by riparian development, pollution, and diversion.  The genus Microphis is thought to be particularly susceptible to the aquarium trade, but this species has not been identified in trade to date. Further research is needed in order to determine the status of this species' freshwater habitat, the population size and trend, and to quantify the level of offtake, if any. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Microphis jagorii inhabits fresh and brackish waters (Dawson 1984). Little is known about its feeding, but it is likely similar to other pipefishes in feeding on small crustaceans (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). They are ovoviviparous, and males brood the embryos in a pouch beneath their trunk prior to giving live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1985).  They grow to a maximum size of 17.5 cm SL, and males are brooding at 12.15 cm (Dawson 1985).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation. River systems in the Philippines are being degraded due to riparian development, pollution, and water diversion, although none of these have been quantified. The species may be used in the aquarium trade. This needs to be investigated further, and, if present, quantified.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Microphis jagorii. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends for this species.
range: Microphis jagorii is known from fresh and brackish waters in the Philippines and the Ryukyu Islands (specifically Okinawa Island), southern Japan (Dawson 1984, 1985; Yoshino and Yoshigou 1998).
useTrade: Microphis jagorii has not been documented in trade to date, but pipefishes in general are traded for use in traditional medicine, as curios, and in the aquarium trade (Vincent et al. 2011). The genus Microphis is thought to be particularly susceptible to the aquarium trade (Dawson 1985). Levels of offtake are unknown and should be investigated.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place for Microphis jagorii. It's not clear whether the species occurs in any protected areas, and it is not mentioned in any international legislation or trade regulations.

rationale: Microphis pleurostictus is a freshwater pipefish species that is endemic to the waters in and around Lake Bato, Southern Luzon, Philippines. Although very little is known about its ecology or populations size, the species is endemic to less than five locations which have been severely degraded due to pollution, and has an area of occupancy of less than 500 km². Therefore this species is listed as Endangered under criterion B2ab(iii).
habitat: Microphis pleurostictus is a freshwater demersal species (Herre 1953). It is likely to feed on small benthic and/or planktonic crustaceans, similar to other syngnathids (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). The species is ovoviviparous and males brood the young (Dawson 1985).
threats: The freshwater Lake Bato has been severely polluted with trash and debris in recent decades (Aguiba 2014, Escandor 2014, Imperial and Saldilco 2014). Although it is unclear how such degradation affects the population of Microphis pleurostictus, the species appears to be endemic to the lake and surrounding waters.
population: Microphis pleurostictus is known from very few specimens, and no dedicated surveys or population estimates have been undertaken. The species is endemic to the heavily degraded Lake Bato, which suffers from pollution from garbage and solid waste (Aguiba 2014, Escandor 2014). Such degradation is likely leading to declines.
range: Microphis pleurostictus occurs in freshwater ecosystems where it is endemic to Batu (Bato) Lake and Yassot Creek in Luzon, Philippines (Herre 1953, Dawson 1985). It may also be present in other tributaries to the lake.
useTrade: Microphis pleurostictus has not been recorded in trade.
conservationActions: There is a Lake Bato revitalization project currently underway, led by both provincial and local government officials: the Department of Environment and Natural Resources, the Bureau Fisheries and Aquatic Resources, and senators. It was launched in February 2014 (Imperial and Saldilco 2014). Legislation and restoration are required to ensure the health of the Lake Bato ecosystem.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,004 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in four threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: Both adults and juveniles of this species have been recorded living in and around clear, relatively cold, fast-flowing streams in montane cloud forest that are shaded with 70–90% tree canopy cover  (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012, Gabadage et al. 2014). Water temperature in the streams range between 16.9–18.6 degrees C (17.8 ± 0.5 degrees C) and the depth of water varies from 40–80 cm. Individuals have been commonly observed on the moss-covered boulders by, next to, and in streams. Most boulders have accumulated leaf litter on the surface, under which individuals and amplectant pairs have been found (Gabadage et al. 2014). All juveniles were observed near stream banks covered with leaf litter and gravel. All other individuals were found on the land within ~1-2 m of water. Of the males observed, 89% were found on boulders (2–4 m circumference, 30–50 cm above the water level) in mid-stream (Gabadage et al. 2014). When disturbed, individuals of this species dive into the streams and retreat into submerged rocky crevices, remaining underwater up to 15–25 minutes without emerging. Ten pairs in amplexus have also been found underwater, but no details of egg laying and development have been noted (Gabadage et al. 2014). It is expected to breed in streams by larval development, as with its congeners. This species is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). A stream at one of the popular tourist sites, 'Seethagagula', has been blocked in one place by a private company, and the water has been diverted to an artificial tank to facilitate a place for visitors to bathe (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Downstream from this site large amounts of domestic chemicals (e.g., shampoo) are being disposed of in the stream, and it is suspected that this could negatively impact amphibian populations given that large aggregations of tadpoles (not of this species) were observed at higher elevations of the same stream, but in areas below the polluted site low densities or no individuals were observed (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Furthermore, during the dry season the reduced volume of water in the stream may lead to greater concentrations of chemicals in the breeding pools (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).

Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. Additionally, during the wet season fish species such as the Stone Sucker (Garra ceylonensis) travel upstream and block the stream in several places, which could create a barrier for the breeding of this species as it is suspected to breed in streams (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Invasive plant species are also suspected of causing changes to the understory and canopy cover of the area (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Road construction and the planting of non-native tree species may lead to soil erosion and landslides, making existing habitat unsuitable for this species (Gabadage et al. 2014). Within Piduruthalagala Forest Reserve, the construction of mini hydropower stations pose a threat to the species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also presents a threat to this species, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016).  This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented within Peak Wilderness, and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species was previously known from only two specimens (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). There had been no sightings since the original description and the species was believed to be extinct (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 1998), given that surveys in the the general area of Kandy turned up no new records. It was rediscovered in 2009, when close to 100 individuals were recorded over the course of a two-year study to document amphibian species richness across an elevational gradient (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). Another subpopulation of 57 individuals was discovered 42 km away during further surveys from 2011-2014 (Gabadage et al. 2014). This species is thought to be common in suitable habitats during the wet season, however the pristine stream habitats in which it occurs are difficult to find (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range:
This species is endemic to Sri Lanka and for a long time was known only from the general type locality of "Ceylon" (= Sri Lanka). The scientific name appeared to suggest that it might have been collected in the vicinity of the city of Kandy in central Sri Lanka; however, all of the Central Province was referred to as Kandy in the late 19th century, when the species was described (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). 

In 2009 the species was rediscovered in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary in Central Province, Sri Lanka, at 1,879 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). The Sanctuary comprises 240 km², of which 211.75 km² have natural or semi-natural vegetation (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). Its eastern boundary is adjacent to Horton Plains National Park (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). In 2014, Gabadage et al. published a report of this species from another locality, in the southern portion of Pidurutalagala Forest Reserve from 1,400-1,600 m asl, which is ~42 km from the population in Peak Wilderness Sanctuary. It has since also been recorded from Hirikatuoya (S. Wijayasekara unpub. data February 2020) and Canyon village in Maskeliya (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020). Adenomus dasi has also been synonymised with this species, which provides additional individuals in Moray Estate in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary (Meegaskumbura et al. 2015). 

Overall, this species occurs at elevations ranging between 1,000-1,879 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012, Gabadage et al. 2014, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). This species is thought to be restricted to its known range, although it likely occurs at suitable elevations between mapped localities (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,004 km2, which is thought to represent four threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Although this species is found within the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, which has been declared part of the Central Hills World Heritage Sites, its habitat is under severe human pressure (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). It is also found within Piduruthalagala Forest Reserve and Hirikatuoya (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected areas where this species occurs, and expanded protection of cloud forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of tourism, pollution, encroaching agriculture, hydropower development, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Cyprinodon dearborni is broadly distributed throughout coastal habitats in Venezuela and the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao in the Netherland Antilles. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 163,122 km2. This species is dominant in coastal habitats throughout Caribbean drainages in Venezuela, and there is currently no indication of major population declines. Therefore, C. dearborni is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Cyprinodon dearborni occupies a range of coastal estuarine habitat, including lagoons, quiet backwaters, and mangrove pools (Pérez et al. 2012, Hylkema et al. 2015). This species is capable of temporary emersion, and can persist in thin films of water for several days when evaporative processes reduce available water in salt marshes and inland lagoons (Turko and Wright 2015). This species can withstand a broad range of salinities, and most often occurs in hypersaline lagoons (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970). Diet is comprised of detritus, unicellular algae, small macroalgae, zooplankton (Artemia), small crustaceans and bryozoans (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970, Carmona 1983, Cervigón 1991). Maximum reported body size is approximately 6.1 cm total length (TL) (Cervigón 1991).

Hypersaline estuaries are common on the northern coast of South America, due to their shallow depth (<1 m), rain regime with little rainfall and fresh water inputs, very high sunlight throughout the year, high water temperatures and consequently high evaporation. The salinity of these water bodies can vary between 36 ‰ to more than 60 ‰ in marginal areas of the lagoons, and between 80 ‰ and close to 140 ‰. In areas referred to as “Salinas”, depth can be just a few centimetres (Mago 1965, Kristensen 1970, Kristensen and Hulscher-Emeis 1972, Boer et al 1973, Cervigón and Gómez 1986, Cervigón 1991, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012).

Cyprinodon dearborni does not occur in freshwater rivers (lotic ecosystems) or freshwater inland lagoons (lentic ecosystems). In a number of studies, this species has been reported from lagoons that vary dramatically in salinity depending on the season. However, it is rarely found at salinities lower than 35 ‰ for any extended periods of time (Hulscher-Emeis 1972, Chung 1997, López et al. 1996, Marín 2000, Toledo et al. 2000, Torcatt 2015).

Females mature at an average size of 2.5 cm and an average age of 86 days (Carmona 1983, Cervigón 1991). Fecundity increases with size, ranging from 87 oocytes in females of 20 to 29 mm TL and 298 oocytes in females greater than 40 mm TL. Embryogenesis is temperature dependent and is completed in three days at 35 ° C and in six days at 26 ° C and is not affected up to a salinity of 51 ‰. There is diurnal territorial behaviour among males, for the defence of a mating and spawning area, as well as parental care by these of the fertilized eggs. The larvae are born with 3.42 and 3.96 mm TL and the yolk sac is reabsorbed five days after hatching and larval development is completed in 44 days at 12.5 mm TL.
threats:
In Venezuela, deforestation rates are exceeding 164,000 hectares annually, primarily resulting from agricultural expansion (Mazón et al. 2017). Coastal pollution including the discharge of heavy metals into coastal waterways is probably negatively impacting aquatic habitat in Laguna de Chacopata, Laguna de Los Patos, and in other regions characterized by urbanization and industrial processes (Toledo et al. 2000). In the Western region, north of Lake Maracaibo and the Gulf of Venezuela, as well as the coasts of the Falcón states, and the central eastern coasts of the Miranda, Anzoátegui, Sucre and Nueva Esparta states (Isla de  Margarita and Coche), oil spills, deforestation (slash and burn) of forests in the headwaters of the basins and mangrove forests, alteration of natural drainages (reservoirs, dredging and canals, dikes, channels, artificial lagoons), erosion and sedimentation, destructive floods, physical modification of Salinas associated with shrimp aquaculture and salt exploitation, contamination by domestic and industrial effluents, use of agrochemicals in upper and middle river basins, extraction of mineral material, and improper disposal of artificial solid waste (domestic and industrial waste) all continue to impact habitat quality (Rodríguez Altamiranda 1999, Conde and Carmona-Suarez 2003, Medina and Barboza 2006, Colonnello and Lasso-Alcalá 2011, Flores 2016, Suarez 2016, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2018).

The non-native Oreochromis mossambicus was introduced in 1964 in Laguna de los Patos (Sucre state) (Carvajal 1965) and its impact on native species has been well documented, displacing 80% of native species in a decade (Aguilera and Carvajal 1976). Likewise, this species has been recorded in some coastal lagoons on the Isla de Margarita (Lasso-Alcalá et al. 2008). Oreochromis nilotucus has been recorded in peripheral lagoon systems of Lago de Maracaibo, as well as in the Ciénagas de El Gran Eneal and Los Olivitos in the Gulf of Venezuela, though its impact on the native species has not yet been evaluated (González-Bencomo and Borjas 2003, Andrade et al. 2005, Lasso-Alcalá et al. 2008). Eleotris picta is an estuarine piscivore registered in a locality near the Morrocoy National Park and the “Cuare” Wildlife Refuge (Falcón state), where C. dearboni is present (Pezold and Cage 2002).

In the Netherland Antilles, naturally occurring freshwater habitat is vulnerable to human impact, including water extraction, impoundment, channelization, and contamination (Debrot 2003). There is anecdotal evidence suggesting that loss of connection with coastal habitat reduces the success of this species in inland waters due to alterations in food availability (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970). The economies of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao are driven largely by tourism, and continued coastal development will likely impact the availability and quality of habitat (Nijman et al. 2009).

The Mozambique Tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus) has established throughout coastal habitats on Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao, where it comprises a dominant portion of ichthyofaunal biomass and has apparently reduced the abundance of native species (Debrot 2003, Debrot et al. 2011, Buurt and Debrot 2012). Similarly, the Guppy (Poecilia reticulata) is established on all three islands, where it has been widely introduced as a biological control to mosquito larvae (Debrot 2003). There is a single collection of Xiphophorus helleri reported from Bonaire, but there is currently no evidence to suggest permanent establishment (Hulsman et al. 2008).

Despite inferred continuing decline in habitat quality, there is currently no indication that existing threats have resulted in major declines in population size or range extent.
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. However, it is reported as common to dominant throughout much of the western Caribbean province of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2007, 2011). Population trend is suspected to stable in the absence of major documented declines.
range:
Cyprinodon dearborni is broadly distributed throughout coastal habitats in Venezuela (Esmaeili et al. 2018), and the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao in the Netherland Antilles (Hulsman et al. 2008, Smith et al. 2011). Its reported coastal distribution extends from the Guajira Peninsula in eastern Colombia eastward to Isla de Margarita, Venezuela (Haney et al. 2009). The type locality of this species is Willemstad, Curaçao (Esmaeili et al. 2018). Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 163,122 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records.

In Colombia, this species is reported by de Beaufort (1940) from a single collection locality on the Península de la Guajira (station 114; 11.710, -72.664).

In western Venezuela, this species occurs in coastal lagoons of Pájaro (Goajira Península), Laguna Borrachón, Salina Rica, Salina Santa Rosa, Laguna Las Peonías, adjacent to Lago de Maracaibo, (Zulia State), and Tucacas salt flats, near the current Morrocoy National Park (Falcón State) and different lagoons and Salinas adjacent to Puerto Cabello (Carabobo state) (Beaufort 1940, Schultz 1949, Andrade 1984, Moscó and Viloria 2000). In the Gulf of Venezuela, it has been recorded from Laguna de Carapátida, the hypersaline lagoons of Sauca and Punta Caimán (Golfete de Coro), the Paraguaná Peninsula, and in the lagoon system of the “Cuare” Wildlife Refuge in the State of Falcón (Schultz 1949, Valdéz and Aguilera 1987, López et al. 1996, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2015).

In the Netherlands Antilles, this species is known from Willemstad Bay, Curaçao, and from numerous coastal lagoons, salt flats and closed bays of Aruba, Curaçao (María Pompuna, Saint Joris Bay, Zaquito), Bonaire (Pos Francés and Pos Lansberg, Salinas Plenchi, Oranje Pan, Pekelmer, Goto, Slagbaai, Bartool, Cay) and Klein Bonaire (Salina klein Bonaire) (Meek 1909, Metzelaar 1919, Beaufort 1940, Hummelinck 1940, de Boer et al. 1973).

In the eastern region of the coasts and islands of Venezuela, this species has been collected from numerous hypersaline littoral lagoons on Isla de Margarita (Laguna de La Restinga, Punta de Mangle, Punta de Piedras Los Portillos, Boca de Palo) and Isla de Coche (salinas) (Cervigón 1966, 1991, Cardona 1983, Cervigón and Gómez 1986, Ramírez Villarroel 1994a, 1994b, Nirchio 1996, González and Nirchio 1997, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012,)  and in lagoons of the Archipiélago de Los Roques (Laguna del Gran Roque, Cayo Sal) (Martín Salazar 1956, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012). Likewise, it is widespread throughout coastal lagoons to the northwest of Barcelona (Anzoategui State) (Schultz 1949), Salinas to the West of Cumaná (Laguna de Los Patos: Sucre State), in areas near the sea of Laguna de Unare (Anzoategui State) (Mago 1965, Marín 2000), in Laguna de Los Patos (Chung 1997, Toledo et al. 2000, Alfonsi et al. 2003) and in the Laguna de Bocaripo (Chacopata and Pérez et al. 2012).

According to the databases of the national museums of Venezuela (Museo de Historia Natural La Salle: MHNLS, Museo Oceanológco Benigno Román: MOBR, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de Guanare: MCNG, Museo de Biología Universidad Central de Venezuela: MBUCV and Museo de la Estación Biológica de Rancho Grande: EBRG, Colección Regional de Peces, Universidad Centrocidental Lisandro Alvarado: CP-UCLA), this species has 70 records in coastal marine lagoons or coastal lagoons hypersaline in the Isla de Margarita, Coche, Archipiélago de Los Roques, and continental coasts of the Zulia, Falcón, Miranda, Anzoátegui and Sucre states.

The presence of Cypinodon dearborni in Trinidad and Guyana, as suggested by Wildekamp (1995) and Haney et al. (2009), is unlikely, given high rainfall in the region that is not conducive to the development of hypersaline estuaries where this species lives. Additionally, in the most recent and complete listings for that region (Ramjohn 1999, Lasso et al. 2009, 2010, Vari et al. 2009, Phillip et al. 2013, Lemopoulos and Covain 2018), Cyprinodon dearborni has not been recorded.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
In Venezuela, some 400 areas have been decreed under the Special Administration Regime Areas, among which 98 protected areas stand out, such as two biosphere reserves, 43 national parks and 36 natural monuments, seven refuges and a fauna sanctuary (Flores 2016). However, only 32 have management plans and use regulations, and none have defined management programs (Flores and Aponte 2016). Therefore, their effectiveness is highly speculative. Some have suggested the need for modification and expansion of existing protected area networks to improve their effectiveness for aquatic conservation (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011).

The range of this species extends into a number of these coastal protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), including Médanos de Coro and Morrocoy National Parks (Falcón State), Archipiélago de Los Roques (Francisco de Miranda State), Laguna de Tacarigua (Miranda State), Laguna de La Restinga (Margarita Island, Nueva Esparta State), and Laguna Las Marites Natural Monuments (Margarita Island, Nueva Esparta State), Ciénaga de Los Olivitos (Zulia State), and Cuare (Falcón State) Wildlife Refuges, Hueque-Sauca, Tucurere (Falcón State) and Ciénaga de La Palmita and Isla de Pájaros (Zulia State) Wildlife Reserves, and Cabos, Puntas, Islands and Lagoons of Isla de Margarita (Nueva Esparta State) and Playa Norte (Falcón State) Protected Zones.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) because extensive surveys have not recorded the species since it was last collected in 1981. During the intervening time chytridiomycosis is known to have swept through the region causing devastating declines for many amphibian species, including species within this genus. Therefore the population, if any individuals remain, is estimated to be very small.
habitat: This species has been recorded from primary cloud forest on herbaceous vegetation and fallen leaves. It is also found in rocks near brooks and streams. It breeds by direct development.
threats:
Major threats include habitat loss and degradation caused by logging, agriculture activities and cattle grazing throughout its small range. The known locality passes a road and there is accumulation of garbage in the water bodies.

Other species of the genus that are associated with streams have undergone dramatic declines and disappearances, possibly due to chytridiomycosis, but there is no evidence that this species has declined due to this factor (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop August 2016).

While there is currently no direct information confirming that chytrid has caused declines in this species, [the lack of records since/in the 1990s] is consistent with the pattern of decline in many other montane Atelopus species, and it is therefore reasonable to infer that the disease might be the cause of declines in this species (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop August 2016).
population: It is uncommon; two specimens were collected in 1978 and a further four in 1981. Since then extensive repeated searches of the type locality have not found any individuals, and surveys in the surrounding areas have not recorded this species (G. González pers. comm. August 2016). The population trend is therefore unknown and the population size is thought to be fewer than 50 mature individuals.
range: This species is only known from the type locality: 4 km south of the junction of the Sonsón-Dorada and Argelia roads in Sonsón Municipality, Antioquia Department, in the northern part of the Central Cordillera of the Colombian Andes, at 2,350 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
The type locality does not fall within a protected area and the habitat has been so badly disturbed that it might not even be suitable for protection. In light of the possibility that chytrid may have been involved in declines, any surviving individuals might need to form the basis for the establishment of an ex situ population.

Research Needed
Further survey work is required to determine whether or not the species still survives at the type locality.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because, despite being common at some   localities and showing some degree of tolerance to human  intervention, it has an estimated extent of occurrence of only 2,030 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is known from only two locations where lowland and premontane forests are  rapidly being lost due to urban expansion.
habitat: It is a diurnal, riparian species that inhabits along narrow mountain creeks surrounded by dry lowland forests, humid premontane and montane forests. However, it can also be found in creeks surrounded by secondary forest, and at its type locality, the specimens were collected from an inundated culvert beneath a dirty road (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010), from which some degree of tolerance to habitat modification is inferred. Males call along the creeks, during the day (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010). Like other Mannophryne, it is presumed to make terrestrial nests near creeks and the males carry their tadpoles on their back to small pools in the creeks, where they complete their development.
threats: Although the subpopulation at Río Negro is within the limits of El Tamá National Park and the species' range also overlaps with Tapo-Caparo National Park, the lack of surveillance and law enforcement in the Venezuelan system of protected areas has undermined their protective function. The main threat to this species is habitat loss caused by small-scale agriculture (crops and livestock), pollution by agrochemicals, sewage and solid waste, forest clearance to establish pastureland, and surface water abstraction for irrigation and domestic use.
population: There is no precise information on its population size or trends, but it appears to be a common species throughout its range.
range: This species is known only from two distant localities in the southeastern part of the Venezuelan Andes on both sides of the Táchira depression: in Río Negro, on the northern slope of Tamá massif, and in the road Pregonero-La Trampa, on the southern part of Cordillera de Mérida in Venezuela. It has been recorded between 482–1,192 m asl (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010). Its current estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,030 km2, although its range is likely to extend more widely in this region.
useTrade: There are no records of use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
There are no conservation actions specifically aimed at this species. One of the two known subpopulations is within the limits of El Tamá National Park, and its range is likely to overlap with Tapo-Caparo National Park. This species is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in the Venezuelan Fauna Red List (Rodríguez et al. 2015).

Conservation Needed
Surveillance and enforcement of restrictions in El Tamá National Park and Tapo-Caparo National Park need to be strengthened to guarantee the conservation of the species’ habitat. Strengthening compliance with national laws related to watershed and forest protection would also contribute to the conservation of this species outside the national parks.

Research Needed
Research is required on its natural history, ecology, population size and trends, threats and geographic distribution. Also, because emerging diseases are a potential threat to the species, research is also needed on their occurrence, prevalence, and the species vulnerability to these diseases.

rationale: This species occurs in estuaries, coastal lagoons and coastal systems on the Atlantic slope of Central America from Belize, eastward to Panama. Population size and trend are unknown. Given a relatively broad distribution, a number of known collection localities, lacking evidence of major population decline, and inclusion in at least one protected area in each reported country, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Leptophilypnus fluviatilis is found in coastal lagoons and systems, mangroves and turbid streams over muddy bottoms. It has been reported in areas with salinity 5-15 ppm ranges (J. Carrasco 2020 pers. comm). It has been reported to feed on hyacinth roots (Nordlie 2006). In Costa Rica, elevational distribution ranges from 0-6 meters above sea level (Angulo et al. 2013).
threats: There is no specific threat information available for this species. However, this species is dependent on tropical estuarine systems and may be threatened by habitat loss and alterations. Specific threats include cattle ranching and banana growing in the Tortuguero watershed, Costa Rica, which may contribute to erosion, siltation and hydrological instability (Carr 1982). Plastic bags that are used to cover bananas in the plantations are transported to the coast and may pollute the habitats where this species is found. The development of mining in some areas of Costa Rica is also a possible concern. Loss of coastal mangrove habitat associated with urban and commercial development is an ongoing threat that continues to result in declines in habitat quality and availability (Polidoro et al. 2010).
population: This species is common, but not abundant (F. Pezold pers. comm. 2011). It was the least abundant elotrid collected from the Tortuguero Lagoon estuary in Costa Rica (Nordlie 1981). It is considered uncommon in Honduras where captured (C. Lardizabal pers. comm. 2020).
range:
Leptophilypnus fluviatilis is found in estuaries, coastal lagoons and freshwater systems along the Atlantic coast of Central America from the Belize to the Gulf of Uraba in Colombia (Thacker et al. 2006, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014, FishNet2 2020, GBIF 2020). It has also been reported from the Pacific side of the Panama Canal, and from the Osa Peninsula in southern Pacific Costa Rica (Robertson and Allen 2015).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 371,240 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calcualted around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020). Despite the presence of locally and regionally pervasive threats, this species is inferred to occur in greater than 10 threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions directed towards L. fluviatilis. However, the range of this species falls within a number of protected areas, including Cuyamel National Park, Jeannete Kawas National Park in Honduras, Tortugero National Park in Costa Rica, San Lorenzo forest protected area, Chagres National Park and Portobelo National Park in Panama (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). More information regarding population size and trend, and the magnitude of potential threats would be useful in guiding future conservation action.

rationale: Microphis fluviatilis is a freshwater pipefish species that is distributed on the east coast of Africa from Kenya to South Africa and Madagascar. There is no information available regarding the species' population size or trends in abundance. The species is likely declining due to a range of threats to freshwater systems across its range in southeastern Africa, including habitat degradation from pollution, altered flow regimes, overfishing, invasive species, and deforestation resulting in sedimentation. It's not clear to what extent these threats affect wild populations of Microphis fluviatilis.  Therefore the species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
Microphis fluviatilis occurs in coastal rivers and streams where it can be found in quiet water among vegetation (Skelton 2001) or in the vicinity of logs at river edges.This species likely feeds on minute invertebrate organisms such as crustaceans and insects (Dawson 1985). Ovoviviparous, during mating the female passes eggs to the male and the eggs become fertilized as they pass into the pouch of the male. The male brood the eggs and larvae in an abdominal pouch and give birth to fully formed young. 
Juveniles and adolescent individuals of some species in the same genus occur in marine waters whilst brooding males and adult females inhabit freshwaters or brackish water areas (Ishihara and Tachihara 2008).
threats: Threats to freshwater systems in the region are substantial and include flow alteration from dams, overexploitation, invasive species, and pollution. Most freshwater ecoregions within the range of Microphis fluviatilis are considered Vulnerable or Endangered, with some even being assessed as Critical (Thieme et al. 2005). Such threats are likely leading to declines in abundance for this species, but it's not clear to what extent they are applicable and how big of an effect they are having on wild populations.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Microphis fluviatilis. Further research is needed in order to understand population size and trends in abundance. The species is likely declining, as freshwater habitats in the region are considered either Vulnerable or Endangered when assessed against terrestrial, in-stream, and biotic stressors (Thieme et al. 2005).
range: This species is widespread throughout the coastal rivers of Eastern Africa, as well as Madagascar (Skelton 2001). It is found along the entire coast length from Sabaki River, Kenya, southwards to Coffee Bay, South Africa. It is also reported from Zimbabwe (Bell-Cross and Minshull 1988).
useTrade: This species has not been detected in trade. Other syngnathids are used for traditional medicine and in the aquarium trade (Vincent et al. 2011), and this species may also be present but likely in low numbers.
conservationActions:
Microphis fluviatilis is protected in some coastal reserves in southern Africa. More information on threats to this species is needed, as well as monitoring of population trends.
This species was assessed as Least Concern at various regional levels in Africa, but additional information about the poor status of freshwater habitats in eastern Africa (Thieme et al. 2005) lead to a listing of Data Deficient globally.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered as this species has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of only 36 km<sup>2</sup> and is known from only one threat-defined location. It is also facing a continuing decline in the quality of its habitat, resulting in a suspected decreasing population trend.
habitat: This species is known only from the highest peak in Indochina, occupying higher altitudes than any other species of Leptobrachella. It is associated with upper montane forest with a temperature range of -3°C to 20°C, heavy rainfall, and occasional snow in December (Rowley et al. 2013, Nguyen et al. unpubl. data August 2020). Males have been observed calling from under leaf litter next to small streams and females have been found nearby (Rowley et al. 2013). The species breeds in rocky streams by larval development. Its tadpoles have only been observed under submerged rocks in pools beneath small waterfalls (Nguyen et al. 2020). It is unclear whether breeding is truly restricted to waterfall microhabitats, however tadpoles of stream-breeding frogs are often microhabitat specialists (Inger 1986), and many congeneric larvae are thought to depend on rocky or gravel substrate (Ohler et al. 2011). The quality of habitat used by this species is currently in decline due to tourism (Rowley et al. 2013, Nguyen et al. 2020).
threats: The most immediate threat to this species' persistence is habitat degradation associated with tourism. Pollution by garbage and runoff from toilets is affecting the habitat of the species (Rowley et al. 2013, J. Rowley pers. comm. January 2016) and the construction of a cable car from Sa Pa to the summit of Mount Fansipan is likely to affect it (T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2015). Vegetation adjacent to the stream is being cut for use as fuel (J. Rowley pers. comm. January 2016). In addition, rocks and gravel that make up the species' larval microhabitat are being mined directly from streams for the construction and lining of tourist walking paths. This was observed in the same stream and only several hundred metres from where a tadpole was observed, and the rate of  gravel removal was observed to increase over surveys from 2017 to 2019 (Nguyen et al. 2020). Historic burning and subsequent ecosystem conversion of the summit of Mount Fansipan and adjacent areas, which are thought to have been previously covered in forest (Nguyen and Harder 1996), are also likely to have disturbed this species. The species' restriction to high altitudes near the mountain peaks will probably present an issue as tropical montane forests are expected to be particularly prone to alteration by climate change (Rowley et al. 2013, Foster 2001).
population: Very little is known about the size and trends of this species' population except that seven adult males and two adult females were found during surveys in 2012 (Rowley et al. 2013), and the species was detected again during surveys in 2015 (J. Rowley pers. comm. January 2016). During a series of eight surveys between 2017 and 2019, adults were detected 40 times, however it is possible that the same individuals were observed more than once (Nguyen et al. unpubl. data August 2020). The species is difficult to detect, even when calling (Rowley et al. 2013). The population is very likely to be in decline due to past and present habitat loss and disturbance, and pollution, which are ongoing in its range and specifically at one of its known localities (Rowley et al. 2013, Nguyen et al. 2020).
range: This species is known only from three localities, each less that 5 km apart in the Hoang Lien National Park, Lao Cai Province, Viet Nam. Its currently known elevation range is between 2,578-2,815 m asl (Rowley et al. 2013, Nguyen et al. 2020). At the time of its description, the species was only known from 2,795-2,815 m asl, and Rowley et al. (2013) estimated that its range may include some of the few small, isolated areas above 2,700 m asl in adjacent parts of the Hoang Lien Son Mountain Range. Such areas are about 20 km or more away, however the species' recent discovery at 2,578 m asl (Nguyen et al. 2020), makes it seem more likely that it occurs in a chain of areas above 1,550 m asl extending approximately 15 km southeast of known localities, each separated by distances of less that 1 km. The species has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of only 36 km2, and is known from only one threat-defined location, and is thus very restricted geographically.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: This species is currently only known from Hoang Lien National Park (Rowley et al. 2013). However, as habitat degradation from tourism practises is an ongoing threat, strategies for additional protection of habitat within its range is warranted. Further research into the species' ecology, distribution, abundance and population trends would improve conservation decisions.

rationale: Listed as Endangered as this species faces a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, and is known from five or fewer threat-defined locations, and has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 639 km².
habitat: This species is associated with upper montane bamboo, mixed bamboo and elfin moss forest (Nguyen et al. 2013, Rowley et al. 2013, Tapley et al. 2020), and secondary forest with medium and large hardwood species (C.T. Pham pers. comm. August 2020). Individuals have been observed on rocks in streams and in associated rock crevices and shallow, still water sections (Nguyen et al. 2013, Rowley et al. 2013, Tapley et al. 2020). The climate in its range is characterized by a temperature range of -3°C to 20°C, heavy rainfall, and occasional snow (Rowley et al. 2013). Much remains unknown about this species' life history including its reproduction; however free-swimming tadpoles have been observed in March (Tapley et al. 2020). This species has not been reported from disturbed areas and is forest-dependent. There is an ongoing decline in the extent and quality of forest habitat within this species' range (Sodhi et al. 2009, Tapley et al. 2020).
threats: The most immediate threat to this species' persistence is habitat degradation associated with tourism. Pollution by garbage and runoff from toilets is affecting the habitat of the species (Rowley et al. 2013, J. Rowley pers. comm. January 2016, Tapley et al. 2020) and the construction of a cable car from Sa Pa to the summit of Mount Fansipan is likely to affect it (T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2015, Tapley et al. 2020). Vegetation adjacent to the stream is being cut for use as fuel (J. Rowley pers. comm. January 2016). Historic burning and subsequent ecosystem conversion of the summit of Mount Fansipan and adjacent areas, which are thought to have been previously covered in forest (Nguyen and Harder 1996), are also likely to have disturbed this species. The species' restriction to high altitudes will probably present an issue as tropical montane forests are expected to be particularly prone to alteration by climate change (Foster 2001, Rowley et al. 2013). It is threatened by forest loss more broadly throughout its range (Sodhi et al. 2009).
population: Mount Fansipan has been surveyed relatively extensively compared to the majority of the region (e.g. Ohler et al. 2000, Nguyen et al. 2009, Rowley et al. 2013, Tapley et al. 2020), however, still little is known about the size and trends of this species' population except that it was locally abundant (>20 individuals observed) in 2012 and was observed again during surveys in 2015 (J. Rowley pers. comm. January 2016). Other surveys from 2016-2019 have found the species to be somewhat abundant at several stream sites (B. Tapley and L. Nguyen pers. comm. August 2020). Past and present habitat loss and disturbance, including pollution in the range of this forest dependent species is very likely causing declines in its population (Sodhi et al. 2009, Tapley et al. 2020).
range: This species is known only from Lai Chau and Lao Cai provinces in northern Viet Nam. Its currently known elevation range is 2,345-3,108 m asl (Tapley et al. 2020, C. T. Pham pers. comm. August 2020). This is unlikely to represent the actual limits of this species' range; habitat and elevations similar to those at its known localities occur in adjacent and intervening areas. Further surveys may reveal the species' presence in these areas and they have been included in the range map associated with this assessment as potential range. The species' estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 639 km², and its range is comprised of five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilised.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known from Hoang Lien National Park, Hoang Lien Son - Lai Chau Nature Reserve and Bat Xat Nature Reserve, Viet Nam (IUCN and UNEP 2014, Tapley et al. 2020). It may possibly occur in nearby Hoang Lien-Van Ban Nature Reserve based on habitat and elevation data but there have been no surveys there to confirm the species' presence. 

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur. 

Research Needed
The first step towards ensuring this species' persistence is addressing the lack of data; further research is needed on its true distribution, habitat and ecology, threats, and the size and trends of its population.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable because this species has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 19,712 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals occur in six to 10 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in the middle Río Marañón valley in the northern Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This frog is confined to rocky mountain streams of the Cordilleras Central and Occidental, in an area otherwise dominated by dry cactus scrub. It appears to exhibit a particular preference for the spray zones of waterfalls. Tadpoles of this species develop in small pools in streams (Duellman 2004, Koch et al. 2018), although adults and larvae have also been observed in a roadside artificial water chamber, suggesting some degree of tolerance to habitat modification (C. Koch pers. comm. March 2018). It is likely that this frog lays eggs on land and transports newly-hatched larvae to the natal pool; clutch size is unknown, but is between 12 and 40 eggs in related species (Duellman 2004).
threats:
The major threat to this species is habitat loss and degradation due to agricultural activities, fire clearing, and pollution of its breeding habitat (C. Koch pers. comm. March 2018). The landscape of Limon has been modified for agricultural reasons, and some local people in the region use tubes to divert water from streams to irrigate their cultivation, which might cause some problems to the species if it uses those streams to breed (C. Koch pers. comm. March 2018).

The fungal disease chytridiomycosis was first reported from Peru in 1998 (Lips et al. 2008), and has been associated with severe declines and extinctions among Andean amphibians, especially of high-elevation, stream-breeding frogs with small ranges (Whittaker and Vredenburg 2010). It is, however, unknown whether this disease represents a specific threat to this species. Restricted as it is to aquatic habitats scattered through an arid landscape, this frog may be vulnerable to climate change if rising temperatures result in the loss of high-altitude streams.
population: The species was described by Duellman (2004) from material collected in the 1970s and 1980s. In 2009, nine additional specimens were collected during surveys in Limon, Celendín Province in the Río Marañón valley (Koch et al. 2018). The species appeared to be quite abundant in Limon, and many adult specimens and larvae of different stages were observed over several days (C. Koch pers. comm. March 2018).
range: This species is endemic to Peru, where it has been recorded from a number of localities in the middle Río Marañón valley, at elevations between 1,260–2,600 m asl (Duellman 2004, Koch et al. 2018). Known sites are located within Chachapoyas, Bongará, and Bagua Provinces in the Region of Amazonas (Duellman 2004, Santos et al. 2014), and Celendín, Cajamarca, and Chota Provinces in the Region of Cajamarca (Duellman 2004, Santos et al. 2009, Koch et al. 2018). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 19,712 km2 and all individuals occur in six to 10 threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized. However, Peruvian species of Hyloxalus, in common with other poison dart frogs, may be at risk from smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
No conservation actions are currently known for this species. It is not known from any national protected areas (Aguilar et al. 2010).

Conservation Needed
This species would benefit from habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, despite taxonomic uncertainties with the Peninsular Malaysia subpopulations, in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: All three Peninsular Malaysian localities are in forest in the foothills and, in Indonesia, the species is found in forest at low and higher elevations. It is usually confined to forest and forest edge habitats. It breeds in stagnant ponds and slow-flowing water.
threats: The subpopulation at Batu Caves in Peninsular Malaysia is severely impacted by religious and recreational use of the site, and encroachment by expanding residential housing. It was previously impacted by quarrying, however this has now ceased (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018). The threats are unknown for the other subpopulations on Peninsular Malaysia (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018). On Sumatra, forest loss caused by agriculture is the main threat, and on Java forest loss is caused by human settlements and infrastructure development (M. Kusrini and R. Eprilurahman pers. comm. May 2017). It is found in the pet trade, but not found at levels that will pose a significant risk to the wild population (M. Kusrini pers. comm. May 2017).
population: The population status of this species in Peninsular Malaysia is unknown. A single specimen was collected in 1998 in Terengganu. In Indonesia, the species is very abundant in several places, such as Mount Gede Pangrango National Park in western Java, but less common in others (Indonesia Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). Surveys between 2010-2017 in Semarang State University in central Java recorded this species and found it to be common and abundant (Abdullah 2012). Surveys in 2013 and 2015 in Yogyakarta Province recorded a couple of individuals over the period of four to five months (Yudha et al. 2014, R. Eprilurahman and D. Satria pers. comm. May 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously reported from three widely separated locations in Peninsular Malaysia (Batu caves, Kuala Tahan in Taman Negara National Park, and Sekayu waterfalls in the adjoining area of Terengganu; Berry 1975, Leong and Tan 2001). However these records are now uncertain, and further taxonomic work is required to verify the identity of these subpopulations (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018). For the purposes of this assessment, these records are retained in the distribution until the uncertainty has been resolved. This species is also known from various localities in Indonesia, including Sumatra (Kurniati 2008, Hamidy and Matsui 2010, Teynie et al. 2010), Nias, Java (Kusrini et al. 2008 and Yudha et al. 2014), Madura and Bali (Riyanto and Mumpuni 2013). It is patchily distributed in Indonesia within the range that is mapped.
useTrade: This species is found in the pet trade, but not at levels that constitute a major threat to it (M. Kusrini pers. comm. May 2017).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in several protected areas in Indonesia and Peninsular Malaysia. For example, it has been recorded from Bali Barat National Park (Riyanto and Mumpuni 2013) and Kerinci Seblat National Park (Kurniati 2008), both in Indonesia. 

Conservation Needed
Ensuring adequate long-term protection of the known sites is necessary for the long-term conservation of this species.

Research Needed 
Taxonomic work is required to confirm the identity of the Peninsular Malaysian subpopulations (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018). Further surveys of known and possible additional localities are needed.

rationale: The species is listed as Least Concern on the basis of its broad distribution range and its large population size. Nevertheless, it is noteworthy to highlight that many aspects of the species are still unknown, including information on its life history, ecology, population status, trend, and threats to the species that are still lacking at present. Therefore, further survey and monitoring to gather such data are necessary.
habitat: The species is a large-sized benthopelagic barb that seems to prefer the lower and middle reaches of the river basins as it is reported that this fish occurs only in the mainstream of the Kapuas basin and its larger tributaries, while it migrates more upstream in the dry season to reproduce (Kottelat and Widjanarti 2005). Many ecological aspects and the life history of this species are still unknown including its diet and development.
threats: No major threats to the species are known on a range-wide scale at present. Overfishing is likely to be the main threat to this fish, especially in the Kapuas basin. More localised threats to the riverine habitats may exist such as habitat degradation primarily due to pollution resulting from logging, urbanisation, and agriculture. It is, however, still uncertain to what extent these threats have impacted the species.
population: Little is known about the current population status of the species, and its population trend remains unknown. Based on the museum collections alone, this fish appears to be rare and uncommon, but it has been reported to be frequently marketed in cities and towns along the middle reach of the Kapuas basin (Roberts 1989). Therefore, population size is uncertain, yet it is possibly rather large as estimated to be more than 10,000 adult individuals given its broad distribution range.
range: This fish is endemic to north-western Borneo as it has been recorded from the Kapuas, Rajang, and Baram basins (Roberts 1989, Kottelat and Widjanarti 2005, Parenti and Lim 2005). Its extent of occurence (EOO) is estimated at 89,890 km<sup>2</sup> (based on total area within a minimum convex polygon around sites where the species has been recorded).
useTrade: This fish is caught by local people and sold in the markets for food.
conservationActions: Parts of the species' range are likely to be within protected areas (e.g. the Danau Sentarum National Park). Further survey and monitoring are needed to understand the life history and ecology of this fish, to determine the current population status and its trend, to monitor the harvest trend, as well as to identify any major threats to the species on a range-wide scale.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern on the basis of large population size, stable population trend, and lack of major threats.
habitat: The species is a pelagic small-sized minnow that lives in different types of freshwater habitat, such as gravel-bottomed hill streams, moderate-flowing turbid midstreams, and acidic blackwater peat swamps (Lumbantobing 2010). Species of Rasbora play important trophic roles as both predator and prey, and are pelagic omnivores that feed primarily on small animal matter (Brittan 1972, Ward-Campbell et al. 2005).
threats: Localised threats may exist, such as habitat degradation due to local urbanisation, agricultural activities (e.g., oil palm plantation, rubber, and crops), and pollution. Nevertheless, no major threats are known on a range-wide scale.
population: The species has been recorded as common and abundant in a number of localities throughout its range. The total adult population size is uncertain but is thought to be very large and is suspected to be more than 10,000 individuals. Trends over the past 10 years or three generation are uncertain but are probably relatively stable.
range: This species of minnow is endemic to north-western Sumatra (Indonesia). In the region, its range encompasses the Alas drainage (Lumbantobing 2010). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 11,780 km<sup>2</sup> while its area of occupancy (AOO) within this EOO is estimated at 5,672 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records that the species is utilized.
conservationActions: Parts of its range is within protected areas (Gunung Leuser National Park). Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern and does not require significant additional protection, major monitoring, or research action.

rationale: Acantopsis octoactinotos, known only from the Kinabatangan River, Sabah, Malaysia, has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 12,385-14,065 km2. This species is considered to occur in less than 10 locations. This species is currently threatened by a continuing decline in habitat quality, largely due to an increase in industrial and agricultural water pollution and sedimentation in the Kinabatangan River basin. Thus, this species is assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: Acantopsis octoactinotos is a demersal species that occurs within freshwater rivers (Kottelat 2013). Little more is known of this species' habitat preferences or ecological role. The max length is known to be 9.6 cm (SL male/unsexed; Kottelat et al. 1993).
threats: The Kinabatangan River basin faces a number of threats, including clearing for agriculture, logging and oil palm plantations.  Water quality has been declining since the 1960s, when commercial logging started in the upper catchment, and further declined in the 1980s when the oil palm plantations and mills began operations. The main pollution sources in the catchment are effluent from palm oil mills, pesticides, and fertilizers; sediment from plantations; sediment from logging activities; and sewage and refuse from villages along the river (Indran 2006).
population: No data are available regarding the population size or trend of this species and so more research is required.
range: Acantopsis octoactinotos is known only from the Kinabatangan River, Sabah (Siebert 1991, Sulaiman and Mayden 2012, Kottelat 2013). This species' extent of occurrence (EOO) likely ranges from the length of Kinabatangan River to the Kinabatangan River basin catchment area (12,385-14,065 km2).
useTrade: Acantopsis octoactinotos is not believed to be utilised as a species.
conservationActions: The lower part of the Kinabatangan River is protected as the Kinabatangan Wildlife Sanctuary. Acantopsis octoactinotos is known only from the Kinabatangan River, Sabah but its population size and trend is unknown. More research into this species' distribution and populations is recommended.

rationale: This loach is listed as Vulnerable based on its restricted area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,308-2,000 km<sup>2</sup>, occurrence at six to ten threat-based locations and continuing declines in AOO, EOO and habitat.
habitat: The loach is a demersal/benthic (bottom-dweller) fish that lives in rocky riffles with swift currents in hill streams (Randall and Riggs 2015). Apart from this ecological note, limited information or details are available. The broad-scale degradation of freshwater habitats is likely to be recorded across the species range given that the massive urban development and the expansive agricultural activities have been taking place in many areas throughout Sundaland. Accordingly, a continuing decline in habitat is likely to exist in many parts of the species range.
threats: The major threat affecting this loach on a range-wide scale is uncertain, but regionalised threats are evident, such as habitat degradation due to destruction of the forest cover (urbanisation, logging or agricultural activities), modification of stream morphology (building dams or reservoirs), and pollution (urban and agricultural development), especially in Java where local extirpation has likely taken place. In Sumatra and Borneo these threats may be causing a continuing decline in species' range (both extent of occurrence and area of occupancy), although the extent of this decline is uncertain.
population: The species has likely been extirpated from Java (Randall and Riggs 2015). As for Sumatra and Borneo, there is very little information about the population and its trends, but data based on museum material suggest that the species is relatively very rare in the wild and is suspected to decrease given the continuing decline in the habitat quality and its extent of occurrence (EOO). Although uncertain, the number of mature individuals is suspected to be around 10,000 considering that the species is relatively widespread in Borneo and Sumatra.
range: This loach is known from the Musi and Tulangbawang basins in southern Sumatra as well as the Kapuas basin in western Borneo, Indonesia. Historically, the species has also been recorded from the Citarum basin in West Java, but it has likely been extirpated from this highly developed area (Randall and Riggs 2015). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 138,398 km2 (based on total area within a minimum convex polygon around sites where the species has been recorded and where the potential habitat suitable for the species may be located). The area occupied within this EOO (area of occupancy: AOO) is between 1,308 km2 (based on a 2x2 km2 grid overlay on the range map) and 2,000 km2 (based on potential habitat). It is estimated that the species has been experiencing a continuing decline in AOO and EOO due to continuing decline in habitat quality. There are six to ten threat-based locations for this species, based on the threat of land conversion.
useTrade: It is not known whether the species is used in the aquarium trade or it is being consumed by local people.
conservationActions: Parts of the range of the species may be in protected areas. Further survey work is required to determine whether or not this species is experiencing a genuine decline, or is undergoing natural population fluctuations and to identify the actual major threats to the species.

rationale: The species is assessed as Endangered owing to its restricted distribution in swamp forests in northeastern Peninsular Malaysia and the extreme south of (peninsular) Thailand (EOO less than 5,000 km2), its presence in only four threat-based locations, as well as high likelihood of being impacted by ongoing degradation/clearing of peat swamp forests and freshwater swamps.
habitat: The species occurs in both blackwater and clear-water habitats in peat swamp forests and freshwater swamps, with a known pH and temperature range of 5.5–7 and 25–26 °C, respectively (Linke 1991, Schindler and Schmidt 2008). It has been captured from amongst dense riparian vegetation in shallow waters (5–50 cm depth). It is a paternal bubblenester (Linke 1991).
threats: Large-scale conversion of peat swamp forests and freshwater swamps to industrial-scale forestry and monoculture plantations pose a threat to this species (Giam et al. 2012). A major threat is landfill (rubbish dumping) in Kuala Berang, which clears suitable habitat and causes pollution and sedimentation, and the population of this species in this area is likely to be extinct (A. Ahmad pers. comm. 2019). The population south of Marang is also thought to be extinct due to the impacts of urbanisation (A. Ahmad pers. comm. 2019).
population: Current population trends are unknown, however populations of this species in Kuala Berang and south of Marang are thought to be extinct due to the threats of landfill (rubbish dumping) and urbanisation (A. Ahmad pers. comm. 2019).
range: The species occurs in Terengganu and Kelantan in northeastern Peninsular Malaysia, and northwards to Narathiwat in southern (Peninsular) Thailand (Kottelat and Ng 2005, Schindler and Schmidt 2008). Populations of this species in Kuala Berang and south of Marang are thought to be extinct due to the threats of landfill (rubbish dumping) and urbanisation (A. Ahmad pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information available for this species. It is unknown if it has been exported in any substantial quantities for the aquarium trade in recent years.
conservationActions: This species has been recorded in a protected area, Hutan Lipur Lata Belatan, which is on the southern edge of its range and provides some habitat protection (Ahmad pers. comm. 2019). There are no known species specific conservation actions in place for this species. Research into its population, life history, and threats is needed alongside monitoring of habitat trends and the development of an area-based management plan. Site and habitat protection is also recommended. Public educational programmes should be put in place to raise awareness on the vulnerability of the species due to habitat fragmentation or modification.

rationale: This species has a small global population which is threatened by predation plus degradation of its breeding and wintering habitat. It is classified as Near Threatened as there is presently no evidence that a decline is taking place.
habitat: It breeds on the open shores of freshwater or brackish lakes and shallow pools, and perhaps sometimes by rivers, in steppe-like regions up to 1,200 m, but generally at lower elevations in the south. Outside the breeding season, it occurs along rivers (Imberti 2003) and on the coast, mostly in sheltered bays, lagoons and river mouths. It feeds primarily on tiny arthropods during the breeding season, with chironomid larvae apparently forming the staple food in winter, when it forages in small flocks (Piersma 1996a).
threats: There are few apparent reasons for its scarcity. However, the destruction and degradation of natural grassland in Patagonia by grazing livestock and introduced herbivores must have had some impact on mainland breeding habitat, and numbers are perhaps limited by the carrying capacity of the hostile environment (Fjeldså 1988, Dinerstein et al. 1995, S.
