useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation actions directed toward G. intermedius. The range of this species falls into more than one Protected Areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). More information regarding population size and population trend, life history and ecology, and the scope and magnitude of existing threats would be useful in guiding future conservation outcomes.

rationale: This species is distributed throughout the Chiriqui, Santa Maria, Chagres, and Tuira River drainages in Panama, and the Atrato River drainage on the Atlantic slope of Colombia. Extent of Occurrence is estimated to be 70,647 km2. Localized threats include mining activities, pollution from urban centers, and introduced predators, competitors, and parasites. However, there is no indication of major population decline. As such, H. dariensis is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This freshwater species occurs in streams and backwaters (Robles and Vega 2004). Additional habitat preferences and life history characteristics have not been evaluated in detail.
threats:
Localized threats exist in Panama and Colombia. While the combined impacts of these threats have likely resulted in continuous declines in the availability or quality of habitat, their direct impacts on population status have not been evaluated.

In Panama, the future availability of water resources may affect the extent and quality of habitat in lake Gatun and Lake Alajuela, which serve as primary water sources for the urban cities of Colón and Panama City (Larsen 2019). The peacock bass Cichla monoculus has been introduced in both Lake Gatun and Lake Alajuela (Sharpe et al. 2017). Additionally, the invasive Asian fish tapeworm Bothriocephalus acheilognathi has been reported from the Chagres River (Choudhury et al. 2013). Solid waste and raw sewage discharge from urban centres have the potential to negatively impact water quality (Ibáñez et al. 2002).

Gold mining activities in Colombia have the potential to negatively affect local habitat by discharging mercury and sediment loads into adjacent rivers and streams (Helwege 2015). Mercury pollution is especially apparent in the departments of Antioquia and Choco (Veiga 2010, Vallejo Torro et al. 2016, Palacios-Torres et al. 2018).
population: Total population size is unknown. In Darien National Park, this species comprised 1.6% of relative fish abundance, based on limited sampling (Garcés and García 2007). Population trend is suspected to be stable, given no evidence of major population decline.
range:
Hemibrycon dariensis is distributed throughout the Chiriqui, Santa Maria, Chagres, and Tuira River drainages in Panama (Smith and Bermingham 2005, Vega et al. 2006), southward to the Atrato River drainage on the Atlantic slope of Colombia (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2012, Donascimiento et al. 2017). In Panama, it has been reported from at least 22 catchments within these larger drainages (W. Matamoros pers. comm. 2019).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 70,647 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019).
useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation actions directed towards H. dariensis. This species has been reported from Darien National Park (Garcés and García 2007), and is likely to occur in additional Protected Areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). Additional research regarding the scope and magnitude of existing threats would be useful in guiding future conservation outcomes. Taxonomic research is needed particularly with regard to subpopulations in South America. Future taxonomic changes have the potential to cause changes to conservation status of some subpopulations.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 629 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is known from with upper montane bamboo forest, mixed bamboo forest and disturbed secondary broadleaf forest with a relatively open canopy (Tapley et al. 2018). All individuals have been encountered at night and found in riparian habitat along 1–2 m wide streams with clear water and rocky stream beds. The majority of these frogs were encountered in the month of June; fewer were observed in September. Males were calling from stream-side vegetation and a gravid female was found adjacent to a fast-flowing stream during June (Tapley et al. 2018). It breeds in water by larval development, larvae have been observed in March in a small 1 m wide low-gradient stream in disturbed evergreen forest on Mount Fansipan (Tapley et al. 2020). This species has been recorded from disturbed forest areas (Tapley et al. 2020), but is likely dependant on some intact forest.
threats: This species is seemingly restricted to the very high montane streams in which it is found, given it was undetected during surveys of Mount Fansipan at elevations of 1,200 m asl (2016), 1,700 m asl (2012, 2016) and 1,900 m asl (2016, 2017) (Tapley et al. 2018). The high elevation sites where this species occurs face the immediate threat of habitat degradation and pollution due to the impact of tourists; habitats were noticeably polluted with garbage and runoff from toilets near the stream (Tapley et al. 2018). In addition, if this species is truly restricted to a narrow, high-elevation band, then the species is likely to be particularly vulnerable to climate change (Tapley et al. 2018).
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the 14 specimens that constitute the type series. Forest loss and degradation is ongoing throughout its range (Tapley et al. 2018), and is likely causing some declines in this forest-associated species.
range: This species is known from Mount Fansipan, Sa Pa and Van Ban Districts, Lao Cai Province, Viet Nam  (Tapley et al. 2018, Luan Nguyen unpubl. data September 2020). It was not detected in habitat similar to that found on Mount Fansipan during recent surveys on Mount Ky Quan San, 25 km north of the type locality (Tapley et al. 2018). It has been found at elevations between 2,200 and 2,813 m asl (Tapley et al. 2018). The species' estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 629 km2.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known to occur in Hoang Lien National Park.

Research Needed
Addressing the lack of data is the first step towards ensuring the species' long-term persistence. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: This species occurs in the San Pedro, Santa Maria, Chagres, and Tuira River drainages in central and eastern Panama. Population size is unknown. Population trend is inferred to be slowly declining, based on recent evidence that suggests extirpation in parts of Lake Gatun. Extensive sampling has confirmed the presence of this species in 15 localities throughout its range. Threats exist, but they are likely to be localized. This species is assessed as Least Concern on the basis of a fairly broad distribution and no evidence of major range-wide population decline.
habitat: The biology and ecology of this species are largely unknown.
threats:
The primary threat to this species is habitat loss associated with deforestation (R. González pers. comm. 2019), but the direct impact, scope, and magnitude of deforestation have not been evaluated in detail. There is no indication that existing threats have resulted in major range-wide population declines.

The future availability of water resources may affect the extent and quality of habitat in lake Gatun and Lake Alajuela, which serve as primary water sources for the urban cities of Colon and Panama City (Larsen 2019). The peacock bass Cichla monoculus has been introduced in both Lake Gatun and Lake Alajuela (Sharpe et al. 2017). Additionally, the invasive Asian fish tapeworm Bothriocephalus acheilognathi has been reported from the Chagres River (Choudhury et al. 2013). Solid waste and raw sewage discharge from urban centers have the potential to negatively impact water quality (Ibáñez et al. 2002).
population: Total population size is unknown. This species comprised a 1.2% relative abundance in limited samples taken from Darien National Park, Panama (Garcés and García 2007). There is currently no indication of major range-wide population decline.
range:
Pseudocheirodon arnoldi is known from the San Pedro, Santa Maria, Chagres, and Tuira River drainages in central and eastern Panama (Smith and Bermingham 2005). This species has been reported from 15 distinct catchments within these larger drainages (W. Matamoros pers. comm. 2019).

Extent of Occurrence is estimated to be 42,227 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019).

This species is probably extirpated from the Trinidad Arm of Lake Gatun due to the introduction of the non-native Cichla monoculus (Sharpe et al. 2017). However, subpopulations probably still exist in small tributary creeks of the Panama Canal watershed.
useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation actions directed towards P. arnoldi. The range of this species occurs in Darien National Park (Garcés and García 2007), and may occur in additional Protected Areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). More information regarding population size, population status, biology and ecology, and the impacts of potential threats are needed.

rationale: This species has been reported from the Rio Mandinga and Rio Carti that drain into the Gulf of Guna Yala to the Rio Narka. Potential threats in the region include water use, pollution from untreated sewage and solid waste from urban and rural communities, and the establishment of introduced species. However, the impacts of these threats are likely negligible, and there is no indication of major population decline or habitat quality decline. Therefore, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The ecology and specific habitat preferences of this species are unknown.
threats: The future availability of water resources (Larsen 2019), introduced piscivores (Sharpe et al. 2017), introduced parasites (Choudhury et al. 2013), and pollution in the form of solid waste and sewage discharge (Ibáñez et al. 2002) are all potential threats that may affect the extent, area, or quality of suitable habitat. However, the direct impacts of these threats are unknown, given a near complete lack of information regarding distribution, population size, and population trend. Currently, these threats are suspected to have a negligible impact on overall habitat quality, and there is no indication of major range-wide population decline (R. González pers. comm. 2019).
population: There is no information regarding total population size or population trend.
range:
Roeboides carti has been reported from the Rio Mandinga and Rio Carti that drain into the Gulf of Guna Yala to the Rio Narka (Smith and Bermingham 2005, Lucena 2014, Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute 2019). 

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 908 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019). Area of Occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be 40 km2, based on relatively few collection records overlain by a 2 km2 grid (GBIF 2019). However, both EOO and AOO are likely to be underestimated due to considerable sampling bias.
useTrade: There is no information on the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species specific actions directed towards R. carti. The range of this species may extend into Chagres National Park (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). More comprehensive sampling is needed to determine extent of distribution, population size, and population trend. Additional information is needed regarding life history and ecology, and the direct impacts of potential localized and regional threats.

rationale: This species is restricted to the Chagres and Indio River drainages and their tributaries on the Atlantic versant of Panama. Population trend is suspected to be declining in at least a part of this species' range, but the rate of decline is unknown. Potential threats include pollution resulting from solid waste, non-native predators and parasites, and future reductions in the availability of water resources. However, the scope of these threats are unknown and the number of locations where this species occurs cannot be determined with accuracy. Given these uncertainties regarding the number of locations where this species occurs, current population status, and rate of population decline, this species is assessed Near Threatened (NT) under criterion B1b(iii,v).
habitat: This species occurs in small streams and rivers characterized by high forest cover and sand and gravel substrates. This species prefers pool habitat with low water velocity. Reproduction occurs throughout the year, with more adults typically present during the dry season (R. González pers. comm. 2019). Diet is comprised primarily of aquatic and terrestrial insects, and fish scales (Angermeier and Karr, 1983, Kramer and Bryant 1995).
threats:
The introduced piscivorous peacock cichlid Cichla monoculus has probably resulted in population declines in the Trinidad Arm of Lake Gatun (Sharpe et al. 2017). The introduced parasite Bothriocephalus acheilognathi has been detected in the Chagres River and parasitizes a broad range of host species, but has not been confirmed from R. guatemalensis  (Choudhury et al. 2013).

The future availability of water resources may affect the extent and quality of habitat in Lake Gatun and Lake Alajuela, which serve as primary water sources for the urban cities of Colon and Panama City (Larsen 2019). Solid waste and raw sewage discharge from urban centres have the potential to negatively impact water quality (Ibáñez et al. 2002). The combined impacts of these threats are inferred to have resulted in a decrease in the area, extent, and quality of habitat. However, the magnitude of impact is unknown.
population: Total population size is unknown. This species was historically dominant in Lake Gatun (Zaret and Paine 1973). Population trend is suspected to be in decline, based on recent samples taken from the Trinidad Arm of Lake Gatun where Sharpe et al. (2017) failed to detect this species. This species still appears fairly abundant in small creeks and rivers along the Panama Canal watershed (R. González pers. comm. 2019).
range:
Roeboides guatemalensis occurs in the Chagres River drainage and its tributaries on the Atlantic slope of Panama, including Lake Gatun (Smith and Bermingham 2004, Sharpe et al. 2017). Native distribution extends from the Indio River to the Cascajal River in Colón (Lucena 2013, R. González pers. comm. 2019). This species may have colonized the Rio Grande on the Pacific slope of Panama by dispersing through the Panama Canal, but confirmation is needed (Smith et al. 2004). 

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be between 3,814-20,068 km2 based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019), and on the extent of potentially suitable habitat within the Chagres River and adjacent drainages. Additional sampling would be useful in determining a more accurate distribution. The total number of locations where this species occurs cannot be estimated with accuracy given uncertainties regarding the scope of major pervasive threats.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation action directed towards R. guatemalensis. This species occurs in at least three protected areas, namely Chagres National Park, Soberania National Park, and possibly in Arraijan Forest Protected Area (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). More information regarding distribution, population size and trend, and the direct impacts and scope of major threats would be useful in guiding future conservation action.

rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of  its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is  likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable.  Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is found in fresh to brackish water, in small streams, estuaries and mangroves (usually with freshwater influence) (Hoese et al. 2006, Larson 2010). It prefers sandy substratum and is found in association with estuarine water bodies, such as river mouths and lagoons, along the coastal sea belt (De Silva et al. 2015).
threats: There are currently no major threats to this species. Potential threats include damage to coastal waterways and mangrove habitats through clearing, and possibly trade. In Sri Lanka, water pollution due to garbage dumping to the estuaries is a main threat to this species (Fernando et al. 2013).
population: The species is widespread and appears to be common, but not abundant (Larson 2010).
range: This species is known from East Africa and Madagascar to southern Japan, Micronesia and South to New Caledonia. It also found in estuaries in the coastal region of wet zone of Sri Lanka.
useTrade: This species is often sought as an aquarium fish and is "imported sporadically" (Monks 2006, Larson 2010, Gunasekara 2011).
conservationActions: Information is required as to the number of individuals removed from the wild for the aquarium trade. Although the species is common and widespread, it is not abundant and could be locally extirpated by collectors. In Australia, it is afforded some protection in that part of the population is on Aboriginal land and islands (thus largely excluding aquarium collectors). It is likely that the species occurs in other protected areas throughout its range and it is known to occur in protected areas in Madagascar.

rationale: Microphis ocellatus is a freshwater pipefish that inhabits Sri Lanka and Indonesia. Little is known about the species' distribution, habitats, ecology, or threats, although freshwater systems in both places are threatened by pollution and water diversion. The genus Microphis is thought to be particularly susceptible to the aquarium trade. Further research is needed in order to determine the status of this species' freshwater habitat, the population size and trend, and to quantify the level of offtake, if any. There is inadequate information to make a direct, or indirect, assessment of its risk of extinction based on the available information. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
Microphis ocellatus inhabits slow-moving freshwater in perennial streams and rivers (Pethiyagoda 1991). Little is known about the species' feeding, but it likely preys on small benthic and/or planktonic crustaceans similar to other pipefishes (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). They are ovoviviparous, and males brood embryos under their trunk prior to giving birth to live young (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1985). They grow to a maximum length of 12.5 cm and males brood once they reach 8.5 cm (Dawson 1985).

It occupies the upper middle strata of the water column along the sides of the rivers and usually occurs among marginal weeds and roots.
threats: The threats to this species are largely unknown. Freshwater habitats in Indonesia and Sri Lanka are threatened by riparian development, erosion and sedimentation due to forestry and agriculture, and pollution, although these have not been well-quantified. The species may be exploited for use in the aquarium trade - this needs to be investigated further, and, if present, quantified.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Microphis ocellatus. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Microphis ocellatus inhabits freshwater streams and rivers in Sri Lanka and Indonesia (including Simeulue, Nias, and Sulawesi) (Dawson 1984, 1985). In Sri Lanka, it can be found in the coastal belt of south western wet zone and one locality from the Eastern coast.
useTrade:
Microphis ocellatus has not been specifically reported in trade, but in general pipefishes are often traded for use in traditional medicines, as curios, and for the aquarium trade (Vincent et al. 2011).

The genus Microphis is thought to be particularly susceptible to the aquarium trade (Dawson 1985). Levels of offtake are unknown and in need of investigation.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place for Microphis ocellatus. It's not clear whether the species occurs in any protected areas, and it is not mentioned in any international legislation or trade regulations.

rationale: Puntius thermalis is an endemic fresh water fish species in Sri Lanka and has wide distribution throughout the dry zone from the lowland to mid hills. Due its estimated Extent of Occurrence (EOO) which is 45558 km2 and distribution in 20 locations, this species has been assessed as a Least Concerned (LC) species.
habitat: This species is widely distributed in slow moving streams, rivers, tanks, reservoirs and marshes. It shows a preference to gravel, sandy or muddy bottomed water bodies and, despite being a herbivore, it includes some zooplankton in its diet (Senanayake 1980, De Silva et al. 2015).
threats: Threats of habitat loss and degradation, owing to pollution from urban sources and effects of deforestation near by, have caused some populations of Puntius thermalis around urban marshlands to become extinct.
population: There is no available population data for this species regarding the size or developmental trends. However, it is possible to infer a decline in its populations due to threats such as habitat degradation, pollution and modifications to its natural habitats. It is a common species within the island.
range: Puntius thermalis is endemic to Sri Lanka and found in the lowland dry and wet zone. It has a range which extends from the coastal belt to mid hills (De Silva et al. 2015).
useTrade: Puntius thermais is known to be used for human consumption at a local scale.
conservationActions: No known conservation actions have been put in place for this species.

rationale: Chiloglanis camarabounyi is listed as Vulnerable because of its restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 11,406 km2) and occurrence at three threat-based locations. These locations are widely disjunct and are experiencing a decrease in quality and area of habitat through the effects of deforestation, small-scale agriculture, hydropower developments and human pollution.
habitat: Chiloglanis camarabounyi prefers flowing water over rocks and other debris. At the type locality many specimens were collected over solid bedrock. It appears that these species feed on the periphyton found on the exposed bedrock.
threats: Chiloglanis camarabounyi is experiencing a decrease in the amount and quality of habitat throughout its range. The principal threats are deforestation, conversion of riparian zones to agriculture, pollution and the effects of large and small-scale hydropower developments.
population: No information is available on the population.
range: Chiloglanis camarabounyi was described from the Badi River basin, a small tributary to the Konkouré River in Guinea, West Africa. There are slightly distinct populations that also occur in the upper reaches of the Konkouré River drainage (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017). One population occurs downstream of waterfalls in the northern portion of the drainage, and the other population is restricted to areas upstream of the large reservoir created by the Garafiri dam.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the Badi River and Konkouré River draiange. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis kolente is listed as Endangered, based on its known distribution, because it has a small extent of occurrence (EOO: 724 km2), and only occurs in four threat-based locations. Each location is experiencing declines in the quality and availability of habitat, based on the principal threats of deforestation, conversion of riparian zones for agriculture and pollution from human activities.
habitat: Chiloglanis kolente prefers flowing water over gravel and woody debris. This species was collected under the concrete footings of a newly constructed bridge in a small stream.
threats: The small streams and rivers in the upper Kolente River drainage are experiencing deforestation, loss of riparian vegetation through conversion to agriculture, mining, and pollution from human activities. These activities are reducing the amount of habitat available for Chiloglanis kolente, in addition to the quality of habitat.
population: No information is available on the population. This species was abundant in the main stem of the Kolente River in 1956, but no specimens were collected in 2003 and 2013.
range: Chiloglanis kolente is only known to occur in the upper Kolente River drainage in Guinea and is likely to occur in suitable habitats in the drainage in Sierra Leone (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017).
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the Kolente River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis kabaensis is listed as Endangered, based on its known range, because it has a small extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,197 km2) and is only known from three threat-based locations in the upper Little Scarcies drainage. The amount and quality of habitat in these locations is under threat from deforestation, agricultural activities and pollution from human activities.
habitat: Chiloglanis kabaensis occurs in fast flowing waters around rocks and woody debris (Schmidt et al. 2017). It can be found in small streams and larger rivers.
threats: The principal threats facing Chiloglanis kabaensis are the ongoing effects from deforestation, small-scale agriculture along the riparian zone and pollution.
population: No information is available on the population. This species was abundant in collections in the region in 2003, but fewer specimens were collected in 2013.
range: Chiloglanis kabaensis occurs in the upper reaches of the Little Scarcies drainage in Guinea and possibly in Sierra Leone (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017).
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the Little Scarcies drainage in Guinea and Sierra Leone. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis dialloi only occurs in the upper Moa River drainage in the Upper Guinea Forests in Guinea and potentially in Sierra Leone and Liberia. This species is listed as Endangered based on its current known range because it has a relatively small extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,654 km2) and is restricted to four threat-based locations that contain forested streams with a mostly closed canopy and abundant riparian vegetation. Primary ongoing threats to these small streams in the Moa River drainage include deforestation, pollution and the effects of small-scale mining.
habitat: This species was collected under a bridge in the Masseni River. The bridge created two rocky runs where this species, along with two other Chiloglanis spp. were collected in the fast flowing water. The canopy over the stream was largely enclosed and there was abundant riparian vegetation along the sides.
threats: The small rivers and streams in the upper Moa River drainage are increasingly under threat from the effects of pollution from human activities, deforestation, and small-scale mining activities. These activities disrupt these small forested streams opening up the canopy and increasing the temperature and turbidity of the waters.
population: No information is available on the population.
range: Chiloglanis dialloi is only known from the upper reaches of the Moa River drainage in Guinea, West Africa (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017). This species may also occur in Moa River drainage in Sierra Leone and Liberia.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Moa River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis loffabrevum is listed as Endangered due to it restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,333 km2), occurrence in one threat-based location (the upper Loffa River drainage), and the continuing decline in quality of habitat from agricultural activities, deforestation, pollution, and mining.
habitat: Chiloglanis loffabrevum occurs in small streams and rivers in the upper Loffa River drainage. It inhabits reaches with moderate to swift flow and is usually found over gravel or woody debris.
threats: The quality and availability of freshwater habitats in the upper Loffa River drainage are declining from the effects of deforestation, agriculture, pollution, and small-scale mining activities.
population: No information is available on the population.
range: Chiloglanis loffabrevum occurs in the upper reaches of the Loffa River drainage in Guinea and may also occur in Liberia (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017).
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Loffa River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis longibarbis only occurs in the upper Moa River drainage in the Upper Guinea Forests in Guinea and potentially in Sierra Leone and Liberia. This species is listed as Endangered, based on its known range, because it has a relatively small extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,654 km2) and is restricted to four threat-based locations that contain forested streams with a mostly closed canopy and abundant riparian vegetation. Primary ongoing threats to these small streams in the Moa River drainage include deforestation, pollution and the effects of small-scale mining.
habitat: Chiloglanis longibarbis was collected in fast flowing water over rocks and concrete pilings in a forested stream in the upper Moa River drainage. This species also likely occurs around woody debris in flowing waters. The stream was mostly closed canopy and the riparian zones were fully vegetated.
threats: The small rivers and streams in the upper Moa River drainage are increasingly under threats from the effects of pollution from human activities, deforestation and small-scale mining activities. These activities disrupt these small forested streams by opening up the canopy and increasing the temperature and turbidity of the waters.
population: No information is available on the population.
range: Chiloglanis longibarbis is only known to occur in the upper reaches of the Moa River drainage in Guinea, West Africa (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017). This species may also occur in the Moa River drainage in Liberia and Sierra Leone.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Moa River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis pezoldi is listed as Endangered based on its known range because of its restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,333 km2) and occurrence in only one threat-based location (the upper Loffa River drainage). In addition, the amount and quality of habitat in this location is under threat from agricultural activities, deforestation, pollution, and mining.
habitat: Chiloglanis pezoldi was collected in two streams in the upper Loffa River system. It occurs over gravel and woody debris in flowing waters.
threats: The quality and availability of freshwater habitats in the upper Loffa River drainage are declining from the effects of deforestation, agriculture, pollution and small-scale mining activities.
population: No information is available on the population.
range: Chiloglanis pezoldi occurs in the upper reaches of the Loffa River drainage in Guinea and may also occur in Liberia (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017).
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Loffa River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis nzerekore is listed as Endangered, based on its known range, because of a restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 1,092 km2), occurrence in only one threat-based location (the upper St. Paul River drainage), and due to a decline in quality and abundance of suitable habitat as a result of deforestation, agricultural activity, pollution, and mining.
habitat: Chiloglanis nzerekore prefers flowing water in small, medium, and large streams. Specimens from the type locality were collected in the exposed tree roots along a cut bank.
threats: The forested rivers and streams in the upper St. Paul River drainage are seeing a decline in the amount and quality of suitable habitat for Chiloglanis nzerekore. The principal threats are deforestation, small-scale agriculture, pollution, and the effects from mining.
population: No information is available on the population of Chiloglanis nzerekore.
range: Chiloglanis nzerekore occurs in several tributaries in the upper St. Paul River drainage in Guinea and is presumed to also occur in Liberia (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017).
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper St. Paul River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis tweddlei is listed as Endangered because of its restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,647 km2), and its occurrence in two threat-based locations, based on the small to medium forested streams that it inhabits facing several key threats. Primarily, these habitats are threatened by small and large-scale mining activities. Due to this threat coupled with deforestation, pollution and riparian agriculture, the quality and extent of these habits is diminishing.
habitat: Chiloglanis tweddlei prefers flowing water in small to medium forested streams. The species was collected in small riffles below a tree fall and along cut banks in the submerged tree roots (Schmidt et al. 2017).
threats: The small to medium forested streams in the upper St John River drainage are being effected by small and large-scale mining activities. Additionally, deforestation, agriculture and pollution are negatively affecting the habitats required for Chiloglanis tweddlei to persist.
population: No information is available on the population.
range: Chiloglanis tweddlei only occurs in the upper St. John River drainage in Guinea and Liberia (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017).
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper St. John River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis waterloti is listed as Least Concern because of its relatively widespread distribution (with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 22,569 km2), in the upper Senegal and Niger River drainages in Guinea, West Africa.
habitat: Chiloglanis waterloti prefers flowing waters and is associated with rocks or woody debris.
threats: Ongoing effects of deforestation, converting riparian areas for agriculture, potential hydropower projects and pollution are the main threats facing Chiloglanis waterloti.
population: No information is available on the population.
range: Chiloglanis waterloti is found throughout the upper Senegal and Niger river drainages in Guinea, West Africa (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017).
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Senegal and Niger River drainages. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Chiloglanis occidentalis is found in the upper reaches of the Sassandra River drainage in Côte d'Ivoire and is also reported in the Volta and Pra rivers. In just considering the confirmed population in the Sassandra River, this species has a large extent of occurrence (EOO: 28,867 km2). This wide distribution results in C. occidentalis being listed as Least Concern (LC).
habitat: This species is found in the flowing waters of the upper Sassandra River basin. It is likely associated with woody debris in the river channel and exposed tree roots along the river banks.
threats: Ongoing land use conversion to agriculture and pollution are likely negatively affecting the quality and amount of habitat available to C. occidentalis in the upper Sassandra River drainage.
population: No information is available on the population.
range: This species was once thought to be widespread throughout West Africa, but recent studies shown that many of these populations represent new species (Schmidt et al. 2016, 2017). Described from the Sassandra River in the Côte d'Ivoire, this species is also reported in the Volta River (Côte d'Ivoire) and the Pra River in Ghana, but these records require confirmation. This species appears to be widespread within the upper Sassandra River basin.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species throughout their presumed range. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Amphilius rheophilus is listed as Least Concern, due to the its large EOO (29,105 km2). The ongoing effects of mining, deforestation, agriculture, pollution and dams are limiting the quality and extent of the preferred habitat so there may be localized extirpation of this species. Additional research is needed to determine the extent of this species within the Rio Corubal and Gambie River drainages.
habitat: Amphilius rheophilus occurs in flowing waters over cobble and gravel.
threats: The principal threats that Amphilius rheophilus is facing are the effects of deforestation, agriculture, mining, pollution and dams.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
Amphilius rheophilus is known to occur in the Gambie and Rio Corubal river systems in Guinea and Senegal (Schmidt and Pezold 2011, Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 29,105 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 9,280 km2.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species.

rationale: This species is listed at Vulnerable because of the restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 10,711 km<sup>2</sup>), area of occupancy (AOO: 1,988 km<sup>2</sup>) and as it is only known to occur in three threat-based locations. The primary threats which reduce the amount and quality of habitat for this species are: the effects of small and large scale hydropower projects, deforestation, conversion of riparian zones for agriculture and pollution.
habitat: This species is found in flowing waters over rocks and cobble.
threats: This species is experiencing a decrease in the amount and quality of habitat throughout its range. The principal threats are the effects of large and small-scale hydropower developments, deforestation, conversion of riparian zones to agriculture and pollution.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
This species is only found in three areas of the Konkouré River drainage in Guinea, West Africa. In the Kakrima River, downstream of Chutes de Sala, in the Konkouré River proper upstream of the reservoir created by the Garafiri dam, and the Mayonkouré River (Schmidt and Pezold 2011, Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 10,711 km2, an area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,988 km2 and is known from three threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the Konkouré River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO: 422 km<sup>2</sup>), area of occupancy (AOO: 396 km<sup>2</sup>)<sup> </sup>and its occurrence at one threat-based location (upper Kokoulo River drainage in Guinea, West Africa). This location is based on the primary threats of ongoing activities in the area (e.g. land-use change, pollution, hydropower development) that will likely reduce the amount and quality of available habitat.
habitat: This species in found in relatively fast flowing waters over cobble and large boulders.
threats: Land-use change, pollution and the potential development of hydroelectric projects in the region threaten the small area in the Kokoulo River drainage that this species occupies.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
It is only known from the upper reaches of the Kokoulo River (Konkouré River drainage) in the Fouta Djallon highlands in Guinea, West Africa (Schmidt and Pezold 2011, Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 422 km2, an area of occupancy (AOO) of 396 km2 and is only known from one threat-based location.
useTrade: This species is not used for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the Kokoulo River basin. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: The species is listed as Vulnerable due to its restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 5,165 km<sup>2</sup>) and since it is only known to occur in three threat-based locations in the upper Senegal River drainage. Principal threats reducing the amount and quality of habitat in this area are deforestation, pollution, small-scale agriculture and dams.
habitat: This species prefers flowing waters and is usually associated with cobble and gravel substrate.
threats: The rivers and streams in the upper Senegal River drainage in Guinea are experiencing several ongoing threats. These principal threats are deforestation, conversion of riparian zones for agriculture, pollution and small and large dams.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
This species is only known to occur within the upper Senegal River drainage in Guinea, West Africa (Schmidt and Pezold 2011, Schmidt 2014). It may also occur in tributaries to the Senegal River in southern Senegal.

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 5,165 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 2,240 km2 and is known from three threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Senegal River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered because of its restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,197 km<sup>2</sup>) and as it is only known from three threat-based locations. The primary threats facing this species are pollution, deforestation, and land-use changes along the riparian zone, which are leading to a continuing decline in habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in swift waters over cobble and boulders.
threats: The principal threats facing this species are deforestation, the effects of small-scale agriculture along the riparian zone, and pollution.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
This species occurs in the upper reaches of the Little Scarcies drainage in Guinea and possibly in Sierra Leone (Schmidt and Pezold 2011, Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 3,197 km2, an area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,364 km2 and is known from three threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the Little Scarcies drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered due to its restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 1,539 km<sup>2</sup>) and since it is only known to occur in one threat-based location. The rivers and streams in the upper Tinkisso River basin are under threat from the effects of deforestation, small-scale agriculture along riparian zones, pollution, and dams. This is leading to continuing decline in habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in flowing waters over gravel and cobble.
threats: The flowing waters in the upper Tinkisso River basin are affected by pollution, deforestation, small-scale agriculture, and small and large dams and the associated reservoirs.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
This species is only known to occur in the Tinkisso River and associated tributaries in the upper Niger River drainage in Guinea, West Africa (Schmidt and Pezold 2011, Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,539 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 1,384 km2; it is known from one threat-based location.
useTrade: No information is available.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Niger River drainage in Guinea. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered due to the restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,654 km<sup>2</sup>) and since it only potentially occurs in four threat-based locations. The principal threats affecting this species and the small forested streams they inhabit are deforestation, mining, small-scale agriculture and pollution. These are leading to continuing declines in habitat area and quality.
habitat: This species is found in clear, fast flowing waters over cobbles and boulders.
threats: The habitat utilized by this species is declining in amount and quality. The forested streams in the upper Moa River drainage are threatened by deforestation, small-scale agriculture along the riparian zone, mining, and pollution.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
This species is only known from the upper reaches of the Moa River drainage in Guinea, West Africa. This species may also occur in Moa River drainage in Sierra Leone and Liberia (Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 3,654 km2, an area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,944 km2 and is known from four threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Moa River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered due to a restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 4,819 km<sup>2</sup>) and since it is only known to occur in one threat-based location. The principal threats facing this species are deforestation, agriculture, pollution and the effects of mining activities. The small forested streams in which this species resides are particularly affected by these land-use changes and the habitats are in continuing decline.
habitat: This species occurs in the small forested streams in the upper Loffa River drainage. This species prefers flowing clear waters and is found over gravel and cobble.
threats: The quality and availability of freshwater habitats in the upper Loffa River drainage are declining from the effects of deforestation, agriculture, pollution, and small-scale mining activities. The small forested-streams in which this species inhabit are particularly susceptible to these threats.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
This species is only known to occur in the upper reaches of the Loffa River drainage in Guinea, West Africa. It may also occur in preferred habitats within the Loffa River drainage in Liberia (Schmidt and Pezold 2011, Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 4,819 km2, area of occupancy (AOO) is 4,528 km2 and it is known from one threat-based location.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Loffa River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

scientificName: Amphilius sp. nov. 'St. Paul River drainage'
rationale: This species is listed as Endangered due to its restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 4,047 km<sup>2</sup>) and as it is only known to occur in three threat-based locations. The main threats facing this species are the effects of mining, pollution, deforestation and small-scale agriculture. These are leading to a continuing decline in the extent and quality of available habitat.
habitat: This species in found in moderately flowing water over gravel, cobble, and boulders.
threats: The streams and rivers that this species inhabits are all experiencing a decrease in the quality and extent of available habitat. The principal threats facing these locations are pollution, mining, deforestation and small-scale agriculture.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
This species is only known to occur in the upper St Paul River drainage in Guinea, West Africa but may also occur within the drainage in Liberia (Schmidt and Pezold 2011, Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 4,047 km2, an area of occupancy (AOO) of 3,392 km2 and is known from three threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper St. Paul River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

scientificName: Amphilius sp. nov. 'St. John River drainage'
rationale: This species is listed as Endangered due to its restricted extent of occurrence (EOO: 3,647 km<sup>2</sup>) and as it is only known to occur in two threat-based locations. The principal threats facing this species are the effects from mining, deforestation, pollution and small-scale agriculture. These are leading to a continuing decline in the extent and quality of habitat.
habitat: This species is found in small forested streams in the upper St. John River drainage. It prefers moderately flowing water over gravel substrate.
threats: This species is only found in forested streams in the upper St. John River basin. The quality and extent of this habitat is threatened by mining activities, deforestation, pollution, and small-scale agriculture.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
This species is only known to occur in the upper St John River drainage in Guinea. It potentially also occurs in Liberia (Schmidt 2014).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 3,647 km2, an area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,752 km2 and it is known from two threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper St. John River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: Enteromius foutensis is listed as Endangered because is has a restricted EOO (2,110 km2) and is only known to occur in three threat-based locations within the upper Little Scarcies drainage in Guinea. The principal threats reducing the quality and amount of available habitat in this region are deforestation, small-scale agriculture and pollution.
habitat: Enteromius foutensis occurs in areas of moderate flow over gravel and sand.
threats: The principal threats facing Enteromius foutensis are the ongoing effects from deforestation, small-scale agriculture along the riparian zone and pollution.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
Enteromius foutensis is likely restricted to the Little Scarcies drainage in Guinea and is also probably extant in this drainage in Sierra Leone (Schmidt et al. 2019).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 2,110 km2, an area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,564 km2 and is known from three threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the Little Scarcies drainage in Guinea and Sierra Leone. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

scientificName: Enteromius sp. nov. '1 - Upper Konkoure River basin'
rationale: Enteromius aff. foutensis sp. 1 is listed as Endangered because of its restricted EOO (985 km2) and since it is only known to occur in one threat-based location. It is restricted to a few streams in the small area upstream of the large reservoir created by the Garafiri Dam. Ongoing effects from hydro power developments, small-scale agriculture, deforestation and pollution are limiting the quality and amount of habitat available to E. aff. foutensis sp. 1.
habitat: Enteromius aff. foutensis sp. 1 prefers areas of moderate flow, over sand or gravel, and with submerged aquatic vegetation.
threats: Enteromius aff. foutensis sp. 1 is facing numerous threats within the restricted area that it occupies. Principal threats affecting these small streams include deforestation, small-scale agriculture within the riparian zone, pollution and hydropower developments in the area.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
Enteromius aff. foutensis sp. 1 only occurs in streams upstream of the large impoundment created by the Garafiri dam in the Konkouré River drainage in Guinea, West Africa (Schmidt et al. 2019).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 985 km2, an area of occupancy (AOO) of 904 km2 and is known from one threat-based location.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the Konkouré River drainage. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

scientificName: Enteromius sp. nov. '2 - Upper Senegal and Gambie River basins'
rationale: Enteromius aff. foutensis sp. 2 is listed as Vulnerable based on its EOO (14,973 km2) and being restricted to six threat-based locations in the upper Gambie and Senegal River drainages. The principal threats that are limiting the amount and quality of habitat for this species are pollution, small-scale agriculture within the riparian zones, deforestation, and small and large-scale hydropower developments.
habitat: Enteromius aff. foutensis sp. 2 prefer areas in streams with moderate flow over sand and gravel.
threats: The principal threats facing Enteromius aff. foutensis sp. 2 are the ongoing effects from deforestation, small-scale agriculture along the riparian zone, pollution, and small and large-scale hydropower developments.
population: No information is available on the population.
range:
Enteromius aff. foutensis sp. 2 occurs in the rivers and streams in the upper Gambie and Senegal River drainages in Guinea, West Africa. This species may also occur in the Gambie river drainage in Senegal (Schmidt et al. 2019).

It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 14,973 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 9,996 km2 and is known from six threat-based locations.
useTrade: This species is not harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions for this species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the population size and distribution of this species within the upper Senegal and Gambie River drainages. The life history traits and ecology also need to be investigated.

rationale: The population of Chitra chitra is suspected to have declined by over 80% in the past three generations from targeted exploitation and extensive habitat degradation. Despite conservation actions, many of the impacts continue and there are no indications yet that the population decline has been halted or reversed. It is therefore listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat:
Chitra chitra inhabits large rivers with clear water and sandy substrate; records exist from reservoirs, but the long-term suitability of reservoirs for the species is unknown. In Indonesia, it has been found in muddy rivers in Ciliwung (recently collected near Jakarta).

Generation length is estimated at 45 years (age of first reproduction = 15 x 3). Three generations is 135 years.
threats: The main threats to Chitra chitra include collection for meat consumption and international pet trade. The eggs are also collected for consumption. The species is rarely found in the wild now. In addition, habitat impacts are substantial, and include the downstream effects of dams and reservoirs (affecting water temperature and turbidity, substrate texture, and water levels, potentially flooding nesting sites), river alteration, pollution, and sand dredging. (Sharma and Tisen 2000, van Dijk and Palasuwan 2000, Kitimasak et al. 2005).
population: The subpopulation of Chitra chitra in the Mae Klong and Mae Nam Pachi basins of western Thailand inhabits a relatively small river system and animals are uncommon within the basin, with the subpopulation considered to be in continuing decline (Kitimasak et al. 2005). Subpopulations in the Chao Phraya and Bang Pakong systems appear to have disappeared since 1890 (Kitimasak and Thirakhupt 2002, Webb and van Dijk 2004). It was listed in the 1997 OEPP Red List and 2005 ONEP Red Data for Thailand as Critically Endangered. The Peninsular Malaysian subpopulation appears to be even more sparse, with only a few individual animals reported over the past 80 years. The species is considered very rare in Indonesia and is only recorded from accidental sightings. A recent targeted survey in 2014 in Jambi could not find the species (T. Lescher, unpublished report 2014). It is suspected that the population of this species has been reduced by over 80% in the past three generations due to exploitation and extensive habitat degradation.
range: Chitra chitra is known from the Mae Khlong and Mae Nam Pachi River systems of western Thailand, the Pahang River of Peninsular Malaysia, the Solo River of central Java, and the Brantas River in eastern Java, and Ciliwung River in western Java, Indonesia; it is reputed to occur in Sumatra but this remains unconfirmed. Recent records exist for eastern Java. Historically, the species was cited by local inhabitants as present in the Chao Phraya and Bang Pakong River systems of central Thailand, but there are no actual specimens or records to support this.
useTrade: Chitra chitra is collected for consumption and the international pet trade throughout its range. Its eggs are also collected for consumption.
conservationActions:
Chitra chitra has been listed on CITES Appendix II since 2002 and is protected from exploitation in Thailand under the Wildlife Preservation and Protection Act (WARPA law) of 1992. It is also protected in Indonesia under the Government Regulation of Indonesia No. 7 of 1999.

A conservation breeding program was established in Kanchanaburi by the Fisheries Department of Thailand in the late 1990s with the goal of supporting the population through release of headstarted captive-bred juveniles. Further in situ conservation measures, including strict protection of nesting sites and adjoining river areas, environmentally sensitive operation of hydroelectric reservoirs, public awareness and education, and further population surveys and monitoring, are needed (van Dijk and Palasuwan 2000; Kitimasak et al. 2003, 2005).

rationale: All available information indicates substantial shrinkage of the overall range of Geoclemys hamiltonii, and decline of many but not all subpopulations within the remaining range through exploitation and habitat loss. Available information indicates a recently accelerated and ongoing decline across its range, estimated to exceed 50% since about 1980 (two generations at 20 years generation length; and assuming it was stable before then the decline over the past three generations would have exceeded 50%) and this is projected to continue into the near future. The species qualifies for listing as Endangered under criterion A4cd.
habitat:
Geoclemys hamiltonii prefers shallow, densely vegetated standing waterbodies, but may also occur in rivers, ponds and reservoirs and basks preferentially in reed beds (Das 1991). This species apparently feeds mostly on snails, taking also dragonfly larvae and other insects, freshwater crustaceans and a wide range of other vegetable and animal food items (Minton 1966, Das and Bhupathy in Das 1991, Rashid and Swingland 1997).

Animals may reach 40.5 cm carapace length, at a maximum weight of 6 kg. Females in Bangladesh averaged 30 cm (20.7-40.5, N=14), males are similar-sized averaging 29 cm (21.1-39.2 cm, N=13) (Rashid and Swingland 1997). Maturity in captivity may be reached after 6-8 (Gurley 2003) or 12 years (Artner 2006). Generation time was estimated at 20 years (Singapore Red List Workshop participants 2011).

Females reproduce during two distinct nesting seasons, with the second clutch usually a bit smaller than the first (Das 1991, Das and Bhupathy 2010); females produce clutches of 12-36 eggs (Bhupathy and Choudhury 1993, Basu and Singh 1998, Das 2001, Artner 2006). Hatchlings measure about 37 mm (Ewert 1979).
threats:
Geoclemys hamiltonii was widely collected for local subsistence consumption and local and national trade up to the 1980s, but visible trade had disappeared by the early 1990s (Das 1991, Choudhury et al. 2000). By the late 1990s the species appeared in the East Asian food trade (IUCN TFTSG and ATTWG 2000). The species has become highly popular in the East and Southeast Asian pet trade since about 2006 and continues to be extensively traded illegally.


Das (1991) and Das and Bhupathy (2010) suspected that human agricultural land use pressures on standing waterbodies along the major river systems have affected the species. Accidental capture, entanglement and drowning in fishing nets, and destruction of nesting habitat have also been noted as impacts (Lucknow Red List Workshop participants, Sept 2005).
population:
Status data on Geoclemys hamiltonii are highly variable, with the species considered common in several protected locations (e.g. Kaziranga) and reported as uncommon or rare at other sites, but on balance, Das (1991) considered the species rare. Choudhury et al. (2000) considered the species common in the Brahmaputra floodplains and rare elsewhere, and rated its population as apparently stable in India. By 2011, this situation was understood to have continued with populations still in good shape in protected areas, but rarely found outside. It is nearly extirpated outside protected areas in Assam (Ahmed and Das 2010).

In Bangladesh, the species was considered rare after an abrupt population decline in the past 20 years and total disappearance from extensive parts of its range in Bangladesh (Rashid and Khan 2000). By 2011, the species was considered to be more threatened than previously thought and estimated to have lost at least half its population since 1980, qualifying nationally as Endangered (M.A. Rashid pers. comm. at Singapore Red List Workshop, 2011).

In Pakistan, Akbar et al. (2006) reported the species as ‘frequent’ in the five major rivers of the Punjab region, relative to other sympatric freshwater turtle species.

Participants of the 2018 Tortoises and Freshwater Turtles of Tropical Asia Red List Workshop in Singapore agreed that all available evidence points toward a substantial shrinkage of the range of G. hamiltonii and a decline of many but not all subpopulations within the remaining range through exploitation and habitat loss. This decline has recently accelerated, and ongoing decline across its range is estimated to exceed 50% since about 1980 (two generations at 20 years generation length).
range: Geoclemys hamiltonii inhabits the lowlands of the Indus, Ganga and Brahmaputra River basins of Pakistan; Assam, Bihar, Jammu, Meghalaya, Punjab, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal in India; Bangladesh; and Nepal.
useTrade: Geoclemys hamiltonii was widely collected for local subsistence consumption and local and national trade up to the 1980s, but visible trade had disappeared by the early 1990s (Das 1991, Choudhury et al. 2000). By the late 1990s, the species appeared in the East Asian food trade (IUCN TFTSG  and ATTWG and 2000). The species has become highly popular in the East and Southeast Asian pet trade since about 2006 and continues to be extensively traded illegally. Well over 11,400 live specimens, in at least 70 shipments, were reported as seized from illegal trade during the period 2000-2015, the fifth most numerously seized CITES-listed turtle species (CITES CoP17 Doc73). In 2011-2015, there were 4,000 juveniles of this species confiscated in India. In 2017, 1,500 of this species were confiscated (S. Singh pers. comm. 2018).
conservationActions:
Geoclemys hamiltonii is included in CITES Appendix I, prohibiting all forms of international commercial trade. It is also protected under Schedule I of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (amended) which includes endangered species that may only be hunted under exceptional circumstances under licence from both federal and provincial authorities.

Geoclemys has been recorded from Kaziranga National Park , Orang National Park and Dibru Saikhowa National Park (Assam), Harike Lake (Punjab), and Keoladeo National Park (Rajasthan) in India (Das 1991, Hanfee 1999, Das and Bhupathy 2010); its populations are apparently quite secure at Harike Lake and other lakes in Punjab, where it occurs in most inundated areas, and in the terai belt of India (B.C. Choudhury and D. Basu pers. comm. 2005). The protected river valley in Assam's Kaziranga-Orang Riverine Landscape (KURL) is an important area for the species future (Ahmed and Das 2010).

Status and distribution surveys are needed throughout the range of the species, with emphasis on occurrence in protected areas. Efforts to address subsistence consumption, through education and alternative protein provision, are likely necessary.

Reintroduction or population augmentation with captive-bred or release of confiscated specimens may be considered. The illegal trade in this species must be addressed through a combination of enforcement of existing laws and regulations, improvement of pertinent laws in destination countries, and consumer awareness programs in destination countries. Studies of ecology and life history and population dynamics are needed.

rationale: Archocentrus cetrarchus is distributed in Atlantic and Pacific drainages of Central America, from southern Honduras to Central Costa Rica. EOO is estimated to be 28,435 km2. Existing threats are broad in scope and include pollution, deforestation, and potential competition with non-native species. The direct impact of these threats on population status are unknown. Due to a relatively wide distribution, local abundance in some areas, and no evidence of declines, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This benthopelagic freshwater species appears to prefer stagnant waters characterized by turbid conditions, temperatures of 26-36 °C and muddy substrates (Bussing 1998). In the northern portion of Costa Rica, it is also relatively abundant in irrigation canals and in waterlogged crops (e.g., rice). Diet is typically comprised of detritus, crustaceans, and aquatic insects (Bussing 1998, Winemiller et al. 2011).

This species lays eggs on cleaned surfaces of rocks or tree branches once or twice (but up to six) times per year (A. Angulo pers. comm. 2019). Parents incubate eggs and guard young, tend and fan embryos, and transport newly hatched to excavated pits in the substrate (Conkel 1993, Bussing 1998, A. Angulo pers. comm. 2019). Dark cavities are preferred as nests to conceal the brood and make them less conspicuous to visual predators (Conkel 1993, Bussing 1998). Approximately 150-250 eggs are deposited and are vigorously guarded and cared for by both male and female (A. Angulo pers. comm. 2019).

Maximum reported body size is 11 cm (Conkel 1993).
threats:
Pollution from agricultural runoff, sewage discharge, urban and industrial wastewater, and solid waste have probably resulted in considerable declines in habitat quality throughout much of Nicaragua and Costa Rica (Parello et al. 2008, Diepens et al. 2014, Vammen et al. 2019). Widespread historical deforestation has resulted in increased sedimentation rates (Gourdji et al. 2015, Stan et al. 2019). Tilapia (Oreochromis spp.) have become widely established in Nicaragua, and may compete with native species for resources (McCrary et al. 2007).

Construction of the proposed Nicaragua Canal is very likely to produce negative effects on habitat quality (Chen et al. 2016, Härer et al. 2017).
population: Total population size is unknown, but presumably exceeds 10,000 individuals given a relatively broad distribution. Population trend is unknown. This species was well-represented in samples taken from the Frio River in the Vida Silvestre Caño Negro National Refuge, Costa Rica (Sánchez et al. 2006), but was uncommon in samples taken from the Pacuare River, Costa Rica (Barboza and Villalobos 2018).
range:
Archocentrus centrarchus is distributed on the Pacific slope of Honduras, and on the Atlantic slopes of Nicaragua and Costa Rica. In Honduras, it occurs in the Choluteca and Negro River drainages, which drain into the Gulf of Fonseca (Matamoros et al. 2009). In Nicaragua, it is distributed throughout the San Juan River drainage, including lakes Managua, Nicaragua, Jiloá, and Apoyo (Kullander 2003). In Costa Rica, it occurs from the San Juan drainage southward to the Parismina and Matina River drainages (Angulo et al. 2013). Elevation ranges from 0-45 meters above sea level (Angulo et al. 2013).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 28,435 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019).
useTrade: This species is relatively common in the ornamental trade, but the total volume of wild harvest is unknown. In Europe, the majority of traded specimens are aquacultured (A. Angulo pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific actions directed towards A. centrarchus. The range of this species includes multiple Protected Areas, which may provide indirect protection against habitat degradation (Sánchez et al. 2006, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). Additional research regarding population size, population trend, and the scope and impact of existing threats would be useful in guiding future conservation outcomes.

rationale: This species has narrow habitat requirements and it is likely to have a moderately small population, fragmented into small subpopulations, and it may be declining owing to habitat loss. It is therefore considered Near Threatened.
habitat: This species occurs up to an elevation of 1,100 m in small marshes and swales, as well as in short trees and shrubs bordering wet areas. It is closely associated with the spiny apiaceous herb "caraguata" Eryngium spp., which is abundant in marshes throughout its range (Ridgely and Tudor 1994). It also occurs locally away from water in upland thickets of Eryngium pandanifolum.
threats: In Argentina, and particularly in the heavily populated Buenos Aires province, its habitat is threatened by house-building, rubbish dumps and water pollution (Chebez 1994). It is presumably also threatened by intensive grazing, marsh drainage, extensive willow Salix plantations and, particularly in east Entre Ríos, the drying effects of Eucalyptus and Pinus spp. plantations (Pearman and Abadie 1995).
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'fairly common but patchily distributed' (Stotz et al. 1996). The total population size is therefore suspected to be small and fragmented.
range: Limnoctites rectirostris occurs in extreme south Brazil (Santa Catarina and Rio Grande do Sul), south Uruguay and east Argentina (Entre Ríos and extreme north-east Buenos Aires) (Ridgely and Tudor 1994, Babarskas and Fraga 1998). It is very locally distributed, but locally common in appropriate habitats.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway

None known.

Conservation Actions Proposed

Repeat surveys of known sites in order to determine rates of population decline and range contraction. Encourage the conservation of wetland habitats within the range, including the gazetting of protected areas at key sites.

rationale: This species qualifies as Vulnerable because it has a very small range, being confined to one very small island and one tiny islet, and it is therefore susceptible to stochastic events and human impacts.
habitat: It nests in burrows or under rock cavities and occasionally between tree buttresses from sea level to 900 m, but mostly between 500 and 800 m (Bester et al. 2002, Bester 2003). On Lord Howe, it breeds in forest, as once did the population of Norfolk Island, so the Phillip Island population is atypical, burrows being in eroded cliffs of soft volcanic tuff (Priddel et al. 2010). It is a winter breeder, with birds from Phillip Island breeding at the same time as Lord Howe Island (Priddel et al. 2010). Adults arrive at Phillip from mid-April, a single egg is laid mid- to late May, hatching starts mid-July, and chicks are near-fledged by early November (Bester et al. 2007, Priddel et al. 2010). Adults land during daylight, often about 15.30 h (Priddel et al. 2010). A study on Lord Howe Island in 2000-2001 determined 54% breeding success in burrows visited twice and contents not handled, with 34-36% success in burrows repeatedly visited (Bester et al. 2007). Nests closest to burrow entrances had lowest breeding success, with the main causes of failure being flooding and predation of eggs and chicks by the endemic, threatened Lord Howe Woodhen Hypotaenidia sylvestris (Bester et al. 2007). A study in 2008 on Lord Howe Island found the breeding success in a small lowlands population to be three times higher (58%; n = 104) than in populations on Mount Gower (15%; n = 33) (D. Binder unpubl. data). Additionally, adult provisioning trips were between 2–12 days (mean 4.8), with no evidence of a bimodal distribution of long and short trips (Binder et al. 2013). The adults feed predominantly on squid and fish with crustaceans less important. The most important prey item is bioluminescent fish from the genus Electrona; maximum diving depths have been recorded at 5 m (Bester 2003). It also scavenges for food taking fish offal and has been recorded scavenging on a Shining Bronze-cuckoo Chalcites lucidus (Bester 2003). It only occasionally follows fishing boats (Kuroda 1955, Bester 2003), but some fishing material has been reported in their diet (Bester 2003).
threats:
This species is at risk from flooding due to heavy rains and the flooding of burrows represented the main cause of breeding failure on Lord Howe Island in the 2000 and 2001 breeding seasons (Bester et al. 2007). Although flooding is unlikely to kill adult birds, it kills eggs and chicks through chilling and can weaken burrows, causing them to collapse (Bester et al. 2007).

The native Lord Howe Woodhen is known to prey on eggs and young chicks and is known to be a significant source of nesting mortality (Bester et al. 2007). Wedge-tailed Shearwaters are also problematic, known to evict smaller petrels from burrows, they have been seen to kill chicks in the small population on Phillip Island (Priddel et al. 2010). Invasive and introduced species have also been a problem in the past, however, wild pigs, cats and goats have been successfully eradicated from Lord Howe Island (Department of the Environment and Energy 2015). Rat predation accounts for a small proportion of breeding failures each year (Bester et al. 2007). The rat population on Lord Howe is being controlled by baiting, with some plans to eradicate them in the future. If rat eradication does occur, introduced masked owls may switch to preying on petrels, potentially causing problematic declines (Bester et al. 2007), for this reason there are plans for the eradication of this species on Lord Howe (Milledge et al. 2010).

The Providence Petrel is at risk from drowning due to entrapment in fishing gear, however, this is not thought to be a significant source of mortality (Bester et al. 2007).
