Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thevakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires, but natural fires are unknown in rainforests where the species occurs. The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation may also impact negatively on amphibians. Findings from Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that mist- and rain-water acidity may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a problem for species that are found in areas where mist is present for a long time, and species that are found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats could be more vulnerable to this threat (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Additionally, within the central hills various species of invasive plants are encroaching on the natural forest habitat causing habitat loss and degradation (M. Meegaskumbura, N. Wijayathilaka, M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is patchily distributed across its range, but is abundant where it is found (M. Meegaskumbura and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm. February 2020). However, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the Peak Wilderness and the Central Hill Country of southwestern Sri Lanka, and has been recorded at elevations ranging between 810-1,600 m asl (K. Ukuwela pers. comm. February 2020). Known localities include Seethagangula, Sri Palabaddala, Aulton Watta, Norwood, and Moray (M. Wickramasinghe unpub. data 2020). It is not likely to occur more widely than current records suggest (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), its distribution is thought to represent five or fewer threat-defined locations due to the influence of tourism and small-scale agriculture on the landscape, and the extent of occurrence (EOO) is 507 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is found in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, Agra-Bopath Forest Reserve, Rilagela Forest Reserve, and Horton Plains National Park (M. Meegaskumbura and K. Ukuwela pers. comm. February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of loss of habitat, agrochemical pollution, and disturbance by tourism.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 11,663 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in shaded places including rainforests and anthropogenic habitats such as home gardens. It is usually observed 0.3-2 m above ground, perched on branches or leaves. Calling males are sometimes found concealed in dried, curled leaves, although in Gilimale males were always observed vocalizing while on leaves (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). Breeding is by direct development. This species is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance as it requires forest cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats: Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season, during which a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. In this region the forest is dying back, possibly due to pollution and/or climate change. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Within Morningside, it is threatened by the loss of forest canopy for expansion of cardamom and tea plantations at the expense of cloud forest habitat, clearing of undergrowth, small-scale collection of firewood, and encroaching human settlements. Changing agricultural practices within cardamom plantations could also negatively affect this species, particularly if the change involves the use of agro-chemicals. Small-scale potato cultivation and the resulting pollution from pesticide use also presents a threat to this species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Lowland species (e.g. P. rus and hallidayi encroaching into highland habitats within the Morningside reserve may also constitute a threat to this species as it is displacing and out competing other species (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Additionally, invasive plant species (e.g. Acacia sp.) are actively being planted in the region, which is resulting in forest clearing (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Climate change also poses a threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia (the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month), which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is common (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species is endemic to the southwestern lowlands of Sri Lanka, and is found at elevations from 60-1,000 m asl. It has been recorded from Kottawa, Haycock, Gilimale and Induruwa (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). This species is restricted to its known range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 11,663 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in several reserves, including Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Gilimale Nature Reserve, Kanneliya Forest Reserve, Kottawa Forest Reserve and Haycock Hill Forest Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of conversion of habitat for plantation agriculture, and agro-chemical pollution.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 394 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits montane forest and is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It presumably breeds by direct development.
threats:
Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. 

Climate change also poses a threat, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016).  This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is uncommon and its abundance varies seasonally (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to Sri Lanka and is was previously known only from the imprecise type locality of "Ceylon [=Sri Lanka]" (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005), rendering it impossible to map. It has since been rediscovered from Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, Loolkandura (M. Wickramasinghe unpub. data February 2020), Kolony in Vidulipura village in Norton Bridge (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020), and Mussakele (D. Samarasinghe unpub. data February 2020) where it occurs at elevations ranging between 1,200-1,400 m asl (M.  <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Wickramasinghe"}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14851,"3":{"1":0},"4":{"1":3,"3":2},"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":2236962},"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). It is possible that this species occurs more widely than is currently known (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), but the extent of occurrence (EOO) of its currently mapped distribution is 369 km<sup>2</sup>, and represents three threat defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known to occur in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary and Nature Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed  
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture, tourism, and the potential impacts of climate change. There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,996 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits both closed and open canopy rainforest, where it has been found at night on boulders and branches near streams. It has also been founded in shaded, wet rural gardens, however it is a water associated species and therefore these gardens must contain streams (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). This species is forest and stream-dependent, and is not thought to be tolerant to habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It has not been found away from forest (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). During the day, it hides in rock crevices on the margins of streams. Breeding is by direct development. The female excavates a deep hole in the forest floor where the eggs are then deposited.
threats:
This species is likely threatened by habitat loss due to farming (cultivation of cardamom and tea), small-scale collection of firewood, timber extraction and plantations (pine), and expanding human settlements, as well as pollution by agro-chemicals (resulting in deterioration of water quality). Additional sources of pollution include domestic sources, solid waste, and disturbance by tourists as people bathe in streams (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016).  This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species was previously thought to be uncommon, but due to increased survey effort it is now known to be abundant within suitable habitat (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to central Sri Lanka, occurring in two disjunct subpopulations: one in the Central Hill Country and the other in the Knuckles Range. There are specific records from the Gannoruwa forest and Hanthana Environmental Protected Area (P. Samarawickrama unpub. February 2020), Agra-Bopath, Bogowantalawa, and the Knuckles Range (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005).  It has been recorded at elevations ranging between 1,200-1,600 m asl (Pethiyagoda and Manamendra-Arachchi 2012). This species is not thought to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,996 km2 and its distribution is thought to represent at least two, but no more than five, threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in the Knuckles Forest Reserve, Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, Hanthana Environmental Protected Area, Gannoruwa Forest Reserve, Punawala Forest Area, Morningside Forest Reserve, Sinharaja World Heritage Site, and Thangamale Protected Area (P. Samarawickrama, D. Kandambi, M. Meegaskumbura and M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss to agriculture, collection of firewood, timber extraction and pine plantations, expanding human settlements, pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Peak Wilderness.
habitat: This is a canopy species, being found at in cloud forest canopy, 1-10 m above the forest floor (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). It is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (M. Wickramasinghe and D. Samarasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). It presumably breeds by direct development.
threats:
Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area, however at present this species is not being affected. 

Annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation may also impact negatively on amphibians. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Findings from Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that mist- and rain-water acidity may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a problem for species that are found in areas where mist is present for a long time, and species that are found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats could be more vulnerable to this threat (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). 

With decrease in the canopy cover, alien invasive species, such as Clusia rosea, and Pteribium revolutum, are widely distributed in lower areas and slowly spreading to higher elevations, which can potentially become a threat in the future if the presence of these species alter the vegetation structure and potential micro-habitats within this species' range (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).
population: This species was known only from the lost holotype until its rediscovery in 2013. There have been no records at the type locality since the species was described in 1853. At its new locality, the species is highly seasonal, being found more often at certain times of year. In general it is thought to be rare, with only 1-2 individuals observed at a single time. Despite a paucity of records, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
range:
This species was previously known only from the type locality of Nuwara Eliya (Newera-Ellia in type locality description), in Sri Lanka (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). No observations have been recorded in this area since 1853 and the species is now believed to be locally extinct at the type locality. 

However, it was rediscovered in Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve in 2013. Records of the species indicate that it has an elevational range of 1,540-1,679 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). This species is not thought to occur more widely (M. Wickramasinghe and D. Samarasinghe pers. comm. February 2020) and the extent of occurrence (EOO) of its extant distribution is 10 km2. The new locality is considered a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place 
This species is known from the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of cloud forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss, pollution, and the impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,223 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat:
This subterranean species inhabits evergreen forests, rubber plantations, tea plantations, paddy fields, rural gardens and farms, wetlands (boggy areas), and cattle pastureland. The adults are often found in humus. It is assumed to be oviparous with terrestrial eggs and aquatic larvae.

This species has been recorded in agricultural habitats that retain high enough levels of vegetation and moisture. However, it is not thought to be tolerant of more extreme changes that result in much lower soil moisture levels, consistently alter soil chemistry, and have have the potential to result in fragmentation (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Furthermore, it appears to be less adaptable than Ichthyophis glutinosus.
threats:
The species is known from both intact habitats and agricultural landscapes. Elevated levels of human activity may actually be causing a high enough level of disturbance such that it constitutes a cause for concern. Therefore, localized threats are considered to be extreme habitat loss due to agroindustry and clear cutting, as well as heavy use of pesticides and other agrochemicals due to chemical leaching into the soil. In addition, since 2005, construction of large-scale dams, large-scale hydropower stations (Kalugaga and Moragahakanda, established in 2019), several small-scale hydropower stations, as well as water extraction for agricultural purposes in some localities, all pose a threat to this species as these activities cause desiccation of larval habitats (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Additional threats include roads, road construction, and the accompanying concrete barriers and drains within the species' range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Sand mining and subsequent erosion is a threat throughout its range (M. Wickremasinghe pers. comm. February 2020), as is land filling for domestic waste. 

Climate change also poses a threat to the species due to changes in the spatial and temporal patterns of rainfall, which results in the soil drying (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is uncommon and was last recorded from within the Pattipola Reserve in 1986, despite five general amphibian surveys to the area, and many general amphibian surveys conducted throughout the rest of its known range which failed to record the species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The most recent record is from Haldummulla in 2004 (S. Karunarathna unpub. data 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the mountains of south central Sri Lanka. It has been recorded at elevations between 460-1,890 m asl and is likely restricted to its currently known range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,223 km<sup>2 </sup>and, given the possibility of local extinctions and the ongoing threat of clear-cutting within its small range, this species is likely restricted to fewer than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from Pattipola Forest Reserve and Namunakula Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss and pollution throughout its range. Additionally, it is necessary to investigate about this species complex in order to elucidate the taxonomic identity of its members.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,697 km2, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This forest-dependent species occurs in lowland and mid-elevation rainforests, is restricted to primary and secondary forests with extensive canopy cover (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009), and therefore has a low tolerance threshold towards habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Individuals can be found perching on leaves of shrubs that they climb at night to vocalize (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009). Males have been observed 0.5-1.5 m above ground level (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009). This species breeds by direct development. Eggs are laid in a depression in the soil and the female covers it up later (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. October 2010).
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in Peak Wilderness and now a large area has been affected, but the cause is still unknown (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).

Climate change also poses a threat through potential changes in precipitation patterns. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia, where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: Although the species' distribution within canopy-covered forest is not uniform, it is considered to be common where it is found (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. October 2010, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Forest fragmentation is limiting its dispersal ability and the population is therefore considered to be severely fragmented (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. November 2010). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is endemic to Sri Lanka and is currently known from Kanneliya-Dediyagala-Nakiyadeniya (KDN Complex), Kitulgala, Kottawa Forest Reserve, and the Sinharaja World Heritage Site (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009, M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. November 2010), Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Gilimale, Aberdeen falls (S. Wijayasekara unpub. data February 2020), and Balanthota village in Ginigathhena (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020). This species is thought to occur between known localities, but is not likely to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its elevational range is 60-700 m asl (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,697 km2, and it is thought to occur in at least three but no more than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve and the Kottawa, Kitulgala, Sinharaja and Kanneliya-Dediyagala-Nakiyadeniya Forest Reserves. 

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed 
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of human activities such as encroaching agriculture and pollution, as well as the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) does not exceed 10 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Peak Wilderness Reserve.
habitat: This species is found from the forest floor to about 1.5 m high in shrubs within lowland rain forests and lower montane rain forests (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). It is not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance, as it has only ever been found in primary forest (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). This species is presumed to breed by direct development (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Also within the Peak Wilderness Area, the species is threatened by the presence of naturally occurring invasive Heliconia sp. that is encroaching on the species' habitat and tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires, but natural fires are unknown in rainforests where the species occurs. The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation may also impact negatively on amphibians. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Findings from Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that mist- and rain-water acidity may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a problem for species that are found in areas where mist is present for a long time, and species that are found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats could be more vulnerable to this threat (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: Surveys conducted since 2012 have observed several hundred individuals (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). However, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat. General amphibian surveys have been conducted outside of the species' type locality, including within secondary habitats, and have failed to record the species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species known only from the vicinity of the type locality at Sripada Peak in the Peak Wilderness Area, Ratnapura District, Sabaragamuwa Province, Sri Lanka where it is known from 750-1,400 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). It is not likely to occur more widely (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Because of its restricted distribution, its extent of occurrence (EOO) has been estimated to be 10 km2. Should further localities be identified in future, its EOO is expected to remain smaller than 100 km2. The type locality is considered a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known from Peak Wilderness Protected Area. 

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture, tourism, and the potential impacts of climate change. There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km<sup>2</sup>, and due to its highly restricted distribution, this is unlikely to increase in future. In addition, it is considered to occur in just one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits cloud forests, is found from the forest floor up to about 2 m high in shrubs and bamboo, and is not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance as it has only ever been found in primary forest (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). It is presumed to breed by direct development (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area.

This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species.

(1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that mist- and rain-water acidity may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a problem for species that are found in areas where mist is present for a long time, and species that are found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats could be more vulnerable to this threat (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is only known from 7-10 specimens, including the type series (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Therefore, little is known about the population size and trends of this species. However, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat. General amphibian surveys have been conducted outside of the species' type locality, including within secondary habitats, and have failed to record the species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality at Sripada Peak in the Peak Wilderness Area, Ratnapura District, Sabaragamuwa Province, Sri Lanka, where it occurs at elevations ranging between 1,550-1,900 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). It is not likely to occur more widely than this area (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Because of its restricted distribution, its extent of occurrence (EOO) has been estimated to be 10 km2. Should further localities be identified in future, its EOO is expected to remain smaller than 100 km2. The type locality is considered a single threat-defined location.

Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

habitat: The species is found mainly in cloud forest, from the forest floor to about 6 m high in trees. They are commonly observed on tree trunks with lichens, or hidden in crevices on bark, or on shrubs (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). This species is presumed to breed by direct development, as with congeners. This species is not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance, as it has only ever been found in primary forest (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).

February 2020).
population: This species is uncommon (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). It is a seasonal frog and, although uncommon, it is not thought to be as rare as P. newtonjayawardenai and P. stellatus. A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat. (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality at Sripada Peak in the Peak Wilderness Protected Area, Ratnapura District, Sabaragamuwa Province, Sri Lanka, where it has been found at elevations ranging from 1,600-1,750 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). This species is not likely to occur more widely (M. Wickremasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality of Sripada Peak, Peak Wilderness Protected Area, in the Ratnapura District of Sabaragamuwa Province, Sri Lanka. Given that it is only known from the area of the type locality, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is presumed to be less than 10 km2 and it is thought to occur in a single threat-defined location.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 763 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least three but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: Individuals of this species have been observed perched on rocks in shady places during the day and perched on 1 m high bushes at night. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). It is presumed to breed by direct development similar to its congeners.

population: This species is common in suitable habitat (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). However, a decreasingly population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is currently confirmed from three localities, including the type locality of Sripada Peak in the Peak Wilderness Protected Area, Nuwara Eliya District in the Central Province of Sri Lanka, Chariot path in the Central Province (S. Wijayasekara unpub. data February 2020), and Nonpareil Estate in Sabaragamuwa Province (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020). This species might occur at suitable elevations and habitat between known localities; however, because the elevation and availability of suitable habitat is inconsistent in the intervening areas, it may be restricted to the vicinity of the known localities (S. Wijayasekara pers. comm. February 2020), which is reflected in the map. It occurs at elevations between 1,800-2,100 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 763 km2, and its distribution is thought to represent at least three but no more than five threat-defined locations.

Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species.
population: This species is uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). However, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality of Sripada Peak, Peak Wilderness, Ratnapura District, in the Sabaragamuwa Province of Sri Lanka. This species has been located at elevations ranging from 1,000-1,400 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Because of its restricted distribution, its extent of occurrence (EOO) has been estimated to be 10 km2. Should further localities be identified in future, its EOO is expected to remain smaller than 100 km2. The type locality is considered a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known to occur in Peak Wilderness Protected Area (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of expanding agriculture, tourism, and the potential impacts of climate change. There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Peak Wilderness.
habitat: This species inhabits montane cloud forests where specimens were found in the canopy among mosses on trees and branches about 10 m above the forest floor (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). This species is not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance, as it has only ever been found in primary forest (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). It is presumed to breed by direct development (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. Within the Peak Wilderness Area, the species is threatened by the presence of naturally occurring invasive Heliconia sp. that is encroaching on the species habitat (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016).  This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation may also impact negatively on amphibians. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Findings from Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that mist- and rain-water acidity may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a problem for species that are found in areas where mist is present for a long time, and species that are found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats could be more vulnerable to this threat (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is rare (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020), and a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality of Sripada Peak, Peak Wilderness, Ratnapura District, in the Sabaragamuwa Province of Sri Lanka where it has been found at elevations ranging from 1,600-1,700 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is currently limited to this restricted distribution and is 10 km2, which is also thought to represent a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known to occur in Peak Wilderness Protected Area (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of cloud forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of expanding agriculture, tourism, and the potential impacts of climate change. There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,798 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in lowland rainforest. Individuals have commonly been observed near the forest edge with open canopy, and are found in greater abundance in these areas than in closed canopy forest (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). Observations of breeding behavior indicate that this species does not have a free-living larval stage, however it is unclear if they are foam nesters or a direct developing species (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). Further studies need to clarify the breeding biology of this species (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). This species is thought to tolerate a small amount of habitat disturbance, however it requires pristine breeding habitats and some forest cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February).
threats:
Threats to this species include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

In parts of this species range, specifically along the Induru River, one of the main branches of the Kalu River that flows through the Gilimale Forest Reserve, forest fragmentation has become the major threat in this area due to the fast rate of deforestation. The Induruwa Mukalana and Guruluwana regions became separated due to deforestation between 2002 and 2012 and are now two separate islands. Many isolated forest patches that existed in the area disappeared between 2007 and 2012, having been cleared and converted to human settlements. By 2012, the gravel road which consisted of water holes during the monsoonal rains had been concreted about half the road's length (750 m of the total 1,500 m). This has led to more visitors and more vehicles entering the forest reserve, which also resulted in large quantities of garbage being discarded in the forest, and the remaining temporary water holes drying out quickly when vehicles are driven through them. Forest patches also are being cleared and converted to small tea plantations. Apart from logging, hazardous activities such as gem mining, sand mining, use of agro-chemicals, cutting and burning the forest edge, drying out of water bodies, and soil erosion are also threats.

Climate change also poses an additional threat to this species, as its range includes the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains the regions biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing species. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is rare (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species was previously known only from the type locality in Gilimale Forest, Ratnapura, Sabaragamuwa Province, Sri Lanka. Additional records from Dolukanda (S. Wijayasekara and D. Samarasinghe unpub. data February 2020) and from Baduraliya in Mathugama (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020) have now been found. The subpopulation at Dolukanda is isolated, as surveys to the surrounding areas have not recorded the species to date (S. Wijayasekara pers. comm. February 2020), but it is likely to occur more widely than currently mapped (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).  It is known from around 150 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,798 km2, and it is thought to occur in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known from the Gilimale Forest Reserve and Dolukanda Conservation Forest (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture and urbanization, mining, hydropower, pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change. Additionally, there is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: Only hybridised specimens of this species currently remain in the wild. The last collection of non-hybridised specimens was in 1967, despite intensive sampling throughout the entire species' range from this date, until present day. This species is now considered Extinct in the Wild, with the only remaining specimens held ex-situ at Universidad Autonoma de Nuevo Leon, Facultad de Ciencias Biologicas - Refuge Centre for Endangered Fish Species.  Successful re-introduction of the species is dependent upon recovery of the habitat which remains threatened by habitat loss and degradation caused by the over-extraction of water resources leading to the desiccation of the endothermal springs which the species inhabits. Viability of suitable habitat is also threatened by water pollution from urban sewage and run-off, and competition and predation from introduced invasive alien species. Development of ex-situ populations is an immediate priority for this species.
habitat: The Monterrey Platyfish inhabits densely shaded, quiet, clear water of springs, their outflows, and in pools or headwaters of spring-fed streams not far from sources. It inhabits substrates of fine sand and mud (often deep) at depths to 0.6 m (Miller et al. 2015).
threats: The species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation caused by urban encroachment, sewage pollution, desiccation of the natural springs and competition and predation from introduced invasive alien species (Ceballos et al. 2016). Ojo de Agua de Apodaca has been transformed into an urban recreational pool. This species has been extirpated from this habitat for over ten years (A. Valdés Gonzalez pers. comm. 2018).
population: Although once found more widely in the region of Monterrey, most sub-populations have been lost to urban sprawl, with water habitats either drying up due to land reclamation and water extraction or being heavily polluted. Currently the species sub-populations are very restricted to a few small springs in Apodaca, suburban area of Monterrey (Ceballos et al. 2016). However, these sub-populations belong to a putative new species (X. apodaca). Hybridization with the Sunset Platty (Xiphophorus variegatus) (Cui et al. 2013) has eliminated pure lineages of X. couchianus and the putative new species X. apodaca in the wild (A. Valdés Gonzalez pers. comm 2018). No non-hybrid specimens have been collected since 1967 despite intensive sampling throughout the entire species' range (Contreras Balderas and Escalante 1984, A. Valdés  Gonzalez pers. comm. 2018). Captive populations of the putative X. apodaca are currently held in two facilities (A. Valdés Gonzalez pers. comm 2018).
range: The Monterrey Platyfish is an endemic species restricted to the Atlantic Slope of Mexico, where it's historical range included the endothermal springs of upper Rio San Juan including rios Apodoca, Monterrey, and Santa Catarina, and the Rio Bravo basin in Nuevo Leon. As a result of habitat loss and degradation the species is currently restricted to only one natural locality (Ojo de Agua de Apodaca, at Apodaca, Nuevo Leon) (Miller et al. 2015). Subpopulations occurring in the Rio Pesquerias (Founder Spring, Apodoca) are a putative new species and are taxonomically distinct (A. Valdes Gonzales pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: This species has been used in medical research for 15-20 years (A. Vald<span class="st">és Gonzalez pers. comm. 2018).
conservationActions: The species is protected under the NOM-059-SERMANAT-2010 and bred in captivity (Aguilera González 1998). Despite protection, this species is now considered extinct in the wild and is held in captivity at Universidad Autonoma de Nuevo Leon, Facultad de Ciencias Biologicas - Refuge Centre for Endangered Fish Species (A. Valdés Gonzalez pers. comm. 2018) in addition to the aquarium of the Zoological Society of London, United Kingdom (B. Zimmerman pers. comm. 2019). City policy changes (Apodaca) are required in order to effectively reintroduce this species into the wild. Recovery of habitat is also necessary prior to reintroduction. It will also be important to develop further ex-situ populations to better guarantee the stability of the species, moving forward.

rationale: This species is endemic to Panama, occurring within the Chagres, Tuira, and Bayano River drainages. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to range from 5,591-15,114 km2. A number of threats exist, including non-native predators, parasites, pollution associated with raw sewage discharge and poor solid waste management, and potential agricultural and hydropower expansion. While the direct impact of these threats are unknown, they are inferred to have resulted in declines in habitat quality and availability. Additionally, the apparent extirpation of this species from one section of Lake Gatun infers reductions in total population size. However, uncertainties regarding the scope of existing threats makes it difficult to accurately determine the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs. Therefore, this species is assessed as Near Threatened because it nearly meets the criterion for a threatened category under B1ab(iii).
habitat: This species occurs in rivers and streams characterized by moderate water velocity, water temperatures ranging from 26-30 °C, and substrates comprised of small stones, sand, rocks, and leaf debris (Conkel 1993). Diet is comprised primarily of aufwuchs (Conkel 1993). Parents will occasionally use alternative foraging tactics (e.g., fin digging, leaf lifting) to increase food availability for fry (Silva de Souza 2019). Maximum reported population size is 13 cm total length (TL) (Kullander 2003).
threats:
In the Chagres River drainage, P. panamensis is a demonstrated host of the non-native Asian fish tapeworm Bothriocephalus acheilognathi, which may reduce individual fitness in parasitized individuals (Choudhury et al. 2013). The establishment of non-native Cichla monoculus may have resulted in the extirpation of this species from the Trinidad Arm of Lake Gatun (Sharpe et al. 2017). Lacking sewage treatment and insufficient solid waste management has resulted in intense localized pollution in watersheds adjacent to towns and cities (Ibáñez et al. 2002).

Future water use for hydropower development and agricultural expansion may pose a significant threat to freshwater fauna in central Panama (Larsen 2019).
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. The rarity of this species within its distribution is largely unknown. There is currently no indication of major range-wide population decline.
range:
Panamius panamensis is distributed on the Atlantic and Pacific slopes of central and eastern Panama (Kullander 2003). It has been reported from the Chagres, Tuira, and Bayano River drainages (Conkel 1993, Smith and Bermingham 2005). The type locality of this species is the Mandingo River, Bas Obispo, Canal Zone, Panama (Kullander 2003).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to range between 5,591-15,114 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019). While threats exist and are likely to be impacting habitat quality and availability, the scope and magnitude of these threats are unknown and therefore the number of locations where this species occurs cannot be determined with accuracy. There is currently no evidence to suggest severe fragmentation.
useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation actions directed towards this species. However, it occurs in at least one protected area (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019), which may provide indirect protection against habitat degradation. More information regarding population size, population status, and the direct impacts of potential threats would be useful in guiding future conservation action.

rationale: The cause of the population reduction in this species (commercial whaling) is reversible, understood, and is not currently in operation. For this reason, the species is assessed under criterion A1, not under A2, A3 or A4. Physeter macrocephalus is globally widespread (thus not qualifying as threatened under criterion B), and does not have a global population that warrants listing under criteria C-D. Empirical trend data for this species globally are unavailable. However, commercial whaling at a large scale for this species in the North Pacific and Antarctic within the last three generations (82 years) certainly resulted in a global decline during this period. Commercial whaling for this species has ceased and therefore this population is evaluated under the A1 criterion rather than under the A2-4 criteria. A peer-reviewed publication (Whitehead 2002) provides a model-based estimate of global trend that can be used to evaluate the population under the A1 criterion. The results from that study gave a 6% probability for Endangered, a 54% probability of meeting the Vulnerable category, and a 40% probability of falling into the Near Threatened category. The results suggest little chance that the population would meet the criteria for Endangered or for Least Concern. There is credible and realistic evidence for either the Vulnerable or Near Threatened category. Given that the results give greater probability for at least the Vulnerable category (60%), and that this is the more precautionary category, the species is classified as Vulnerable.
habitat:
The habitat of the Sperm Whale is the open sea. More specifically, Sperm Whales can be found in almost all marine waters deeper than 1,000 m that are not covered by ice, except in the Black Sea and possibly the Red Sea (Rice 1989; Whitehead 2003). In some areas, particularly in the western North Atlantic, sperm whales, especially males, can occur in shallower waters (e.g., Scott and Sadove 1997). Females and young are usually restricted to waters at latitudes lower than about 40-50º and to areas where sea surface temperatures are greater than about 15ºC (Rice 1989). Sperm Whales are generally more numerous in areas of relatively high primary productivity (Jaquet et al. 1996), although there are some exceptions, such as the Sargasso Sea and the central North Pacific gyre (Barlow and Taylor 2005).

The Sperm Whale is an animal of extremes in size (up to 18 m), sexual dimorphism (mature males have three times the mass of mature females), ecological imprint (sperm whales take roughly the same amount of biomass from the oceans as humans), and many other attributes (Whitehead 2003). The commercial value of the animal (a function of its size and the quality of Sperm Whale oil) drove two massive worldwide hunts: the technologically primitive “open-boat” hunt from 1712-~1920 (Starbuck 1878; Best 1983), and modern whaling using engine-driven whaling ships and harpoon guns from ~1910-1988 (Tonnessen and Johnsen 1982). The complex social structure of sperm whales may have been affected by whaling, lowering potential population growth rates, which are very low anyway (Whitehead 2003). On the positive side, Sperm Whales are very widely distributed (see above), and their primary prey, deep-water squid, are not yet major targets of fisheries.

The generation time (mean age of mothers) for Sperm Whales can be calculated if one assumes a set of population parameters, specifically age at first birth, mortality rate of mature females, and reproductive rate of mature females. There is uncertainty about these parameters, so two calculations were made using different assumptions:

a) Applying the population parameters most recently used for Sperm Whales by the International Whaling Commission’s Scientific Committee (International Whaling Commission 1982): age at first birth = 10 years; female reproductive rate in unexploited population = 0.20/year; female adult mortality = 0.055/yr): generation time = 27.3 years.

b) The estimates of mortality used by the International Whaling Commission are particularly problematic, and Sperm Whales likely have age-specific survival and reproductive rates. Thus it may be more realistic (Whitehead 2002) to use the well-established mortality schedule of Killer Whales (Orcinus orca; Olesiuk et al. 1990) and an age-specific pregnancy rate taken from the sperm whale data presented by Best et al. (1984; pregnancy rate for mature females = 0.257-0.0038xAge in years): generation time = 27.5
threats:
The greatest threat to Sperm Whales, extensive commercial whaling, has ceased. However, a number of other threats of various dimensions remain.

Sperm Whales have had a long history of local whaling going back at least to the 1500s and intense commercial whaling beginning around 1712 and continuing to 1988. The “modern” highly mechanised phase was particularly intense around 1950, and at its peak killed around 25,000 whales per year, dramatically depleting the global population. In recent decades, some tens of whales were taken each year from small boats in Indonesia (Reeves 2002), although none have been taken in the last two years (H. Whitehead pers. comm.), and 10 are taken annually by Japan under IWC Special Permit (Clapham et al. 2003).

Entanglement in fishing gear, particularly gillnets, has been a particular problem in the Mediterranean Sea (Reeves and Notarbartolo di Sciara, 2006), but Sperm Whales die from entanglement in nets and lines in many other areas and in a variety of fisheries as well (e.g., Haase and Félix 1994; Barlow and Cameron 2003). Considering the widespread distribution of Sperm Whales, observations of occasional takes in relatively small scale gillnet fisheries (e.g. Barlow and Cameron 2003) suggest much larger takes in unobserved, unregulated high seas driftnet fisheries such as were common before the 1989 adoption of resolution 44/225 of the UN General Assembly.

Sperm Whales sometimes take fish off fishing gear (most often demersal long-line gear), an activity known as “depredation.” Depredation of long-line catches appears to be a recent and increasing phenomenon, and now occurs in many regions (e.g., South East Alaska, Chile, South Georgia and several other southern ocean island areas, North Atlantic). This interaction has resulted in a few reported entanglements and deaths (e.g. Salas 1987; Hucke-Gaete et al. 2004), and has incurred hostility from some fishermen (National Marine Fisheries Service 1998; Donoghue et al. 2003), including shooting of whales (González and Olivarría 2002).

Sperm Whale tissues have high levels of some contaminants (O'Shea 1999; Nielsen et al. 2000); however, any population-level effects on health are unknown. The effects of noise on Sperm Whales are also uncertain. Some evidence suggests that they are highly sensitive to noise (e.g., Watkins et al. 1985; Bowles et al. 1994) while other studies have found little or no effect (e.g., Madsen and Møhl 2000; Madsen et al. 2002). To date, all published studies of Sperm Whales and noise focus on short-term behavioural effects. Avoidance of sonar (Dawson pers. comm.) and seismic surveys (Mate et al. 1994; but see Madsen et al. 2002) has been observed but no mortality has been documented.

Whaling on Sperm Whales has at various times focussed almost exclusively on one sex or the other. Removals of large numbers of males may have had lingering effects on pregnancy rates in some subpopulations (Best 1979; Clarke et al. 1980; Whitehead et al. 1997) and large males are noticeably uncommon on some breeding grounds (Whitehead 2003). The removal of large numbers of females from social groups, and of older females in particular, may have lingering, socially disruptive effects.
