Furthermore, recovery might be inhibited via temporary or permanent loss of social cohesion and of socio-ecological knowledge such as is known to occur in other large-brained, long-lived social mammals (e.g., elephants, Poole and Thomsen 1989).

Maximum rates of increase for Sperm Whale populations are very low, possibly on the order of 1% per year (Whitehead 2002). Population growth/recovery can be expected to be low in the species.

Sperm Whales face other threats at a more regional level. These include collisions with ships (Laist et al. 2001), for instance off the Canary Islands (André and Potter 2000) and in the Mediterranean (Pesante et al. 2002), and ingestion of marine debris in the Mediterranean (e.g., Viale et al. 1992).

Causes for optimism: On the one hand, the Sperm Whale is not being heavily whaled at present and seems relatively secure from this threat in the short and medium term. When not being actively hunted, the Sperm Whale has rather little interaction with humans: most of its habitat is far from land, and few of its food sources (principally deep-water squid) are of currently harvested (Clarke 1977). Some populations, for instance the animals in the western North Atlantic that were little affected by modern whaling, seem healthy with reasonably high population densities and evidence of satisfactory reproduction (Gordon et al. 1998; National Marine Fisheries Service 2000).

Causes for concern: on the other hand, the Sperm Whale, with a maximum rate of increase of around 1% per year (Whitehead 2002), is not well adapted to recover from population depletion. Furthermore, the population model considers only one anthropogenic threat, whaling, and thus posits that the Sperm Whale population has recovered since about 1980 (Fig. 1 in linked PDF document), when large-scale commercial whaling was rapidly coming to an end. This recovery is purely theoretical, and may not be occurring as sperm whales carry high levels of some chemical contaminants (O'Shea 1999; Nielsen et al. 2000), ocean noise is increasing (Gordon and Moscrop 1996), interactions with fisheries continue to result in sperm whale deaths (International Whaling Commission 1994), and the lingering, socially disruptive effects of whaling may be inhibiting recovery of this highly social species (Whitehead et al. 1997). Some regional populations of sperm whales are declining or are apparently not recovering from depletion. Even in the absence of whaling, the Mediterranean population appears to have declined over the past 20 years, with bycatch in driftnets a likely principal cause (Reeves and Notarbartolo di Sciara 2006). The southeastern Pacific Sperm Whale population, very heavily whaled during the period 1950-1980, has an extremely low recruitment rate (probably below replacement), perhaps because of the social disruption caused by intense whaling (Whitehead et al. 1997). The population of mature and maturing males in the Antarctic was also heavily whaled over the same period, but should have repopulated from less heavily exploited breeding populations at lower latitudes following the end of large-scale commercial whaling. However, systematic surveys of Sperm Whales in the Antarctic showed no substantial or statistically significant increase between 1978 and 1992 (Branch and Butterworth 2001).
population:
The only recent quantitative analysis of sperm whale population trends (Whitehead 2002; Fig. 1 in supplementary material, which constitutes an integral part of this assessment) suggests that a pre-whaling global population of about 1,100,000 had been reduced by about 29% by 1880 through “open-boat” whaling, and then to approximately 360,000 (67% reduction from initial) by the 1990s through modern whaling, although much uncertainty is associated with all these estimates (Fig. 1 in supplementary material). There is no direct evidence that any part of the population has increased since the end of large-scale whaling in about 1980, although for most areas there is also no direct evidence that they have not. In some areas there is concern that populations are continuing to decline (see below).

The species has a huge geographic range (Rice 1989) and a global population size in the 100,000's (Whitehead 2002; Fig 1). Although there is considerable uncertainty about sperm whale population parameters and levels of exploitation, Whitehead (2002) estimated historical trajectories of sperm whale abundance incorporating many, but not all, sources of uncertainty (Fig. 1 in supplementary material). That model was modified slightly (to produce an endpoint in 2003) and run to estimate the decline in global sperm whale population size between 1921 and 2003 (i.e. over approximately 3 generations; 82yr; see below for estimation of generation time) (H. Whitehead pers. comm.). As sperm whale population size seems to have changed rather little between about 1910-1930 (Whitehead 2002; Fig. 1 in supplementary material), the calculations are probably quite robust with reference to the estimated generation time. Using the “best” estimates of the model parameters (as in Whitehead 2002), the population in 2003 would have been 44% of that in 1921. Of 1,000 runs using model parameters randomly selected from within reasonable ranges (as in Whitehead 2002), 6% gave populations in 2003 of <30% of that in 1922, 54% gave a 2003 population between 30-50% of that in 1992, and 40% suggested depletion levels of less than 50% over this time.

Arguments can be made that the model results are overly optimistic or overly pessimistic. Factors that would contribute to making the results overly optimistic that are not accounted for in the model include not accounting for under-reporting of illegal Soviet catches in the North Pacific and Antarctica and under-reporting of Japanese catches in the North Pacific (Kasuya and Brownell 2001), other continuing threats (described below), and factors such as continuing effects of social disruption from whaling that might inhibit recovery (consistent with an apparent lack of recovery in many areas). Factors that would contribute to making the results overly pessimistic include the assumption of a relatively low rate of increase in the model and the extrapolation of a relatively high estimate of g(0) (the proportion of whales detected on the trackline) from a single study to the global population. The direction of the effect of other uncertainties in model inputs, including the effects of sex-biased catches, is not certain. Despite these uncertainties, the Whitehead model provides the best available scientific evidence upon which to base this assessment. To reduce these uncertainties, future analyses would need to address the concerns identified above.

Efforts to assess the conservation status of sperm whales and the impact of historical whaling on contemporary structure are compromised by the absence of a good model of sperm whale population structure; pooling data may obscure distinct geographic patterns. While Sperm Whales are known to show long distance movements (Ivashin and Rovnin 1967; Mitchell 1975) and low genetic differentiation among ocean basins, several lines of evidence suggest that sperm whales past and present, have significant geographic structure. Analyses based on historical and contemporary data from tagging records (Rice 1974; Kasuya and Miyashita 1988), blood types (Fujino 1963), catch distributions, sighting patterns, size composition, lack of recovery from exploitation (Japan), timing of pregnancy (Best et al.1984), photo-identification (Whitehead 2003), genetics (Drouot 2004; Mesnick et al. 1999), cultural markers (Rendell and Whitehead 2003) and combinations thereof (Bannister and Mitchell 1980; Kasuya and Miyashita 1988) suggest evidence for structure in many regions. Over the past decade, several authors have investigated population structure in female Sperm Whales using sequence variation within the mitochondrial control region DNA (mtDNA) and/or polymorphic nuclear loci (microsatellites). In general, results tend to find low genetic differentiation among ocean basins and little evidence of subdivision within ocean basins, with the exception of some isolated basins such as the Mediterranean and Gulf of Mexico (Lyrholm et al. 1999; Mesnick et al. 1999; Drouot et al. 2004). However, factors such as low sample sizes, low mtDNA haplotypic diversity and social structure alone and together reduce the power to detect population structure. In addition, it is clear that biologically discrete populations of odontocetes can occur independently of strong geographic or oceanographic features. Alternative, non-geographic based hypotheses of population structure, such as dialect and differences in diet such as are found in Killer Whales, have not been thoroughly examined. For example, Rendell and Whitehead (2003) suggest that female populations seem to be culturally structured within oceans by “coda” vocalizations and may be genetically distinct (Rendell and Whitehead 2005, Rendell et al. 2005).
range: The Sperm Whale has a large geographic range (Rice 1989). It can be seen in nearly all marine regions, from the equator to high latitudes, but is generally found in continental slope or deeper water. The distribution extends to many enclosed or partially-enclosed seas, such as the Mediterranean Sea, Sea of Okhotsk, Gulf of California, and Gulf of Mexico.
useTrade: The large-scale commercial harvesting of this species has ceased. Small-scales fisheries continue in Japan and Indonesia.
conservationActions:
The species is on Appendix I of CITES and Appendices I and II of CMS.

Management plans need both development and implementation. The International Whaling Commission manages sperm whale populations under the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling, and Schedule of the Convention lists Sperm Whale seasons, Sperm Whale size limits and Sperm Whale catch limits (0 at present), as well as sanctuaries for all species in the Indian and Southern Oceans. However, no scheme for managing Sperm Whale populations is in place. Moreover, many range states are not members of the International Whaling Commission.

Regional subpopulations of Sperm Whales exist, and there has been an apparent lack of recovery in some areas or even continued decline (e.g., the Mediterranean (Reeves and Notarbartolo di Sciara 2006). Therefore, further assessments of the status of Sperm Whales should be conducted at the subpopulation level.

rationale: This species is reasonably widespread and can be common in suitable habitat (e.g. sand/muddy mangroves). Although little is known about its population status and life history, it does not appear to be facing any major threats. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species can be found on muddy to sandy bottoms of tidal streams, estuaries, mangroves and marine lakes (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2019). It reaches a maximum size of at least 6.1 cm SL (D. Hoese pers. comm. 2020).
threats: As this species is found in mangroves and estuaries, any threats to these habitats may affect its population. It does occur in some areas close to development and sources of rubbish. Another potential threat is from coastal habitat shifting and alteration caused by climate change.
population: This species can be locally common but not abundant in collections. The overall population trend is unknown.
range: There are records of this species from Thailand, Malaysia, Brunei, Singapore, Indonesia, New Guinea and northern Australia (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2020, Jaafar in prep.).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilised.
conservationActions: This species is found in at least one protected area (Sungei Seletar Wetland Reserve). Research into its population, ecology and threats is recommended alongside monitoring of habitat and population trends. The development of area based-management plans, site and habitat protection and awareness raising is also needed where this species is threatened.

rationale: This species is known from the Fly River delta, New Guinea, where it may be locally abundant, from eastern Bintuni Bay, West Papua, where it is less well known, and from one specimen from the Ramu River. Its population status is unknown in both countries, while threats are present and ongoing but their effects are unknown. However, its known locations are widespread and the species may be more common than is apparent, due to its difficult to access habitat. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The Slender Mudskipper is mainly encountered in tidal open mudflats adjacent to turbid, fresh to brackish rivers and creeks, and has been encountered completely out of water on muddy substrates littered with detritus at low tide. It digs shallow burrows in the mud, actively feeding and interacting on the exposed substrate. Out of water, its feeding behaviour is similar to other phytoplanktivorous species such as Pseudapocryptes elongatus and Boleophthalmus spp. (G. Polgar pers. observ. 2007, Polgar et al. 2010). This species can grow to a maximum size of 7.3 cm SL (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2019).
threats: Logging at Bintuni Bay has occurred within the Nature Reserve and may be ongoing and human activities increasing in the north part of the bay (Erftemeijer et al. 2008, Gandhi et al. 2008). The Fly River system is affected by the Ok Tedi mine, which has severely damaged the upper Fly river but the mine's effects downstream are less well studied. Invasive species are also present within its range. It is not known how these threats affect this species.
population: In the lower Fly River this species can be observed in large numbers on muddy river banks and pools on open mudflats at low tide (Polgar et al. 2010). However, it is not common in museum collections, most likely due to its difficult habitat. One specimen is known from the Ramu River (WAM database). The Bintuni Bay population is known from freshwater and mangrove habitats but no abundance information provided (Erftemeijer et al. 1989). The overall population trend is unknown.
range: This species is known only from New Guinea where it has been collected in the Fly and Ramu rivers of Papua New Guinea, and the eastern part of Bintuni Bay in West Papua Province, Indonesia (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information available for this species.
conservationActions: The Bintuni Bay Nature Reserve was established on paper in 1981, but apparently several changes to its borders have been made (Gandhi et al. 2008). Its other populations are not protected. Research is needed into the population, ecology, threats and potential conservation actions, alongside monitoring of habitat and population trends and the development of an area based management plan. Additional site protection and management are needed, alongside habitat restoration where threats occur.

rationale: The native range of Parachromis managuensis extends along the Atlantic versant of Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica. It has been translocated into many Atlantic and Pacific drainages in Central America, and a number of countries worldwide. Given its fairly wide distribution and high reported abundances at a limited number of sample localities, this species is inferred to be relatively common throughout its range. Deforestation, introduced species, widespread pollution resulting from agricultural runoff, solid waste, and wastewater discharge have likely reduced the quality of available habitat in much of the native range. However, there is currently no indication of major range-wide population decline. As such, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species typically occurs in lakes, rivers, and estuarine lagoons characterized by low velocity water at temperatures of 25-36 C (Bussing 1998, Mendoza-Carranza et al. 2016, Pease et al. 2018). It is most often found in stagnant water around debris along lake and river shorelines (Bussing et al. 1998).
threats:
Non-native tilapia (Oreochromis spp.) have been widely introduced in Nicaragua, where they are harvested with P. managuensis in artisanal and small-scale commercial fisheries (McCrary et al. 2007). However, the direct impact of these species on the distribution and population status of P. managuensis have not been evaluated. Additionally, Nicaragua is subject to a number of water quality modifications, including eutrophication of surface waters, pollution of crater lakes, large surface lakes, and groundwater resulting from agricultural runoff, pollution resulting from artisanal and industrial mining activities, increased sedimentation due to widespread deforestation, and pollution due to inadequate wastewater treatment and solid waste management (McCrary et al. 2006, Vammen et al. 2019). The proposed construction of the Nicaragua Canal is likely to exacerbate habitat disturbance and pollution in Lake Nicaragua (Chen et al. 2016). 

In Costa Rica, Mining activities may have localized impacts where they occur (Espinoza Mendiola 2008). Agricultural development and associated runoff has likely impacted the water quality of adjacent rivers (Diepens et al. 2014, Arias-Andrés et al. 2018, Fournier et al. 2018).
population: Total population size within the native range of P. managuensis is suspected to be greater than 10,000, given a relatively wide distribution. There is limited evidence of population decline in the Nicaragua Canal zone, potentially resulting from the introduction of Oreochromis spp. and Hypostomus panamensis (Härer et al. 2017). This species was dominant in recent samples taken from the Medio Queso River, Costa Rica (Castillo-Pérez 2016).
range:
The native range of Parachromis managuensis extends along the Atlantic versant of Central America from the Ulua River, Honduras, southward to the Parismina River drainage in Costa Rica (Angulo et al. 2013, Matamoros et al. 2009). Elevation ranges from 0-45 meters above sea level (Bussing 1998). In The Tirimbina Biological Reserve, Costa Rica, it was reported from one of 13 sample sites (Angulo et al. 2017). Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 194,177 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around native-range collection records (Matamoros et al. 2009).

In Central America, this species has been intentionally introduced into the majority of Pacific slope drainages as a food fish, released intentionally through the ornamental aquarium trade, or released incidentally by aquaculture operations (Bussing 1998, Matamoros et al. 2009). Additionally, introductions have occurred in southern Guatemala (Valdez-Moreno et al. 2005, McMahan et al. 2013, Álvarez Calderón 2014), in Gatun and Alajuela Lake, in Panama (Sharpe et al. 2017), and in the Lempa, Paz, and Grande San Miguel River drainages of El Salvador. In El Salvador, below 800 metres, this species is widespread and abundant (E. Barraza pers. comm. 2020). 

This species has also been widely introduced outside of Central America, including Campeche, Chiapas, Jalisco, and Tabasco, Mexico (Macossay-Cortez et al. 2011, Castillo-Dominguez et al. 2015, Mendoza-Carranza et al. 2016, Pease et al. 2018), Brazil (Barros et al. 2012), parts of the United States (Schofield and Loftus 2015), Singapore (Kwik et al. 2013), and the Philippines (Aquilino et al. 2011).
useTrade: This species is harvested in subsistence, artisanal, and small-scale commercial fisheries throughout much of its range, where it is typically marketed fresh (McCrary et al. 2007, Esselman and Opperman 2010). Non-native subpopulations in Brazil and Mexico support productive subsistence and artisanal fisheries (Medeiros et al. 2010, Mendoza-Carranza et al. 2013, França et al. 2017).
conservationActions: Currently, this species is of relatively low conservation concern. The range of this species includes a number of Protected Areas (Sánchez et al. 2006, Angulo et al. 2017, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019).

rationale: Cynodonichthys brunneus is an amphibious, non-annual killifish distributed in the Chagres and Tuira biogeographical provinces in central and eastern Panama, where it occurs in small streams and often isolated populations above barrier waterfalls. Total population size and population trend have not been evaluated. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 206-1,986 km2, but is based on very few georeferenced collection records. Potential threats exist, but their direct impact on C. brunneus, scope, and magnitude have not been evaluated in detail. Given these uncertainties, it is not possible to make an indirect or direct estimate of extinction risk. Therefore, this species is assessed as Data Deficient until more information becomes  available.
habitat: This species is an amphibious, non-annual killifish that occurs in small streams throughout central and eastern Panama (Turko and Wright 2015, Thompson et al. 2017). It has been observed at predator-free sites above barrier waterfalls, and in the presence of piscivorous species, including Aequidens coeruleopunctatus, Piabucina panamensis, Brycon spp., Hoplias microlepsis, Roeboides guatemalensis, and Rhamdia wagneri (Jennions and Telford 2002, Brown et al. 2004). This species exhibits predator avoidance by jumping out of the water (Turko and Wright 2015). Eggs exhibit a delayed hatching time of up to 40 days in response to desiccation (Varela-Lasheras and Van Dooren 2014, Thompson et al. 2017).
threats:
Small streams in the Chagres River drainage appear to be largely unaffected by human activity, given relatively low rates of deforestation (Ibáñez et al. 2002). Despite these protections, lacking sewerage and solid waste disposal around urban and rural centres have resulted in localized pollution in nearby streams (Ibáñez et al. 2002). Agricultural development and altered flow hydrology to support irrigation of sugar cane, coffee, corn, and fruit plantations may be having an impact on aquatic habitat quality (Larsen 2019). Industrial wastewater discharge may present additional threats (Larsen 2019).

The scope, magnitude, and direct impact of these threats on habitat availability and quality are largely unknown.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. In a single reported ichthyological survey discussing the abundance of freshwater fishes in streams from the Chagres River drainage, this species appeared fairly abundant (Angermeier and Karr 1983).
range:
Cynodonichthys brunneus is distributed in the Chagres drainage to the Claro River in the coastal area of Colon Province (Smith and Bermingham 2005). The specific drainages where this species occurs have not been evaluated in detail. Construction of the Panama Canal does not appear to have resulted in cross-cordillera exchange into Pacific drainages of central Panama (Smith et al. 2004). Four records exist from the Gulf of Panama (GBIF 2019), which are likely erroneous.

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 206-1,986 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around a limited number of georeferenced collection records in coastal Colon Province (GBIF 2019). Given uncertainties regarding the scope and magnitude of potential threats, and reported isolated subpopulations above barrier waterfalls that may be relatively free from threatening impacts, the number of locations where this species occurs cannot be determined with accuracy.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards C. brunneus. However, this species has been documented in Soberania National Park and likely occurs in San Lorenzo Reserve (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019), which may provide indirect protection against habitat degradation. Additional research regarding distribution, population size, population trend, and the scope and magnitude of potential threats is needed to accurately assess this species.

rationale: Cynodonichthys montium is restricted to the Chagres river drainage on the Atlantic slope of central Panama and exhibits an Extent of Occurrence (EOO) and an Area of Occupancy of 8 km2. A number of impacts associated with agricultural and urban expansion have reduced the area and quality of available habitat, especially in regions along the trans-isthmian corridor adjacent to the Panama Canal. At least one subpopulation occurs within the well-protected Chagres National Park, where anthropogenic impacts are minimal. The number of locations where C. montium occurs is therefore estimated to be 2-3. As such, this species is assessed as Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii).
habitat: This non-annual killifish occurs primarily in headwater creeks and streams, and reaches a maximum reported size of 8 cm total length (TL) (Reis et al. 2003).
threats:
The upper Chagres River basin is minimally affected by human activities, whilst other adjacent drainages have been deforested, resulting in erosion and increased sedimentation that is approximately twice that of the upper Chagres basin (Harmon 2005). Subpopulations within Chagres National Park, are relatively well-protected against habitat degradation due to effective park boundary management and enforcement in an effort to protect dry-season flow rates within the Chagres River drainage (Robinson et al. 2004, Harmon 2005, Oestreicher et al. 2009, Condit 2015). The entire range of this species is impacted by land use changes associated with urbanization and agricultural expansion (R. González pers. comm. 2019).

The invasive Asian fish tapeworm Bothriocephalus acheilognathi has been reported in the Chagres River drainage and may reduce the fitness in parasitized individuals (Choudhury et al. 2013). The introduction of this parasite is probably the result of intentional grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idella) stocking during early attempts to control aquatic vegetation in the Panama Canal zone (Choudhury et al. 2013). Additional impacts resulting from solid waste and domestic pollution in streams near larger towns have been documented within the Chagres River drainage (Ibáñez et al. 2002).

Despite uncertainties regarding the scope and magnitude of existing threats, they are producing inferred and continuous declines in habitat quality and possibly habitat availability.
population: The total population size and population trend are this species have not been evaluated in detail. This species was rare in ichthyological samples taken from Lake Alajuela and surrounding tributaries (Maturell 1984).
range:
Cynodonichthys montium is distributed throughout upland regions of the Chagres river drainage on the Atlantic slope of central Panama (Breder 1944, Smith and Bermingham 2005, Matamoros et al. 2015). The type locality of this species is a small hillside stream between the Boquerón and Pequeni rivers (Reis et al. 2003).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 2.8 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georefernced collection localities (GBIF 2019). Area of Occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be 8 km2, based on a 2 km2 grid overlain on validated georeferenced localities. As the calculated EOO is smaller than the AOO, the EOO is increased to match the AOO thus they are both 8 km2. Given the pervasive threat of land-use change associated with expanding urbanization and agriculture and an inferred cumulative effect on downstream aquatic habitat, but occurrence within Chagres National Park (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019), this species is inferred to occur in two to three locations.
useTrade: There is little information regarding the use and trade of this species. It may be kept in a limited capacity by ornamental aquarium hobbyists, but the majority of specimens in trade are probably captive bred individuals.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation actions directed towards C. montium. However, subpopulations within Charges National Park are suspected to be relatively well-protected, given the Panamanian government’s interest in protecting headwaters of the Chagres River drainage to maintain dry-season flow rates (Robinson et al. 2004, Harmon 2005, Ostreicher et al. 2009, Condit 2015). Despite these protections, more comprehensive ichthyological sampling, and additional information regarding population size, population trend, and the direct impacts of pervasive threats to aquatic habitat availability would be useful in guiding future conservation action.

rationale: This species is known only from Mindoro Island in Luzon, Philippines. It is assessed as Vulnerable based on its small geographic range. It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 5,483 km<sup>2</sup> and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,376 km<sup>2</sup> covering an estimate of 8-9 threat-based locations. It is inferred that the quality of habitat of this species will continue to decline due to uncontrolled human migration and increasing population, introductions of alien fishes, illegal fishing practices, siltation, pollution from agricultural and domestic wastes, and garbage, and various land-use conversions. Immediate research on its population status is needed as this species is becoming very rare. Various threats in Naujan Lake may push this species to extinction.
habitat: This species occurs in lake and rivers in Mindoro, Luzon. Little is known about the biology of this species.
threats: Major threats to this species in Naujan Lake and river tributaries are the introductions of exotic species, illegal fishing practices, siltation, pollution from agricultural and domestic wastes and garbage, and various land-use conversions (De Castro et al. 2013, Mindoro Biodiversity Conservation Foundation, Inc. and Department of Environment and Natural Resources Region IVb 2014). Uncontrolled human migration and increasing population may exert more pressure on the biodiversity of Naujan Lake (Mindoro Biodiversity Conservation Foundation, Inc. and Department of Environment and Natural Resources Region IVb 2014).
population: Museum collections (GBIF.org 2020) have 1-533 individuals per locality. This species was recorded in 2011 in river tributaries of Naujan Lake (Mindoro Biodiversity Conservation Foundation, Inc. and Department of Environment and Natural Resources Region IVb 2014). It was not found during fish landing and market surveys conducted in February-March 2013 around Naujan Lake (De Castro et al. 2013). It was verified by local knowledge through key informant interviews and focus group discussions that this species has not been found in the lake and river tributaries for the past several years (De Castro et al. 2013). A recent survey from the Calapan River recorded only a single specimen (Labatos 2017). The current population size in Mindoro is unknown but it is likely becoming rare.
range: This species is endemic to Mindoro in Luzon, Philippines (Herre 1953, Roberts 1989). It has been recorded from Naujan Lake and river tributaries (Mamboc, Sabaan [Subaang], Baco and Calapan Rivers) in Oriental Mindoro, and streams flowing into Mangarin Bay in Occidental Mindoro (Herre 1953, Roberts 1989, Labatos 2017). Reports from Taal Lake, Batangas Province (Mercene 1997, BFAR 1996) may refer to a different species and need further confirmation. Fisheries assessments in Taal lake conducted from 1996-2011 did not record this species (Mutia et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species was not seen in markets and fish landing sites around Naujan Lake during February-March 2013 surveys (De Castro et al. 2013).
conservationActions: Naujan Lake, one of the habitats of this species, is within the Naujan Lake National Park and is a Key Biodiversity Area (KBA). Further taxonomic work is needed for this species as it is considered either a valid species closely related to Barbodes binotatus or a geographical race of B. binotatus (Roberts 1989). This includes molecular studies to validate the identity of this species.

rationale: Brachyrhaphis episcopi is distributed on the Pacific slope of Panama from the Anton River eastward to the Bayano River and on the Atlantic slope of Panama from the Mandinga River to the Cocle del Norte River. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 7,959 km2, and the taxon is suspected to occur in greater than 10 locations. Total population size is suspected to exceed 10,000, and there is no indication of major range-wide population decline. Existing threats to this species include land-use change and deforestation associated with agricultural, industrial, and urban expansion along the Trans-Isthmian Highway and the Pan-American Highway. However, the direct impacts of these threats on B. episcopi have not been evaluated in detail. While the EOO for this species is below the threshold for Vulnerable, there is no evidence of major population decline and the range of this species extends into a number of well protected areas. Therefore, B. episcopi is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species typically inhabits upstream habitat both in the presence and absence of major piscivores, and is replaced downstream by the close congener B. cascajalensis (Jennions and Telford 2002). It occurs in a broad range of habitat types across an elevational and ecological gradient (Ingley 2014). This species gives live birth, which is characterized by a lack of superfetation (Turner 1938, Jennions and Telford 2002). Significant reproductive plasticity has been observed between subpopulations exposed to high levels of predation versus those exposed to little or no predation (Jennions and Telford 2002, Belk et al. 2011). Reproductive output peaks in the wet season (Stallsmith 2018). This species reaches a maximum reported body size of 3.5 cm total length (TL) (Lucinda 2003).
threats:
The upper Chagres River basin is minimally affected by human activities, whilst other adjacent drainages have been deforested, resulting in erosion and increased sedimentation that is approximately twice that of the upper Chagres basin (Harmon 2005). Subpopulations within Chagres National Park, Soberania National Park, and those situated along the Panama Canal corridor are relatively well-protected against habitat degradation due to effective park boundary management and enforcement in an effort to protect dry-season flow rates within the Chagres River drainage (Robinson et al. 2004, Harmon 2005, Oestreicher et al. 2009, Condit 2015), but subpopulations in the eastern Panama Canal Watershed outside of protected area boundaries are likely to be experiencing continuous and projected declines in habitat quality due to gradual deforestation resulting from land-use changes associated with agricultural, industrial and urban expansion along the trans-isthmian highway between Panama City and Colón (Harmon 2005). These effects are especially evident in streams adjacent to road development between Lake Gatun and Lake Alajuela (Helson and Williams 2013). Additional impacts resulting from solid waste and domestic pollution in streams near larger towns have been documented within the Chagres River drainage (Ibáñez et al. 2002).

Threats to this species outside of the Chagres River drainage have not been evaluated in detail.
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. However, extensive sampling and large collection sizes suggest that population size is likely greater than 10,000 individuals (Jennions and Telford 2002). There is currently no indication of major range-wide population decline.
range:
Brachyrhaphis episcopi is distributed on the Pacific slope of Panama from the Anton River eastward to the Bayano River and on the Atlantic slope of Panama from the Mandinga River to the Cocle del Norte River (Loftin 1965, Vega et al. 2006), including Barro Colorado in Lake Gatun, Panama (Breder 1944). The type locality of this species is a stream near Obispo Station in the Panama Canal Zone (Lucinda 2003).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 7,959 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019). However, additional ichthyological sampling may increase this estimate. Given uncertainties regarding the direct impacts of potential threats, the number of locations where this species occurs cannot be determined with accuracy, but is suspected to be greater than 10 because range extends into a number of protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards B. episcopi. However, the range of this species extends into multiple protected areas, including Santa Fe Chagres, and Soberania national parks (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019), which provide indirect protection against habitat degradation. More research regarding distribution, population size, population trend, and the impacts of existing threats would be useful in guiding future conservation action.

rationale: Ancistrus chagresi is distributed in Atlantic and Pacific slope drainages of Central Panama. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 19,750-30,145 km2. Total population size is unknown. However, it is qualitatively reported as abundant and there is currently no indication of major range-wide population decline. The range of this species extends into a number of well-managed protected areas, and it is suspected to occur in more than 10 locations. In the absence of documented evidence of major habitat loss or population declines, A. chagresi is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This species occupies stream and river habitat, where it typically inhabits crevices in deeper pools during the day, and moves into riffle habitat to feed at night (Gee 1976). Habitat is characterized by riffles, runs, and pools, submerged tree roots and logs. Cobble substrate in riffles serve as shelter for young individuals, and larger individuals move into deeper habitat to avoid predation by fishing birds (Power 1984; identified as A. spinosus).The stomach of this species can be used as an accessory air-breathing organ in hypoxic conditions (Graham et al. 1983). Diet is comprised almost exclusively of periphyton, which is scraped from hard substrates (Angermeier and Karr 1983). This species reaches a maximum reported body size of 19.5 cm standard length (SL) (Reis et al. 2003). 

Species of Ancistrus are known to spawn in crevices or under rocks where males protect eggs until they hatch, and larvae until and perhaps slightly beyond when the yolk sac is absorbed. Males have elongated tentacles on the snout that may act as larval mimics (Sabaj et al. 1999).
threats:
The upper Chagres River basin is minimally affected by human activities, whilst other adjacent drainages have been deforested, resulting in erosion and increased sedimentation that is approximately twice that of the upper Chagres basin (Harmon 2005). Subpopulations within Chagres National Park, Soberania National Park, and those situated along the Panama Canal corridor are relatively well-protected against habitat degradation due to effective park boundary management and enforcement in an effort to protect dry-season flow rates within the Chagres River drainage (Robinson et al. 2004, Harmon 2005, Oestreicher et al. 2009, Condit 2015), but subpopulations in the eastern Panama Canal Watershed outside of protected area boundaries are undergoing a continuous and projected decline in habitat quality due to gradual deforestation, resulting from land-use changes associated with agricultural, industrial and urban expansion along the trans-isthmian highway between Panama City and Colón (Harmon 2005). These effects are especially evident in streams adjacent to road development between Lake Gatun and Lake Alahuela, including the Puerquera, Duque, Ancha, Chilibre, and La Cabima streams (Helson  and Williams 2013). Subpopulations within Chagres National Park may be subject to limited habitat degradation from a small population of 150-200 Santo Domingo and La Llana Puebloan residents that depend on agriculture for their livelihoods (Brossard and Pritz 2013).

The invasive Asian fish tapeworm Bothriocephalus acheilognathi has been reported in the Chagres River drainage and may reduce the fitness of parasitized individuals (Choudhury et al. 2013). The introduction of this parasite is likely the result of intentional grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idella) stocking during early attempts to control aquatic vegetation in the Panama Canal zone (Choudhury et al. 2013). Additional impacts resulting from solid waste and domestic pollution in streams near larger towns have been documented within the Chagres River drainage (Ibáñez et al. 2002).
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. However, it is qualitatively reported as abundant in the Chagres River drainage (Moody et al. 2019), and it is often the dominant loricariid in stream pools (Power 1984, Power et al. 1989; species reported as A. spinosus). There is currently no indication of major, range-wide population decline.
range:
Ancistrus chagresi is distributed from the Río Cocle del Norte drainage (ACP 2003) east to the Acla River at Gunayala (Loftin 1965) on the Atlantic slope of Panama, and from the Chorrera (Caimito) River drainage to the Bayano River drainage on the Pacific slope of Panama (Reis et al. 2003, Smith and Bermingham 2005, Taphorn et al. 2013). The range of this species has also expanded to include the Rio Grande on the Pacific slope of central Panama, mediated by the construction of the Panama Canal (Smith et al. 2004).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 19,750-30,145 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019) and reported range by Taphorn et al. (2013). Given feasible inclusion within the boundaries of at least five protected areas and multiple river drainages, this species is suspected to occur in greater than 10 locations.
useTrade: This species is kept in aquaria where is is reported to be easy to keep and spawn (PlanetCatfish 2020).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards A. chagresi. The range of this species extends into a number of protected areas that are relatively well managed, namely Barro Colorado Natural Monument, Soberania National Park, Camino de Cruces National Forest, and Chagres National Park, among others (Robinson et al. 2004, Harmon 2005, Oestreicher et al. 2009, Condit 2015, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019). Additional research regarding distribution, population size, population trend, and the direct impacts of existing threats would be useful in clarifying conservation status.

rationale: Rineloricaria uracantha is distributed on the Atlantic slope of Central America from the Chagres River to the Armila River in eastern Panama, and on the Pacific slope of Central America from the Coto River drainage, Costa Rica, eastward to the San Pedro River in western Panama. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 58,861 km2. Total population size is unknown, but the species si reported to be abundant in much of central and eastern Panama. A number of localized and regional threats exist, including land-use changes and deforestation associated primarily with agricultural expansion, and pollution from agricultural, domestic, and industrial sources. However, there is currently no indication of major range-wide population declines. As such, R. uracantha is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthic freshwater species inhabits rivers and creeks characterized by moderate water velocity, being most abundant in pools and riffles (Gee 1976, Bussing 1998). The diet of this species is comprised of periphyton and detritus (Power 1984). Reproduction occurs throughout the year (Moodie and Power 1982, Moody et al. 2019). Eggs are laid in natural cavities and are guarded by males until they hatch (Moodie and Power 1982). This species reaches a maximum reported body size of 16.5 cm standard length (SL) (Reis et al. 2003).
threats:
In Costa Rica, the Coto River drains extensive areas of plantation agriculture (Spongberg and Davis 1998). These localities have undergone significant deforestation and land-use changes in the last 35-45 years, and now consist primarily of coffee plantations (Reeves and Lilieholm 1993, Santos-Barrera et al. 2008).

In Panama, deforestation and associated increases in sedimentation and erosion is evident in the lower reaches of the Chagres River and in adjacent drainages (Harmon 2005, Larsen et al. 2019). However, subpopulations within Chagres National Park, Soberania National Park, and those situated along the Panama Canal corridor are relatively well-protected against habitat degradation due to effective park boundary management and enforcement in an effort to protect dry-season flow rates within the Chagres River drainage (Robinson et al. 2004, Harmon 2005, Oestreicher et al. 2009, Condit 2015). Subpopulations in the eastern Panama Canal Watershed outside of protected area boundaries are likely to be undergoing a continuous and projected decline in habitat quality due to gradual deforestation, resulting from land-use changes associated with agricultural, industrial and urban expansion along the Trans-Isthmian Highway and Inter-American Highway (Harmon 2005, Suman 2007).The invasive Asian fish tapeworm Bothriocephalus acheilognathi has been reported in the Chagres River drainage and may reduce the fitness of parasitized individuals (Choudhury et al. 2013). Additional impacts resulting from solid waste and domestic pollution in streams near larger towns have been documented within the Chagres River drainage (Ibáñez et al. 2002).

While the combined impacts of existing threats have probably resulted in localized declines in both habitat quality and availability, their scope and magnitude have not been evaluated in detail. Additionally, there is no evidence of major range-wide population decline.
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. However, this species is reported to be highly abundant in drainages throughout central and eastern Panama (Moody et al. 2019), and comprises a dominant portion of ichthyofauna in select river drainages (Power 1989). This species is considered uncommon in the southern Pacific region of Costa Rica (Bussing 1998). There is currently no indication of major range-wide population decline.
range:
Rineloricaria uracantha is distributed on the Atlantic slope of Central America from the Coclé del Norte River to the Armila River in eastern Panama. On the Pacific slope of Central America, this species exhibits a disjunct distribution, occurring from the Coto River drainage in Costa Rica eastward to the San Pablo River in Veraguas Province, Panama, and within the Bayano River drainage (Bussing 1998, Reis et al. 2003, Smith and Bermingham 2005, Vega et al. 2006, Angulo et al. 2013, R. González pers. comm. 2019). Distribution does not extend to the Pacific side of the Panama Canal zone (Smith et al. 2004). Elevational distribution in Costa Rica ranges from 20-160 meters above sea level (Angulo et al. 2013).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 58,861 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2019).
useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards R. uracantha. However, the range of this species extends into a number of protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019), which probably confer indirect benefits against habitat degradation. Additional research regarding population size, population trend, and the direct impacts of existing threats would be useful in guiding future conservation efforts.

rationale: This species has an extremely large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (Extent of Occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2</sup> combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). Despite the fact that the population trend appears to be decreasing, the decline is not believed to be sufficiently rapid to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size is extremely large, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
habitat: This marine species occurs offshore and along rocky sea coasts. Its diet is comprised mainly of planktonic crustaceans, specifically euphausiids and amphipods, early and calanoid copepods during chick-rearing, and it is supplemented with varying amounts of other invertebrates and small fish. Food is usually obtained at considerable distance from colonies. Spring arrival and the start of laying is variable depending on latitude, starting earliest in the south of its range and latest in the extreme north. It is monogamous with high site fidelity and presumably high mate fidelity between years. Colonies are loose and range from small to large, breeding on offshore islands using dark crevices and cavities in steep sea cliffs, rocky talus slopes and beach boulder fields as nesting sites (del Hoyo et al. 1996).
threats:
Climate related trophic shifts appear to have led to considerable declines in the numbers of Parakeet Auklet in Prince William Sound (Agler et al. 1999), although whether populations are affected more widely in Alaska is unknown. Modern populations are considered likely to be much lower than in the 19th century as a result of harvesting and the introduction of invasive predators to many islands for fur production (Nettleship et al. 2018). Additionally, large numbers were previously killed in the particularly destructive high seas salmon drift-net fishery (DeGange and Day 1991), which was closed in the 1990s following improved regulation. Numbers affected today are much smaller with an estimate across all gear types of 36 auklets caught annually between 2007 and 2015 (Eich et al. 2016), and this level of mortality is unlikely to impact populations. Similarly, a total of only 31 oiled individuals were recovered after the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989, with the climate driven trophic shift more likely to have impacted the population (Agler et al. 1999).
Subsistence hunting takes place at Pribilof, St. Lawrence and Little Diomede Island, but mortality levels have not been quantified. Out of 24 studied seabirds in the North Pacific, this species ranked highest in mean number of plastic particles per bird (Robards et al. 1995). The impacts of plastic ingestion are unknown, but birds collected at Buldir showed no relationship between number of plastic pellets in crop and body condition, chicks were not fed plastic by parents (Bond et al. 2010) and no population impact has been demonstrated.
Some colonies are suspected of being affected by non-native predators with Arctic Vulpes lagopus and Red Foxes V. vulpes introduced on the Aleutian Islands for fur farming (Bailey 1993) and the accidental introduction of Rats Rattus rattus to many Alaskan islands. However the species continues to breed on islands where Arctic Foxes are native (Pribilof, St. Matthew and St. Lawrence) and the scattered nature of this species's colonies reduces the likelihood that a small number of predators could severely impact a colony.
population: The global population is estimated to number 1.4 million mature individuals (Partners in Flight 2019).
range: The Parakeet Auklet is found in the North Pacific Ocean, from Hokkaido, Japan and far off the coast of California (U.S.A.) in the south, up to and including the southern part of the Chukchi Sea. It breeds on islands throughout this area, as well as on the coast of Alaska (U.S.A.) and the eastern coast of Siberia, Russia.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 313 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals occur in fewer than five locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Batolito San Lorenzo y Humacao, Puerto Rico.
habitat: It has highly specialized habitat requirements, being found only in caves and rock grottos known as "guajonales" and in rocky stream banks covered with moss, ferns and other vegetation (Vega-Castillo 2000). Eggs are laid on damp boulder surfaces in grottoes, bamboo trunks and muddy substrates, and cared for by males and develop directly (Burrowes 2000, Longo et al. 2013). The area where this species occurs in the Icaco Valley is second-growth forest intermixed with line-planted timber trees, and few of the trees are over 30 years in age (Nelson et al. 2010). The presence of this frog in this area demonstrates that properly managed second-growth forests may play a role in conservation efforts of this species (Greenhawk 2013), as long as they are associated with granodiorite rock formations and perennial or ephemeral streams (A. Longo pers. comm. 2020).
threats:
All of this species' critical habitats are fragmented and confined to private lands (López-Torres and Longo 2013). The main threat to this species is habitat destruction that is taking place due to agricultural expansion, soil erosion, urban development, and issues with roadside pollution (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). The widespread use of herbicides and insecticides have also been posed as a threat to this species (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). 

The passing of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) in 2016 to address Puerto Rico’s economic crisis has created a new level of uncertainty about the future of public protected areas on the island as control over decision making is transferred from local authorities to an unelected board of financial managers (Snow 2017, Castro-Prieto et al. 2019). It is feared that this change might favor economic activities that will facilitate land use changes, driving the destruction and degradation of important habitats, and negatively impacting both biodiversity and human populations across Puerto Rico who depend on healthy and intact ecosystems for survival (Puerto Rico Red List Workshop June 2020).

This species is potentially susceptible to chytridiomycosis, as some subpopulations are associated with streams and the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, has recently been recorded in this species (López-Torres and Longo 2013, Longo et al. 2020). Soft ticks (Carios spp.) have been found on this species and individuals were observed to be lethargic, but the severity of this threat remains unknown (Vega-Castillo 2000, Longo et al. 2020).

The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Peterson et al. 2002, Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Precipitation patterns are not as clear, but some studies have shown a significant drying trend (Nurse et al. 2001, Neelin et al. 2006, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). The frequency of extreme events like hurricanes, heavy rains, and droughts has increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavorable to this species (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). Climate warming and drought have been associated with a decrease in arthropods (Lister and Garcia 2018), an important food item for frogs; however, there have been doubts regarding the methodology used by Lister and Garcia (2018) (see Willig et al. 2019). The effects of climate change can also be associated with an increased risk of chytridiomycosis (Longo et al. 2010).

While some studies have shown that Small Indian Mongoose (Urva auropunctata) prey upon native coquis, only a small proportion (~1%) of their stomach contents include amphibians (Wolcott 1953, Pimentel 1955, Viella 1998). The introduced Cuban Tree Frog (Osteopilus septentrionalis) is a generalist predator that may include coquis in its diet, however the proportion of amphibians found in stomach content analysis (3.5%) is also low (Glorioso et al. 2010). This information suggests that the relative threat level of introduced predators on this species is low (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
population: Population size is highly variable across critical habitats (A. Longo pers. comm. 2020). Adults and eggs were recorded in the Icaco Valley in 2011 and 2012 (Greenhawk 2013), but the species was not detected in one of its critical habitats (Unit 5 Jacaboa) in 2013 (Longo et al. 2020). It was observed in Juncos, Humacao, and Las Piedras in 2019, following Hurricane Maria, but occurred in lower abundances compared to pre-hurricane levels (S. Vega pers. comm. 2020). The species has been seen as recently as 2020, in the Sierra Pandura (O. Monzón pers comm. to R. Joglar 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species has a restricted distribution and it is exclusively associated with the geomorphologic region known as 'Batolito San Lorenzo y Humacao', which includes Sierra Pandura and lowlands of southeastern Puerto Rico. Its elevational range is 26–421 m asl (López‐Torres 2008), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 313 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals occur in five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
A small portion of the species' range occurs in Carite Forest, but most of its distribution is limited to privately owned lands. The Puerto Rican Conservation Trust, a local NGO, has acquired 70 ha securing some of the critical habitats for perpetuity (López-Torres and Longo 2013). It was listed as Threatened on the U.S. Endangered Species List in 1997 and its recovery plan was released in 2004 (USFWS 2004).

Conservation Needed
In view of the negative effects of anthropogenic climate change on this species and its habitat, national and global policies are needed to curb the use of and reliance on fossil fuels. Protection and restoration of the habitat of this species is urgently needed. Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained. Community education and awareness programmes aimed to generate knowledge of and appreciation for Puerto Rico's endemic amphibians are recommended (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
Future studies should assess the genetic diversity and patterns of gene flow (i.e. connectivity) between subpopulations (López-Torres and Longo 2013). Additional research and monitoring is needed, including efforts to understand the species-specific response to Bd and the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}" data-sheets-textstyleruns="{"1":0}[null,75,{"5":1}]{"1":78}[null,216,{"5":1}]{"1":224}">Listed as Critically Endangered because it is restricted to two wetland systems in northern Puerto Rico with an extent of occurrence (EOO) is 61 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and its habitat is threatened by removal of vegetation for flood control, contamination of water by nearby landfills, looming urban development, and the effects of climate change.
habitat:
The species inhabits palustrine (freshwater) herbaceous wetland. The wetland is seasonally flooded with fresh water; the soil consists of swamp and marsh organic deposits. Herbaceous vegetation in this habitat includes the toothed midsorus fern (Blechnum serrulatum), willdenow's maiden fern (Thelypteris interrupta), bulltongue arrowhead (Sagittaria lancifolia), flatsedges (Cyperus sp.), spike rushes (Eleocharis sp.), and vines and grasses. The habitat at the type locality occupies ca 180 ha; the species was not found in other wetland sites in the northern coastal plain. Individuals are active between 19:00-22:00 hours, while perching, sitting, or calling on herbaceous vegetation, between 0.4 m and 1.2 m above water level. Calling sites for males were found to be between 0.6 and 1.2 m above ground level. Egg clutches vary between 1-5 eggs and are mostly deposited on leaf axils of S. lancifolia. Embryos hatch after approximately 19 days (Rios-López and Thomas 2007; N. Rios-López pers. comm. 2008).

This species is thought to have year-round reproduction given the frequency of juveniles found in any given month. However, most adult activity (including calling males) is greater during the warm and wet months (May to November), and diminishes during the cooler and drier months (particularly between the end of January and end of March). It is expected that recruitment rates reflect this seasonal pattern with a greater amount of clutches being produced during the warm and wet months. The seasonal breeding pattern in this frog is similar to that of other species of the genus in Puerto Rico, such as E. antillensis, E. cochranae, E. coqui, E. cooki, E. gryllus and E. portoricensis. (N. Rios-López pers. comm. 2008).
threats:
Its type locality has, in the past, experienced little disturbance partly due to restricted access of local people by the US Naval Security Group Activity Sabana Seca (USNSGASS) and the limited development of military installations in this wetland. However, it is now threatened by private and governmental housing, industrial, and recreational projects that are spreading rapidly through the region after the USNSGASS ceased operations in 2005 (Rios-López and Thomas 2007), as well as, leachate from a municipal landfill and removal of vegetation for flood control, among other threats (Rios-López et al. 2014). At Caño Tiburones, the species' habitat is being degraded by the dumping of trash and subsequent heavy metal pollution of the wetlands (S. Vega pers. comm. 2020). 

The Caribbean region shows evidence of climate warming at regional (Peterson et al. 2002, Stephenson et al. 2014, IPCC 2018) and local scales (Burrowes et al. 2004, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). Precipitation patterns are not as clear, but some studies have shown a significant drying trend (Nurse et al. 2001, Neelin et al. 2006, Bhardwaj et al. 2016). The frequency of extreme events like hurricanes, heavy rains, and droughts has increased significantly in the last decade (Méndez-Lázaro et al. 2014, Oppenheimer et al. 2019) and may continue to rise in the future (IPCC 2014, 2018). Sea level rise is an additional threat for this coastal species (Oppenheimer et al. 2019, Puerto Rico Red List Workshop 2020). Due to characteristics intrinsic to their biology and physiology, patterns of recent climate change in the Caribbean are expected to be unfavorable to this species. Climate warming and drought have been associated with a decrease in arthropods (Lister and Garcia 2018), an important food item for frogs; however, there have been doubts regarding the methodology used by Lister and Garcia (2018) (see Willig et al. 2019). The effects of climate change can also be associated with an increased risk of chytridiomycosis (Longo et al. 2010).

While some studies have shown that Small Indian Mongoose (Urva auropunctata) prey upon native coquis, only a small proportion (~1%) of their stomach contents include amphibians (Wolcott 1953, Pimentel 1955, Viella 1998). The introduced Cuban Tree Frog (Osteopilus septentrionalis) is a generalist predator that may include coquis in its diet, however the proportion of amphibians found in stomach content analysis (3.5%) is also low (Glorioso et al. 2010). This information suggests that the relative threat level of introduced predators on this species is low (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
population: The species appears to be common in the type locality, but it is the least abundant species among sympatric Eleutherodactylus (E. brittoni, E. cochranae, and E. coqui) (Rios-López and Thomas 2007, N. Ríos-López pers. comm. 2008). The status of the subpopulation at Caño Tiburones is unknown as it was only recently discovered; up to 30 individuals were recorded during a couple hours of surveying, but further surveys are needed to understand trends (N. Ríos-López pers. comm. 2020). While wetland habitat has expanded since the curbing of intensive agriculture practices in the region more than 90 years ago, which is positive for this species over the long-term (N. Ríos-López pers. comm. 2020), a decreasing population trend is inferred largely due to the ongoing effects of habitat loss and climate change. Furthermore, the population is considered to meet the severely fragmented IUCN subcriterion because more than half (> 50%) of the individuals (or more than half of the occupied habitat area) are in small and isolated patches between which there is little to no dispersal.
range: This species is restricted to two small areas of freshwater wetlands in the northern part of Puerto Rico. It was formerly only known from the type locality: Sabana Seca, Toa Baja Municipality, in the vicinity of the US Naval Security Group Activity Sabana Seca (USNSGASS) and the Caribbean Primate Research Center, Puerto Rico (Rios-López and Thomas 2007), but a second subpopulation was discovered inside Reserva Natural Caño Tiburones and its buffer zone (Morales-Pérez et al. submitted). It occurs at elevations between 10 and 20 m asl and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 61 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place 
This species has been recorded in Reserva Natural Caño Tiburones (Morales-Pérez et al. submitted). Some other conservation measures in place include the assigning of the species to a Critically Endangered (CR) status and the designation of its ecosystem and surroundings of the type locality as Essential Critical Natural Habitats, issued by the Departamento de Recursos Naturales y Ambientales (DRNA) of Puerto Rico. This designation provides a legal basis for the regulation and enforcement of the area's conservation. Although this is the first time the DRNA has issued this kind of designation, it is being challenged at local courts by a landowner and by the municipal government of Toa Baja. In the meantime, there is still no management plan and no actions have been undertaken to create a Natural Reserve at this site, which limits the protection that this designation can afford (N. Ríos-López pers. comm. 2008). Initial plans are underway to implement ex-situ breeding projects (individuals of this species have been successfully bred in captivity with a relatively simple methodology; N. Ríos-López pers. comm. 2008) and eventual reintroduction of captive bred individuals (N. Ríos-López pers. comm. 2020).

Conservation Needed
Conservation measures are urgently needed to protect the unprotected wetland system where the species is known to occur, and also the associated limestone hills to the south, which include two watersheds that drains freshwater into this wetland (N. Ríos-López pers. comm. 2008, 2020). Other conservation measures may also include the restoration of wetlands with similar characteristics as those at known sites, the implementation of ex-situ breeding projects and reintroduction of the species into these restored wetlands (N. Ríos-López pers. comm. 2008). Economic development should not be granted priority over currently federally protected natural resource areas in Puerto Rico and the protected status of such lands should be maintained (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). Community education and awareness programmes aimed to generate knowledge of and appreciation for Puerto Rico's endemic amphibians are recommended (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Research Needed
Long-term studies such as monitoring programmes, including acoustic monitoring, are required to evaluate its population status (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). Given that a second subpopulation was recently recorded at Caño Tiburones, outside of its formerly known range, additional surveys are urgently needed to determine whether other subpopulations exist (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020). More research is needed to better understand the species-specific response to the effects of climate change (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

rationale: Hypostomus yaku occurs in the Quente River, a small tributary of the Piracanjuba River in the upper Paraná River basin, central Brazil that is characterized by thermally warmed waters. Extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO) are estimated to be 8 km2, and the species is known from a single threat-based location. Comprehensive ichthyological sampling in the region failed to identify any additional collection localities in the immediate vicinity and this species is likely restricted to warm water. Threats to this species are localized and include urban expansion, habitat degradation and solid waste pollution associated with tourism, and organic pollutants associated with urban runoff. Continuing decline in habitat quality is inferred. Therefore, H. yaku is assessed as Critically Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii).
habitat: This species is reported from the Quente River, a small tributary characterized by a width of three meters, depths of 1-1.5 m, with moderate flow and substrates of sand, pebbles, and rock (Martins et al. 2014). This species appear to be restricted to warm waters such as the Quente River Resort and other sites in the urban area of the Municipality of the Rio Quente (Martins et al. 2014). Sampling in other nearby streams with lower water temperature did not yield any additional specimens (Martins et al. 2014).
threats:
The type locality from which this species is described is impacted by urban expansion, tourism, and organic pollutants (Martins et al. 2014). Solid waste pollution associated with tourism is apparent in areas within the municipality of the Rio Quente (Ramos and Ferreira 2013a). Bathing and recreational activities in the Quente River is supported by tourism infrastructure and has the potential to further degrade habitat (Romas and Ferreira 2013b). This species co-occurs with two widely established invasive species, Xiphophorus hellerii and Oreochromis niloticus (Martins et al. 2014), but the direct impacts of these species on native ichthyofauna are not known.

Despite uncertainty regarding the scope and direct impact of existing threats, continuing decline in habitat quality is inferred.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. However, it is abundant at the type locality (Martins et al. 2014).
range:
Hypostomus yaku occurs in the Quente River, a small tributary of the Piracanjuba River in the upper Paraná River basin, central Brazil (Martins et al. 2014).

Extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO) are estimate to be 8 km2, based on a 2x2 km grid overlain on the three known collection localities for which this species is reported (Martins et al. 2014). This species is assigned to a single threat-based location because all collection localities are closely adjacent to one another, and are likely impacted by pollutants from the municipality of Rio Quente.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards H. yaku. This species does not occur in any protected areas. Comprehensive ichthyological sampling in the region failed to identify any additional collection localities in the immediate vicinity (Martins et al. 2014). Frequent population monitoring is a warranted conservation priority (Martins et al. 2014). Habitat monitoring and site protection may be warranted.

rationale: Jenynsia darwini is restricted to coastal drainages in northeastern Rio de Janeiro State between Grussaí Lagoon and Imboassíca Lagoon. Extent of Occurrence is estimated to be 1,455 km2 and the species in at least 14 known threat-based locations. This species is abundant where it occurs and there is no evidence of major range-wide population declines. Loss of coastal habitat and associated declines in aquatic habitat quality are evident throughout the majority of northern Rio de Janeiro State due to a large human population, development, agricultural production, and associated pollution. Despite uncertainties regarding the direct impact of existing threats, there is clear evidence that habitat quality is declining continuously in some areas. However, this species also occurs in several localities within established protected areas like Jurubatiba National Park, which are free from major impact. Given a relatively wide distribution, inclusion within existing protected area networks, and lacking evidence of major range-wide declines, J. darwini is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs primarily in brackish water lagoons and sand-spit areas (Amorim 2018). Females give birth to live young, and reproductive response is relatively plastic based on ambient water temperatures and other environmental changes (Turner 1957). This species is omnivorous and consumes a broad variety of aquatic insects, larvae, algae, and vegetal material (Turner 1957).
threats:
Rio de Janeiro State is the most populated portion of Brazil (Marques et al. 2004). As a result, Restinga ecosystems (herbaceous, shrubby coastal sand-dune habitats) and coastal inland aquatic habitat on the Atlantic coast of Brazil are threatened by high rates of habitat loss and degradation associated with a number of anthropogenic activities that include highway and street construction, tourism, residential infrastructure, solid waste disposal, quarrying, agricultural development, and livestock production (Agostinho et al. 2005, Rocha et al. 2007, Cosendey et al. 2016, Azevedo-Santos et al. 2019). Agricultural activities and domestic waste products are responsible for elevated concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in Jurubatiba National Park (Meire et al. 2008). Imboassíca Lagoon is highly eutrophic and receives a large output of sewage from Macaé City (Dos Santos Furtado et al. 2002). Artificial openings have exposed the lagoon to oceanic influence (Dos Santos Furtado 2002). Grussaí is impacted by a large seasonal influx of tourism and urban development, and there is evidence that human activities have altered the trophic function of surrounding habitats (Costa et al. 2017). Relatively high concentrations of mercury has been detected in lagoons and lakes exposed to runoff in northern Rio de Janeiro State, and can likely be attributed to the use of mercurial fungicides on sugar cane plantations up until 1980 (De Sousa et al. 2004). Other heavy metals in the environment are relatively low based on reported concentrations in oysters (Ferreira et al. 2005).

This species occurs in a number of collection localities within Jurubatiba National Park that are free from anthropogenic threats (P. Amorim pers. comm. 2021). Additionally, some lagoons from which J. darwini has been reported are minorly impacted by bathing and swimming activities, but are otherwise well-preserved due to their touristic importance (P. Amorim pers. comm. 2021).

Despite uncertainties regarding the direct impact of existing localized and regional threats on J. darwini, continuing decline in habitat quality is inferred. Additional study will be necessary to qualitatively define the extent of habitat loss.
population: This species is abundant at most of the collection localities from which it is reported, including in habitat impacted by urban pollution such as Imboassica and Grussai (P. Amorim pers. comm. 2021). Given occurrence at a number of collection localities that are within Jurubatiba National Park and free from anthropogenic threats, population trend is suspected to be stable.
range:
Jenynsia darwini occurs throughout coastal drainages in northeastern Rio de Janeiro State, between Grussaí Lagoon and Imboassíca Lagoon (Amorim 2018). Specific collection records are also available from Jurubatiba National Park, Iquiparí and Lagamar lagoons, Barra do Furado, and the lower Macaé River (Amorim 2018).

Extent of occurrence is estimated to be 1,455 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records reported in Amorim (2018) and subsequent collections that were reported after the time of description (P. Amorim pers. comm. 2021). This species has been reported from 14 distinct collection localities that are either impacted independently by existing threats, or do not appear to be impacted by any major anthropogenic threats. Therefore, the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs is estimated to be 14.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards J. darwini. Range extends into multiple protected areas, including Jurubatiba National Park, which are free from major anthropogenic impacts on habitat quality and availability (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). However, it is important to note that protected area networks are typically developed around terrestrial ecosystems and may have limited efficacy in the protection of freshwater biodiversity (Azevedo-Santos et al. 2019).

Additional research regarding range extent, population size, population trend, and the direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale:
The number of mature individuals in the population number considerably more than 10,000. Area of occupancy is very large and substantial subpopulation mixing may occur due to large scale movements of adult paddlefish.

Competition, predation, diseases and parasites were evaluated in the 1992 review (USFWS 1992) and determined not to be limiting factors for paddlefish stocks. Although dams, habitat, and water quality concerns still occur in several locations, the majority of formerly occupied habitats remain available to this species. Continued application of existing U.S. laws (e.g., Clean Water Act, Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act, etc.) and current and future mitigation and habitat improvements designed to improve pallid sturgeon breeding and nursery habitats should benefit the paddlefish.

The 1992 USFWS status review for paddlefish determined that listing this species as threatened under the ESA was not warranted at that time.
